From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

# Welcome to [Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia")

,

the [free](/wiki/Free_content "Free content") [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") that [anyone can edit](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_Wikipedia "Help:Introduction to Wikipedia").

* [269,020](/wiki/Special:Statistics "Special:Statistics") active editors
* [7,117,440](/wiki/Special:Statistics "Special:Statistics") articles in [English](/wiki/English_language "English language")

## From today's featured article

In September 1826, **[Margaret Warden died](/wiki/Poisoning_of_Margaret_Warden "Poisoning of Margaret Warden")** by [arsenic poisoning](/wiki/Arsenic_poisoning "Arsenic poisoning"), near [Dundee](/wiki/Dundee "Dundee"), Scotland. Warden, a young servant girl, was pregnant at the time of her death; the father was George Smith, the son of Warden's employers, Mary and David Smith. The attending doctor thought Warden died of [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera"), but rumours of poisoning soon spread and she was exhumed. Her stomach contents were tested; [arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic "Arsenic") was found, and in October Mary Smith was committed for trial for murder. Her defence advocates called nearly fifty witnesses, and the trial began on 19 February. Testimony at the trial made it clear that Smith had given Warden something to drink shortly before she became ill. The defence called witnesses who testified that Warden might have committed suicide. The jury returned a verdict of [not proven](/wiki/Not_proven "Not proven"), acquitting Smith of the crime. Popular opinion at the time was that Smith was guilty, and ballads were written about the case. One of Smith's lawyers later wrote that he was sure she had committed the murder. *(**[Full article...](/wiki/Poisoning_of_Margaret_Warden "Poisoning of Margaret Warden")**)*

## Did you know ...

Eugene Parker

* ... that **[Eugene Parker](/wiki/Eugene_Parker "Eugene Parker")** *(pictured)* described the mathematics behind his theory of solar wind as just "four lines of algebra"?
* ... that the **[Papyrus Bingen 45](/wiki/Papyrus_Bingen_45 "Papyrus Bingen 45")** may contain a word handwritten by Cleopatra?
* ... that the **[Free Universal Construction Kit](/wiki/Free_Universal_Construction_Kit "Free Universal Construction Kit")** connects ten otherwise incompatible children's construction toys?
* ... that the courtesan in **[a Buddhist tale](/wiki/A%E1%B9%AD%E1%B9%ADh%C4%81na_J%C4%81taka "Aṭṭhāna Jātaka")** has been described as an "omnipotent dictator"?
* ... that male and female specimens of ***[Skimmia japonica](/wiki/Skimmia_japonica "Skimmia japonica")*** were once thought to belong to different species?
* ... that estimates of the boost to the British **[fashion industry by Catherine, Princess of Wales](/wiki/Fashion_of_Catherine,_Princess_of_Wales "Fashion of Catherine, Princess of Wales")**, range from £152 million to £1 billion per year?
* ... that **[Chen Diexian](/wiki/Chen_Diexian "Chen Diexian")**'s 1913 autobiographical novel ***[The Money Demon](/wiki/The_Money_Demon "The Money Demon")*** mainly details his own love affairs?
* ... that a committee rejected six designs for the **[National Baseball Hall of Fame commemorative coins](/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_commemorative_coins "National Baseball Hall of Fame commemorative coins")** before approving a seventh, which was sketched during the meeting?
* ... that pianist **[Derek Han](/wiki/Derek_Han "Derek Han")** inherited "a barrel of cash" and became a successful financier?

## On this day

**[January 5](/wiki/January_5 "January 5")**: **[Twelfth Night](/wiki/Twelfth_Night_(holiday) "Twelfth Night (holiday)")** (Western Christianity)

Battle of Turckheim

* [1675](/wiki/1675 "1675") – [Franco-Dutch War](/wiki/Franco-Dutch_War "Franco-Dutch War"): French troops defeated Austrian and Brandenburg forces at the **[Battle of Turckheim](/wiki/Battle_of_Turckheim "Battle of Turckheim")** *(pictured)* in [Alsace](/wiki/Alsace "Alsace").
* [1925](/wiki/1925 "1925") – **[Nellie Tayloe Ross](/wiki/Nellie_Tayloe_Ross "Nellie Tayloe Ross")** was inaugurated as [Governor of Wyoming](/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Wyoming "List of governors of Wyoming"), the first [woman to serve as the governor of a U.S. state](/wiki/List_of_female_governors_in_the_United_States "List of female governors in the United States").
* [1975](/wiki/1975 "1975") – The bulk carrier *[Lake Illawarra](/wiki/SS_Lake_Illawarra "SS Lake Illawarra")* struck a bridge over the [River Derwent](/wiki/River_Derwent_(Tasmania) "River Derwent (Tasmania)") in [Hobart](/wiki/Hobart "Hobart"), Australia, **[causing the deaths](/wiki/Tasman_Bridge_disaster "Tasman Bridge disaster")** of seven of the ship's crewmen and five motorists on the bridge.
* [1976](/wiki/1976 "1976") – [The Troubles](/wiki/The_Troubles "The Troubles"): In response to the **[killings of six Catholics](/wiki/Reavey_and_O%27Dowd_killings "Reavey and O'Dowd killings")** the previous night, [South Armagh Republican Action Force](/wiki/South_Armagh_Republican_Action_Force "South Armagh Republican Action Force") gunmen **[killed ten Protestants](/wiki/Kingsmill_massacre "Kingsmill massacre")** in [County Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh "County Armagh"), Northern Ireland.
* [1991](/wiki/1991 "1991") – The [embassy of the United States to Somalia](/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Mogadishu "Embassy of the United States, Mogadishu") was **[evacuated by helicopter airlift](/wiki/Operation_Eastern_Exit "Operation Eastern Exit")** days after violence enveloped [Mogadishu](/wiki/Mogadishu "Mogadishu") during the [Somali Civil War](/wiki/Somali_Civil_War "Somali Civil War").

* **[Philippa of England](/wiki/Philippa_of_England "Philippa of England")** (d. 1430)
* **[Hayao Miyazaki](/wiki/Hayao_Miyazaki "Hayao Miyazaki")** (b. 1941)
* **[Diane Keaton](/wiki/Diane_Keaton "Diane Keaton")** (b. 1946)
* **[Deepika Padukone](/wiki/Deepika_Padukone "Deepika Padukone")** (b. 1986)

## From today's featured list

[Ilia Malinin](/wiki/Ilia_Malinin "Ilia Malinin"), three-time U.S. national champion in [men's single skating](/wiki/Single_skating "Single skating")

The **[U.S. Figure Skating Championships](/wiki/U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "U.S. Figure Skating Championships")** are an annual [figure skating competition](/wiki/Figure_skating_competition "Figure skating competition") to crown the national champions of the United States in [figure skating](/wiki/Figure_skating "Figure skating"). Organized by [U.S. Figure Skating](/wiki/U.S._Figure_Skating "U.S. Figure Skating"), medals are awarded in [men's singles, women's singles](/wiki/Single_skating "Single skating"), [pair skating](/wiki/Pair_skating "Pair skating") and [ice dance](/wiki/Ice_dance "Ice dance"), at the senior and junior levels. The first U.S. Championships were held in 1914 in [New Haven, Connecticut](/wiki/New_Haven,_Connecticut "New Haven, Connecticut"); while they were interrupted during World War I, they have been held without interruption since 1920. [Dick Button](/wiki/Dick_Button "Dick Button") and [Roger Turner](/wiki/Roger_Turner_(figure_skater) "Roger Turner (figure skater)") are tied for winning the most U.S. Championships titles in men's singles (with seven each), while [Maribel Vinson](/wiki/Maribel_Vinson "Maribel Vinson") and [Michelle Kwan](/wiki/Michelle_Kwan "Michelle Kwan") are tied for winning the most titles in women's singles (with nine each). [Theresa Weld-Blanchard](/wiki/Theresa_Weld "Theresa Weld") and [Nathaniel Niles](/wiki/Nathaniel_Niles_(sportsman) "Nathaniel Niles (sportsman)") hold the record in pair skating (with nine), while [Meryl Davis and Charlie White](/wiki/Meryl_Davis_and_Charlie_White "Meryl Davis and Charlie White"), and [Madison Chock](/wiki/Madison_Chock "Madison Chock") and [Evan Bates](/wiki/Evan_Bates "Evan Bates"), are tied for winning the most titles in ice dance (with six each). (**[Full list...](/wiki/U.S._Figure_Skating_Championships "U.S. Figure Skating Championships")**)

## Today's featured picture

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
|  | ***[Chromodoris annae](/wiki/Chromodoris_annae "Chromodoris annae")*** is a species of [sea slug](/wiki/Sea_slug "Sea slug") in the family [Chromodorididae](/wiki/Chromodorididae "Chromodorididae"). It is found in the tropical central area of the Indo-Pacific region from Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines to the Marshall Islands, a region rich in biodiversity and rich in [coral](/wiki/Coral "Coral"), [mangroves](/wiki/Mangrove "Mangrove") and [seagrasses](/wiki/Seagrass "Seagrass"). *C. annae* has an elongated body, reaching a maximum length of 5 centimetres (2.0 in), and is coloured in various shades of blue with black spots, its mantle edge and foot being bordered with white and orange-to-yellow lines. The sea slug's diet consists solely of *Petrosaspongia*, part of the [Thorectidae](/wiki/Thorectidae "Thorectidae") family of sea sponges. It absorbs a noxious chemical from the sponge, storing it in its glands and using it to deter predation. *C. annae* is generally a docile species, but individuals have been occasionally sighted fighting each other. These *C. annae* sea slugs were photographed in the diving resort of Anilao in [Mabini, Batangas](/wiki/Mabini,_Batangas "Mabini, Batangas"), in the Philippines.  Photograph credit: [Diego Delso](/wiki/User:Poco_a_poco "User:Poco a poco")  Recently featured: * [Larsen Ice Shelf](/wiki/Template:POTD/2026-01-04 "Template:POTD/2026-01-04") * [*Portrait of Charles Marcotte*](/wiki/Template:POTD/2026-01-03 "Template:POTD/2026-01-03") * [Pacific kingfisher](/wiki/Template:POTD/2026-01-02 "Template:POTD/2026-01-02")  * **[Archive](/wiki/Wikipedia:Picture_of_the_day/Archive "Wikipedia:Picture of the day/Archive")** * **[More featured pictures](/wiki/Wikipedia:Featured_pictures "Wikipedia:Featured pictures")** |

## Other areas of Wikipedia

* **[Community portal](/wiki/Wikipedia:Community_portal "Wikipedia:Community portal")** – The central hub for editors, with resources, links, tasks, and announcements.
* **[Village pump](/wiki/Wikipedia:Village_pump "Wikipedia:Village pump")** – Forum for discussions about Wikipedia itself, including policies and technical issues.
* **[Site news](/wiki/Wikipedia:News "Wikipedia:News")** – Sources of news about Wikipedia and the broader Wikimedia movement.
* **[Teahouse](/wiki/Wikipedia:Teahouse "Wikipedia:Teahouse")** – Ask basic questions about using or editing Wikipedia.
* **[Help desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Help_desk "Wikipedia:Help desk")** – Ask questions about using or editing Wikipedia.
* **[Reference desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk "Wikipedia:Reference desk")** – Ask research questions about encyclopedic topics.
* **[Content portals](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contents/Portals "Wikipedia:Contents/Portals")** – A unique way to navigate the encyclopedia.

## Wikipedia's sister projects

Wikipedia is written by volunteer editors and hosted by the [Wikimedia Foundation](/wiki/Wikimedia_Foundation "Wikimedia Foundation"), a non-profit organization that also hosts a range of other volunteer [projects](https://wikimediafoundation.org/our-work/wikimedia-projects/ "foundationsite:our-work/wikimedia-projects/"):

* [Meta-Wiki](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/ "m:")  
  Wikimedia project coordination
* [Wikibooks](https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/ "b:")  
  Free textbooks and manuals
* [Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/ "d:")  
  Free knowledge base
* [Wikinews](https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/ "n:")  
  Free-content news

  Collection of quotations
* [Wikisource](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/ "s:")  
  Free-content library
* [Wikispecies](https://species.wikimedia.org/wiki/ "species:")  
  Directory of species
* [Wikiversity](https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/ "v:")  
  Free learning tools
* [Wikivoyage](https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/ "voy:")  
  Free travel guide
* [Wiktionary](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ "wikt:")  
  Dictionary and thesaurus

## Community bulletin board

This section is [transcluded](/wiki/Help:Transclusion "Help:Transclusion") from [Wikipedia:Community bulletin board](/wiki/Wikipedia:Community_bulletin_board "Wikipedia:Community bulletin board"). ([edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Community_bulletin_board&action=edit) | [history](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Community_bulletin_board&action=history))

| How to add to the community bulletin board |
| --- |
| |  | | --- | | The community bulletin board has 2 sections that can be used by Wikipedians for announcements: "Events and projects" and "WikiProject notices". In general, keep it **concise** (under 2 lines), refrain from **fancy formatting**, and new entries should be placed at the **top** of their section.  * Before editing, make sure you are on [Wikipedia:Community bulletin board](/wiki/Wikipedia:Community_bulletin_board "Wikipedia:Community bulletin board"), not Wikipedia:Community portal, where the board is transcluded. * **Events and projects**: In this section, only organized events, projects, and/or competitions should be listed. These are organized by how often they occur:   + The **Yearly** section is for uncommon events, like events that only occur every year, once, or irregularly. The **Monthly** section is for events that occur each month, or are always ongoing. * **WikiProject notices**: In this section, any announcement, request for help or other notice from a WikiProject should be listed here.   + Entries should be signed, and ordered from newest to oldest.   + Entries are to be removed after a period of **6 months**. | |

Welcome to the **community bulletin board**, which is a page used for announcements from [WikiProjects](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikiproject "Wikipedia:Wikiproject") and other groups. Included here are coordinated efforts, events, projects, and other general announcements.

* [Dashboard](/wiki/Wikipedia:Dashboard "Wikipedia:Dashboard")
* [News](/wiki/Wikipedia:News "Wikipedia:News")
* [Task Center](/wiki/Wikipedia:Task_Center "Wikipedia:Task Center")
* [Goings-on](/wiki/Wikipedia:Goings-on "Wikipedia:Goings-on")
* [Meetups](/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetups "Wikipedia:Meetups")
* [In the media](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_in_the_media "Wikipedia:Wikipedia in the media")
* [Mailing lists](/wiki/Wikipedia:Mailing_lists "Wikipedia:Mailing lists")

Events and projects [[add]](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Wikipedia:Community_bulletin_board "Special:EditPage/Wikipedia:Community bulletin board")

**Yearly or infrequent events**

**Monthly or continuous events**

* **[Monthly contest, WikiProject Military history](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Military_history/Contest "Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Contest").** The contest department of the Military history WikiProject aims to motivate increased quality in military history articles by offering a form of friendly competition for project members making improvements to them. The primary contest available is a simple rolling competition that awards points for improving articles. The contest runs from the first to last day of each month.
* **Guild of Copy Editors' editing drive**. The **[January 2026 backlog drive](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Guild_of_Copy_Editors/Backlog_elimination_drives/January_2026 "Wikipedia:WikiProject Guild of Copy Editors/Backlog elimination drives/January 2026")** is a one-month-long effort by the [**Guild of Copy Editors**](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Guild_of_Copy_Editors "Wikipedia:WikiProject Guild of Copy Editors") to reduce the backlog of articles that require copy editing: those carrying the {{[copy edit](/wiki/Template:Copy_edit "Template:Copy edit")}} tag (also {{[awkward](/wiki/Template:Awkward "Template:Awkward")}}, {{[copy edit section](/wiki/Template:Copy_edit_section "Template:Copy edit section")}}, {{[inappropriate person](/wiki/Template:Inappropriate_person "Template:Inappropriate person")}}, {{[copy edit inline](/wiki/Template:Copy_edit_inline "Template:Copy edit inline")}}, and their redirects) or are listed on the [GOCE Requests page](/wiki/Wikipedia:GOCE/REQ "Wikipedia:GOCE/REQ"). It began on 1 January, 00:00 (UTC), and will end on 31 January, 23:59 (UTC).

## Tip of the day

[Tip of the day...](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tip_of_the_day "Wikipedia:Tip of the day")

**Are your hands full?**

You have just grabbed the page's title to place a link on another page, but now you want to add a section title to it to create a section link, but the copy cache is already full. Instead of making two trips back and forth to the page you wish to add the link to, try this...

...use the search box as a quick-and-dirty edit window.

1. [Copy/paste](/wiki/Cut,_copy,_and_paste "Cut, copy, and paste") the title into the search box, followed by a "#"
2. Copy/paste the section title after the "#"
3. Enclose in double square [brackets](/wiki/Bracket "Bracket") and copy/paste the whole string to the page you wish to edit.

The search box is also a handy place to store copy text while you copy/paste something else. (But do not forget it is there!)

[Prior tip](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tip_of_the_day/January_2 "Wikipedia:Tip of the day/January 2") – [Tips library](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tips "Wikipedia:Tips") – [Next tip](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tip_of_the_day/January_4 "Wikipedia:Tip of the day/January 4")

*[Become a Wikipedia tipster](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_tipster "Wikipedia:Wikipedia tipster")*

**Joseph Robinette Biden Jr.**[[a]](#cite_note-1) (born November 20, 1942) is an American politician who was the 46th [president of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") from 2021 to 2025. As a member of the [Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States) "Democratic Party (United States)"), he represented [Delaware](/wiki/Delaware "Delaware") in the [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") from 1973 to 2009. Biden served as the 47th [vice president](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the United States") under President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") from 2009 to 2017.

Born in [Scranton, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania "Scranton, Pennsylvania"), Biden graduated from the [University of Delaware](/wiki/University_of_Delaware "University of Delaware") in 1965 and the [Syracuse University College of Law](/wiki/Syracuse_University_College_of_Law "Syracuse University College of Law") in 1968. He was elected to the [New Castle County Council](/wiki/New_Castle_County_Council "New Castle County Council") in 1970 and the [U.S. Senate in 1972](/wiki/1972_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1972 United States Senate election in Delaware"). [As a senator](/wiki/US_Senate_career_of_Joe_Biden "US Senate career of Joe Biden"), Biden chaired the Senate [Judiciary Committee](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_the_Judiciary "United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary") and [Foreign Relations Committee](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_Foreign_Relations "United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations"). He drafted and led passage of the [Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act](/wiki/Violent_Crime_Control_and_Law_Enforcement_Act "Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act") and the [Violence Against Women Act](/wiki/Violence_Against_Women_Act "Violence Against Women Act"). Biden also oversaw six [U.S. Supreme Court](/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court "U.S. Supreme Court") confirmation hearings, including contentious [hearings for Robert Bork](/wiki/Robert_Bork_Supreme_Court_nomination "Robert Bork Supreme Court nomination") and [Clarence Thomas](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas_Supreme_Court_nomination "Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination"). He opposed the [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") in 1991 but voted in favor of the [Iraq War Resolution](/wiki/Iraq_War_Resolution "Iraq War Resolution") in 2002. Biden ran unsuccessfully for the [1988](/wiki/1988_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "1988 Democratic Party presidential primaries") and [2008 Democratic presidential nominations](/wiki/2008_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2008 Democratic Party presidential primaries"). In 2008, Obama chose him as his running mate, and Biden was a close counselor to Obama [as vice president](/wiki/Vice_presidency_of_Joe_Biden "Vice presidency of Joe Biden"). In the [2020 presidential election](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election"), Biden chose [Kamala Harris](/wiki/Kamala_Harris "Kamala Harris") as his running mate, and they defeated [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)") incumbents [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") and [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence").

As president, Biden signed the [American Rescue Plan Act](/wiki/American_Rescue_Plan_Act_of_2021 "American Rescue Plan Act of 2021") in response to the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") and [subsequent recession](/wiki/COVID-19_recession "COVID-19 recession"). He signed bipartisan bills on [infrastructure](/wiki/Infrastructure_Investment_and_Jobs_Act "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act") and [manufacturing](/wiki/CHIPS_and_Science_Act "CHIPS and Science Act"). Biden proposed the [Build Back Better Act](/wiki/Build_Back_Better_Act "Build Back Better Act"), aspects of which were incorporated into the [Inflation Reduction Act](/wiki/Inflation_Reduction_Act "Inflation Reduction Act") that he signed into law in 2022. He [appointed Ketanji Brown Jackson](/wiki/Ketanji_Brown_Jackson_Supreme_Court_nomination "Ketanji Brown Jackson Supreme Court nomination") to the [Supreme Court of the United States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States"). In [his foreign policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_Joe_Biden_administration "Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration"), the U.S. reentered the [Paris Agreement](/wiki/Paris_Agreement "Paris Agreement") and enacted the [New Atlantic Charter](/wiki/New_Atlantic_Charter "New Atlantic Charter"). Biden oversaw the [complete withdrawal of U.S. troops](/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_U.S._troop_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan "2020–2021 U.S. troop withdrawal from Afghanistan") that ended the [war in Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)"), leading to [the Taliban seizing control](/wiki/2021_Taliban_offensive "2021 Taliban offensive"). He [responded to the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/United_States_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine") by imposing [sanctions on Russia](/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine") and authorizing [aid to Ukraine](/wiki/United_States_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "United States military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War"). During the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war"), Biden condemned the actions of [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas") as terrorism, [strongly supported Israel](/wiki/United_States_support_for_Israel_in_the_Gaza_war "United States support for Israel in the Gaza war"), and sent limited humanitarian aid to the [Gaza Strip](/wiki/Gaza_Strip "Gaza Strip"). A temporary [ceasefire proposal](/wiki/January_2025_Gaza_war_ceasefire "January 2025 Gaza war ceasefire") he backed was adopted shortly before his presidency ended.

[Concerns about Biden's age and health](/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Joe_Biden "Age and health concerns about Joe Biden") persisted throughout his presidency. He became the first president to turn 80 years old while in office. He began his presidency with majority support, but saw his approval ratings decline significantly throughout his presidency, partially due to public frustration over [persistently high inflation](/wiki/2021-2023_inflation_surge "2021-2023 inflation surge") for most of his term. Biden initially [ran for reelection](/wiki/Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign "Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign") and, after the [Democratic primaries](/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries"), became the party's presumptive nominee in the [2024 presidential election](/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election "2024 United States presidential election"). After his performance in the [first presidential debate](/wiki/2024_Joe_Biden%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_presidential_debate "2024 Joe Biden–Donald Trump presidential debate"), intensifying scrutiny from across the political spectrum about his age and health led him to [withdraw his candidacy](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election "Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election"). During his time in office, Biden's administration was [ranked favorably](/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#Scholar_survey_summary "Historical rankings of presidents of the United States") by historians and scholars, diverging from [unfavorable public assessments](/wiki/United_States_presidential_approval_rating "United States presidential approval rating") of his tenure. He is the [oldest living former U.S. president](/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age#Age_of_presidents "List of presidents of the United States by age"), the [oldest living former U.S. vice president](/wiki/List_of_vice_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age "List of vice presidents of the United States by age"), and the oldest person to have served as president.

## Early life (1942–1965)

Main article: [Early life and career of Joe Biden](/wiki/Early_life_and_career_of_Joe_Biden "Early life and career of Joe Biden")

Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. was born on November 20, 1942,[[1]](#cite_note-cong-bio-2) at St. Mary's Hospital in [Scranton, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania "Scranton, Pennsylvania"),[[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover20105-3) to Catherine Eugenia "Jean" Biden ([née](/wiki/Birth_name#Maiden_and_married_names "Birth name") Finnegan)[[3]](#cite_note-4) and Joseph Robinette Biden Sr.[[4]](#cite_note-5) He is the oldest child in a [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") family of mostly Irish descent. Biden has a sister, [Valerie](/wiki/Valerie_Biden_Owens "Valerie Biden Owens"), and two brothers, [James](/wiki/James_Biden "James Biden") and Francis.[[5]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover20108–9-6)

### Home life

Joseph Sr. had been wealthy, and the family purchased a home in the affluent Long Island suburb of [Garden City, New York](/wiki/Garden_City,_New_York "Garden City, New York"), in 1946.[[6]](#cite_note-7) After he suffered business setbacks around the time Biden was seven years old,[[7]](#cite_note-8)[[8]](#cite_note-promises2008-9)[[9]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover20107–8-10) the family lived with Jean's parents in Scranton for several years.[[10]](#cite_note-nyt-father-11) Scranton fell into economic decline during the 1950s, and Joseph Sr. could not find steady work.[[11]](#cite_note-ap-scranton-12) Beginning in 1953, when Biden was ten,[[12]](#cite_note-13) the family lived in an apartment in [Claymont, Delaware](/wiki/Claymont,_Delaware "Claymont, Delaware"), before moving to a house in nearby [Mayfield, Delaware](/wiki/Mayfield,_Delaware "Mayfield, Delaware").[[b]](#cite_note-16) Joseph Sr. later became a successful [used-car salesman](/wiki/Used-car_salesman "Used-car salesman"), maintaining the family in a middle-class lifestyle.[[10]](#cite_note-nyt-father-11)[[11]](#cite_note-ap-scranton-12)[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17)

### Sports and young adulthood

At [Archmere Academy](/wiki/Archmere_Academy "Archmere Academy") in Claymont,[[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201027,_32-18) Biden played baseball and was a standout [halfback](/wiki/Halfback_(American_football) "Halfback (American football)") and [wide receiver](/wiki/Wide_receiver "Wide receiver") on the [high school football](/wiki/High_school_football "High school football") team.[[10]](#cite_note-nyt-father-11)[[17]](#cite_note-19) Though a poor student, he was [class president](/wiki/Class_president "Class president") in his junior and senior years.[[18]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201040–41-20)[[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor199099-21) He graduated in 1961.[[18]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201040–41-20) At the [University of Delaware](/wiki/University_of_Delaware "University of Delaware") in [Newark](/wiki/Newark,_Delaware "Newark, Delaware"), Biden briefly played freshman football[[20]](#cite_note-22)[[21]](#cite_note-23) and received a Bachelor of Arts degree with a [double major](/wiki/Double_major "Double major") in history and [political science](/wiki/Political_science "Political science") in 1965.[[22]](#cite_note-ap-timeline-24)[[23]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor199098-25)

## Marriages, law school, and early career (1966–1973)

Main article: [Early career of Joe Biden](/wiki/Early_life_and_career_of_Joe_Biden "Early life and career of Joe Biden")

See also: [Family of Joe Biden](/wiki/Family_of_Joe_Biden "Family of Joe Biden")

Biden married [Neilia Hunter](/wiki/Neilia_Hunter_Biden "Neilia Hunter Biden"), a student at [Syracuse University](/wiki/Syracuse_University "Syracuse University"), on August 27, 1966,[[22]](#cite_note-ap-timeline-24)[[24]](#cite_note-26) after overcoming her parents' disinclination for her to wed a Catholic. Their wedding was held in a Catholic church in [Skaneateles, New York](/wiki/Skaneateles,_New_York_(village) "Skaneateles, New York (village)").[[25]](#cite_note-27) They had three children: [Joseph R. "Beau" Biden III](/wiki/Beau_Biden "Beau Biden"), [Robert Hunter Biden](/wiki/Hunter_Biden "Hunter Biden"), and Naomi Christina "Amy" Biden.[[22]](#cite_note-ap-timeline-24)

Biden earned a [Juris Doctor](/wiki/Juris_Doctor "Juris Doctor") from [Syracuse University College of Law](/wiki/Syracuse_University_College_of_Law "Syracuse University College of Law") in 1968. In his first year of law school, he failed a course because he [plagiarized](/wiki/Plagiarism "Plagiarism") a law review article, but the failing grade was later stricken. His grades were relatively poor, and he graduated 76th in a class of 85.[[26]](#cite_note-nyt091887-28) He was [admitted](/wiki/Admission_to_the_bar_in_the_United_States "Admission to the bar in the United States") to the [Delaware bar](/wiki/Delaware_bar "Delaware bar") in 1969.[[1]](#cite_note-cong-bio-2)

Biden clerked at a law firm headed by prominent local [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)") William Prickett in 1968 and self-identified as a Republican.[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29)[[28]](#cite_note-30) He disliked incumbent Democratic Delaware governor [Charles L. Terry](/wiki/Charles_L._Terry "Charles L. Terry")'s conservative racial politics and supported a more liberal Republican, [Russell W. Peterson](/wiki/Russell_W._Peterson "Russell W. Peterson"), who defeated Terry in 1968.[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29) Local Republicans attempted to recruit Biden, but he registered as an [independent](/wiki/Independent_politician "Independent politician") because of his distaste for Republican presidential candidate [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon").[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29)

### Law practices

In 1969, Biden resumed practicing law, first as a [public defender](/wiki/Public_defender "Public defender") in [Wilmington, Delaware](/wiki/Wilmington,_Delaware "Wilmington, Delaware"). Most of his clients were [African Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") from Wilmington's east side.[[29]](#cite_note-31)[[30]](#cite_note-32) Biden then joined a firm headed by Sid Balick, a locally active Democrat.[[31]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoritz198743-33)[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29) Balick named him to the Democratic Forum, a group trying to reform and revitalize the state party,[[32]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201086-34) and Biden switched his registration to Democratic.[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29) He also started his own firm, Biden and Walsh.[[31]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoritz198743-33) [Corporate law](/wiki/Corporate_law "Corporate law"), however, did not appeal to him, and [criminal law](/wiki/Criminal_law "Criminal law") did not pay well.[[10]](#cite_note-nyt-father-11) He supplemented his income by managing properties.[[33]](#cite_note-watn020109-35)

Biden ran for the fourth district seat on the [New Castle County Council](/wiki/New_Castle_County,_Delaware#County_Council "New Castle County, Delaware") in 1970 on a liberal platform that included support for public housing in the suburbs.[[34]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201059-36)[[35]](#cite_note-37) Biden won the general election, defeating Republican Lawrence T. Messick, and took office on January 5, 1971.[[36]](#cite_note-38)[[37]](#cite_note-39) He served until January 1, 1973.[[38]](#cite_note-40)[[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201052–64-41) During his time on the county council, Biden opposed large highway projects, which he argued might disrupt Wilmington neighborhoods.[[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201052–64-41)

Biden had not openly supported or opposed the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") until he ran for Senate and opposed [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon")'s conduct of the war.[[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201050,_75-42) While studying at the University of Delaware and Syracuse University, Biden obtained five student [draft](/wiki/Conscription "Conscription") deferments. Based on a physical examination, he was given a conditional medical deferment in 1968; in 2008, a spokesperson for Biden said his having had "[asthma](/wiki/Asthma "Asthma") as a teenager" was the reason.[[41]](#cite_note-43)

### 1972 U.S. Senate campaign in Delaware

Main article: [1972 United States Senate election in Delaware](/wiki/1972_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1972 United States Senate election in Delaware")

Biden defeated Republican incumbent [J. Caleb Boggs](/wiki/J._Caleb_Boggs "J. Caleb Boggs") to become the junior U.S. senator from Delaware in 1972. He was the only Democrat willing to challenge Boggs and, with minimal campaign funds, was thought to have no chance of winning.[[42]](#cite_note-cby-43-44)[[10]](#cite_note-nyt-father-11) Family members managed and staffed the campaign, which relied on meeting voters face-to-face and hand-distributing position papers,[[43]](#cite_note-npr-72-45) an approach made feasible by Delaware's small size.[[33]](#cite_note-watn020109-35) He received help from the [AFL-CIO](/wiki/AFL-CIO "AFL-CIO") and Democratic pollster [Patrick Caddell](/wiki/Patrick_Caddell "Patrick Caddell").[[42]](#cite_note-cby-43-44) His platform focused on the environment, withdrawal from Vietnam, civil rights, mass transit, equitable taxation, health care and public dissatisfaction with "politics as usual".[[42]](#cite_note-cby-43-44)[[43]](#cite_note-npr-72-45) A few months before the election, Biden trailed Boggs by almost thirty percentage points,[[42]](#cite_note-cby-43-44) but his energy, young family, and ability to connect with voters' emotions worked to his advantage,[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) and he won with 50.5% of the vote.[[43]](#cite_note-npr-72-45)

### Death of first wife and daughter

A few weeks after Biden was elected senator, his wife Neilia and one-year-old daughter Naomi were killed in an automobile accident in [Hockessin, Delaware](/wiki/Hockessin,_Delaware "Hockessin, Delaware"), on December 18, 1972.[[22]](#cite_note-ap-timeline-24)[[44]](#cite_note-46) Their sons Beau (aged 3) and Hunter (aged 2) were in the car and were taken to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover201093,_98-47) He considered resigning to care for them,[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) but [Senate Majority Leader](/wiki/Senate_Majority_Leader "Senate Majority Leader") [Mike Mansfield](/wiki/Mike_Mansfield "Mike Mansfield") persuaded him not to.[[46]](#cite_note-48) Biden contemplated suicide and was filled with anger and religious doubt.[[47]](#cite_note-49)[[48]](#cite_note-50) He wrote that he "felt God had played a horrible trick" on him[[49]](#cite_note-51) and had trouble focusing on work.[[50]](#cite_note-52)[[51]](#cite_note-53)

### Second marriage

Biden met teacher [Jill Tracy Jacobs](/wiki/Jill_Tracy_Jacobs "Jill Tracy Jacobs") in 1975 on a [blind date](/wiki/Blind_date "Blind date").[[52]](#cite_note-54) They married at the [United Nations chapel](/wiki/Church_Center_for_the_United_Nations "Church Center for the United Nations") in New York on June 17, 1977,[[53]](#cite_note-55)[[54]](#cite_note-56) and spent their honeymoon at [Lake Balaton](/wiki/Lake_Balaton "Lake Balaton") in the [Hungarian People's Republic](/wiki/Hungarian_People%27s_Republic "Hungarian People's Republic").[[55]](#cite_note-57)[[56]](#cite_note-58) Biden credits her with the renewal of his interest in politics and life.[[57]](#cite_note-59)

In 1981, the couple had a daughter, [Ashley Biden](/wiki/Ashley_Biden "Ashley Biden"),[[22]](#cite_note-ap-timeline-24) who is a social worker, activist, and fashion designer.[[58]](#cite_note-60) Jill helped raise her stepsons, Hunter and Beau, who were seven and eight respectively at the time of her marriage. Hunter has worked as a Washington lobbyist and investment adviser; his business dealings, [personal life](/wiki/Hunter_Biden_laptop_controversy "Hunter Biden laptop controversy"), and [legal troubles](/wiki/Weiss_special_counsel_investigation "Weiss special counsel investigation") came under [significant scrutiny](/wiki/United_States_House_Oversight_Committee_investigation_into_the_Biden_family "United States House Oversight Committee investigation into the Biden family") during his father's presidency. In December 2024, Biden pardoned Hunter following his [conviction](/wiki/Weiss_special_counsel_investigation "Weiss special counsel investigation") on gun and tax charges despite repeated promises that he would not do so.[[c]](#cite_note-65) Beau became an Army [judge-advocate](/wiki/Judge-advocate "Judge-advocate") in Iraq and later [Delaware attorney general](/wiki/Delaware_attorney_general "Delaware attorney general")[[63]](#cite_note-66) before dying of brain cancer in 2015.[[64]](#cite_note-67)[[65]](#cite_note-68)

### Teaching

From 1991 to 2008, as an [adjunct professor](/wiki/Adjunct_professor "Adjunct professor"), Biden co-taught a [seminar](/wiki/Seminar "Seminar") on [constitutional law](/wiki/Constitutional_law "Constitutional law") at [Widener University School of Law](/wiki/Widener_University_School_of_Law "Widener University School of Law").[[66]](#cite_note-69)[[67]](#cite_note-70)

## U.S. Senate (1973–2009)

Main article: [US Senate career of Joe Biden](/wiki/US_Senate_career_of_Joe_Biden "US Senate career of Joe Biden")

Elected to the U.S. Senate in [1972](/wiki/1972_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1972 United States Senate election in Delaware"), Biden was reelected in [1978](/wiki/1978_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1978 United States Senate election in Delaware"), [1984](/wiki/1984_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1984 United States Senate election in Delaware"), [1990](/wiki/1990_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1990 United States Senate election in Delaware"), [1996](/wiki/1996_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "1996 United States Senate election in Delaware"), [2002](/wiki/2002_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "2002 United States Senate election in Delaware"), and [2008](/wiki/2008_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "2008 United States Senate election in Delaware"), regularly receiving about 60% of the vote.[[68]](#cite_note-aap08-366-71) Aged 30 when first elected, he was the [seventh-youngest senator in U.S. history](/wiki/List_of_youngest_members_of_the_United_States_Congress#List_of_youngest_U.S._senators "List of youngest members of the United States Congress").[[69]](#cite_note-72) He was junior senator to [William Roth](/wiki/William_Roth "William Roth") until Roth was defeated in 2000.[[70]](#cite_note-73) He remains one of the [longest-serving senators](/wiki/List_of_members_of_the_United_States_Congress_by_longevity_of_service "List of members of the United States Congress by longevity of service") in U.S. history.[[71]](#cite_note-74) For 36 years, he commuted from Washington to Wilmington via [Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak"), earning him the nickname "Amtrak Joe".[[72]](#cite_note-75)

### Senate activities

During his early years in the Senate, Biden focused on consumer protection and environmental issues and called for greater government accountability.[[73]](#cite_note-76) In 1974, he described himself as liberal on civil rights and liberties, senior citizens' concerns, and healthcare, but conservative on other issues, including abortion and [military conscription](/wiki/Military_conscription "Military conscription").[[74]](#cite_note-77) Biden was the first U.S. senator to endorse Governor [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter") for president in the [1976 Democratic primary](/wiki/1976_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "1976 Democratic Party presidential primaries"). Carter won the Democratic nomination and the [1976 election](/wiki/1976_United_States_presidential_election "1976 United States presidential election").[[75]](#cite_note-78) Biden also worked on [arms control](/wiki/Arms_control "Arms control").[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79)[[77]](#cite_note-80) After Congress failed to ratify the [SALT II](/wiki/SALT_II "SALT II") Treaty signed in 1979 by [Soviet general secretary](/wiki/Soviet_general_secretary "Soviet general secretary") [Leonid Brezhnev](/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev "Leonid Brezhnev") and President Carter, Biden met with Soviet foreign minister [Andrei Gromyko](/wiki/Andrei_Gromyko "Andrei Gromyko") and secured changes that addressed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's objections.[[78]](#cite_note-81) He received considerable attention when he excoriated Secretary of State [George Shultz](/wiki/George_Shultz "George Shultz") at a Senate hearing for the Reagan administration's support of [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") despite its policy of [apartheid](/wiki/Apartheid "Apartheid").[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29) In a congressional hearing in 1984, he objected to the [Strategic Defense Initiative](/wiki/Strategic_Defense_Initiative "Strategic Defense Initiative") plan to construct autonomous systems of ICBM defense.[[79]](#cite_note-82)[[80]](#cite_note-83) Biden was an advocate for Delaware military installations, including [Dover Air Force Base](/wiki/Dover_Air_Force_Base "Dover Air Force Base") and [New Castle Air National Guard Base](/wiki/New_Castle_Air_National_Guard_Base "New Castle Air National Guard Base").[[81]](#cite_note-84)

In the mid-1970s, Biden was one of the Senate's strongest opponents of [race-integration busing](/wiki/Race-integration_busing "Race-integration busing"). His Delaware constituents strongly opposed it, and such opposition nationwide later led his party to mostly abandon school integration policies.[[82]](#cite_note-Gadsden-85) In his first Senate campaign, Biden had expressed support for busing to remedy *de jure* segregation, as in the South, but opposed its use to remedy *de facto* segregation arising from racial patterns of neighborhood residency, as in Delaware; he opposed a proposed constitutional amendment banning busing entirely.[[83]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGadsden2012214-86) Biden supported a 1976 measure forbidding the use of federal funds for transporting students beyond the school closest to them.[[82]](#cite_note-Gadsden-85) He co-sponsored a 1977 amendment closing loopholes in that measure, which President Carter signed into law in 1978.[[84]](#cite_note-87)

Biden became [ranking minority member](/wiki/Ranking_minority_member "Ranking minority member") of the [Senate Judiciary Committee](/wiki/Senate_Judiciary_Committee "Senate Judiciary Committee") in 1981. He was a Democratic floor manager for the successful passage of the [Comprehensive Crime Control Act](/wiki/Comprehensive_Crime_Control_Act "Comprehensive Crime Control Act") in 1984. His supporters praised him for modifying some of the law's worst provisions, and it was his most important legislative accomplishment to that time.[[85]](#cite_note-cby-44-88) In 1994, Biden helped pass the [Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act](/wiki/Violent_Crime_Control_and_Law_Enforcement_Act "Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act"), which included [a ban on assault weapons](/wiki/Federal_Assault_Weapons_Ban "Federal Assault Weapons Ban"),[[86]](#cite_note-89)[[87]](#cite_note-90) and the [Violence Against Women Act](/wiki/Violence_Against_Women_Act "Violence Against Women Act"),[[88]](#cite_note-91) which he has called his most significant legislation.[[89]](#cite_note-92) The 1994 crime law was unpopular among progressives and criticized for resulting in mass incarceration;[[90]](#cite_note-93)[[91]](#cite_note-94) Biden later expressed regret for passing the bill.[[92]](#cite_note-95)

Biden voted for a 1993 provision that deemed homosexuality incompatible with military life, thereby banning [gay people](/wiki/List_of_gay,_lesbian_or_bisexual_people "List of gay, lesbian or bisexual people") from serving in the armed forces.[[93]](#cite_note-96)[[94]](#cite_note-97) In 1996, he voted for the [Defense of Marriage Act](/wiki/Defense_of_Marriage_Act "Defense of Marriage Act"), which prohibited the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages, thereby barring people in such marriages from equal protection under federal law and allowing states to do the same.[[95]](#cite_note-NYT_Biden_Evolution_on_LGBTQ-98) In 2015, the act was ruled unconstitutional in *[Obergefell v. Hodges](/wiki/Obergefell_v._Hodges "Obergefell v. Hodges")*.[[96]](#cite_note-99)

Biden was critical of [Independent Counsel](/wiki/United_States_Office_of_the_Independent_Counsel "United States Office of the Independent Counsel") [Ken Starr](/wiki/Ken_Starr "Ken Starr") during the 1990s [Whitewater controversy](/wiki/Whitewater_controversy "Whitewater controversy") and [Clinton–Lewinsky scandal](/wiki/Clinton%E2%80%93Lewinsky_scandal "Clinton–Lewinsky scandal") investigations, saying "it's going to be a cold day in hell" before another independent counsel would be granted similar powers.[[97]](#cite_note-100) He voted to acquit during the [impeachment of Bill Clinton](/wiki/Impeachment_of_Bill_Clinton "Impeachment of Bill Clinton").[[98]](#cite_note-101) During the 2000s, Biden sponsored bankruptcy legislation sought by credit card issuers (such as [MBNA](/wiki/MBNA "MBNA"), one of Delaware's largest companies).[[99]](#cite_note-102)[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") vetoed the bill in 2000, but it passed in 2005 as the [Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act](/wiki/Bankruptcy_Abuse_Prevention_and_Consumer_Protection_Act "Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act"),[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) with Biden being one of only 18 Democrats to vote for it, while leading Democrats and consumer rights organizations opposed it.[[100]](#cite_note-103) As a senator, Biden strongly supported increased [Amtrak](/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak") funding and rail security.[[68]](#cite_note-aap08-366-71)[[101]](#cite_note-104)

### Brain surgeries

In February 1988, after several episodes of severe neck pain, Biden underwent surgery to correct a leaking [intracranial berry aneurysm](/wiki/Intracranial_berry_aneurysm "Intracranial berry aneurysm").[[102]](#cite_note-105)[[103]](#cite_note-nyt-4cmed-106) While recuperating, he suffered a [pulmonary embolism](/wiki/Pulmonary_embolism "Pulmonary embolism").[[103]](#cite_note-nyt-4cmed-106) A second aneurysm was surgically repaired in May.[[103]](#cite_note-nyt-4cmed-106)[[104]](#cite_note-107) His recuperation kept him away from the Senate for seven months.[[105]](#cite_note-108)

### Senate Judiciary Committee

Biden was a longtime member of the [Senate Committee on the Judiciary](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_the_Judiciary "United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary"). He chaired it from 1987 to 1995 and was a [ranking minority member](/wiki/Ranking_member "Ranking member") from 1981 to 1987 and again from 1995 to 1997.[[106]](#cite_note-109)

As chair, Biden presided over two highly contentious [U.S. Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States") confirmation hearings.[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) When [Robert Bork was nominated](/wiki/Robert_Bork_Supreme_Court_nomination "Robert Bork Supreme Court nomination") in 1988, Biden reversed his approval‍—‌given in an interview the previous year‍—‌of a hypothetical Bork nomination. Conservatives were angered,[[107]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronner1989138–139,_214,_305-110) but at the hearings' close Biden was praised for his fairness, humor, and courage.[[107]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronner1989138–139,_214,_305-110)[[108]](#cite_note-nyt-lg-87-111) Rejecting the arguments of some Bork opponents,[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) Biden framed his objections to Bork in terms of the conflict between Bork's strong [originalism](/wiki/Originalism "Originalism") and the view that the [U.S. Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States") provides rights to liberty and privacy beyond those explicitly enumerated in its text.[[108]](#cite_note-nyt-lg-87-111) Bork's nomination was rejected in the committee by a 5–9 vote[[108]](#cite_note-nyt-lg-87-111) and then in the full Senate, 42–58.[[109]](#cite_note-112)

During [Clarence Thomas's nomination hearings](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas_Supreme_Court_nomination "Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination") in 1991, Biden's questions on constitutional issues were often convoluted to the point that Thomas sometimes lost track of them,[[110]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMayerAbramson1994213,_218,_336-113) and Thomas later wrote that Biden's questions were akin to "[beanballs](/wiki/Beanball "Beanball")".[[111]](#cite_note-114) After the committee hearing closed, the public learned that [Anita Hill](/wiki/Anita_Hill "Anita Hill") had accused Thomas of [making unwelcome sexual comments](/wiki/Sexual_harassment "Sexual harassment") when they had worked together.[[112]](#cite_note-115)[[113]](#cite_note-116) Biden had known of some of these charges, but initially shared them only with the committee because Hill was then unwilling to testify.[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) The committee hearing was reopened and Hill testified, but Biden did not permit testimony from other witnesses, such as a woman who had made similar charges and experts on harassment.[[114]](#cite_note-nyt-hill-117) The full Senate confirmed Thomas by a 52–48 vote, with Biden opposed.[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17) Liberal legal advocates and women's groups felt strongly that Biden had mishandled the hearings and not done enough to support Hill.[[114]](#cite_note-nyt-hill-117) In 2019, he told Hill he regretted his treatment of her, but Hill said afterward she remained unsatisfied.[[115]](#cite_note-118)

### Senate Foreign Relations Committee

Biden was a longtime member of the [Senate Foreign Relations Committee](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_Foreign_Relations "United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations"). He became its ranking minority member in 1997, and chaired it from June 2001 to 2003 and 2007 to 2009.[[116]](#cite_note-aap08-365-119) His positions were generally [liberal internationalist](/wiki/Liberal_internationalism "Liberal internationalism").[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79)[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) He collaborated effectively with Republicans and sometimes went against elements of his own party.[[116]](#cite_note-aap08-365-119)[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) During this time he met with at least 150 leaders from 60 countries and international organizations, becoming a well-known Democratic voice on foreign policy.[[118]](#cite_note-121)

Biden voted against authorization for the [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") in 1991.[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) He became interested in the [Yugoslav Wars](/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars") after hearing about Serbian abuses during the [Croatian War of Independence](/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence "Croatian War of Independence") in 1991.[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79) Once the [Bosnian War](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War") broke out, Biden was among the first to call for the "[lift and strike](/wiki/Lift_and_strike_(Bosnian_War) "Lift and strike (Bosnian War)")" policy.[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79)[[116]](#cite_note-aap08-365-119) [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W. Bush") and [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") were both reluctant to implement the policy, fearing Balkan entanglement.[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79)[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) In April 1993, Biden had a tense three-hour meeting with Serbian leader [Slobodan Milošević](/wiki/Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Slobodan Milošević").[[119]](#cite_note-wapo-bosnia-122) Biden worked on several versions of legislative language urging the U.S. toward greater involvement.[[119]](#cite_note-wapo-bosnia-122) He has called his role in affecting Balkan policy in the mid-1990s his "proudest moment in public life" related to foreign policy.[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) In 1999, during the [Kosovo War](/wiki/Kosovo_War "Kosovo War"), Biden supported the [NATO bombing of Yugoslavia](/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia "NATO bombing of Yugoslavia").[[76]](#cite_note-nyt-foreign-79) He and Senator [John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John McCain") co-sponsored the McCain-Biden Kosovo Resolution, which called on Clinton to use all necessary force, including ground troops, to confront Milošević over Yugoslav actions toward [Kosovo Albanians](/wiki/Kosovo_Albanians "Kosovo Albanians").[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120)[[120]](#cite_note-wsj082508-123)

#### Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq

Main article: [War on terror](/wiki/War_on_terror "War on terror")

Biden was a strong supporter of the [War in Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)"), saying, "Whatever it takes, we should do it."[[121]](#cite_note-124) As head of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, he said in 2002 that Iraqi president [Saddam Hussein](/wiki/Saddam_Hussein "Saddam Hussein") was a threat to national security and there was no other option than to "eliminate" that threat.[[122]](#cite_note-125) In October 2002, he voted in favor of the [Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq](/wiki/Authorization_for_Use_of_Military_Force_Against_Iraq "Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq"), approving the [U.S. invasion of Iraq](/wiki/U.S._invasion_of_Iraq "U.S. invasion of Iraq").[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120) As chair of the committee, he assembled witnesses to testify in favor of the authorization. They gave testimony grossly misrepresenting the intent, history, and status of Saddam and his government, and touted Iraq's fictional possession of [weapons of mass destruction](/wiki/Weapons_of_mass_destruction "Weapons of mass destruction").[[123]](#cite_note-126) Biden eventually became a critic of the war, calling his vote a "mistake" by 2005,[[124]](#cite_note-127)[[125]](#cite_note-128) but did not push for withdrawal.[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120)[[119]](#cite_note-wapo-bosnia-122) He supported the appropriations for the occupation, but argued that the war should be internationalized, that more soldiers were needed, and that the Bush administration should "level with the [American people](/wiki/Americans "Americans")" about its cost and length.[[116]](#cite_note-aap08-365-119)[[120]](#cite_note-wsj082508-123)

By late 2006, Biden's stance had shifted considerably. He opposed the [troop surge of 2007](/wiki/Troop_surge_of_2007 "Troop surge of 2007"),[[117]](#cite_note-lat-foreign-120)[[119]](#cite_note-wapo-bosnia-122) saying General [David Petraeus](/wiki/David_Petraeus "David Petraeus") was "dead, flat wrong" in believing the surge could work.[[126]](#cite_note-nytm-traub-129) Biden, through a plan developed with [Council on Foreign Relations](/wiki/Council_on_Foreign_Relations "Council on Foreign Relations") president [Leslie H. Gelb](/wiki/Leslie_H._Gelb "Leslie H. Gelb"), instead advocated dividing Iraq into a loose [federation of three ethnic states](/wiki/Federalism_in_Iraq "Federalism in Iraq").[[d]](#cite_note-134) In September 2007, a non-binding resolution endorsing the plan passed the Senate,[[131]](#cite_note-135) but the idea failed to gain traction.[[126]](#cite_note-nytm-traub-129)

## 1988 and 2008 presidential campaigns

### 1988 campaign

Main article: [Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign](/wiki/Joe_Biden_1988_presidential_campaign "Joe Biden 1988 presidential campaign")

Biden declared his candidacy for the [1988 Democratic presidential nomination](/wiki/1988_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "1988 Democratic Party presidential primaries") on June 9, 1987.[[132]](#cite_note-136) He was considered a strong candidate because of his moderate image, his speaking ability, his high profile as chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee at the upcoming [Robert Bork Supreme Court nomination](/wiki/Robert_Bork_Supreme_Court_nomination "Robert Bork Supreme Court nomination") hearings, and his appeal to [Baby Boomers](/wiki/Baby_Boomer "Baby Boomer").[[27]](#cite_note-dmn-87-29)[[133]](#cite_note-nyt083187-137)[[134]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor199083-138) He raised more in the first quarter of 1987 than any other candidate.[[133]](#cite_note-nyt083187-137)[[134]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor199083-138)

By August, Biden's campaign messaging had become confused due to staff rivalries,[[135]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor1990108–109-139) and in September, he was accused of plagiarizing a speech by [British Labour Party](/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)") leader [Neil Kinnock](/wiki/Neil_Kinnock "Neil Kinnock").[[136]](#cite_note-140) Biden had credited Kinnock on previous occasions,[[137]](#cite_note-141)[[138]](#cite_note-lat-speech-142) but did not on two occasions in August.[[139]](#cite_note-143): 230–232[[138]](#cite_note-lat-speech-142) Earlier that year, Biden had also used passages from a speech by [Robert F. Kennedy](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy "Robert F. Kennedy") (for which his aides took blame) and the [inaugural address of John F. Kennedy](/wiki/Inaugural_address_of_John_F._Kennedy "Inaugural address of John F. Kennedy"). Two years earlier he had used a 1976 passage by [Hubert Humphrey](/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey "Hubert Humphrey").[[140]](#cite_note-144) Biden responded that politicians often borrow from one another without giving credit, and that one of his rivals for the nomination, [Jesse Jackson](/wiki/Jesse_Jackson "Jesse Jackson"), had called him to point out that Jackson had used the same material by Humphrey that Biden had used.[[15]](#cite_note-aap08-bio-17)[[26]](#cite_note-nyt091887-28) A few days later, it was publicized that, while in law school, Biden had taken text from a *[Fordham Law Review](/wiki/Fordham_Law_Review "Fordham Law Review")* article with inadequate citations.[[26]](#cite_note-nyt091887-28) At Biden's request the Delaware Supreme Court's Board of Professional Responsibility reviewed the incident and concluded that he had violated no rules.[[141]](#cite_note-145)

Biden has made several false or exaggerated claims about his early life: that he had earned three degrees in college, that he attended [law school](/wiki/Law_school "Law school") on a full scholarship, that he had graduated in the top half of his class,[[142]](#cite_note-146)[[143]](#cite_note-147) and that he had marched in the [civil rights movement](/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement").[[144]](#cite_note-148) The limited amount of other news about the presidential race amplified these disclosures,[[145]](#cite_note-149) and on September 23, 1987, Biden withdrew his candidacy.[[146]](#cite_note-150)

### 2008 campaign

Main article: [Joe Biden 2008 presidential campaign](/wiki/Joe_Biden_2008_presidential_campaign "Joe Biden 2008 presidential campaign")

After exploring running in several previous cycles, in January 2007, Biden declared [his candidacy in the 2008 elections](/wiki/2008_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2008 Democratic Party presidential primaries").[[68]](#cite_note-aap08-366-71)[[147]](#cite_note-151)[[148]](#cite_note-152) Biden focused on the [Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War"), his record as chairman of major Senate committees, and his foreign-policy experience.[[149]](#cite_note-153) Biden was noted for his [one-liners](/wiki/One-line_joke "One-line joke") during the campaign; in one debate he said of Republican candidate [Rudy Giuliani](/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani "Rudy Giuliani"), "There's only three things he mentions in a sentence: a noun, and a verb and [9/11](/wiki/Cultural_influence_of_the_September_11_attacks "Cultural influence of the September 11 attacks")."[[150]](#cite_note-154)

Biden had difficulty raising funds, struggled to draw people to his rallies, and failed to gain traction against the high-profile candidacies of [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") and [Hillary Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton").[[151]](#cite_note-155) He never rose above single digits in [national polls of the Democratic candidates](/wiki/Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_Democratic_Party_2008_presidential_candidates "Nationwide opinion polling for the Democratic Party 2008 presidential candidates"). In the first contest on January 3, 2008, Biden placed fifth in the [Iowa caucuses](/wiki/Iowa_Democratic_caucuses,_2008 "Iowa Democratic caucuses, 2008"), garnering slightly less than one percent of the state delegates.[[152]](#cite_note-156) He withdrew from the race that evening.[[153]](#cite_note-157)

Despite its lack of success, Biden's 2008 campaign raised his stature in the political world.[[154]](#cite_note-gamechange-158): 336 In particular, it changed the relationship between Biden and Obama. Although they had served together on the [Senate Foreign Relations Committee](/wiki/Senate_Foreign_Relations_Committee "Senate Foreign Relations Committee"), they had not been close: Biden resented Obama's quick rise to political stardom,[[126]](#cite_note-nytm-traub-129)[[155]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolffe2009218-159) while Obama viewed Biden as garrulous and patronizing.[[154]](#cite_note-gamechange-158): 28, 337–338 Having gotten to know each other during 2007, Obama appreciated Biden's campaign style and appeal to working-class voters, and Biden said he became convinced Obama was "the real deal".[[155]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolffe2009218-159)[[154]](#cite_note-gamechange-158): 28, 337–338

## 2008 and 2012 vice presidential campaigns

### 2008 campaign

Main articles: [Barack Obama 2008 presidential campaign](/wiki/Barack_Obama_2008_presidential_campaign "Barack Obama 2008 presidential campaign") and [2008 Democratic Party vice presidential candidate selection](/wiki/2008_Democratic_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection "2008 Democratic Party vice presidential candidate selection")

In August 2008, Obama and Biden met in secret to discuss the possibility of a place for Biden in the Obama administration,[[156]](#cite_note-ny-lizza-160) and developed a strong personal rapport.[[155]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolffe2009218-159) On August 22, Obama announced that Biden would be his [running mate](/wiki/Running_mate "Running mate").[[157]](#cite_note-161) *[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")* reported that the choice reflected a desire for someone with [foreign policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy "Foreign policy") and [national security](/wiki/National_security "National security") experience.[[158]](#cite_note-162) Others pointed out Biden's appeal to middle-class and [blue-collar](/wiki/Blue-collar "Blue-collar") voters.[[159]](#cite_note-163)[[160]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolffe2009217-164) Biden was officially nominated for vice president on August 27 at the [2008 Democratic National Convention](/wiki/2008_Democratic_National_Convention "2008 Democratic National Convention") in [Denver](/wiki/Denver "Denver").[[161]](#cite_note-165)

Biden's vice-presidential campaigning gained little media attention, as the press devoted far more coverage to the Republican nominee and then-[governor of Alaska](/wiki/Governor_of_Alaska "Governor of Alaska"), [Sarah Palin](/wiki/Sarah_Palin "Sarah Palin").[[162]](#cite_note-nyt-no2-166)[[163]](#cite_note-167) Under instructions from the campaign, Biden kept his speeches succinct and tried to avoid offhand remarks.[[164]](#cite_note-168)[[165]](#cite_note-169) Privately, Biden's remarks frustrated Obama. "How many times is Biden gonna say something stupid?", he once angrily asked.[[154]](#cite_note-gamechange-158): 411–414, 419 Obama campaign staffers called Biden's blunders "Joe bombs" and kept Biden uninformed about strategy discussions, which irked Biden.[[166]](#cite_note-nyt0508122-170) Relations between the two campaigns became strained for a month, until Biden apologized to Obama and the two built a stronger partnership.[[154]](#cite_note-gamechange-158): 411–414

As the [2008 financial crisis](/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis") reached a peak in September 2008, and the proposed [Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008](/wiki/Emergency_Economic_Stabilization_Act_of_2008 "Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008") became a major factor in the campaign, Biden voted for the $700 billion [Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008](/wiki/Emergency_Economic_Stabilization_Act_of_2008 "Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008"), which passed in the Senate.[[167]](#cite_note-171) On October 2, he participated in the [vice-presidential debate](/wiki/2008_United_States_presidential_debates "2008 United States presidential debates") with Palin at [Washington University in St. Louis](/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis "Washington University in St. Louis"). Post-debate polls found that while Palin exceeded many voters' expectations, Biden had still won the debate overall.[[168]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitcover2010655–661-172) On November 4, Obama and Biden [were elected](/wiki/2008_United_States_presidential_election "2008 United States presidential election").[[169]](#cite_note-173)[[170]](#cite_note-174)[[171]](#cite_note-175)

As Biden was running for vice president, he was also running for reelection to the Senate,[[172]](#cite_note-176) as permitted by Delaware law.[[68]](#cite_note-aap08-366-71) Having been [reelected](/wiki/2008_United_States_Senate_election_in_Delaware "2008 United States Senate election in Delaware") to the Senate as well as the vice presidency,[[173]](#cite_note-177) Biden made a point of not resigning from the Senate before he was sworn in for his seventh term in January 2009.[[174]](#cite_note-178) He [resigned from the Senate](/wiki/Resignation_from_the_United_States_Senate "Resignation from the United States Senate") on January 15.[[175]](#cite_note-179)[[176]](#cite_note-180)

### 2012 campaign

Main article: [Barack Obama 2012 presidential campaign](/wiki/Barack_Obama_2012_presidential_campaign "Barack Obama 2012 presidential campaign")

In October 2010, Biden said Obama had asked him to remain as his running mate for the [2012 presidential election](/wiki/2012_United_States_presidential_election "2012 United States presidential election"),[[177]](#cite_note-nyt1013102-181) but with Obama's popularity declining, [White House Chief of Staff](/wiki/White_House_Chief_of_Staff "White House Chief of Staff") [William M. Daley](/wiki/William_M._Daley "William M. Daley") conducted some secret polling and focus group research in late 2011 on the idea of replacing Biden with Hillary Clinton.[[178]](#cite_note-nyt-dd-replace-182) The notion was dropped when the results showed no appreciable improvement,[[178]](#cite_note-nyt-dd-replace-182) and White House officials later said Obama himself never entertained the idea.[[179]](#cite_note-183)

Biden's May 2012 statement that he was "absolutely comfortable" with [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage") gained considerable public attention in comparison to Obama's position, which had been described as "evolving".[[180]](#cite_note-184) Biden made his statement without administration consent, and Obama and his aides were irked, since Obama had planned to shift position in the build-up to the party convention.[[166]](#cite_note-nyt0508122-170)[[181]](#cite_note-ap051012-185)[[182]](#cite_note-186) Gay rights advocates seized upon Biden's statement,[[181]](#cite_note-ap051012-185) and within days, Obama announced that he too supported same-sex marriage, an action in part forced by Biden's remarks.[[183]](#cite_note-187)

Biden had a heavy schedule of appearances in swing states as the reelection campaign began in earnest in spring 2012.[[184]](#cite_note-time-be-joe-188)[[185]](#cite_note-time-mo-189) An August 2012 remark before a mixed-race audience that Republican proposals to relax Wall Street regulations would "put y'all back in chains" again drew attention to Biden's propensity for colorful remarks.[[184]](#cite_note-time-be-joe-188)[[186]](#cite_note-190)[[187]](#cite_note-191)

Following the first presidential debate of the general election, in which Obama's performance was considered surprisingly lackluster,[[188]](#cite_note-192) his lead over Romney collapsed,[[189]](#cite_note-193) putting pressure on Biden to stop the bleeding with a strong showing against the Republican vice-presidential nominee, [Paul Ryan](/wiki/Paul_Ryan "Paul Ryan").[[190]](#cite_note-194)[[191]](#cite_note-195) Some political analysts considered Biden's performance in the October 11 vice-presidential debate one of the best of his career[[192]](#cite_note-196)[[193]](#cite_note-197) and a key factor in Obama's rebound in the polls and eventual victory.[[194]](#cite_note-198)[[195]](#cite_note-199) The debate also became memorable for the popularization of Biden's use of the phrase "a bunch of malarkey" in response to an attack by Ryan on the administration's response to the [attacks on the U.S. embassy in Benghazi](/wiki/2012_Benghazi_attack "2012 Benghazi attack") in September.[[196]](#cite_note-200)[[197]](#cite_note-201) Biden reused the phrase during his 2020 presidential campaign.[[198]](#cite_note-202) On November 6, Obama and Biden were reelected.[[199]](#cite_note-203)

## Vice presidency (2009–2017)

Main article: [Vice presidency of Joe Biden](/wiki/Vice_presidency_of_Joe_Biden "Vice presidency of Joe Biden")

See also: [Presidency of Barack Obama](/wiki/Presidency_of_Barack_Obama "Presidency of Barack Obama")

### First term (2009–2013)

See also: [First inauguration of Barack Obama](/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama "First inauguration of Barack Obama")

Biden said he intended to eliminate some explicit roles assumed by [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush")'s vice president, [Dick Cheney](/wiki/Dick_Cheney "Dick Cheney"), and did not intend to emulate any previous vice presidency.[[200]](#cite_note-204) He was sworn in on January 20, 2009.[[201]](#cite_note-205) He was the first vice president from [Delaware](/wiki/Delaware "Delaware")[[202]](#cite_note-206) and the first [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") vice president.[[203]](#cite_note-207)[[204]](#cite_note-208) Members of the Obama administration said Biden's role in the White House was to be a contrarian and force others to defend their positions.[[205]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2-209) White House chief of staff [Rahm Emanuel](/wiki/Rahm_Emanuel "Rahm Emanuel") said Biden helped counter [groupthink](/wiki/Groupthink "Groupthink").[[206]](#cite_note-nyt032809-210) The Bidens maintained a relaxed atmosphere at their [official residence](/wiki/Number_One_Observatory_Circle "Number One Observatory Circle") in Washington, often entertaining their grandchildren, and regularly returned to their home in Delaware.[[207]](#cite_note-211)

Biden oversaw [infrastructure spending from the Obama stimulus package](/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009#Infrastructure_investment "American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009") intended to help counteract the [ongoing recession](/wiki/Late-2000s_recession "Late-2000s recession").[[208]](#cite_note-212) Confronted with rising unemployment through July 2009, Biden acknowledged that the administration had "misread how bad the economy was", but maintained confidence the stimulus package would create many more jobs once the pace of expenditures picked up.[[209]](#cite_note-213) When he completed that role in February 2011, he said the number of fraud incidents with stimulus monies had been less than one percent.[[210]](#cite_note-214)

Biden's off-message response to a question in April 2009, during the beginning of the [swine flu outbreak](/wiki/2009_flu_pandemic "2009 flu pandemic"), led to a swift retraction by the White House.[[211]](#cite_note-215) The remark revived Biden's reputation for [gaffes](/wiki/Political_gaffe "Political gaffe").[[212]](#cite_note-216)[[213]](#cite_note-nw-cov-1010092-217)[[214]](#cite_note-218) A [hot mic](/wiki/Hot_mic "Hot mic") picked up Biden telling Obama that his signing the [Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act") was "a big fucking deal" on March 23, 2010.[[215]](#cite_note-219) Despite their different personalities, Obama and Biden formed a friendship, partly based around Obama's daughter Sasha and Biden's granddaughter Maisy, who attended [Sidwell Friends School](/wiki/Sidwell_Friends_School "Sidwell Friends School") together.[[166]](#cite_note-nyt0508122-170)

Biden visited [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") in May 2009 and affirmed the U.S. position that its "independence is irreversible".[[216]](#cite_note-220) He lost an internal debate to Secretary of State [Hillary Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton") about [sending 21,000 new troops to Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)"),[[217]](#cite_note-221)[[218]](#cite_note-222) but his skepticism was valued,[[219]](#cite_note-pol091609-223) and his views gained more influence as Obama reconsidered his Afghanistan strategy.[[213]](#cite_note-nw-cov-1010092-217) Obama delegated Biden to oversee Iraq policy, and he became the administration's point man in delivering messages to Iraqi leadership before the exit of U.S. troops in 2011.[[e]](#cite_note-226)

Biden campaigned heavily for Democrats in the [2010 midterm elections](/wiki/United_States_elections,_2010 "United States elections, 2010"), maintaining an attitude of optimism in the face of predictions of large-scale losses for the party.[[177]](#cite_note-nyt1013102-181) After big Republican gains in the elections and Emanuel's departure, Biden's past relationships with Republicans in Congress became more important.[[222]](#cite_note-pol1209102-227)[[223]](#cite_note-nyt1211102-228) He led the successful administration effort to gain Senate approval for the [New START treaty](/wiki/New_START_treaty "New START treaty").[[222]](#cite_note-pol1209102-227)[[223]](#cite_note-nyt1211102-228) In December 2010, Biden's advocacy for a middle ground, followed by his negotiations with Senate minority leader [Mitch McConnell](/wiki/Mitch_McConnell "Mitch McConnell"), were instrumental in producing the administration's compromise tax package that included a temporary [extension of the Bush tax cuts](/wiki/Extension_of_the_Bush_tax_cuts "Extension of the Bush tax cuts").[[223]](#cite_note-nyt1211102-228)[[224]](#cite_note-229) The package passed as the [Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010](/wiki/Tax_Relief,_Unemployment_Insurance_Reauthorization,_and_Job_Creation_Act_of_2010 "Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010").

Obama delegated Biden to lead negotiations with Congress during the [2011 U.S. debt ceiling crisis](/wiki/United_States_debt-ceiling_crisis_of_2011 "United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011").[[225]](#cite_note-230) Biden's relationship with McConnell brought about the [Budget Control Act of 2011](/wiki/Budget_Control_Act_of_2011 "Budget Control Act of 2011") that solved the crisis.[[226]](#cite_note-231)[[227]](#cite_note-232)[[228]](#cite_note-233) Some reports suggest that Biden opposed proceeding with the May 2011 [U.S. mission to kill Osama bin Laden](/wiki/U.S._mission_to_kill_Osama_bin_Laden "U.S. mission to kill Osama bin Laden"),[[185]](#cite_note-time-mo-189)[[229]](#cite_note-234) lest failure adversely affect Obama's reelection prospects.[[230]](#cite_note-235)[[231]](#cite_note-236) In 2012, Biden made the case for Obama's reelection: "Osama bin Laden is dead and General Motors is alive."[[232]](#cite_note-237)

Obama named Biden to head the [Gun Violence Task Force](/wiki/Gun_Violence_Task_Force "Gun Violence Task Force"), created to address the causes of [school shootings](/wiki/School_shooting "School shooting") and consider possible [gun control](/wiki/Gun_control "Gun control") measures in the aftermath of the [Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting](/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting "Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting"), in December 2012.[[233]](#cite_note-238) Later that month, during the final days before the United States fell off the "[fiscal cliff](/wiki/United_States_fiscal_cliff "United States fiscal cliff")", Biden's relationship with McConnell again proved important as the two negotiated a deal that led to the [American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012](/wiki/American_Taxpayer_Relief_Act_of_2012 "American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012") being passed at the start of 2013.[[234]](#cite_note-239)[[235]](#cite_note-ap-cliff-240)

### Second term (2013–2017)

See also: [Second inauguration of Barack Obama](/wiki/Second_inauguration_of_Barack_Obama "Second inauguration of Barack Obama")

Biden was inaugurated to a second term on January 20, 2013, at a small ceremony at [Number One Observatory Circle](/wiki/Number_One_Observatory_Circle "Number One Observatory Circle"), his official residence, with Justice [Sonia Sotomayor](/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor "Sonia Sotomayor") presiding (a public ceremony took place on January 21).[[236]](#cite_note-241) He played little part in discussions that led to the October 2013 passage of the [Continuing Appropriations Act, 2014](/wiki/Continuing_Appropriations_Act,_2014 "Continuing Appropriations Act, 2014"), which resolved the [federal government shutdown of 2013](/wiki/2013_United_States_federal_government_shutdown "2013 United States federal government shutdown") and the [debt-ceiling crisis of 2013](/wiki/United_States_debt-ceiling_crisis_of_2013 "United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2013"). Senate Majority Leader [Harry Reid](/wiki/Harry_Reid "Harry Reid") and other Democratic leaders cut him out of direct talks with Congress, feeling Biden had given too much away during previous negotiations.[[237]](#cite_note-242)[[238]](#cite_note-243)[[239]](#cite_note-244)

Biden's Violence Against Women Act was reauthorized again in 2013.
