The act led to related developments, such as the [White House Council on Women and Girls](/wiki/White_House_Council_on_Women_and_Girls "White House Council on Women and Girls"), begun in the first term, as well as the [White House Task Force to Protect Students from Sexual Assault](/wiki/White_House_Task_Force_to_Protect_Students_from_Sexual_Assault "White House Task Force to Protect Students from Sexual Assault"), begun in January 2014 with Biden and [Valerie Jarrett](/wiki/Valerie_Jarrett "Valerie Jarrett") as co-chairs.[[240]](#cite_note-245)[[241]](#cite_note-246) He talked about sexual violence while introducing [Lady Gaga](/wiki/Lady_Gaga "Lady Gaga") at the [88th Academy Awards](/wiki/88th_Academy_Awards "88th Academy Awards") in 2016, receiving a [standing ovation](/wiki/Standing_ovation "Standing ovation") from the audience.[[242]](#cite_note-247)

Biden favored arming [Syria's rebel fighters](/wiki/Timber_Sycamore "Timber Sycamore").[[243]](#cite_note-248) As the [ISIL](/wiki/ISIL "ISIL") [insurgency in Iraq](/wiki/War_in_Iraq_(2013%E2%80%932017) "War in Iraq (2013–2017)") intensified in 2014, renewed attention was paid to the Biden-Gelb Iraqi federalization plan of 2006, with some observers suggesting Biden had been right all along.[[244]](#cite_note-249)[[245]](#cite_note-250) He had close relationships with several Latin American leaders and visited the region 16 times during his vice presidency, the most of any president or vice president.[[246]](#cite_note-251) In August 2016, Biden visited [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), where he met with the Serbian Prime Minister [Aleksandar Vučić](/wiki/Aleksandar_Vu%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Aleksandar Vučić") and expressed condolences for civilian victims of the bombing campaign during the Kosovo War.[[247]](#cite_note-252) Biden never [cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate](/wiki/List_of_tie-breaking_votes_cast_by_vice_presidents_of_the_United_States "List of tie-breaking votes cast by vice presidents of the United States"), making him the longest-serving vice president with this distinction.[[248]](#cite_note-253)

During his second term, Biden was often said to be preparing for a bid for the [2016 Democratic presidential nomination](/wiki/2016_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2016 Democratic Party presidential primaries").[[249]](#cite_note-Itkowitz1-254) With his family, friends, and donors encouraging him in mid-2015 to enter the race, and with [Hillary Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton")'s favorability ratings in decline at that time, Biden was reported to be seriously considering the prospect and a "[Draft](/wiki/Draft_(politics) "Draft (politics)") Biden 2016" [Political action committee](/wiki/Political_action_committee "Political action committee") (PAC) was established.[[249]](#cite_note-Itkowitz1-254)[[250]](#cite_note-255)[[251]](#cite_note-256) During 2015, Biden was uncertain about running, particularly due to the recent death of his son Beau,[[252]](#cite_note-257) before announcing his decision not to run that October.[[253]](#cite_note-258)[[254]](#cite_note-259)[[255]](#cite_note-260)

## Post-vice presidency (2017–2021)

Biden left office on January 20, 2017, and was succeeded by the 48th [vice president of the United States](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the United States"), [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence"). After leaving the vice presidency, Biden became an honorary professor at the [University of Pennsylvania](/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania "University of Pennsylvania"), developing the [Penn Biden Center for Diplomacy and Global Engagement](/wiki/Penn_Biden_Center_for_Diplomacy_and_Global_Engagement "Penn Biden Center for Diplomacy and Global Engagement"). Biden remained in that position until 2019.[[256]](#cite_note-261)[[257]](#cite_note-262)

In 2017, Biden wrote a memoir, *[Promise Me, Dad](/wiki/Promise_Me,_Dad "Promise Me, Dad")*, and went on a book tour.[[258]](#cite_note-263) By 2019, he and his wife reported that they had earned over $15 million since the end of his vice presidency from speaking engagements and book sales.[[259]](#cite_note-264)

Biden remained in the public eye, endorsing candidates while continuing to comment on politics, climate change, and the [presidency of Donald Trump](/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump "First presidency of Donald Trump").[[260]](#cite_note-265)[[261]](#cite_note-foreign-policy2-266)[[262]](#cite_note-267) He also continued to speak out in favor of LGBT rights, continuing advocacy on an issue he had become more closely associated with during his vice presidency.[[263]](#cite_note-268)[[264]](#cite_note-269) In 2018, he gave a eulogy for Senator [John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John McCain").[[265]](#cite_note-270) Biden continued to support [cancer research](/wiki/Cancer_research "Cancer research").[[266]](#cite_note-271)

## 2020 presidential campaign

Main article: [Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign](/wiki/Joe_Biden_2020_presidential_campaign "Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign")

### Speculation and announcement

Between 2016 and 2019, media outlets often mentioned Biden as a likely candidate for [president in 2020](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election").[[267]](#cite_note-272) When asked if he would run, he gave varied and ambivalent answers, saying "never say never".[[268]](#cite_note-273) A [political action committee](/wiki/Political_action_committee "Political action committee") known as [Time for Biden](/wiki/Time_for_Biden "Time for Biden") was formed in January 2018.[[269]](#cite_note-274) Biden launched his campaign on April 25, 2019,[[270]](#cite_note-275) saying he was worried by the [Trump administration](/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump "First presidency of Donald Trump") and felt a "sense of duty".[[271]](#cite_note-276)

### Campaign

Further information: [2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries](/wiki/2020_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries") and [2020 United States presidential debates](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_debates "2020 United States presidential debates")

Public polling showed Biden as one of the best-performing Democratic candidates head-to-head against Trump.[[272]](#cite_note-277)[[273]](#cite_note-278)[[274]](#cite_note-279) With Democrats keenly focused on "electability" for defeating Trump,[[275]](#cite_note-280) this boosted his popularity among Democratic voters.[[276]](#cite_note-281) It also made Biden a frequent target of Trump.[[277]](#cite_note-282)[[278]](#cite_note-283) In September 2019, it was reported that Trump had pressured Ukrainian president [Volodymyr Zelenskyy](/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelenskyy "Volodymyr Zelenskyy") to investigate [alleged wrongdoing](/wiki/Biden%E2%80%93Ukraine_conspiracy_theory "Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory") by Biden and his son [Hunter Biden](/wiki/Hunter_Biden "Hunter Biden").[[279]](#cite_note-284) No evidence was produced of any wrongdoing by the Bidens.[[280]](#cite_note-285)[[281]](#cite_note-286)[[282]](#cite_note-287) Trump was perceived by many as attempting to hurt Biden's chances of winning the presidency,[[283]](#cite_note-288) resulting in [a political scandal](/wiki/Trump%E2%80%93Ukraine_scandal "Trump–Ukraine scandal")[[284]](#cite_note-289) and [Trump's impeachment](/wiki/First_impeachment_of_Donald_Trump "First impeachment of Donald Trump").[[285]](#cite_note-290)

In March 2019 and April 2019, eight women accused Biden of inappropriate physical contact, such as embracing, touching or kissing.[[286]](#cite_note-291) Biden had previously called himself a "tactile politician" and admitted this behavior had caused trouble for him.[[287]](#cite_note-292) Journalist [Mark Bowden](/wiki/Mark_Bowden "Mark Bowden") described Biden's lifelong habit of talking close, writing that he "doesn't just meet you, he engulfs you... scooting closer" and leaning forward to talk.[[288]](#cite_note-The_Atlantic-293) In April 2019, Biden pledged to be more "respectful of people's personal space".[[289]](#cite_note-294)

Throughout 2019, Biden stayed generally ahead of other Democrats in national polls.[[290]](#cite_note-295)[[291]](#cite_note-296) Despite this, he finished fourth in the [Iowa caucuses](/wiki/2020_Iowa_caucuses "2020 Iowa caucuses") and fifth in the [New Hampshire primary](/wiki/New_Hampshire_presidential_primary "New Hampshire presidential primary").[[292]](#cite_note-297)[[293]](#cite_note-298) He performed better in the [Nevada caucuses](/wiki/Nevada_presidential_caucuses "Nevada presidential caucuses"), reaching the 15% required for delegates, but still finished 21.6 percentage points behind [Bernie Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders_2020_presidential_campaign "Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign").[[294]](#cite_note-299) Making strong appeals to Black voters on the campaign trail and in the South Carolina debate, Biden won the [South Carolina primary](/wiki/2020_South_Carolina_Democratic_primary "2020 South Carolina Democratic primary") by more than 28 points.[[295]](#cite_note-300) After the withdrawals and subsequent endorsements of candidates [Pete Buttigieg](/wiki/Pete_Buttigieg "Pete Buttigieg") and [Amy Klobuchar](/wiki/Amy_Klobuchar "Amy Klobuchar"), he made large gains in the [Super Tuesday](/wiki/Super_Tuesday "Super Tuesday") primaries. Biden won [18 of the next 26 contests](/wiki/Results_of_the_2020_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "Results of the 2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries"), putting him in the lead.[[296]](#cite_note-301) [Elizabeth Warren](/wiki/Elizabeth_Warren "Elizabeth Warren") and [Michael Bloomberg](/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg "Michael Bloomberg") soon dropped out, and Biden expanded his lead with victories over Sanders in four states on March 10.[[297]](#cite_note-302) In March 2019, Biden said, "I view myself as a bridge, not as anything else. There's an entire generation of leaders you saw stand behind me. They are the future of this country."[[298]](#cite_note-303)

In late March 2020, Tara Reade, one of the eight women who in 2019 had accused Biden of inappropriate physical contact, [accused](/wiki/Joe_Biden_sexual_assault_allegation "Joe Biden sexual assault allegation") Biden of having sexually assaulted her in 1993.[[299]](#cite_note-nytimesallegations-304) There were inconsistencies between Reade's 2019 and 2020 allegations.[[299]](#cite_note-nytimesallegations-304)[[300]](#cite_note-305) Biden and his campaign denied the sexual assault allegation.[[301]](#cite_note-306)[[302]](#cite_note-307)

When Sanders suspended his campaign on April 8, 2020, Biden became the Democratic Party's [presumptive nominee](/wiki/Presumptive_nominee "Presumptive nominee").[[303]](#cite_note-308) On April 13, Sanders endorsed Biden.[[304]](#cite_note-309) [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") endorsed Biden the next day.[[305]](#cite_note-310) There was a great deal of interest in who his running mate would be, in part because of "the expectation, downplayed but not exactly denied by the Biden campaign, that the 77-year-old would be a one-term president".[[306]](#cite_note-NYT-311) Biden said, "I view myself as a transition candidate."[[306]](#cite_note-NYT-311) On August 11, Biden announced [Kamala Harris](/wiki/Kamala_Harris "Kamala Harris") as his running mate, making her the first African American and first [South Asian American](/wiki/South_Asian_American "South Asian American") vice-presidential nominee on a major-party ticket.[[307]](#cite_note-312) On August 18, at the [2020 Democratic National Convention](/wiki/2020_Democratic_National_Convention "2020 Democratic National Convention"), Biden officially became the Democratic Party nominee for president in the [2020 election](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election").[[308]](#cite_note-313)[[309]](#cite_note-314)

### Presidential election and transition

Main articles: [2020 United States presidential election](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election") and [Presidential transition of Joe Biden](/wiki/Presidential_transition_of_Joe_Biden "Presidential transition of Joe Biden")

Biden was [elected](/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election") the 46th president in November 2020, defeating the incumbent, [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump").[[310]](#cite_note-315) Trump and numerous other Republicans repeatedly made [false claims](/wiki/False_or_misleading_statements_by_Donald_Trump "False or misleading statements by Donald Trump") that widespread [electoral fraud](/wiki/Electoral_fraud "Electoral fraud") had occurred and that only he had legitimately won the election.[[f]](#cite_note-TrumpMakesClaimsOfElectionFraud-318) Biden's transition was delayed by several weeks as the White House ordered federal agencies not to cooperate.[[313]](#cite_note-319) On November 23, [General Services Administrator](/wiki/General_Services_Administration "General Services Administration") [Emily W. Murphy](/wiki/Emily_W._Murphy "Emily W. Murphy") formally recognized Biden as the apparent winner of the 2020 election and authorized the start of a transition process to the Biden administration.[[314]](#cite_note-320)

Although most resulting lawsuits were either dismissed or ruled against by numerous courts,[[g]](#cite_note-CourtsDismissClaimsOfElectionFraud-327) Trump nonetheless [conspired](/wiki/Criminal_conspiracy "Criminal conspiracy")[[311]](#cite_note-JackSmithReportVol1-316): 33–53 with his [campaign](/wiki/Donald_Trump_2020_presidential_campaign "Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign") team to [submit documents in several states](/wiki/Trump_fake_electors_plot "Trump fake electors plot") (all of which Biden had won) that [falsely claimed](/wiki/Making_false_statements "Making false statements") to be legitimate electoral votes for President Trump and Vice President [Mike Pence](/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence").[[h]](#cite_note-TrumpFakeElectors-331) After the submission of these documents, the Trump campaign intended that the [presiding officer of the United States Senate](/wiki/Presiding_Officer_of_the_United_States_Senate "Presiding Officer of the United States Senate"), either [President of the Senate](/wiki/President_of_the_Senate_of_the_United_States "President of the Senate of the United States") Pence or [President pro tempore](/wiki/President_pro_tempore_of_the_United_States_Senate "President pro tempore of the United States Senate") [Chuck Grassley](/wiki/Chuck_Grassley "Chuck Grassley"), would claim the unilateral power to reject [electors](/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College#Electors "United States Electoral College") during the [January 6, 2021, vote counting session](/wiki/2021_United_States_Electoral_College_vote_count "2021 United States Electoral College vote count"); the presiding officer would reject all electors from the several states for which the Trump campaign had submitted false documents, leaving 232 votes for Trump and 222 votes for Biden, thereby [overturning the election results](/wiki/Attempts_to_overturn_the_2020_United_States_presidential_election "Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election") in Trump's favor.[[i]](#cite_note-UnilateralRejectionOfElectors-338) This plan failed after Pence refused to cooperate with it.[[j]](#cite_note-PenceRefusesToRejectElectors-341) Trump nevertheless urged his supporters on January 6 to march to the [Capitol](/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") while the joint session of Congress was assembled there to count electoral votes and formalize Biden's victory, whereupon [hundreds of people stormed](/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack") the building and interrupted the count. During the attack, Biden addressed the nation, calling the events "an unprecedented assault unlike anything we've seen in modern times".[[332]](#cite_note-342)[[333]](#cite_note-343) After the Capitol was cleared, Congress officially counted the election results, with Pence, in his role as president of the Senate, announcing Biden and Harris as the winners.[[334]](#cite_note-344) On January 7, Trump acknowledged the incoming administration without mentioning Biden's name.[[335]](#cite_note-345)

## Presidency (2021–2025)

Main article: [Presidency of Joe Biden](/wiki/Presidency_of_Joe_Biden "Presidency of Joe Biden")

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Joe Biden presidency](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Joe_Biden_presidency "Timeline of the Joe Biden presidency").

### Inauguration

Main article: [Inauguration of Joe Biden](/wiki/Inauguration_of_Joe_Biden "Inauguration of Joe Biden")

Biden was inaugurated as the 46th president of the United States on January 20, 2021.[[336]](#cite_note-hunnicutt-346)[[337]](#cite_note-347) At 78, he was then the oldest person to assume the office up to that point.[[k]](#cite_note-349)[[336]](#cite_note-hunnicutt-346)[[339]](#cite_note-350) Biden was the second [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic "Catholic") U.S. president, after [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy"),[[340]](#cite_note-351)[[341]](#cite_note-352) and the first president elected from the state of [Delaware](/wiki/Delaware "Delaware").[[342]](#cite_note-353) He was also the first person since [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W. Bush") to have been both vice president and president,[[343]](#cite_note-354) and the only president to date from the [Silent Generation](/wiki/Silent_Generation "Silent Generation").[[344]](#cite_note-355)[[345]](#cite_note-356) Biden's inauguration was "a muted affair unlike any previous inauguration" due to COVID-19 precautions as well as massively increased security measures because of the [January 6 United States Capitol attack](/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack").[[346]](#cite_note-357)

### First 100 days

Main article: [First 100 days of the Biden presidency](/wiki/First_100_days_of_the_Biden_presidency "First 100 days of the Biden presidency")

In his first two days as president, Biden signed 17 executive orders. By his third day, orders had included rejoining the [Paris Climate Agreement](/wiki/Paris_Climate_Agreement "Paris Climate Agreement"), ending the state of national emergency at the [border with Mexico](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border "Mexico–United States border"), directing the government to rejoin the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization"), [face mask requirements](/wiki/100_Days_Masking_Challenge "100 Days Masking Challenge") on [federal property](/wiki/Federal_lands "Federal lands"), measures to combat [hunger in the United States](/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States "Hunger in the United States"),[[l]](#cite_note-362) and revoking permits for the construction of the [Keystone XL pipeline](/wiki/Keystone_XL_pipeline "Keystone XL pipeline").[[351]](#cite_note-363)[[352]](#cite_note-364)[[353]](#cite_note-365)

On March 11, Biden signed into law the [American Rescue Plan Act of 2021](/wiki/American_Rescue_Plan_Act_of_2021 "American Rescue Plan Act of 2021"), a $1.9 trillion [economic stimulus](/wiki/Stimulus_(economics) "Stimulus (economics)") and relief package that he had proposed to support the United States' recovery from the [economic](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") and health effects of the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States").[[354]](#cite_note-366) The package included direct payments to most Americans, an extension of increased unemployment benefits, funds for vaccine distribution and school reopenings, and expansions of health insurance subsidies and the [child tax credit](/wiki/Child_tax_credit_(United_States) "Child tax credit (United States)"). Biden's initial proposal included an increase of the [federal minimum wage](/wiki/Minimum_wage_in_the_United_States "Minimum wage in the United States") to $15 per hour, but after the [Senate parliamentarian](/wiki/Parliamentarian_of_the_United_States_Senate "Parliamentarian of the United States Senate") determined that including the increase in a [budget reconciliation](/wiki/Budget_reconciliation "Budget reconciliation") bill would violate Senate rules, Democrats removed it.[[355]](#cite_note-367)[[356]](#cite_note-368)[[357]](#cite_note-369)

Also in March, amid [a rise in migrants entering the U.S. from Mexico](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border_crisis "Mexico–United States border crisis"), Biden said migrant adults were "being sent back", in reference to the continuation of the Trump administration's Title 42 policy for quick deportations.[[358]](#cite_note-370) He earlier announced that his administration would not deport unaccompanied migrant children; the rise in arrivals of such children exceeded the capacity of facilities meant to shelter them, leading the Biden administration in March to direct the [Federal Emergency Management Agency](/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency "Federal Emergency Management Agency") to help.[[359]](#cite_note-371)

On April 14, Biden announced that the United States [would delay the withdrawal of all troops](/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_U.S._troop_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan "2020–2021 U.S. troop withdrawal from Afghanistan") from the [war in Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)") until September 11, signaling an end to the country's direct military involvement in Afghanistan after nearly 20 years.[[360]](#cite_note-372) In February 2020, the Trump administration had [made a deal](/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Taliban_deal "United States–Taliban deal") with the Taliban to completely withdraw U.S. forces by May 1, 2021.[[361]](#cite_note-images-373) Biden's decision met with a range of reactions, from support and relief to trepidation at the possible collapse of the Afghan government without American support.[[362]](#cite_note-374) On April 22–23, Biden held an [international climate summit](/wiki/2021_Leaders%27_Climate_Summit "2021 Leaders' Climate Summit") at which he announced that the U.S. would cut its [greenhouse gas emissions](/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions "Greenhouse gas emissions") by 50%–52% by 2030 compared to 2005 levels.[[363]](#cite_note-375)[[364]](#cite_note-376) On April 28, the eve of his 100th day in office, Biden delivered his [first address to a joint session of Congress](/wiki/2021_Joe_Biden_speech_to_a_joint_session_of_Congress "2021 Joe Biden speech to a joint session of Congress").[[365]](#cite_note-377)

### Domestic policy

See also: [Social policy of the Biden administration](/wiki/Social_policy_of_the_Biden_administration "Social policy of the Biden administration")

On June 17, Biden signed the [Juneteenth National Independence Day Act](/wiki/Juneteenth_National_Independence_Day_Act "Juneteenth National Independence Day Act"), which officially declared [Juneteenth](/wiki/Juneteenth "Juneteenth") a [federal holiday](/wiki/Federal_holidays_in_the_United_States "Federal holidays in the United States").[[366]](#cite_note-378) In July 2021, amid a slowing of [the COVID-19 vaccination rate in the country](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccination_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 vaccination in the United States") and the spread of the [SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant"), Biden said that it was "gigantically important" for Americans to be vaccinated.[[367]](#cite_note-379)

In 2022, Biden endorsed a change to the [Senate filibuster](/wiki/Filibuster_in_the_United_States_Senate "Filibuster in the United States Senate") to allow for the passing of the [Freedom to Vote Act](/wiki/Freedom_to_Vote_Act "Freedom to Vote Act") and [John Lewis Voting Rights Act](/wiki/John_Lewis_Voting_Rights_Act "John Lewis Voting Rights Act").[[368]](#cite_note-380) The rules change failed when two Democratic senators joined Senate Republicans in opposing it.[[369]](#cite_note-381) In April 2022, Biden signed into law the bipartisan [Postal Service Reform Act of 2022](/wiki/Postal_Service_Reform_Act_of_2022 "Postal Service Reform Act of 2022") to revamp the finances and operations of the [United States Postal Service](/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service") agency.[[370]](#cite_note-382) Biden supported the [Bipartisan Safer Communities Act](/wiki/Bipartisan_Safer_Communities_Act "Bipartisan Safer Communities Act") aimed to address gun reform issues following the [Robb Elementary School shooting](/wiki/Robb_Elementary_School_shooting "Robb Elementary School shooting") in [Uvalde, Texas](/wiki/Uvalde,_Texas "Uvalde, Texas");[[371]](#cite_note-383) he signed the bill on June 25, 2022.[[372]](#cite_note-384)

The [Honoring our PACT Act of 2022](/wiki/Honoring_our_PACT_Act_of_2022 "Honoring our PACT Act of 2022") was introduced in 2021 and signed into law by Biden on August 10, 2022.[[373]](#cite_note-385) The act intended to significantly improve healthcare access and funding for veterans who were exposed to toxic substances, including [burn pits](/wiki/Burn_pits "Burn pits"), during military service.[[374]](#cite_note-386)

In 2022, Biden signed the [Respect for Marriage Act](/wiki/Respect_for_Marriage_Act "Respect for Marriage Act"), which repealed the [Defense of Marriage Act](/wiki/Defense_of_Marriage_Act "Defense of Marriage Act") and requires the federal government to recognize the validity of [same-sex](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_the_United_States "Same-sex marriage in the United States") and [interracial](/wiki/Interracial_marriage_in_the_United_States "Interracial marriage in the United States") marriages.[[375]](#cite_note-387)

In June 2024, Biden issued an executive action offering amnesty to unauthorized immigrants married to American citizens. The program included a pathway to U.S. residency and citizenship and was expected to initially affect about 500,000 people. It was later struck down due to a lack of legislation empowering the president to enact the program.[[376]](#cite_note-388)[[377]](#cite_note-389)

In January 2025, Biden declared the lapsed [Equal Rights Amendment](/wiki/Equal_Rights_Amendment "Equal Rights Amendment") ratified as the "28th Amendment" to the [constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States"). The declaration has no formal effect[[378]](#cite_note-Stokols-390)[[379]](#cite_note-391) and the [National Archives](/wiki/National_Archives_of_the_United_States "National Archives of the United States") has said it does not intend to certify the amendment as part of the constitution due to "established legal, judicial, and procedural decisions".[[380]](#cite_note-392)

#### Economic policy

Main article: [Economic policy of the Biden administration](/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_Biden_administration "Economic policy of the Biden administration")

Biden entered office nine months into a recovery from the [COVID-19 recession](/wiki/COVID-19_recession "COVID-19 recession") and his first year in office was characterized by robust growth in real GDP, employment, wages, and stock market returns, amid [significantly elevated inflation](/wiki/2021%E2%80%932022_inflation_surge "2021–2022 inflation surge"). Real GDP grew 5.9%, the fastest rate in 37 years.[[381]](#cite_note-393)[[382]](#cite_note-394) Amid record job creation, the unemployment rate fell at the fastest pace on record.[[383]](#cite_note-395)[[384]](#cite_note-396)[[385]](#cite_note-397) By the end of 2021, inflation rates measured by the consumer price index (CPI) reached a nearly 40-year high of 7.1%, which was partially offset by the highest nominal wage and salary growth in at least 20 years. The inflation rate peaked at 9% in June 2022.[[m]](#cite_note-403) The inflation rate reached 2.9% and core inflation rate reached 3.2% on an annual basis in December 2024, the last full month of Biden's term. Between December 2020 and December 2024, CPI rose 21.3% overall, with an annualized inflation rate of 5.3% throughout Biden's term in office. The inflation rate remained above the Federal Reserve's 2% target every month since March 2021, resulting in elevated interest rates to combat inflation. Average wages increased 19% throughout Biden's presidency, falling behind inflation. The unemployment rate declined by over 2% and real GDP grew 11% during Biden's term. Total household net worth increased by 28%, largely driven by stocks and real estate. The national debt grew to $36.2 trillion, with a debt to GDP ratio of 123% and a deficit to GDP ratio of 6% in FY 2024.[[391]](#cite_note-404)[[386]](#cite_note-chartingecon-398)[[392]](#cite_note-405) In February 2023, the unemployment rate fell to 3.4%, a 53-year low.[[393]](#cite_note-406)

Amid a surge in [inflation](/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge "2021–2023 inflation surge") and [high gas prices](/wiki/2021%E2%80%93present_global_energy_crisis "2021–present global energy crisis"), Biden's approval ratings declined, with his disapproval rating surpassing his approval rating in early 2022.[[394]](#cite_note-407)[[395]](#cite_note-408)[[396]](#cite_note-409) After 5.9% growth in 2021, real GDP growth cooled in 2022 to 2.1%, after slightly negative growth in the first half spurred recession concerns. Job creation and consumer spending remained strong, as the unemployment rate fell to match a 53-year low of 3.5% in December. Inflation peaked at 9.1% in June before easing to 3.2% by October 2023. Stocks had had their worst year since 2008[[397]](#cite_note-410)[[398]](#cite_note-411)[[399]](#cite_note-412) before recovering. Widespread predictions of an imminent recession did not materialize in 2022 or 2023, and by late 2023 indicators showed sharply lower inflation with economic acceleration. GDP growth hit 4.9% in the third quarter of 2023 and the year ended with stocks near record highs, with robust holiday spending.[[400]](#cite_note-413)[[401]](#cite_note-414)[[402]](#cite_note-415)

Biden signed numerous major pieces of economic legislation in the [117th Congress](/wiki/117th_United_States_Congress "117th United States Congress"), including the [American Rescue Plan](/wiki/American_Rescue_Plan_Act_of_2021 "American Rescue Plan Act of 2021"), [Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act](/wiki/Infrastructure_Investment_and_Jobs_Act "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act"), [CHIPS and Science Act](/wiki/CHIPS_and_Science_Act "CHIPS and Science Act"), and the [Inflation Reduction Act](/wiki/Inflation_Reduction_Act "Inflation Reduction Act").[[403]](#cite_note-416) He signed the CHIPS and Science Act into law on August 9, 2022.[[404]](#cite_note-417) It provided billions of dollars in new funding to boost domestic research on and manufacture of [semiconductors](/wiki/Semiconductors "Semiconductors"), to [compete economically with China](/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations#Economic_relations "China–United States relations").[[405]](#cite_note-418) In his third month in office, Biden also signed an executive order to increase the minimum wage for federal contractors to $15 per hour. The order went into effect for 390,000 workers in January 2022.[[406]](#cite_note-419)[[407]](#cite_note-420) His administration rigorously enforced [antitrust law](/wiki/United_States_antitrust_law "United States antitrust law").

In 2022, Biden blocked a [national railroad strike](/wiki/2022_United_States_railroad_labor_dispute "2022 United States railroad labor dispute") planned by multiple labor unions.[[408]](#cite_note-421) During the [United Auto Workers strike](/wiki/2023_United_Auto_Workers_strike "2023 United Auto Workers strike"), he expressed support for the workers.[[409]](#cite_note-422) Biden joined striking UAW workers' [picket line](/wiki/Picketing "Picketing") in Michigan, becoming the first president to join a picket line.[[410]](#cite_note-423) He refused to block a [port strike](/wiki/2024_United_States_port_strike "2024 United States port strike") from the [International Longshoremen's Association](/wiki/International_Longshoremen%27s_Association "International Longshoremen's Association") in October 2024.[[411]](#cite_note-424)

Over the course of five days in March 2023, [three small- to mid-size U.S. banks failed](/wiki/2023_banking_crisis "2023 banking crisis"), triggering a sharp decline in global bank stock prices and swift response by regulators to prevent potential global [contagion](/wiki/Financial_contagion "Financial contagion"). After [Silicon Valley Bank collapsed](/wiki/Collapse_of_Silicon_Valley_Bank "Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank"), the first to do so, Biden expressed opposition to a bailout by taxpayers.[[412]](#cite_note-425) He claimed that the [partial rollback](/wiki/Economic_Growth,_Regulatory_Relief,_and_Consumer_Protection_Act "Economic Growth, Regulatory Relief, and Consumer Protection Act") of [Dodd-Frank regulations](/wiki/Dodd%E2%80%93Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act "Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act") contributed to the bank's failure.[[413]](#cite_note-426)

At the beginning of the [118th Congress](/wiki/118th_United_States_Congress "118th United States Congress"), Biden and congressional Republicans [engaged in a standoff](/wiki/2023_United_States_debt-ceiling_crisis "2023 United States debt-ceiling crisis") after the U.S. hit its [debt limit](/wiki/United_States_debt_ceiling "United States debt ceiling"), which raised the risk that the U.S. would [default](/wiki/Default_(finance) "Default (finance)") on its debt.[[414]](#cite_note-427) Biden and House speaker [Kevin McCarthy](/wiki/Kevin_McCarthy "Kevin McCarthy") struck a deal to raise the debt limit, the [Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023](/wiki/Fiscal_Responsibility_Act_of_2023 "Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023"), which suspended the debt limit until January 2025. Biden signed it on June 3, averting a default.[[415]](#cite_note-428) The deal was generally seen as favorable to Biden.[[416]](#cite_note-429)[[417]](#cite_note-430)

Biden extended the COVID-19 student loan pause through September 2023, with an "on ramp" period that extended some of the pause's protections against credit reporting, collection efforts, and late payment fees through September 30, 2024.[[418]](#cite_note-431) The Biden administration's attempts to implement student loan forgiveness and relief programs have faced legal challenges from a coalition of Republican-led states.[[419]](#cite_note-432) Biden's plans to forgive student loan debt were estimated to cost over $519 billion,[[420]](#cite_note-433) and some critics called them a "disaster".[[421]](#cite_note-434)

#### Judiciary

Further information: [List of federal judges appointed by Joe Biden](/wiki/List_of_federal_judges_appointed_by_Joe_Biden "List of federal judges appointed by Joe Biden")

By the end of 2021, 40 of his nominees to the federal judiciary had been confirmed, more than any president in his first year in office since [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan").[[422]](#cite_note-435) Biden prioritized diversity in his judicial appointments more than any president in U.S. history, with most of his appointees being women and people of color.[[423]](#cite_note-436)

In January 2022, Supreme Court justice [Stephen Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer") announced his intention to retire. During his 2020 campaign, Biden vowed to nominate the first Black woman to the Supreme Court if a vacancy occurred,[[424]](#cite_note-437) a promise he reiterated after Breyer announced his retirement.[[425]](#cite_note-438) On February 25, [Biden nominated](/wiki/Ketanji_Brown_Jackson_Supreme_Court_nomination "Ketanji Brown Jackson Supreme Court nomination") federal judge [Ketanji Brown Jackson](/wiki/Ketanji_Brown_Jackson "Ketanji Brown Jackson").[[426]](#cite_note-439) She was sworn in on June 30.[[427]](#cite_note-440) By the end of his presidency, Biden had appointed 235 judges, more appointments in a single term than any other president in at least 50 years. 63% of Biden's judges were women and 60% were non-white.[[428]](#cite_note-441)[[429]](#cite_note-442) Biden expressed interest in judicial [term limits](/wiki/Term_limits_in_the_United_States#Federal_term_limits "Term limits in the United States") and a binding ethics code for Supreme Court justices.[[430]](#cite_note-BidenSCOTUSreform-443)

#### Infrastructure and climate

Further information: [Build Back Better Plan](/wiki/Build_Back_Better_Plan "Build Back Better Plan") and [Environmental policy of the Biden administration](/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_Biden_administration "Environmental policy of the Biden administration")

As part of Biden's Build Back Better agenda, in late March 2021, he proposed the [American Jobs Plan](/wiki/American_Jobs_Plan "American Jobs Plan"), a $2 trillion package addressing issues including transport infrastructure, utilities infrastructure, broadband infrastructure, housing, schools, manufacturing, research and workforce development.[[431]](#cite_note-444)[[432]](#cite_note-445) After months of negotiations among Biden and lawmakers, in August 2021 the Senate passed a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill called the [Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act](/wiki/Infrastructure_Investment_and_Jobs_Act "Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act"),[[433]](#cite_note-446)[[434]](#cite_note-447) while the House, also in a bipartisan manner, approved that bill in early November 2021, covering infrastructure related to transport, utilities, and broadband.[[435]](#cite_note-448) Biden signed the bill into law in mid-November 2021.[[436]](#cite_note-449)

The other core part of the Build Back Better agenda was the [Build Back Better Act](/wiki/Build_Back_Better_Act "Build Back Better Act"), a $3.5 trillion social spending bill that expands the [social safety net](/wiki/Social_safety_net "Social safety net") and includes major provisions on climate change.[[437]](#cite_note-450)[[438]](#cite_note-451) Democrats attempted to pass it on a [party-line vote](/wiki/Party-line_vote "Party-line vote") through [budget reconciliation](/wiki/Reconciliation_(United_States_Congress) "Reconciliation (United States Congress)"), but struggled to win the support of Senator [Joe Manchin](/wiki/Joe_Manchin "Joe Manchin"), even as the price was lowered to $2.2 trillion.[[439]](#cite_note-452) After Manchin rejected the bill,[[440]](#cite_note-453) it was comprehensively reworked into the [Inflation Reduction Act of 2022](/wiki/Inflation_Reduction_Act_of_2022 "Inflation Reduction Act of 2022"), covering deficit reduction, climate change, healthcare, and tax reform.[[441]](#cite_note-454)

The [Inflation Reduction Act of 2022](/wiki/Inflation_Reduction_Act_of_2022 "Inflation Reduction Act of 2022") was introduced by Manchin and Senator [Chuck Schumer](/wiki/Chuck_Schumer "Chuck Schumer").[[442]](#cite_note-455)[[443]](#cite_note-456) The package aimed to raise $739 billion and authorize $370 billion in spending on energy and [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change"), $300 billion in deficit reduction, three years of [Affordable Care Act](/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act "Affordable Care Act") subsidies, prescription drug reform to lower prices, and [tax reform](/wiki/Tax_reform "Tax reform").[[444]](#cite_note-457) According to an analysis by the Rhodium Group, the bill will lower [U.S. greenhouse gas emissions](/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States "Climate change in the United States") between 31 percent and 44 percent below 2005 levels by 2030.[[445]](#cite_note-Joan-458) On August 7, 2022, the Senate passed the bill (as amended) on a 51–50 vote, with all Democrats voting in favor, all Republicans opposed, and Vice President [Kamala Harris](/wiki/Kamala_Harris "Kamala Harris") [breaking the tie](/wiki/List_of_tie-breaking_votes_cast_by_the_vice_president_of_the_United_States "List of tie-breaking votes cast by the vice president of the United States"). Biden signed the bill on August 16.[[446]](#cite_note-459)[[447]](#cite_note-460)

Before and during the [2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference](/wiki/2021_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference "2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference") (COP26), Biden promoted an agreement that the U.S. and the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") cut methane emissions by a third by 2030 and tried to add dozens of other countries to the effort.[[448]](#cite_note-461) Biden pledged to double climate funding to developing countries by 2024.[[449]](#cite_note-462) Also at COP26, the U.S. and China reached a deal on greenhouse gas emission reduction. The two countries are responsible for 40 percent of global emissions.[[450]](#cite_note-463) In July 2023, when [heat waves hit the United States](/wiki/2023_Western_North_America_heat_wave "2023 Western North America heat wave"), Biden announced measures to protect the population and said the heat waves were linked to climate change.[[451]](#cite_note-464)[[452]](#cite_note-465) In April 2024, he unveiled a plan to protect and restore natural water sources (3.2 million hectares of [wetlands](/wiki/Wetland "Wetland") and 161,000 km of waterways).[[453]](#cite_note-466)

Biden protected 674 million acres of land and ocean from natural resource exploitation, more than any other president. The vast majority of the conservation came from a ban on offshore drilling in 625 million acres of ocean.[[454]](#cite_note-467)[[455]](#cite_note-468)

#### Immigration

Main article: [Immigration policy of the Biden administration](/wiki/Immigration_policy_of_the_Biden_administration "Immigration policy of the Biden administration")

[Illegal border crossings](/wiki/Illegal_entry "Illegal entry") at the [Mexico–United States border](/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_border "Mexico–United States border") began to surge in 2021 when Biden assumed office,[[n]](#cite_note-473) reaching an all-time monthly high in December 2023.[[460]](#cite_note-474)[[461]](#cite_note-475) Throughout 2024, crossings began to significantly decline from the December record, after Biden implemented restrictions on [asylum](/wiki/Asylum_in_the_United_States "Asylum in the United States") claims from migrants who cross the border between ports of entry and urged Mexico to crack down on migrants.[[462]](#cite_note-cbs-border-crossings-476)[[463]](#cite_note-477)[[464]](#cite_note-478) Deportations from October 2023 to September 2024 reached the highest level since 2014.[[465]](#cite_note-479) Biden used [humanitarian parole](/wiki/Humanitarian_parole "Humanitarian parole") to mitigate illegal border crossings, allowing migrants to fly into the U.S. or schedule their entries through official entry points in the U.S.-Mexico border. Over a million migrants had been admitted to the U.S. under humanitarian parole as of January 2024.[[466]](#cite_note-480)[[467]](#cite_note-481)[[468]](#cite_note-482)

In January 2024, Biden expressed support for a proposed bipartisan immigration deal led by Senators [Kyrsten Sinema](/wiki/Kyrsten_Sinema "Kyrsten Sinema") and [James Lankford](/wiki/James_Lankford "James Lankford"). He had previously supported the [U.S. Citizenship Act of 2021](/wiki/U.S._Citizenship_Act_of_2021 "U.S. Citizenship Act of 2021"), which he proposed on his first day in office.[[469]](#cite_note-483)[[470]](#cite_note-484) The proposed bipartisan bill would have allowed [DHS](/wiki/Department_of_Homeland_Security "Department of Homeland Security") to close the border when encounters reach a seven-day average of 5,000 or exceed 8,500 in a single day.[[471]](#cite_note-485)[[472]](#cite_note-486) In addition, the bill would have mandated the detention of migrants seeking asylum and undergoing asylum interviews, with those failing the process repatriated to their home countries.[[473]](#cite_note-487) While not addressing the status of "[Dreamers](/wiki/Deferred_Action_for_Childhood_Arrivals "Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals")", it would have changed immigration law to allow the children of those with [H-1B visas](/wiki/H-1B_visas "H-1B visas") to get work authorizations and freeze their legal ages while waiting for green cards, rather than face deportation once they turn 21, and provide additional funding for immigration judges.[[474]](#cite_note-488)

Former president Donald Trump announced his opposition to the legislation, calling on Congressional Republicans to oppose it; subsequently, leaders such as [Speaker of the House](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives "Speaker of the United States House of Representatives") [Mike Johnson](/wiki/Mike_Johnson "Mike Johnson") announced their opposition, halting further legislative action.[[475]](#cite_note-489)[[476]](#cite_note-490) As a result of continued high immigration levels throughout his tenure, some lawmakers and pundits have criticized Biden's handling of the southern border.[[477]](#cite_note-491)[[478]](#cite_note-492)[[479]](#cite_note-493) Criticism of the bill and broader immigration policy continued to be expressed by both sides, with some liberals considering his policies too harsh while some conservatives considered them too lax.[[480]](#cite_note-494)[[481]](#cite_note-495) On January 17, 2024, a Republican-led non-binding resolution denouncing the Biden-Harris administration's handling of the U.S. southern border passed the House of Representatives by a vote of 225–187, with 211 Republicans and 14 Democrats supporting it.[[482]](#cite_note-496) In the final year of his presidency, the Biden administration worked to extend at least 14 contracts with private prison companies to run immigrant detention centers, despite his 2020 campaign promise to end the practice.[[483]](#cite_note-497) In June 2024, Biden issued an [executive order](/wiki/A_Proclamation_on_Securing_the_Border "A Proclamation on Securing the Border") allowing the president to restrict the Mexico–U.S. border.[[484]](#cite_note-498)[[462]](#cite_note-cbs-border-crossings-476)

#### Pardons and commutations

Biden issued more individual pardons and commutations than any other president.[[485]](#cite_note-APpardons-499) On October 6, 2022, he pardoned all Americans convicted of "small" amounts of [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_(drug) "Cannabis (drug)") possession under federal law.[[486]](#cite_note-500) On December 22, 2023, he pardoned Americans for cannabis use or possession on federal lands regardless of whether they had been charged or prosecuted.[[487]](#cite_note-501)[[488]](#cite_note-502) On December 12, 2024, in the largest single-day clemency act in history, Biden granted clemency to about 1,500 nonviolent felons in [home confinement](/wiki/Home_confinement "Home confinement") who had previously been released from prison.[[489]](#cite_note-503)[[490]](#cite_note-504) The act generated controversy, as it included felons such as [Michael Conahan](/wiki/Michael_Conahan "Michael Conahan"), a judge involved in the [kids for cash kickback scandal](/wiki/Kids_for_cash "Kids for cash"), and [Rita Crundwell](/wiki/Rita_Crundwell "Rita Crundwell"), a comptroller responsible for the single largest municipal fraud in U.S. history. The Biden administration said the offenders who received clemency "deserve a second chance" and were selected based on meeting certain criteria in a uniform decision.[[491]](#cite_note-505)[[492]](#cite_note-506) On December 23, 2024, Biden commuted the sentences of 37 out of 40 federal [death row](/wiki/Death_row "Death row") inmates.[[493]](#cite_note-507) On his last day in office, Biden commuted the sentence of [Leonard Peltier](/wiki/Leonard_Peltier "Leonard Peltier"), convicted of murdering two FBI agents, to house arrest.[[494]](#cite_note-508)

#### Pardons of family members and political figures

Biden issued more pardons for members of his family than any other president.[[495]](#cite_note-lastpardonnyt-509) On December 1, 2024, he issued a "full and unconditional" pardon to Hunter Biden that covered all federal offenses between 2014 and December 1, 2024. The pardon's sweeping extent was "unprecedented".[[496]](#cite_note-:2-510) According to [*Reason*](/wiki/Reason_(magazine) "Reason (magazine)") magazine, Hunter Biden's pardon was even more far-reaching than [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon")'s or other "controversial"[[496]](#cite_note-:2-510) pardons:

> The Hunter pardon is far more comprehensive...in that it covered not just his convictions for drug-related activities and tax fraud, but *any other criminal behavior* since 2014—the year that Hunter joined the board of Ukrainian energy company Burisma. It has been alleged that Hunter's job was essentially to trade on the family name and sell his access to dad. This may not have been illegal, but it does mean that the pardon is clearly designed to offer preemptive protection not just to Hunter, but to Joe Biden himself. These features make the pardon unprecedented, though perfectly in line with the president's executive powers.

Hunter had been convicted on charges related to tax and gun offenses, after which Joe made numerous promises not to pardon him. He and his staff continued to say that Hunter would not be pardoned as late as November, although internal staff discussions affirmed that the option remained on the table even as Biden said otherwise.[[497]](#cite_note-511)[[498]](#cite_note-512)[[59]](#cite_note-NBCpardon-61) Biden and his family finalized the decision to pardon Hunter without consulting senior staff.[[499]](#cite_note-nytdec2-513) In a statement announcing the pardon, Biden said he believed his son was "selectively, and unfairly, prosecuted", blaming "political pressure" for the collapse of a plea bargain. The plea bargain actually fell apart after the presiding judge asked about its unusual construction.[[62]](#cite_note-White_House_2024-64)[[500]](#cite_note-514)[[501]](#cite_note-515) Biden's pardon came amid incoming December sentencing dates for Hunter for his convictions and concerns about the succeeding Trump administration potentially targeting political rivals for prosecution.[[499]](#cite_note-nytdec2-513) Biden said, "I hope Americans will understand why a father and a president would come to this decision."[[502]](#cite_note-:1-516)

On his last day in office, Biden issued pardons for more of his family members and other high-profile figures.[[495]](#cite_note-lastpardonnyt-509) The pardons covered Biden's siblings and their spouses, including [James Biden](/wiki/James_Biden "James Biden"), who was interviewed as part of an impeachment probe into Biden. Others pardoned that day include former [chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff](/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff") [Mark Milley](/wiki/Mark_Milley "Mark Milley"), former [National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Allergy_and_Infectious_Diseases "National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases") director [Anthony Fauci](/wiki/Anthony_Fauci "Anthony Fauci"), and members and participants in the [House Select Committee on the January 6 Attack](/wiki/House_Select_Committee_on_the_January_6_Attack "House Select Committee on the January 6 Attack"), despite many of those pardoned not having been under criminal investigation.[[495]](#cite_note-lastpardonnyt-509)[[485]](#cite_note-APpardons-499) Biden justified the pardons by citing his concern about "baseless and politically motivated investigations" during Trump's second term.[[503]](#cite_note-517)[[504]](#cite_note-518)[[505]](#cite_note-519) Biden added that the pardons were preemptive and should not be seen as implying their recipients' guilt.[[506]](#cite_note-520)[[507]](#cite_note-521) The pardons Biden granted to his family and other political figures had a sweeping scope similar to the one he granted Hunter, covering federal offenses the recipients committed or may have committed between 2014 and the day of the pardon.[[485]](#cite_note-APpardons-499)[[508]](#cite_note-522)

Biden also pardoned two other Democratic officials on his last day in office: Ernest William Cromartie, convicted of [tax evasion](/wiki/Tax_evasion "Tax evasion"), and [Gerald G. Lundergan](/wiki/Gerald_G._Lundergan "Gerald G. Lundergan"), convicted of a scheme to funnel money to his daughter's Senate campaign.[[509]](#cite_note-523)[[510]](#cite_note-524)[[511]](#cite_note-525)

#### 2022 elections

Main article: [2022 United States elections](/wiki/2022_United_States_elections "2022 United States elections")

On September 2, 2022, in a nationally broadcast [Philadelphia speech](/wiki/Battle_for_the_Soul_of_the_Nation_speech "Battle for the Soul of the Nation speech"), Biden called for a "battle for the soul of the nation". Off camera, he called Trump supporters "semi-fascists", which Republican commentators denounced.[[512]](#cite_note-526)[[513]](#cite_note-527)[[514]](#cite_note-528) A predicted Republican [wave election](/wiki/Wave_elections_in_the_United_States "Wave elections in the United States") did not materialize and the race for [U.S. Congress](/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress") control was much closer than expected, with Republicans securing a slim majority of [222 seats in the House of Representatives](/wiki/2022_United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections "2022 United States House of Representatives elections"),[[o]](#cite_note-533) and the Democratic caucus keeping control of the [U.S. Senate](/wiki/2022_United_States_Senate_elections "2022 United States Senate elections").[[519]](#cite_note-534)[[p]](#cite_note-538)

It was the first midterm election since [1986](/wiki/1986_United_States_gubernatorial_elections "1986 United States gubernatorial elections") in which the incumbent president's party achieved a net gain in governorships, and the first since [1934](/wiki/1934_United_States_elections "1934 United States elections") in which the president's party lost no state legislative chambers.[[523]](#cite_note-539) Democrats credited Biden for their unexpectedly strong performance,[[524]](#cite_note-540) but they likely overperformed for other reasons, including [the Supreme Court overturning *Roe v. Wade*](/wiki/Dobbs_v._Jackson_Women%27s_Health_Organization "Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization") and poor Republican candidate quality in many races.[[525]](#cite_note-541)[[526]](#cite_note-542)

### Foreign policy

Main article: [Foreign policy of the Biden administration](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_Biden_administration "Foreign policy of the Biden administration")

In June 2021, Biden took his first trip abroad as president, visiting Belgium, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. He attended [a G7 summit](/wiki/47th_G7_summit "47th G7 summit"), [a NATO summit](/wiki/2021_Brussels_NATO_summit "2021 Brussels NATO summit"), and an EU summit, and held [one-on-one talks](/wiki/2021_Russia%E2%80%93United_States_summit "2021 Russia–United States summit") with Russian president [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin").[[527]](#cite_note-543)

In September 2021, Biden announced [AUKUS](/wiki/AUKUS "AUKUS"), a [security pact](/wiki/Defense_pact "Defense pact") between Australia, the United Kingdom and the United States, to ensure "peace and stability in the [Indo-Pacific](/wiki/Indo-Pacific "Indo-Pacific")".[[528]](#cite_note-544)

In February 2021, the Biden administration announced that the United States was ending its [support for the Saudi-led bombing campaign](/wiki/U.S._support_for_Saudi-led_operations_in_Yemen "U.S. support for Saudi-led operations in Yemen") in Yemen and revoked the designation of Yemen's [Houthis](/wiki/Houthis "Houthis") as terrorists.[[529]](#cite_note-545)[[530]](#cite_note-546) In early February 2022, Biden ordered the counterterrorism raid in northern Syria that resulted in the [death of Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi](/wiki/Abu_Ibrahim_al-Hashimi_al-Qurashi#Death "Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi"), the second leader of the [Islamic State](/wiki/Islamic_State "Islamic State").[[531]](#cite_note-547) In late July, Biden approved the [drone strike](/wiki/Drone_strike "Drone strike") that [killed Ayman al-Zawahiri](/wiki/Killing_of_Ayman_al-Zawahiri "Killing of Ayman al-Zawahiri"), the second leader of [Al-Qaeda](/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda"), and an integral member in the planning of the [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks").[[532]](#cite_note-548) The [2022 OPEC+ oil production cut](/wiki/OPEC#2022_oil_production_cut "OPEC") caused a diplomatic spat with Saudi Arabia, threatening a longstanding [alliance](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Saudi Arabia–United States relations").[[533]](#cite_note-549)[[534]](#cite_note-550)

In August 2024, Biden negotiated and oversaw the [2024 Ankara prisoner exchange](/wiki/2024_Ankara_prisoner_exchange "2024 Ankara prisoner exchange"), the largest [prisoner exchange](/wiki/Prisoner_exchange "Prisoner exchange") since the end of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"). It involved the release of 26 people, including journalist [Evan Gershkovich](/wiki/Evan_Gershkovich "Evan Gershkovich") and former Marine [Paul Whelan](/wiki/Paul_Whelan "Paul Whelan").[[535]](#cite_note-551) In November 2024, the Biden administration announced that it had helped broker a [ceasefire](/wiki/2024_Israel%E2%80%93Lebanon_ceasefire_agreement "2024 Israel–Lebanon ceasefire agreement") agreement in the [Israel–Hezbollah conflict](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Hezbollah_conflict_(2023%E2%80%932024) "Israel–Hezbollah conflict (2023–2024)").[[q]](#cite_note-556)

#### Withdrawal from Afghanistan

Main article: [2020–2021 U.S. troop withdrawal from Afghanistan](/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_U.S._troop_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan "2020–2021 U.S. troop withdrawal from Afghanistan")

American forces had begun withdrawing from Afghanistan in 2020, under the provisions of a [February 2020 US-Taliban agreement](/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Taliban_deal "United States–Taliban deal") that set a May 1, 2021, deadline.[[540]](#cite_note-557) The Taliban began [an offensive](/wiki/2021_Taliban_offensive "2021 Taliban offensive") on May 1.[[541]](#cite_note-558)[[542]](#cite_note-559) By early July, most American troops in Afghanistan had withdrawn.[[361]](#cite_note-images-373) Biden addressed the withdrawal in July, saying, "The likelihood there's going to be the Taliban overrunning everything and owning the whole country is highly unlikely."[[361]](#cite_note-images-373)

On August 15, [the Afghan government collapsed](/wiki/Fall_of_Kabul_(2021) "Fall of Kabul (2021)") under the Taliban offensive, and Afghan President [Ashraf Ghani](/wiki/Ashraf_Ghani "Ashraf Ghani") fled the country.[[361]](#cite_note-images-373)[[543]](#cite_note-messy-560) Biden reacted by ordering 6,000 American troops to assist with evacuating American personnel and Afghan allies.[[544]](#cite_note-561) He faced bipartisan criticism for the manner of the withdrawal,[[545]](#cite_note-562) with the evacuations described as chaotic and botched.[[546]](#cite_note-563)[[547]](#cite_note-564)[[548]](#cite_note-565) On August 16, Biden addressed the "messy" situation, taking responsibility for it, and admitting that the situation "unfolded more quickly than we had anticipated".[[543]](#cite_note-messy-560)[[549]](#cite_note-buck1-566) He defended his decision to withdraw, saying that Americans should not be "dying in a war that Afghan forces are not willing to fight for themselves".[[549]](#cite_note-buck1-566)[[550]](#cite_note-567)

On August 26, a [suicide bombing at the Kabul airport](/wiki/2021_Kabul_airport_attack "2021 Kabul airport attack") killed 13 U.S. service members and 169 Afghans. On August 27, an American drone strike killed two ISIS-K targets, who were "planners and facilitators", according to a U.S. Army general.[[551]](#cite_note-568) The U.S. military completed its withdrawal from Afghanistan on August 30. Biden called the extraction of over 120,000 Americans, Afghans, and other allies "an extraordinary success".[[552]](#cite_note-569) He acknowledged that up to 200 Americans who wanted to leave did not, despite his August 18 pledge to keep troops in Afghanistan until all Americans who wanted to leave had left.[[553]](#cite_note-570)

After the withdrawal, the U.S. continued to send aid to Afghanistan, remaining its biggest aid donor as of August 2024 and spending at least $20.7 billion post-withdrawal. U.S. funding has helped support the Taliban government and stabilize Afghanistan's economy.[[554]](#cite_note-571)[[555]](#cite_note-572) On September 25, 2024, the [United States House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") passed a resolution condemning the Biden administration for the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, with ten Democrats and all Republicans voting in favor.[[556]](#cite_note-573)

#### Russian invasion of Ukraine

Further information: [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine") and [United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/United_States_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

In February 2022, the [Russian Armed Forces](/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces "Russian Armed Forces") under President [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") launched [an invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine"). After warning for several weeks that an attack was imminent, Biden responded by imposing severe [sanctions on Russia](/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "International sanctions during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine") and authorizing over $8 billion in [weapons shipments to Ukraine](/wiki/List_of_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War").[[557]](#cite_note-574)[[558]](#cite_note-575)[[559]](#cite_note-576) On April 29, he asked Congress for $33 billion for Ukraine,[[560]](#cite_note-577)[[561]](#cite_note-578) but lawmakers later increased it to about $40 billion.[[562]](#cite_note-579)[[563]](#cite_note-580)[[564]](#cite_note-581) Biden blamed Putin for the emerging [energy](/wiki/2021%E2%80%93present_global_energy_crisis "2021–present global energy crisis") and [food crises](/wiki/2022_food_crises "2022 food crises").[[565]](#cite_note-582)[[566]](#cite_note-583)[[567]](#cite_note-584)

In 2022, Congress approved about $113 billion in aid to Ukraine.[[568]](#cite_note-585) In October 2023, the Biden administration requested an additional $61.4 billion in aid for Ukraine for the year ahead,[[569]](#cite_note-586) but delays in the passage of further aid by the [House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") inhibited progress, with the additional $61 billion in aid to Ukraine added in April 2024.[[570]](#cite_note-587)[[571]](#cite_note-588)[[572]](#cite_note-589) Actually delivered aid often differed from announced levels and was also often delayed. The [Government Accountability Office](/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office "Government Accountability Office") and [Pentagon Inspector General](/wiki/Department_of_Defense_Office_of_Inspector_General "Department of Defense Office of Inspector General") found that the Biden administration seemed unaware of the pace of weapons deliveries.[[573]](#cite_note-590)

Throughout the conflict, Biden consistently refused Ukrainian requests to allow them to utilize weapons against Russian military targets inside [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"). An exception was granted in May 2024 for targets in the vicinity of [Kharkiv](/wiki/Kharkiv "Kharkiv") for "counter-fire" purposes.[[r]](#cite_note-595) Biden also blocked access for some weapons systems altogether, typically citing fears of escalation, only to permit deliveries for some weapons later on.[[s]](#cite_note-601)

#### China affairs

Further information: [China–United States relations § Biden administration (2021–2025)](/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations#Biden_administration_(2021–2025) "China–United States relations")

The [Solomon Islands-China security pact](/wiki/China%E2%80%93Solomon_Islands_relations "China–Solomon Islands relations") caused alarm in late 2022, as China could build military bases across the South Pacific. Biden sought to strengthen ties with Australia and New Zealand in the wake of the deal.[[583]](#cite_note-602)[[584]](#cite_note-603)[[585]](#cite_note-604) In a September 2022 interview with *[60 Minutes](/wiki/60_Minutes "60 Minutes")*, Biden said that U.S. forces would defend Taiwan in the event of "an unprecedented attack" by the Chinese,[[586]](#cite_note-605) which is in contrast to the long-standing U.S. policy of "[strategic ambiguity](/wiki/Strategic_ambiguity "Strategic ambiguity")" toward China and Taiwan.[[587]](#cite_note-Kine-606)[[588]](#cite_note-607)[[589]](#cite_note-608) The September comments came after three previous comments by Biden that the U.S. would defend Taiwan in the event of a Chinese invasion.[[590]](#cite_note-theories-609) Amid increasing tension with China, Biden's administration has repeatedly walked back his statements and asserted that U.S. policy toward Taiwan has not changed.[[590]](#cite_note-theories-609)[[591]](#cite_note-610)[[587]](#cite_note-Kine-606) In late 2022, Biden issued several executive orders and federal rules designed to slow Chinese technological growth, and maintain U.S. leadership over computing, biotech, and clean energy.[[592]](#cite_note-611)

On February 4, 2023, Biden ordered the United States Air Force to shoot down a [suspected Chinese surveillance balloon](/wiki/2023_Chinese_balloon_incident "2023 Chinese balloon incident") off the coast of [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina").[[593]](#cite_note-612)[[594]](#cite_note-613) The [Chinese government](/wiki/Chinese_government "Chinese government") denied that the balloon was a surveillance device, instead claiming it was a civilian [airship](/wiki/Airship "Airship") that had blown off course.[[595]](#cite_note-614)[[596]](#cite_note-615) Secretary of State [Antony Blinken](/wiki/Antony_Blinken "Antony Blinken") postponed his planned visit to China as the incident further damaged U.S.-China relations.[[597]](#cite_note-616)[[598]](#cite_note-617)[[599]](#cite_note-618) In May 2024, the Biden administration doubled [tariffs](/wiki/Tariff "Tariff") on [solar cells](/wiki/Solar_cell "Solar cell") imported from China and more than tripled tariffs on [lithium-ion electric vehicle batteries](/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery "Lithium-ion battery") imported from China.[[600]](#cite_note-erwgs-619) It also raised tariffs on imports of Chinese steel, aluminum, and medical materials.[[600]](#cite_note-erwgs-619)

In April 2024, Biden signed the [Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act](/wiki/Protecting_Americans_from_Foreign_Adversary_Controlled_Applications_Act "Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act"), which would ban [social networking services](/wiki/Social_networking_service "Social networking service") if they are determined by the president and relevant provisions to be a "foreign adversary controlled application". The act explicitly applies to [ByteDance Ltd.](/wiki/ByteDance "ByteDance") and its subsidiaries, which are based in China. It ceases to be applicable if the application is [divested](/wiki/Divestment "Divestment") and no longer considered to be controlled by a [foreign adversary of the United States](/wiki/United_States_foreign_adversaries#Other_meanings "United States foreign adversaries"). Biden had signed the [No TikTok on Government Devices Act](/wiki/No_TikTok_on_Government_Devices_Act "No TikTok on Government Devices Act") in December 2022, prohibiting the use of TikTok on devices owned by the federal government.[[601]](#cite_note-620)[[602]](#cite_note-621)[[603]](#cite_note-622)

#### Gaza war

Further information: [United States support for Israel in the Gaza war](/wiki/United_States_support_for_Israel_in_the_Gaza_war "United States support for Israel in the Gaza war")

In October 2023, Hamas [launched a surprise attack on Israel](/wiki/October_7_attacks "October 7 attacks") that [devolved into an intensified conflict](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war"), jeopardizing the administration's push to normalize relations [between Israel and Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations "Israel–Saudi Arabia relations").[[604]](#cite_note-623) Biden stated [his unequivocal support for Israel](/wiki/United_States_support_for_Israel_in_the_Gaza_war "United States support for Israel in the Gaza war") and condemned the attack by Hamas, but discouraged Israel from initiating a ground invasion of Gaza.[[605]](#cite_note-624)[[606]](#cite_note-WarWoodward-625) Upon Israel's retaliation against Hamas, Biden deployed aircraft carriers in the region to deter others from joining the war,[[607]](#cite_note-626) and called for an additional $14 billion in military aid to Israel.[[608]](#cite_note-627) He later began pressuring Israel to address the growing [humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip](/wiki/2023_Israeli_blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip "2023 Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip").[[609]](#cite_note-628) Biden rejected calls for a ceasefire but said he supported "humanitarian pauses" to deliver aid to the [Gaza Strip](/wiki/Gaza_Strip "Gaza Strip").[[610]](#cite_note-629) He asked Israel to pause its invasion of Gaza for at least three days to allow for hostage negotiations; Israel agreed to daily four-hour pauses.[[611]](#cite_note-630) He also directed the U.S. military to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid to Palestinians in Gaza.[[612]](#cite_note-631) Biden has said he is a [Zionist](/wiki/Zionist "Zionist").[[613]](#cite_note-632)[[614]](#cite_note-633) He has faced criticism for his unwavering support for Israel. Officials have urged him to take a harder stance against Israel, criticizing his administration's leniency and support despite the Israeli government's contentious offensive, which has led to significant civilian casualties and [humanitarian crises](/wiki/Gaza_humanitarian_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Gaza humanitarian crisis (2023–present)").[[615]](#cite_note-634)[[616]](#cite_note-635)[[617]](#cite_note-636)

Following the [killing of Palestinian civilians receiving food aid](/wiki/Flour_massacre "Flour massacre") on February 29, 2024, Biden said the current level of aid flowing into Gaza was insufficient.[[618]](#cite_note-637) On March 3, the U.S. military began airdropping food aid into Gaza.[[619]](#cite_note-638) Several experts called the U.S. airdrops performative and said they would do little to alleviate the [famine in Gaza](/wiki/Gaza_Strip_famine "Gaza Strip famine").[[620]](#cite_note-639)

Biden continued to support Israel during the course of the war despite significant domestic opposition to American involvement in it and subsequent widespread [protests](/wiki/Gaza_war_protests_in_the_United_States "Gaza war protests in the United States"). A March 2024 Gallup poll found that a strong majority of Americans disapproved of Israeli conduct during the war.[[621]](#cite_note-Gallup_Inc.-640) Beginning in April 2024, widespread [Gaza war protests emerged on university campuses](/wiki/List_of_pro-Palestinian_protests_on_university_campuses_in_the_United_States_in_2024 "List of pro-Palestinian protests on university campuses in the United States in 2024"), denouncing Biden.[[622]](#cite_note-641)

On May 31, 2024, Biden announced his support for an Israeli [ceasefire](/wiki/January_2025_Gaza_war_ceasefire "January 2025 Gaza war ceasefire") proposal, saying that Hamas was "no longer capable" of another large-scale attack.[[623]](#cite_note-642)[[624]](#cite_note-643)[[625]](#cite_note-644) The proposal, which was intended to establish a permanent ceasefire, bring about the release of all hostages, and lead to the reconstruction of the [Gaza Strip](/wiki/Gaza_Strip "Gaza Strip"), was supported by Hamas officials after mediation by [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") and [Qatar](/wiki/Qatar "Qatar").[[626]](#cite_note-645)[[627]](#cite_note-646) The Netanyahu administration responded that Israel's goals regarding "the destruction of Hamas military and governing capabilities" had not changed and that conditions would need to be met before it would agree to a ceasefire.[[628]](#cite_note-647)[[629]](#cite_note-648)[[630]](#cite_note-649) In the first year of the war, it was estimated that the Biden administration had sent Israel at least $17.9 billion in military aid, a record.[[631]](#cite_note-knickmeyer-650) In about the same period, it sent Palestinians $1.2 billion in humanitarian aid.[[632]](#cite_note-ching-voa-651) Biden was reported by journalist [Bob Woodward](/wiki/Bob_Woodward "Bob Woodward") to have clashed throughout the war with Netanyahu regarding his war strategy and lack of a post-war plan for Gaza.[[606]](#cite_note-WarWoodward-625) In the last week of Biden's presidency, Qatari officials announced that Hamas had accepted the ceasefire deal; Biden hailed the deal.[[633]](#cite_note-652)[[634]](#cite_note-653)

#### NATO enlargement

Following the [2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine"), Biden expressed support for expanding [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") to cover [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") and [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland").[[635]](#cite_note-654)[[636]](#cite_note-655) On August 9, 2022, he signed the instruments of ratification stipulating U.S. support for the two countries' entry into NATO.[[637]](#cite_note-656)[[638]](#cite_note-657) [Finnish ascension](/wiki/Finland%E2%80%93NATO_relations "Finland–NATO relations") occurred on April 4, 2023, but opposition by [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") to [Swedish entry](/wiki/Sweden%E2%80%93NATO_relations "Sweden–NATO relations") led to a stalemate.[[639]](#cite_note-658) Biden led diplomatic talks resulting in formal Swedish ascension into NATO on March 7, 2024.[[640]](#cite_note-659)[[641]](#cite_note-660) He has also expressed openness to [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") entry into NATO following the end of the conflict,[[642]](#cite_note-661) supporting an expedited timetable in its ascension and the removal of steps such as the [Membership Action Plan](/wiki/Enlargement_of_NATO#Membership_Action_Plan "Enlargement of NATO") typically required for NATO entry.[[643]](#cite_note-662)[[644]](#cite_note-663)

### Investigations

#### Retention of classified documents

Main article: [Joe Biden classified documents incident](/wiki/Joe_Biden_classified_documents_incident "Joe Biden classified documents incident")

In November 2022, Biden's attorneys found classified documents dating from his vice presidency in a "locked closet" at the [Penn Biden Center](/wiki/Penn_Biden_Center "Penn Biden Center").[[645]](#cite_note-664)[[646]](#cite_note-nytbatch1-665) According to the White House, the documents were reported to the [U.S. National Archives](/wiki/U.S._National_Archives "U.S. National Archives"), which recovered them the next day.[[646]](#cite_note-nytbatch1-665) On November 14, Attorney General [Merrick Garland](/wiki/Merrick_Garland "Merrick Garland") appointed [John R. Lausch Jr.](/wiki/John_R._Lausch_Jr. "John R. Lausch Jr.") to conduct an investigation.[[647]](#cite_note-666)[[648]](#cite_note-667) On December 20, a second batch of classified documents was discovered in the garage of Biden's [Wilmington](/wiki/Wilmington,_Delaware "Wilmington, Delaware") residence.[[649]](#cite_note-668)

On January 12, Garland appointed [Robert K. Hur](/wiki/Robert_K._Hur "Robert K. Hur") as special counsel to investigate "possible unauthorized removal and retention of classified documents or other records".[[650]](#cite_note-669) On January 20, after a 13-hour [consensual search](/wiki/Consent_search "Consent search") by FBI investigators, six more items with classified markings were recovered from Biden's Wilmington residence.[[651]](#cite_note-670) FBI agents searched Biden's home in [Rehoboth Beach](/wiki/Rehoboth_Beach,_Delaware "Rehoboth Beach, Delaware") on February 1 and collected papers from his time as vice president, but did not find any classified information.[[652]](#cite_note-671) On February 8, 2024, Hur announced that no charges would be brought against Biden.[[653]](#cite_note-672)

#### Business activities

Main article: [United States House Oversight Committee investigation into the Biden family](/wiki/United_States_House_Oversight_Committee_investigation_into_the_Biden_family "United States House Oversight Committee investigation into the Biden family")

Further information: [Impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden](/wiki/Impeachment_inquiry_into_Joe_Biden "Impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden")

On January 11, 2023, the [House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") launched [an investigative committee](/wiki/United_States_House_Oversight_Committee_investigation_into_the_Biden_family "United States House Oversight Committee investigation into the Biden family") into the foreign business activities of Biden's son, [Hunter](/wiki/Hunter_Biden "Hunter Biden"), and brother, [James](/wiki/James_Biden "James Biden").[[654]](#cite_note-673) The committee's chair, Representative [James Comer](/wiki/James_Comer "James Comer"), simultaneously investigated alleged corruption related to the [Hunter Biden laptop controversy](/wiki/Hunter_Biden_laptop_controversy "Hunter Biden laptop controversy").[[655]](#cite_note-674)

On September 12, House speaker [Kevin McCarthy](/wiki/Kevin_McCarthy "Kevin McCarthy") initiated a formal impeachment inquiry against Biden, saying that the House investigations "paint a picture of corruption" by Biden and his family.[[t]](#cite_note-679) Congressional investigations, including [by the House Oversight committee](/wiki/United_States_House_Oversight_Committee_investigation_into_the_Biden_family "United States House Oversight Committee investigation into the Biden family"), have discovered no evidence of wrongdoing by Biden as of December 2023.[[u]](#cite_note-684) On December 13, 2023, the [House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives") voted 221–212 to formalize an [impeachment inquiry into Biden](/wiki/Impeachment_inquiry_into_Joe_Biden "Impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden").[[664]](#cite_note-685)[[665]](#cite_note-686)[[666]](#cite_note-687)

In February 2024, [Alexander Smirnov](/wiki/Alexander_Smirnov_(FBI_informant) "Alexander Smirnov (FBI informant)"), a former intelligence [informant](/wiki/Informant "Informant") who was prominent in the bribery allegations against Biden, was charged with [making false statements](/wiki/Making_false_statements "Making false statements").[[667]](#cite_note-688) Smirnov admitted he had publicized a false story given to him by Russian intelligence officials with the goal of damaging Biden's reelection campaign.[[668]](#cite_note-689)[[669]](#cite_note-690)[[670]](#cite_note-691)

### Age and health concerns
