Main article: [Age and health concerns about Joe Biden](/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Joe_Biden "Age and health concerns about Joe Biden")

As of 2025, Biden was the oldest sitting president in U.S. history. His cognitive health was perceived to have declined by Republicans and some media figures,[[671]](#cite_note-692)[[672]](#cite_note-cbsjuly1age-693) and privately by some Democrats. Members of Biden's family and White House staffers insulated Biden from scrutiny of his advanced aging and decline in acuity.[[673]](#cite_note-694)[[674]](#cite_note-wsjagedec-695)[[675]](#cite_note-696)

The media widely covered public concern about Biden's mental acuity after a weak performance in a June 2024 presidential debate,[[672]](#cite_note-cbsjuly1age-693) but gave it limited coverage beforehand, in part due to harsh pushback from White House officials.[[676]](#cite_note-697) Biden initially deemed himself fit to serve two terms as president,[[677]](#cite_note-698) but after the 2024 election said that he may have been too old to serve a second term.[[678]](#cite_note-699)

As part of the [investigation into Biden's handling of classified documents](/wiki/Joe_Biden_classified_documents_incident "Joe Biden classified documents incident"), special counsel [Robert Hur](/wiki/Robert_Hur "Robert Hur") said that Biden did not remember when he was vice president ("if it was 2013—when did I stop being vice president?") or when his son Beau died.[[679]](#cite_note-700) Hur wrote that his memory "appeared to have significant limitations".[[680]](#cite_note-701)

On July 21, 2022, Biden tested positive for [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") with reportedly mild symptoms.[[681]](#cite_note-702)[[682]](#cite_note-AP_News-703) According to the White House, he was treated with [Paxlovid](/wiki/Paxlovid "Paxlovid").[[682]](#cite_note-AP_News-703)[[683]](#cite_note-704) He worked in isolation in the White House for five days[[684]](#cite_note-705) and returned to isolation when he tested positive again on July 30.[[685]](#cite_note-706)[[686]](#cite_note-707) On July 17, 2024, Biden again tested positive for COVID-19.[[687]](#cite_note-708)[[688]](#cite_note-709) In 2023, Biden was asked whether any other Democrats could beat Donald Trump. His response was "Probably 50 of them".[[689]](#cite_note-710)

## 2024 presidential campaign

Main article: [Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign](/wiki/Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign "Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign")

Further information: [2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries](/wiki/2024_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "2024 Democratic Party presidential primaries"), [Abandon Biden](/wiki/Abandon_Biden "Abandon Biden"), [2024 Joe Biden–Donald Trump presidential debate](/wiki/2024_Joe_Biden%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_presidential_debate "2024 Joe Biden–Donald Trump presidential debate"), and [Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election "Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election")

Ending months of speculation,[[690]](#cite_note-711)[[691]](#cite_note-712) on April 25, 2023, Biden confirmed he would run for reelection as president in the [2024 election](/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election "2024 United States presidential election"), with Harris again as his running mate.[[692]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-713) On the day of his announcement, a Gallup poll found that Biden's approval rating was 37 percent, with most of those surveyed saying the economy was their biggest concern.[[693]](#cite_note-pollrui-714) During his campaign, Biden promoted [higher economic growth and recovery](/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_Joe_Biden_administration "Economic policy of the Joe Biden administration").[[694]](#cite_note-715)[[695]](#cite_note-716) He frequently stated his intention to "finish the job" as a political rallying cry.[[692]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-713)[[696]](#cite_note-717)[[697]](#cite_note-718)

[U.S. Representative](/wiki/U.S._Representative "U.S. Representative") [Dean Phillips](/wiki/Dean_Phillips "Dean Phillips") ran against Biden in the 2024 Democratic presidential primaries.[[698]](#cite_note-719) Phillips [campaigned](/wiki/Dean_Phillips_2024_presidential_campaign "Dean Phillips 2024 presidential campaign") as a younger alternative to Biden,[[699]](#cite_note-720) who would be a stronger opponent to Trump in the general election.[[700]](#cite_note-721)[[701]](#cite_note-722) Biden was not on the ballot in the January 23, [New Hampshire primary](/wiki/2024_New_Hampshire_Democratic_presidential_primary "2024 New Hampshire Democratic presidential primary"), but won it in a write-in campaign with 63.8% of the vote.[[702]](#cite_note-723) He had wanted South Carolina to be the first primary, and [won that state on February 3](/wiki/2024_South_Carolina_Democratic_presidential_primary "2024 South Carolina Democratic presidential primary") with 96.2% of the vote.[[703]](#cite_note-724) Biden received 89.3% of the vote in [Nevada](/wiki/2024_Nevada_Democratic_presidential_primary "2024 Nevada Democratic presidential primary") and 81.1% of the vote in [Michigan](/wiki/2024_Michigan_Democratic_presidential_primary "2024 Michigan Democratic presidential primary"). On March 5 ("Super Tuesday"), he won 15 of 16 primaries, netting 80% or more of the vote in 13.[[704]](#cite_note-725)[[705]](#cite_note-726) Biden lost the [American Samoa](/wiki/2024_American_Samoa_Democratic_presidential_caucuses "2024 American Samoa Democratic presidential caucuses") contest to venture capitalist [Jason Palmer](/wiki/Jason_Palmer_(politician) "Jason Palmer (politician)"), becoming the first incumbent president to lose a contest while appearing on the ballot since [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter") in [1980](/wiki/1980_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries "1980 Democratic Party presidential primaries").[[706]](#cite_note-727) On March 6, Phillips suspended his campaign and endorsed Biden.[[707]](#cite_note-728) On March 12, Biden reached more than the 1,968 delegates needed to win the Democratic nomination, becoming the presumptive nominee.[[708]](#cite_note-729)[[709]](#cite_note-730)[[710]](#cite_note-731)

The [first presidential debate](/wiki/2024_Joe_Biden%E2%80%93Donald_Trump_presidential_debate "2024 Joe Biden–Donald Trump presidential debate") was held on June 27, 2024, between Biden and Trump. Biden's performance was widely criticized, with commentators saying he frequently lost his train of thought and gave meandering answers.[[711]](#cite_note-reuters-biden-debate-732)[[712]](#cite_note-apjune27-733)[[713]](#cite_note-PoliticoJune28Dems-734) Several newspaper columnists declared Trump the winner,[[v]](#cite_note-739) and polling indicated the majority of viewers believed Trump won.[[718]](#cite_note-740) After the debate raised questions about [his health and age](/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_of_Joe_Biden "Age and health concerns of Joe Biden"), Biden faced calls to withdraw from the race, including from [fellow Democrats](/wiki/List_of_Democrats_who_opposed_the_Joe_Biden_2024_presidential_campaign "List of Democrats who opposed the Joe Biden 2024 presidential campaign")[[719]](#cite_note-nbc-biden-step-down-741) and the [editorial boards](/wiki/Editorial_boards "Editorial boards") of several major news outlets.[[720]](#cite_note-:0-742)[[721]](#cite_note-743)

Biden initially insisted that he would remain a candidate,[[722]](#cite_note-744) but on July 21, he withdrew from the race, writing that this was "in the best interest of my party and the country".[[723]](#cite_note-745) He immediately endorsed Harris to replace him as the party's presidential nominee.[[724]](#cite_note-746)[[725]](#cite_note-747) On August 6, 2024, Harris officially became the Democratic presidential nominee.[[726]](#cite_note-748) This was the first time an eligible incumbent had declined to run for reelection since [1968](/wiki/1968_United_States_presidential_election "1968 United States presidential election").[[727]](#cite_note-749)

In the general election, Trump defeated Harris. The Senate [went Republican](/wiki/2024_United_States_Senate_elections "2024 United States Senate elections") for the first time since 2018. In a nationally televised speech after the election, Biden congratulated Trump and promised a "peaceful and orderly" transition of power.[[728]](#cite_note-750) In a January 2025 interview, Biden claimed he could have defeated Trump had he not been persuaded to withdraw from the election, despite lagging behind Trump in polling.[[729]](#cite_note-751)[[730]](#cite_note-752) A [YouGov](/wiki/YouGov "YouGov") poll conducted on November 6–7, 2024, found that if Biden had been the Democratic nominee, Trump would have won the popular vote by 49% to 42%. Trump won the popular vote over Harris by 49.8% to 48.3%.[[731]](#cite_note-753)

## Post-presidency (2025–present)

Biden's term ended on January 20, 2025.[[732]](#cite_note-754) At the end of his presidency, Biden designated former [senior advisors](/wiki/Senior_Advisor_to_the_President_of_the_United_States "Senior Advisor to the President of the United States") [Anthony Bernal](/wiki/Anthony_Bernal "Anthony Bernal") and [Annie Tomasini](/wiki/Annie_Tomasini "Annie Tomasini") to raise funds for the [Joseph R. Biden Jr. Presidential Library](/wiki/Joseph_R._Biden_Jr._Presidential_Library "Joseph R. Biden Jr. Presidential Library").[[733]](#cite_note-755) He later signed with talent agency [Creative Artists Agency](/wiki/Creative_Artists_Agency "Creative Artists Agency") (CAA), which previously represented him from 2017 to 2020.[[734]](#cite_note-756)[[735]](#cite_note-757)

On February 7, President Trump revoked Biden's [security clearance](/wiki/Security_clearance "Security clearance").[[736]](#cite_note-758) Former presidents have traditionally been granted access to intelligence briefings, though such access is at the sitting president's discretion. In 2021, Biden had revoked Trump's security clearance for his role in inciting the [January 6 Capitol attack](/wiki/January_6_Capitol_attack "January 6 Capitol attack").[[737]](#cite_note-759)[[738]](#cite_note-760)

On April 15, Biden made his first major public appearance since leaving office, delivering remarks at an Advocates, Counselors and Representatives for the Disabled (ACRD) conference in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago").[[739]](#cite_note-761) In his address, he criticized the Trump administration's handling of the Social Security Administration.[[740]](#cite_note-762) On May 7, Biden appeared on *[The View](/wiki/The_View "The View")* to defend his presidential legacy.[[741]](#cite_note-763)

On April 26, Biden and his wife attended the state funeral of [Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis") in Vatican City.[[742]](#cite_note-764)

On September 6, Biden announced that his proposed [presidential center](/wiki/Joseph_R._Biden_Jr._Presidential_Library "Joseph R. Biden Jr. Presidential Library") would be in Delaware and that he and his foundation had approved a 13-person governance board.[[743]](#cite_note-765)

On his 83rd birthday, November 20, 2025, Biden and his wife attended former Vice President [Dick Cheney](/wiki/Dick_Cheney "Dick Cheney")'s funeral.[[744]](#cite_note-766)

### Health

On May 18, 2025, Biden's office announced that he had been diagnosed with aggressive [prostate cancer](/wiki/Prostate_cancer "Prostate cancer") with [bone metastasis](/wiki/Bone_metastasis "Bone metastasis") during a routine physical examination.[[745]](#cite_note-767) On May 30, Biden confirmed that he had begun treatment.[[746]](#cite_note-768)

On September 4, Biden's spokesperson confirmed that he had recently undergone [Mohs surgery](/wiki/Mohs_surgery "Mohs surgery") to remove skin cancer lesions from his forehead. The procedure followed a 2023 removal of a [basal-cell carcinoma](/wiki/Basal-cell_carcinoma "Basal-cell carcinoma") from his chest.[[747]](#cite_note-769)

On October 11, Biden's spokesperson confirmed that he was undergoing [radiation](/wiki/Radiation_therapy "Radiation therapy") and [hormone therapies](/wiki/Hormonal_therapy_(oncology) "Hormonal therapy (oncology)") for his prostate cancer.[[748]](#cite_note-770) On October 20, Biden completed a course of radiation therapy at Penn Medicine Radiation Oncology at the [University of Pennsylvania](/wiki/University_of_Pennsylvania "University of Pennsylvania"); it is uncertain whether he will need further treatment.[[749]](#cite_note-bidenhealth-771)[[750]](#cite_note-772)

## Political positions

Main article: [Political positions of Joe Biden](/wiki/Political_positions_of_Joe_Biden "Political positions of Joe Biden")

As a senator, Biden was regarded as a [moderate Democrat](/wiki/Moderate_Democrat "Moderate Democrat").[[751]](#cite_note-773) As a presidential nominee, Biden's platform had been called the most progressive of any major party platform in history, although not within his party's ideological vanguard.[[752]](#cite_note-774) Biden says his positions are deeply influenced by [Catholic social teaching](/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching "Catholic social teaching").[[753]](#cite_note-775)[[754]](#cite_note-776)[[755]](#cite_note-777)

According to political scientist Carlo Invernizzi Accetti, Biden represents an Americanized form of [Christian democracy](/wiki/Christian_democracy "Christian democracy"), taking positions characteristic of both the [center-right](/wiki/Center-right "Center-right") and [center-left](/wiki/Center-left "Center-left").[[756]](#cite_note-Foreign_Policy-778) Biden has cited the Catholic philosopher [Jacques Maritain](/wiki/Jacques_Maritain "Jacques Maritain"), credited with starting the Christian democratic movement, as immensely influential in his thinking.[[757]](#cite_note-779) Other analysts have likened his ideology to traditional [liberalism](/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States "Modern liberalism in the United States"), "a doctrine of liberty, equality, justice and individual rights that relies... on a strong federal government for enforcement".[[758]](#cite_note-Greenberg-780) In 2022, journalist [Sasha Issenberg](/wiki/Sasha_Issenberg "Sasha Issenberg") wrote that Biden's "most valuable political skill" was "an innate compass for the ever-shifting mainstream of the Democratic Party".[[759]](#cite_note-781) Some critics claimed Biden's climate policy was [socialist](/wiki/Socialism "Socialism").[[760]](#cite_note-782)[[761]](#cite_note-783)[[762]](#cite_note-784)

Biden proposed partially reversing the corporate tax cuts of the [Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017](/wiki/Tax_Cuts_and_Jobs_Act_of_2017 "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017").[[763]](#cite_note-785)[[764]](#cite_note-786) He voted for the [North American Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "North American Free Trade Agreement") (NAFTA)[[765]](#cite_note-787) and the [Trans-Pacific Partnership](/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership "Trans-Pacific Partnership").[[766]](#cite_note-788) Biden is a staunch supporter of the [Affordable Care Act](/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act "Affordable Care Act") (ACA).[[767]](#cite_note-ACA203-789)[[768]](#cite_note-790) He promoted a plan to build upon it,[[767]](#cite_note-ACA203-789) aiming to expand [health insurance coverage](/wiki/Health_insurance_coverage_in_the_United_States "Health insurance coverage in the United States") to 97% of Americans, including by creating a [public health insurance option](/wiki/Public_health_insurance_option "Public health insurance option").[[769]](#cite_note-791)

Biden did not support national [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage") rights while in the Senate and voted for the [Defense of Marriage Act](/wiki/Defense_of_Marriage_Act "Defense of Marriage Act"),[[770]](#cite_note-792) but opposed proposals for constitutional amendments that would have banned same-sex marriage nationwide.[[771]](#cite_note-793) Biden has supported same-sex marriage since 2012.[[95]](#cite_note-NYT_Biden_Evolution_on_LGBTQ-98)[[772]](#cite_note-794) As a senator, Biden forged deep relationships with police groups and was a chief proponent of a [Police Officer's Bill of Rights](/wiki/Law_Enforcement_Officers%27_Bill_of_Rights "Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights") measure that police unions supported but police chiefs opposed.[[773]](#cite_note-795)[[774]](#cite_note-796) In 2020, Biden also ran on decriminalizing [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis "Cannabis"),[[775]](#cite_note-797) after advocating harsher penalties for drug use as a senator.[[776]](#cite_note-798)[[777]](#cite_note-799)

Biden believes action must be taken on [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change"). As a senator, he co-sponsored the [Boxer–Sanders Global Warming Pollution Reduction Act](/wiki/Global_Warming_Pollution_Reduction_Act_of_2007 "Global Warming Pollution Reduction Act of 2007"), the most stringent climate bill in the [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate").[[778]](#cite_note-800) Biden supports [nature conservation](/wiki/Nature_conservation "Nature conservation"). According to a report from the [Center for American Progress](/wiki/Center_for_American_Progress "Center for American Progress"), he broke several records in this domain.[[779]](#cite_note-801) He took steps to protect [old-growth forests](/wiki/Old-growth_forest "Old-growth forest").[[780]](#cite_note-802) Biden opposes drilling for oil in the [Arctic National Wildlife Refuge](/wiki/Arctic_National_Wildlife_Refuge "Arctic National Wildlife Refuge").[[781]](#cite_note-803) He wants to achieve a carbon-free power sector in the U.S. by 2035 and stop emissions completely by 2050.[[782]](#cite_note-804) His program included reentering the [Paris Agreement](/wiki/Paris_Agreement "Paris Agreement"), [green building](/wiki/Green_building "Green building") and more.[[783]](#cite_note-805) Biden supports [environmental justice](/wiki/Environmental_justice "Environmental justice"), including [climate justice](/wiki/Climate_justice "Climate justice") and [ocean justice](/wiki/Blue_justice "Blue justice").[[w]](#cite_note-810) Biden called global temperature rise above the 1.5 °C limit the "only existential threat humanity faces even more frightening than a nuclear war".[[788]](#cite_note-811) Despite his clean energy policies and congressional Republicans characterizing them as a "War on American Energy", domestic oil production reached a record high in October 2023.[[789]](#cite_note-812)

Biden has said the U.S. needs to "get tough" on China, calling it the "most serious competitor" that poses challenges to the United States' "prosperity, security, and democratic values".[[790]](#cite_note-813)[[791]](#cite_note-814) Biden has spoken about human rights abuses in the [Xinjiang](/wiki/Xinjiang "Xinjiang") region to Chinese leader [Xi Jinping](/wiki/Xi_Jinping "Xi Jinping"), pledging to sanction and commercially restrict Chinese government officials and entities who carry out repression.[[792]](#cite_note-815)[[793]](#cite_note-816) Biden has said he is against [regime change](/wiki/Regime_change "Regime change") but is for providing non-military support to opposition movements.[[794]](#cite_note-817) He opposed direct U.S. [intervention in Libya](/wiki/2011_military_intervention_in_Libya "2011 military intervention in Libya"),[[795]](#cite_note-818)[[205]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2-209) voted against U.S. participation in the [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"),[[796]](#cite_note-819) voted in favor of the [Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War"),[[797]](#cite_note-820) and supports a [two-state solution](/wiki/Two-state_solution "Two-state solution") in the [Israeli–Palestinian conflict](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict "Israeli–Palestinian conflict").[[798]](#cite_note-821) Biden pledged to end U.S. support for the [Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen](/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen "Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen") and to reevaluate the [United States' relationship](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Saudi Arabia–United States relations") with [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia").[[261]](#cite_note-foreign-policy2-266) Biden supported extending the [New START](/wiki/New_START "New START") arms control treaty with Russia to limit the number of [nuclear weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon") deployed by both sides.[[799]](#cite_note-822)[[800]](#cite_note-823) In 2021, Biden officially [recognized](/wiki/Armenian_genocide_recognition "Armenian genocide recognition") the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide"), becoming the first U.S. president to do so.[[801]](#cite_note-824)[[x]](#cite_note-827)

Biden supported [abortion rights](/wiki/Abortion-rights_movements "Abortion-rights movements") throughout his presidency, though he personally opposes abortion because of his Catholic faith.[[804]](#cite_note-828)[[805]](#cite_note-829) In 2019, he said he supported *[Roe v. Wade](/wiki/Roe_v._Wade "Roe v. Wade")* and repealing the [Hyde Amendment](/wiki/Hyde_Amendment "Hyde Amendment").[[806]](#cite_note-830)[[807]](#cite_note-831) After *[Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization](/wiki/Dobbs_v._Jackson_Women%27s_Health_Organization "Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization")*, he criticized [near-total bans on abortion access](/wiki/Abortion_law_in_the_United_States_by_state "Abortion law in the United States by state") passed in a majority of [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)")-controlled states,[[808]](#cite_note-832) and took measures to protect [abortion rights in the United States](/wiki/Abortion_in_the_United_States "Abortion in the United States").[[809]](#cite_note-833) Biden rejected calls to provide abortion services on [federal land](/wiki/Federal_lands "Federal lands").[[810]](#cite_note-834)[[811]](#cite_note-835) He vowed to sign a bill codifying the protections of *Roe* into federal law; such a bill passed the House in 2022, but was unable to clear the Senate filibuster.[[812]](#cite_note-836)[[813]](#cite_note-837)

## Public image

Main article: [Public image of Joe Biden](/wiki/Public_image_of_Joe_Biden "Public image of Joe Biden")

Biden was consistently ranked one of the least wealthy [members of the Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate"),[[814]](#cite_note-838)[[815]](#cite_note-839) which he attributed to having been elected young.[[816]](#cite_note-840) Feeling that less-wealthy public officials may be tempted to accept contributions in exchange for political favors, he proposed [campaign finance reform](/wiki/Campaign_finance_reform_in_the_United_States "Campaign finance reform in the United States") measures during his first term.[[85]](#cite_note-cby-44-88) While a senator, Biden was viewed as being close to the credit card company [MBNA](/wiki/MBNA "MBNA"), a major contributor to his campaigns since 1989, sometimes being called the "senator from MBNA".[[817]](#cite_note-841) As of November 2009[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Joe_Biden&action=edit), Biden's net worth was $27,012.[[818]](#cite_note-842) By November 2020[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Joe_Biden&action=edit), the Bidens were worth $9 million, largely due to sales of Biden's books and speaking fees after his vice presidency.[[819]](#cite_note-843)[[820]](#cite_note-844)

Political columnist [David S. Broder](/wiki/David_S._Broder "David S. Broder") wrote that Biden has grown over time: "He responds to real people—that's been consistent throughout. And his ability to understand himself and deal with other politicians has gotten much, much better."[[33]](#cite_note-watn020109-35) Journalist [James Traub](/wiki/James_Traub "James Traub") has written that "Biden is the kind of fundamentally happy person who can be as generous toward others as he is to himself".[[126]](#cite_note-nytm-traub-129) Particularly since the 2015 death of his elder son Beau, Biden has been noted for his empathetic nature and ability to communicate about grief.[[821]](#cite_note-845)[[822]](#cite_note-846)

Journalist and TV anchor [Wolf Blitzer](/wiki/Wolf_Blitzer "Wolf Blitzer") has called Biden loquacious;[[823]](#cite_note-847) journalist Mark Bowden has said that he is famous for "talking too much", leaning in close "like an old pal with something urgent to tell you".[[288]](#cite_note-The_Atlantic-293) He often deviates from prepared remarks,[[824]](#cite_note-848) and sometimes "puts his foot in his mouth".[[162]](#cite_note-nyt-no2-166)[[825]](#cite_note-849)[[826]](#cite_note-850) Biden has a reputation for being prone to [gaffes](/wiki/Political_gaffe "Political gaffe").[[827]](#cite_note-851)[[828]](#cite_note-852)[[829]](#cite_note-853) *The New York Times* wrote that Biden's "weak filters make him capable of blurting out pretty much anything".[[162]](#cite_note-nyt-no2-166)

According to *The New York Times*, Biden often embellishes elements of his life or exaggerates, a trait also noted by *[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")* in 2014.[[830]](#cite_note-The_New_Yorker-854)[[831]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-855) For instance, he has claimed to have been more active in the [civil rights movement](/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement") than he actually was, and has falsely recalled being an excellent student who earned three college degrees.[[830]](#cite_note-The_New_Yorker-854) The *Times* wrote, "Mr. Biden's folksiness can veer into folklore, with dates that don't quite add up and details that are exaggerated or wrong, the factual edges shaved off to make them more powerful for audiences."[[831]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-855)

### Job approval

See also: [2021](/wiki/2021_opinion_polling_on_the_Biden_administration "2021 opinion polling on the Biden administration"), [2022](/wiki/2022_opinion_polling_on_the_Biden_administration "2022 opinion polling on the Biden administration"), [2023](/wiki/2023_opinion_polling_on_the_Biden_administration "2023 opinion polling on the Biden administration"), and [2024–2025 opinion polling on the Biden administration](/wiki/2024%E2%80%932025_opinion_polling_on_the_Biden_administration "2024–2025 opinion polling on the Biden administration")

According to [Morning Consult](/wiki/Morning_Consult "Morning Consult") polling, Biden maintained an [approval rating](/wiki/Opinion_poll "Opinion poll") above 50% during his presidency's first eight months. In August 2021, it began to decline, reaching the low forties by December.[[832]](#cite_note-856) This was attributed to the Afghanistan withdrawal, increasing hospitalizations from the [Delta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant"), [high inflation and gas prices](/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge "2021–2023 inflation surge"), disarray within the Democratic Party, and a general decline in popularity customary in politics.[[y]](#cite_note-861) In 2023, Biden's approval rating was the lowest of any modern[[z]](#cite_note-862) U.S. president after three years in office.[[837]](#cite_note-gallup2023end-863)

[Gallup, Inc.](/wiki/Gallup,_Inc. "Gallup, Inc.") found Biden's approval ratings to be consistently above 50% during his first few months in office,[[838]](#cite_note-Gallup_Approval-864)[[839]](#cite_note-865) but by August, his ratings began to decline.[[840]](#cite_note-866) He had a 98% approval rating from Democrats in February 2021, but by December only 78% approved of his presidency.[[841]](#cite_note-BidenGallup-867)[[838]](#cite_note-Gallup_Approval-864) By October 2023, his rating among Democrats had reached a record low of 75%.[[837]](#cite_note-gallup2023end-863)[[842]](#cite_note-868) His approval rating among Republicans has been consistently in the single digits, aside from his first few months in office.[[841]](#cite_note-BidenGallup-867) Additionally, Gallup noted that Biden's public support eroded each year he was in office: he averaged 49% approval in his first year,[[843]](#cite_note-869) 41% in his second,[[844]](#cite_note-870) 40% in his third,[[845]](#cite_note-871) and 39% in his fourth.[[846]](#cite_note-gallup20250117-872) In July 2024, just before he withdrew from the 2024 presidential election, Gallup found his approval rating had fallen to an all-time low of 36%.[[847]](#cite_note-873) Gallup found that Biden had an average approval rating of 42.2% throughout his presidency, which was lower than all other presidents' except Trump's first term, at 41.1%. Biden's final approval rating in January 2025 was 40%, which was low but still higher than several other presidents' final approval ratings.[[846]](#cite_note-gallup20250117-872) Gallup's averaged polls of Biden's presidency found that he was the second-least popular president in its polling history, ahead of Trump.[[846]](#cite_note-gallup20250117-872)

CNN and CBS News found Biden's final approval rating to be 37% and 36%, respectively.[[848]](#cite_note-874)[[849]](#cite_note-875) Polling aggregator [FiveThirtyEight](/wiki/FiveThirtyEight "FiveThirtyEight") found that Biden had a final average approval rating of 37%.[[850]](#cite_note-876)

### Media depictions

See also: [*Saturday Night Live* parodies of Joe Biden](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live_parodies_of_Joe_Biden "Saturday Night Live parodies of Joe Biden")

Nine men have portrayed Biden on *[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night Live")*, starting with [Kevin Nealon](/wiki/Kevin_Nealon "Kevin Nealon") in 1991. [Jason Sudeikis](/wiki/Jason_Sudeikis "Jason Sudeikis") portrayed Biden during the 2008 election season and reprised the role many times. During the 2020 election season, Biden was played by [John Mulaney](/wiki/John_Mulaney "John Mulaney"), [Alex Moffat](/wiki/Alex_Moffat "Alex Moffat"), [Mikey Day](/wiki/Mikey_Day "Mikey Day"), [Woody Harrelson](/wiki/Woody_Harrelson "Woody Harrelson"), and [Jim Carrey](/wiki/Jim_Carrey "Jim Carrey"). In 2024, [Dana Carvey](/wiki/Dana_Carvey "Dana Carvey") played the role.[[851]](#cite_note-877)[[852]](#cite_note-878) In 2016, [Greg Kinnear](/wiki/Greg_Kinnear "Greg Kinnear") portrayed Biden in the [HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO") television film *[Confirmation](/wiki/Confirmation_(film) "Confirmation (film)")*, about the [Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination hearings](/wiki/Clarence_Thomas_Supreme_Court_nomination "Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination").[[853]](#cite_note-879)

Biden appears in episodes of *[Parks and Recreation](/wiki/Parks_and_Recreation "Parks and Recreation")* during his time as vice president.[[854]](#cite_note-880) He appears as himself in a 2016 episode of *[Law & Order: SVU](/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit")*.[[855]](#cite_note-881)

*[The Onion](/wiki/The_Onion "The Onion")* featured a series of articles about a [fictionalized Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden_(The_Onion) "Joe Biden (The Onion)").[[856]](#cite_note-882)[[857]](#cite_note-883)

## Assessments

A December 2024 Gallup poll found that 54% of Americans thought Biden's presidency was below average or poor, 26% average, and 19% above average or outstanding.[[858]](#cite_note-884) Gallup found that Americans largely offered negative assessments of Biden's presidency on economic, national, and international issues. Of 18 issue areas Gallup tracked, a majority of Americans said the U.S. lost ground in six, including the economy in general, immigration, and the country's position in the world. A plurality found that the U.S. declined in six other areas, including national infrastructure and energy, education, and trade relations with other countries. A plurality felt the U.S. made progress in only one indicator under Biden: the conditions of [gay, lesbian, and transgender people](/wiki/LGBTQ_people "LGBTQ people").[[859]](#cite_note-885)

Journalist [Amy Walter](/wiki/Amy_Walter "Amy Walter"), editor of the nonpartisan *[The Cook Political Report](/wiki/The_Cook_Political_Report "The Cook Political Report")*, argued that the public deemed Biden's presidency a failure particularly due to frustration over inflation. Walter said that voters considered inflation the most important element of the economy, more important than the stock market, low unemployment, or household income.[[860]](#cite_note-886) Economists debate the extent to which Biden's policies were responsible for inflation,[[861]](#cite_note-887) but according to Gallup, public perception of the economy in 2024 was worse only in 2008 and 1992, helping Trump win the 2024 presidential election.[[862]](#cite_note-888)

The [Siena College Research Institute](/wiki/Siena_College_Research_Institute "Siena College Research Institute")'s 2022 survey [ranked Biden](/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States#2022_Siena_College "Historical rankings of presidents of the United States") 19th out of 45 presidents.[[863]](#cite_note-889) The 2024 *Presidential Greatness Project Expert* survey ranked Biden the 14th-best president.[[864]](#cite_note-bc-890) A February 2024 [American Political Science Association](/wiki/American_Political_Science_Association "American Political Science Association") poll of historians and scholars ranked Biden the 14th-greatest president, diverging from public assessments. The pollsters noted that Biden's ranking was unusually high for a presidency without military victories or institutional expansion. The experts polled generally regarded Biden's signature accomplishment as his victory over Trump in the 2020 election, which was perceived as helping to protect and restore political and institutional norms in U.S. government.[[865]](#cite_note-891)[[866]](#cite_note-892)[[864]](#cite_note-bc-890)

When Biden left office in 2025, journalists and many Democrats viewed his presidency as a failure due to [age and health concerns](/wiki/Age_and_health_concerns_about_Joe_Biden "Age and health concerns about Joe Biden"), public frustration over inflation, and Harris's loss to Trump in the [2024 presidential election](/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election "2024 United States presidential election").[[867]](#cite_note-893) *[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")* called the conclusion of Biden's presidency a "tragedy", particularly because Biden was succeeded by Trump after previously defeating him.[[868]](#cite_note-894) Journalist [Ronald Brownstein](/wiki/Ronald_Brownstein "Ronald Brownstein") compared Biden to [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter"): Biden's presidency was overshadowed by the [2021–2023 inflation surge](/wiki/2021%E2%80%932023_inflation_surge "2021–2023 inflation surge"), much as the [1970s energy crisis](/wiki/1970s_energy_crisis "1970s energy crisis") and [stagflation](/wiki/Stagflation "Stagflation") overshadowed [Carter's presidency](/wiki/Presidency_of_Jimmy_Carter "Presidency of Jimmy Carter"). Both men were Democrats and served a single term as president.[[869]](#cite_note-895) [Biden's withdrawal from the 2024 presidential election](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Joe_Biden_from_the_2024_United_States_presidential_election "Withdrawal of Joe Biden from the 2024 United States presidential election") was compared to [Lyndon B. Johnson's withdrawal from the 1968 presidential election](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_Lyndon_B._Johnson_from_the_1968_United_States_presidential_election "Withdrawal of Lyndon B. Johnson from the 1968 United States presidential election").[[870]](#cite_note-896)[[871]](#cite_note-897)[[872]](#cite_note-898)

About contribution quality predictions These predictions are made by a machine-learning service trained on a large set of edits scored by human editors. Stricter, more accurate filters find fewer false positives but miss more of their target. Less accurate filters find more of their target, but they also find more false positives. [Learn more](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:New_filters_for_edit_review/Quality_and_Intent_Filters)

About user intent predictions These predictions about users' good faith are made by a machine-learning service trained on a large set of edits scored by human editors. Stricter, more accurate filters find fewer false positives but miss more of their target. Less accurate filters find more of their target, but they also find more false positives. [Learn more](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:New_filters_for_edit_review/Quality_and_Intent_Filters)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Wikimedia file upload wizard

[Shortcut](/wiki/Wikipedia:Shortcut "Wikipedia:Shortcut")

* [WP:FUW](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:FUW&redirect=no)[WP:FUW](/wiki/Wikipedia:FUW "Wikipedia:FUW")

Thank you for offering to contribute an image or other media file for use on Wikipedia. This wizard will guide you through a questionnaire prompting you for the appropriate copyright and sourcing information for each file. Please ensure you understand [copyright](/wiki/Wikipedia:Copyrights "Wikipedia:Copyrights") and the [image use policy](/wiki/Wikipedia:Image_use_policy "Wikipedia:Image use policy") before proceeding.

[Upload your own or a freely-licensed file](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:UploadWizard "commons:Special:UploadWizard")

Uploads to [Wikimedia Commons](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikimedia_Commons "Wikipedia:Wikimedia Commons")

[Upload a non-free file](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:File_upload_wizard&withJS=MediaWiki:FileUploadWizard.js&withCSS=MediaWiki:FileUploadWizard.css)

Uploads locally to the English Wikipedia; must comply with the [non-free content](/wiki/Wikipedia:Non-free_content "Wikipedia:Non-free content") criteria

**You do not have JavaScript enabled**

Sorry, in order to use this uploading script, JavaScript must be enabled. You can still use the plain [Special:Upload](/wiki/Special:Upload "Special:Upload") page to upload files to the English Wikipedia without JavaScript.

**You are not currently logged in.**

Sorry, in order to use this uploading script and to upload files, you need to be logged in with your named account. Please **[log in](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:UserLogin&returnto=Wikipedia%3AFile+Upload+Wizard&returntoquery=withJS%3DMediaWiki%253AFileUploadWizard.js)** and then try again.

**Your account has not become confirmed yet.**

Sorry, in order to upload files on the English Wikipedia, you need to have a [confirmed account](/wiki/Wikipedia:AUTOCONFIRM "Wikipedia:AUTOCONFIRM"). Normally, your account will become confirmed automatically once you have made 10 edits and four days have passed since you created it.

You may already be able to upload files on the [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/ "commons:"), but you can't do it on the English Wikipedia just yet. If the file you want to upload has a free license, please go to Commons and upload it there.

**Important note:** if you don't want to wait until you are autoconfirmed, you may ask somebody else to upload a file for you at [Wikipedia:Files for upload](/wiki/Wikipedia:Files_for_upload "Wikipedia:Files for upload").

In very rare cases an administrator may make your account confirmed manually through a request at [Wikipedia:Requests for permissions/Confirmed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Requests_for_permissions/Confirmed "Wikipedia:Requests for permissions/Confirmed").

## Step 2: Describe your file

|  |
| --- |
| Please provide a clear, descriptive name by which your file will be known on Wikipedia. |
|  | This name must be unique across the whole of Wikipedia, so please make it informative and easy to recognize. It's no problem to use a fairly long name. It may also include spaces, commas and most other punctuation marks. Please also note that file names are case sensitive (with the exception of the first letter). **Good:** "City of London, skyline from London City Hall, Oct 2008.jpg". **Bad**: "Skyline.jpg", "DSC0001234.jpg". |

Sorry, a few special characters and character combinations cannot be used in the filename for technical reasons. This goes especially for **# < > [ ] | : { } /** and **~~~**. Your filename has been modified to avoid these. Please check if it is okay now.

The filename you chose seems to be very short, or overly generic. Please don't use:

* Titles that consist only of very generic descriptive words (e.g. "Sunset.jpg", "Townhall.jpg")
* Titles that consist only of a person's first or last name, when that name is likely to be shared by many others (e.g. "John.jpg", "Miller.jpg")
* Titles that consist of mere numbers, of the kind often produced by digital cameras ("DSC\_001234", "IMGP0345"), or random strings like those sometimes found on the web ("30996951316264l.jpg")

**A file of this name already exists on Commons!**

If you upload your file with this name, you will be masking the existing file and make it inaccessible. Your new file will be displayed everywhere the existing file was previously used.

This should not be done, except in very rare exceptional cases.

Please don't upload your file under this name, unless you seriously know what you are doing. Choose a different name for your new file instead.

If you want to replace the existing file with an uncontroversial, improved version of the same work, please go to Commons and upload it there, not here on the English Wikipedia's local wiki.

**A file of this name already exists.**

If you upload your file with this name, you will be overwriting the existing file. Your new file will be displayed everywhere the existing file was previously used. Please don't do this, unless you have a good reason to:

Even if you think it would make for a great addition to an article. We really take these copyright rules very seriously on Wikipedia. Note that media is *assumed* to be fully-copyrighted unless shown otherwise; the burden is on the uploader.  In particular, please don't upload:   * any file you simply found on some website, without knowing who its author or copyright owner is. * any file you found somewhere, even if you have good reason to believe it has a copyright owner who would not mind us using it, but you don't have an explicit licensing statement from them. * any file that was released for publicity purposes by its owners but doesn't have a fully-free license for free re-use for all purposes. * any file credited to a commercial image agency, such as Reuters, AP or Getty Images. Such files normally cannot be used even under the "Fair Use" rules, except in rare cases. * any file that is licensed for use exclusively on Wikipedia, or is free except that the free license excludes commercial use.   If you are in any doubt, please ask some experienced editors for advice before uploading. ## Upload in process

Your file is being uploaded.

This might take a minute or two, depending on the size of the file and the speed of your internet connection.

Once uploading is completed, you will find your new file at this link:

## File successfully uploaded

Your file has been uploaded successfully and can now be found here:

**[File:Example.jpg](/wiki/File:Example.jpg "File:Example.jpg")**

Please follow the link and check that the image description page has all the information you meant to include.

If you want to change the description, just go to the image page, click the "edit" tab at the top of the page and edit just as you would edit any other page. Do not go through this upload form again, unless you want to replace the actual file with a new version.

To insert this file into an article, you may want to use code similar to the following:

```
Example.jpg
```

If you wish to make a link to the file in text, without actually showing the image, for instance when discussing the image on a talk page, you can use the following (mark the ":" after the initial brackets!):

```
Example.jpg
```

See [Wikipedia:Picture tutorial](/wiki/Wikipedia:Picture_tutorial "Wikipedia:Picture tutorial") for more detailed help on how to insert and position images in pages.

**Thank you for using the File Upload Wizard.**  
Please leave your feedback, comments, bug reports or suggestions on the [talk page](/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:File_upload_wizard "Wikipedia talk:File upload wizard").

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Introduction to English-language Wikipedia

[Shortcuts](/wiki/Wikipedia:Shortcut "Wikipedia:Shortcut")

* [WP:ABT](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:ABT&redirect=no)[WP:ABT](/wiki/Wikipedia:ABT "Wikipedia:ABT")
* [WP:ABOUT](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:ABOUT&redirect=no)[WP:ABOUT](/wiki/Wikipedia:ABOUT "Wikipedia:ABOUT")
* [WP:WIKIPEDIA](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:WIKIPEDIA&redirect=no)[WP:WIKIPEDIA](/wiki/Wikipedia:WIKIPEDIA "Wikipedia:WIKIPEDIA")

This is a [general introduction](/wiki/Wikipedia:INFOPAGES "Wikipedia:INFOPAGES") for visitors to Wikipedia. For aspiring contributors, also see this [guide](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contributing_to_Wikipedia "Wikipedia:Contributing to Wikipedia") and [tutorial](/wiki/Help:Introduction "Help:Introduction"). For other uses, see [Wikipedia:Wikipedia (disambiguation)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_(disambiguation) "Wikipedia:Wikipedia (disambiguation)").

Imagine a world in which every single person on the planet is given free access to the sum of all human knowledge. That's what we're doing. — [Jimmy Wales](/wiki/Jimmy_Wales "Jimmy Wales")

**[Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia")** is a [free online encyclopedia](/wiki/Wikipedia:Free_encyclopedia "Wikipedia:Free encyclopedia") that anyone can edit, and [millions already have](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedians#Number_of_editors "Wikipedia:Wikipedians").

[Wikipedia's purpose](/wiki/Wikipedia:Purpose "Wikipedia:Purpose") is to benefit readers by presenting information on all branches of [knowledge](/wiki/Knowledge "Knowledge"). Hosted by the [Wikimedia Foundation](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikimedia_Foundation "Wikipedia:Wikimedia Foundation"), Wikipedia consists of [freely editable](/wiki/Help:Editing "Help:Editing") content, with articles that usually contain numerous links guiding readers to more information.

[Written collaboratively](/wiki/Collaborative_writing "Collaborative writing") by volunteers known as [Wikipedians](/wiki/Wikipedia_community "Wikipedia community"), Wikipedia articles can be edited by anyone with [Internet access](/wiki/Internet_access "Internet access"), except in [limited cases](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy "Wikipedia:Protection policy") in which [editing](/wiki/Editing "Editing") is restricted to prevent [disruption](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disruption "Wikipedia:Disruption") or [vandalism](/wiki/Wikipedia:VAND "Wikipedia:VAND"). Since its creation on [January 15, 2001](/wiki/Wikipedia_Day "Wikipedia Day"), it has grown into the world's [largest](/wiki/Wikipedia:Size_of_Wikipedia "Wikipedia:Size of Wikipedia") reference [website](/wiki/Website "Website"), attracting [over a billion visitors each month](https://stats.wikimedia.org/#/all-wikipedia-projects/reading/unique-devices "stats:"). Wikipedia currently has more than [sixty-six million articles](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/List_of_Wikipedias#All_Wikipedias_ordered_by_number_of_articles "m:List of Wikipedias") in [more than 300 languages](/wiki/Special:SiteMatrix "Special:SiteMatrix"), including 7,111,984 articles in [English](/wiki/English_language "English language"), with 285,648 active contributors in the past month.

Wikipedia's fundamental principles are summarized in its [five pillars](/wiki/Wikipedia:Five_pillars "Wikipedia:Five pillars"). While the [Wikipedia community](/wiki/Wikipedia_community "Wikipedia community") has developed many [policies and guidelines](/wiki/Wikipedia:Policies_and_guidelines "Wikipedia:Policies and guidelines"), new editors do not need to be familiar with them before they start contributing.

[Anyone](/wiki/Wikipedia:Who_writes_Wikipedia%3F "Wikipedia:Who writes Wikipedia?") can [edit](/wiki/Help:Editing "Help:Editing") Wikipedia's text, data, references, and images. The quality of content is more important than the expertise of who contributes it. Wikipedia's content must conform with its [policies](/wiki/Wikipedia:Editing_policy "Wikipedia:Editing policy"), including being [verifiable](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiable "Wikipedia:Verifiable") by published [reliable sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources"). Contributions based on [personal opinions](/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view "Wikipedia:Neutral point of view"), beliefs, or personal experiences, [unreviewed research](/wiki/Wikipedia:Original_research "Wikipedia:Original research"), libellous material, and [copyright violations](/wiki/Wikipedia:Copyright_violations "Wikipedia:Copyright violations") are not allowed, and will not remain. Wikipedia's software makes it easy to reverse errors, and experienced [editors](/wiki/Wikipedia_editor "Wikipedia editor") [watch](/wiki/Wikipedia:Watchlist "Wikipedia:Watchlist") and [patrol](/wiki/Wikipedia:Recent_changes_patrol "Wikipedia:Recent changes patrol") bad edits.

[Wikipedia differs from printed references in important ways](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTPAPER "Wikipedia:NOTPAPER"). Anyone can instantly improve it, add quality information, remove misinformation, and fix errors and [vandalism](/wiki/Wikipedia:Vandalism "Wikipedia:Vandalism"). Since Wikipedia is continually updated, encyclopedic articles on major news events appear within minutes.

For over 24 years, editors have volunteered their time and talents to create history's most comprehensive encyclopedia while providing references and other resources to researchers worldwide (see [Researching with Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia:Researching_with_Wikipedia "Wikipedia:Researching with Wikipedia")). In summary, Wikipedia has tested the [wisdom of the crowd](/wiki/Wisdom_of_the_crowd "Wisdom of the crowd") since 2001 and has found that it succeeds.

To start editing, simply click the `Edit` or `Edit source` button, or the pencil icon , at the top of any [non-protected](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy "Wikipedia:Protection policy") Wikipedia page or section.

###### These words

Description Searches for these words in the title or text.Be aware of the following
*   Multiple words can be entered here.
*   Punctuation marks and other non-alphanumeric characters (with exception of the colon and comma) will be ignored.
*   There may be results that do not contain one or more of your search terms.
*   Word stemming is applied. Example: If _car_ is entered, the search will also consider _cars_. The word stemming is language-specific.

Help page[Full text search](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Full_text_search)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search`sesame street car`

###### Exactly this text

Description Searches for a specific sequence of characters. Punctuation marks are ignored.Be aware of the following(only valid when using quotation marks, see example below) 
*   Separate the search phrases by comma or space e.g. `"good morning"`, `"hello friend!"`.
*   Punctuation marks and other non-alphanumeric characters (with exception of the colon and comma) will be ignored.
*   Search is not case-sensitive.
*   Word stemming is not applied.

Help page[Words, phrases, and modifiers](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Words.2C_phrases.2C_and_modifiers)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words in quotation marks, for example `"Begin at the beginning"`.

###### Not these words

Description Excludes pages containing these words from the search.Be aware of the following
*   Word stemming is applied. Example: If _car_ is entered, the search will also consider _cars_. The word stemming is language-specific.

Help page[Words, phrases, and modifiers](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Words.2C_phrases.2C_and_modifiers)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words with `-` before them, for example `-elephant`.

###### One of these words

Description At least one of the search terms has to be included in the page.Help page[Words, phrases, and modifiers](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Words.2C_phrases.2C_and_modifiers)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words with `OR` in between them like `Laptop OR Notebook`.

###### Page title contains

Description Searches for pages with titles that contain this word Be aware of the following
*   The search includes redirects.
*   Word stemming is applied. Example: If _car_ is entered, the search will also consider _cars_. The word stemming is language-specific.

Help page[Intitle and incategory](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Intitle_and_incategory)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words with `intitle:` before them like `intitle:queen`.

###### Subpages of this page

Description Searches for pages that are subpages of this page.Be aware of the following
*   You can only search for subpages of one page at a time.
*   Don’t forget to enable the namespaces you want to limit your search to in the namespace filter.
*   Do not include the namespace in front of the page name like this: ~~`Wikipedia:Redirect`~~.

Help page[Subpageof](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#subpageof)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search`subpageof:` followed by a page name like `subpageof:Redirect`. Use double quotes if the parent page contains spaces: `subpageof:"Requests for comment"`.

###### Pages in these categories

Description Searches for pages that are in these categories and subcategories.Be aware of the following
*   Only the first 5 subcategory levels will be included in your search.
*   The number of categories is limited to 256.
*   You can look for pages in multiple categories.

Help page[Deepcategory](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Deepcategory)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search`deepcategory:` followed by a category name like `deepcategory:Help`. Use double quotes if the name contains spaces: `deepcategory:"Hidden categories"`.

###### Pages with these templates

Description Searches for pages that contain exactly these templates.Be aware of the following
*   You can find transcluded templates (templates consisting of other templates).
*   The autosuggest function can only find templates which start the same way as your search e.g. a search for `"com..."` will suggest _"commons"_ but not _"nowcommons"_.

Help page[Hastemplate](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Hastemplate)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words in quotation marks with `hastemplate:` before them like `hastemplate:"missing information"`.

###### File type

Description Searches only for files of the selected type.Be aware of the following
*   You can only search for one file type.
*   You can only select the given file types from the drop-down menu.

Help pages[Filetype](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#filetype) and [filemime](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#filemime)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Words with `filetype:` before them like `filetype:ogg`.

###### File width in pixels

Description These fields allow you to specify the width of the file.Be aware of the following
*   This is only applicable to file types that have width and height, like videos and images.

Help page[Filemeasures](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#File_measures)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Numbers with `filew` before them like `filew:>800`.

###### File height in pixels

Description These fields allow you to specify the height of the file.Be aware of the following
*   This is only applicable to file types that have width and height, like videos and images.

Help page[Filemeasures](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#File_measures)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search Numbers with `fileh` before them like `fileh:>600`.

###### Sorting order

Description Change the sorting order of results. The standard is that most relevant pages are placed on top of the results.Help page[Explicit sort orders](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Help:CirrusSearch#Explicit_sort_orders)Syntax-equivalent in the normal search This feature has no keyword that you can type in the search input field since the function is specified via a parameter in the URL.

In other projects

Appearance

This page contains a list of [special pages](/wiki/Help:Special_page "Help:Special page"). Most of the content of these pages is automatically generated and cannot be edited. To suggest a change to the parts that *can* be edited, find the appropriate text on [Special:AllMessages](/wiki/Special:AllMessages "Special:AllMessages") and then request your change on the talk page of the message (using {{[editprotected](/wiki/Template:Edit_fully-protected "Template:Edit fully-protected")}} to draw the attention of administrators).

You can also see what message names are used on a page by adding `?uselang=qqx` to the end of its URL, e.g. <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:SpecialPages?uselang=qqx> will show `(specialpages-summary)` in place of this message, which allows you to find [MediaWiki:Specialpages-summary](/wiki/MediaWiki:Specialpages-summary "MediaWiki:Specialpages-summary").

For an index of special pages, see [Help:SpecialPages](/wiki/Help:SpecialPages#Alphabetical_order "Help:SpecialPages").

Before using these types of content, please ensure that you have the right to use it under the laws which apply in the circumstances of your intended use. *You are solely responsible for ensuring that you do not infringe someone else's personality rights.*

## Jurisdiction and legality of content

Publication of information found in Wikipedia may be in violation of the laws of the country or jurisdiction from where you are viewing this information. The Wikipedia database is stored on servers in the United States of America, and is maintained in reference to the protections afforded under local and federal law. Laws in your country or jurisdiction may not protect or allow the same kinds of speech or distribution. Wikipedia does not encourage the violation of any laws, and cannot be responsible for any violations of such laws, should you link to this domain, or use, reproduce, or republish the information contained herein.

## Not professional advice

If you need specific advice (for example, medical, legal, financial, or risk management), please seek a professional who is licensed or knowledgeable in that area.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Historical dictionary of the English language

This article is about the multi-volume historical dictionary. For other dictionaries published by Oxford University Press, see [Oxford dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_dictionary_(disambiguation) "Oxford dictionary (disambiguation)").

"OED" redirects here. For other uses, see [OED (disambiguation)](/wiki/OED_(disambiguation) "OED (disambiguation)").

*Oxford English Dictionary*

| Seven of the twenty volumes of the printed second edition of *The Oxford English Dictionary* (1989) |
| Country | United Kingdom |
| Language | English |
| Publisher | [Oxford University Press](/wiki/Oxford_University_Press "Oxford University Press") |
| Published | * 1884–1928 (first edition) * 1989 (second edition) * Third edition in preparation[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1) |
| Website | [oed.com](https://oed.com) |

The ***Oxford English Dictionary*** (***OED***) is the principal [historical dictionary](/wiki/Historical_dictionary "Historical dictionary") of the [English language](/wiki/English_language "English language"), published by [Oxford University Press](/wiki/Oxford_University_Press "Oxford University Press") (OUP), a [University of Oxford](/wiki/University_of_Oxford "University of Oxford") publishing house. The dictionary, which began publication in 1884, traces the historical development of the English language, providing a comprehensive resource to scholars and academic researchers, and provides ongoing descriptions of English language usage in its variations around the world.[[2]](#cite_note-2)

Work began on the dictionary in 1857, although publication did not commence until 1884. The work then began to be issued incrementally in unbound [fascicles](/wiki/Serial_(literature) "Serial (literature)") (instalments), as work continued on other parts of the project. The original title was *A New English Dictionary on Historical Principles; Founded Mainly on the Materials Collected by The Philological Society*. In 1895, the title *The Oxford English Dictionary* was first used unofficially on the covers of the series, and in 1928 the full dictionary was republished in 10 bound volumes.

In 1933, the title *The Oxford English Dictionary* fully replaced the former name in all occurrences in its reprinting as 12 volumes with a one-volume supplement. More supplements came over the years until 1989, when the second edition was published, comprising 21,728 pages in 20 volumes.[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1) Since 2000, compilation of a third edition of the dictionary has been underway, approximately half of which was complete by 2018.[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1)

In 1988, the first electronic version of the dictionary was made available, and the online version has been available since 2000. By April 2014, it was receiving over two million visits per month. The third edition of the dictionary is expected to be available exclusively in electronic form; the CEO of OUP has stated that it is unlikely that it will ever be printed.[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1)[[3]](#cite_note-3)[[4]](#cite_note-Simpson-4)

## Historical nature

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Historical nature")]

As a historical dictionary, the *Oxford English Dictionary* features entries in which the earliest ascertainable recorded sense of a word, whether current or obsolete, is presented first, and each additional sense is presented in historical order according to the date of its earliest ascertainable recorded use.[[5]](#cite_note-5) Following each definition are several brief illustrating quotations presented in chronological order from the earliest ascertainable use of the word in that sense to the last ascertainable use for an obsolete sense, to indicate both its life span and the time since its desuetude, or to a relatively recent use for current ones.

The format of the *OED*'s entries has influenced numerous other historical [lexicography](/wiki/Lexicography "Lexicography") projects. The forerunners to the *OED*, such as the early volumes of the *[Deutsches Wörterbuch](/wiki/Deutsches_W%C3%B6rterbuch "Deutsches Wörterbuch")*, had initially provided few quotations from a limited number of sources, whereas the *OED* editors preferred larger groups of quite short quotations from a wide selection of authors and publications. This influenced later volumes of this and other lexicographical works.[[6]](#cite_note-6)

## Entries and relative size

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Entries and relative size")]

According to the publishers, it would take a single person 120 years to "key in" the 59 million words of the *OED* second edition, 60 years to proofread them, and 540 [megabytes](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte") to store them electronically.[[7]](#cite_note-facts2004-7) As of 30 November 2005, the *Oxford English Dictionary* contained approximately 301,100 main entries. Supplementing the entry [headwords](/wiki/Headword "Headword"), there are 157,000 bold-type combinations and derivatives;[[8]](#cite_note-8) 169,000 italicized-bold phrases and combinations;[[9]](#cite_note-9) 616,500 word-forms in total, including 137,000 [pronunciations](/wiki/Pronunciation "Pronunciation"); 249,300 [etymologies](/wiki/Etymology "Etymology"); 577,000 cross-references; and 2,412,400 usage [quotations](/wiki/Quotation "Quotation"). The dictionary's latest, complete print edition (second edition, 1989) was printed in 20 volumes, comprising 291,500 entries in 21,730 pages. The longest entry in the *OED2* was for the verb *set*, which required 60,000 words to describe some 580 senses (430 for the bare verb, the rest in [phrasal verbs](/wiki/Phrasal_verb "Phrasal verb") and idioms). As entries began to be revised for the *OED3* in sequence starting from M, the record was progressively broken by the verbs *make* in 2000, then *put* in 2007, then *run* in 2011 with 645 senses.[[10]](#cite_note-10)[[11]](#cite_note-11)[[12]](#cite_note-12)

Despite its considerable size, the *OED* is neither the world's largest nor the earliest exhaustive dictionary of a language. Another earlier large dictionary is the [Grimm brothers](/wiki/Grimm_brothers "Grimm brothers")' [dictionary of the German language](/wiki/Deutsches_W%C3%B6rterbuch "Deutsches Wörterbuch"), begun in 1838 and completed in 1961. The first edition of the *[Vocabolario degli Accademici della Crusca](/wiki/Vocabolario_degli_Accademici_della_Crusca "Vocabolario degli Accademici della Crusca")* is the first great dictionary devoted to a modern European language (Italian) and was published in 1612; the first edition of *[Dictionnaire de l'Académie française](/wiki/Dictionnaire_de_l%27Acad%C3%A9mie_fran%C3%A7aise "Dictionnaire de l'Académie française")* dates from 1694. The official dictionary of Spanish is the *[Diccionario de la lengua española](/wiki/Diccionario_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola "Diccionario de la lengua española")* (produced, edited, and published by the [Royal Spanish Academy](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Academy "Royal Spanish Academy")), and its first edition was published in 1780. The *[Kangxi Dictionary](/wiki/Kangxi_Dictionary "Kangxi Dictionary")* of Chinese was published in 1716.[[13]](#cite_note-13) The largest dictionary by number of pages is believed to be the Dutch *[Woordenboek der Nederlandsche Taal](/wiki/Woordenboek_der_Nederlandsche_Taal "Woordenboek der Nederlandsche Taal")*.[[14]](#cite_note-14)[[15]](#cite_note-15)
