### Origins

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Origins")]

The dictionary began as a [Philological Society](/wiki/Philological_Society "Philological Society") project of a small group of intellectuals in London (and unconnected to [Oxford University](/wiki/Oxford_University "Oxford University")):[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16): 103–104, 112 [Richard Chenevix Trench](/wiki/Richard_Chenevix_Trench "Richard Chenevix Trench"), [Herbert Coleridge](/wiki/Herbert_Coleridge "Herbert Coleridge"), and [Frederick Furnivall](/wiki/Frederick_James_Furnivall "Frederick James Furnivall"), who were dissatisfied with the existing English dictionaries. The society expressed interest in compiling a new dictionary as early as 1844,[[17]](#cite_note-17) but it was not until June 1857 that they began by forming an "Unregistered Words Committee" to search for words that were unlisted or poorly defined in current dictionaries. In November, Trench's report was not a list of unregistered words; instead, it was the study *On Some Deficiencies in our English Dictionaries*, which identified seven distinct shortcomings in contemporary dictionaries:[[18]](#cite_note-18)

* Incomplete coverage of obsolete words
* Inconsistent coverage of families of related words
* Incorrect dates for earliest use of words
* History of obsolete senses of words often omitted
* Inadequate distinction among [synonyms](/wiki/Synonyms "Synonyms")
* Insufficient use of good illustrative quotations
* Space wasted on inappropriate or redundant content.

The society ultimately realized that the number of unlisted words would be far more than the number of words in the English dictionaries of the 19th century, and shifted their idea from covering only words that were not already in English dictionaries to a larger project. Trench suggested that a new, truly *comprehensive* dictionary was needed. On 7 January 1858, the society formally adopted the idea of a comprehensive new dictionary.[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16): 107–108 Volunteer readers would be assigned particular books, copying passages illustrating word usage onto quotation slips. Later the same year, the society agreed to the project in principle, with the title *A New English Dictionary on Historical Principles* (*NED*).[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): ix–x

### Early editors

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Early editors")]

See also: [List of contributors to the Oxford English Dictionary](/wiki/List_of_contributors_to_the_Oxford_English_Dictionary "List of contributors to the Oxford English Dictionary")

[Richard Chenevix Trench](/wiki/Richard_Chenevix_Trench "Richard Chenevix Trench") (1807–1886) played the key role in the project's first months, but his appointment as [Dean of Westminster](/wiki/List_of_Deans_of_Westminster "List of Deans of Westminster") meant that he could not give the dictionary project the time that it required. He withdrew and [Herbert Coleridge](/wiki/Herbert_Coleridge "Herbert Coleridge") became the first editor.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 8–9

On 12 May 1860, Coleridge's dictionary plan was published and research was started. His house was the first editorial office. He arrayed 100,000 quotation slips in a 54 pigeon-hole grid.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 9 In April 1861, the group published the first sample pages; later that month, Coleridge died of [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis"), aged 30.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): x

Thereupon Furnivall became editor; he was enthusiastic and knowledgeable, but temperamentally ill-suited for the work.[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16): 110 Many volunteer readers eventually lost interest in the project, as Furnivall failed to keep them motivated. Furthermore, many of the slips were misplaced.

Furnivall believed that, since many printed texts from earlier centuries were not readily available, it would be impossible for volunteers to efficiently locate the quotations that the dictionary needed. As a result, he founded the [Early English Text Society](/wiki/Early_English_Text_Society "Early English Text Society") in 1864 and the Chaucer Society in 1868 to publish old manuscripts.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xii Furnivall's preparatory efforts lasted 21 years and provided numerous texts for the use and enjoyment of the general public, as well as crucial sources for lexicographers, but they did not actually involve compiling a dictionary. Furnivall recruited more than 800 volunteers to read these texts and record quotations. While enthusiastic, the volunteers were not well trained and often made inconsistent and arbitrary selections. Ultimately, Furnivall handed over nearly two tons of quotation slips and other materials to his successor.[[21]](#cite_note-21)

In the 1870s, Furnivall unsuccessfully attempted to recruit both [Henry Sweet](/wiki/Henry_Sweet "Henry Sweet") and [Henry Nicol](/wiki/Henry_Nicol "Henry Nicol") to succeed him. He then approached [James Murray](/wiki/James_Murray_(lexicographer) "James Murray (lexicographer)"), who accepted the post of editor. In the late 1870s, Furnivall and Murray met with several publishers about publishing the dictionary. In 1878, Oxford University Press agreed with Murray to proceed with the massive project; the agreement was formalized the following year.[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16): 111–112 20 years after its conception, the dictionary project finally had a publisher. It would take another 50 years to complete.

Late in his editorship, Murray learned that one especially prolific reader, [W. C. Minor](/wiki/William_Chester_Minor "William Chester Minor"), was confined to a mental hospital for (in modern terminology) [schizophrenia](/wiki/Schizophrenia "Schizophrenia").[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16): xiii Minor was a Yale University–trained surgeon and a military officer in the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") who had been confined to [Broadmoor Asylum for the Criminally Insane](/wiki/Broadmoor_Hospital "Broadmoor Hospital") after killing a man in London. He invented his own quotation-tracking system, allowing him to submit slips on specific words in response to editors' requests. The story of how Murray and Minor worked together to advance the *OED* was retold in the 1998 book *[The Surgeon of Crowthorne](/wiki/The_Surgeon_of_Crowthorne "The Surgeon of Crowthorne")* (US title: *The Professor and the Madman*[[16]](#cite_note-Winchester1999-16)), which was the basis for a 2019 film, *[The Professor and the Madman](/wiki/The_Professor_and_the_Madman_(film) "The Professor and the Madman (film)")*, starring [Mel Gibson](/wiki/Mel_Gibson "Mel Gibson") and [Sean Penn](/wiki/Sean_Penn "Sean Penn").

### Oxford editors

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Oxford editors")]

During the 1870s, the [Philological Society](/wiki/Philological_Society "Philological Society") was concerned with the process of publishing a dictionary with such an immense scope.[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1) They had pages printed by publishers, but no publication agreement was reached; both the [Cambridge University Press](/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press "Cambridge University Press") and the [Oxford University Press](/wiki/Oxford_University_Press "Oxford University Press") were approached. The OUP finally agreed in 1879 (after two years of negotiating by Sweet, Furnivall, and Murray) to publish the dictionary and to pay Murray, who was both the editor and the [Philological Society](/wiki/Philological_Society "Philological Society") president. The dictionary was to be published as interval fascicles, with the final form in four volumes, totalling 6,400 pages. They hoped to finish the project in ten years.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 1

Murray started the project, working in a [corrugated iron](/wiki/Corrugated_iron "Corrugated iron") outbuilding called the "[Scriptorium](/wiki/Scriptorium "Scriptorium")" which was lined with wooden planks, bookshelves, and 1,029 pigeon-holes for the quotation slips.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xiii He tracked and regathered Furnivall's collection of quotation slips, which were found to concentrate on rare, interesting words rather than common usages. For instance, there were ten times as many quotations for *abusion* as for *abuse*.[[22]](#cite_note-caught178-22) He appealed, through newspapers distributed to bookshops and libraries, for readers who would report "as many quotations as you can for ordinary words" and for words that were "rare, obsolete, old-fashioned, new, peculiar or used in a peculiar way".[[22]](#cite_note-caught178-22) Murray had American philologist and [liberal arts college](/wiki/Liberal_arts_college "Liberal arts college") professor [Francis March](/wiki/Francis_March "Francis March") manage the collection in North America; 1,000 quotation slips arrived daily to the Scriptorium and, by 1880, there were 2,500,000.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 15

The first dictionary fascicle was published on 1 February 1884—twenty-three years after Coleridge's sample pages. The full title was *A New English Dictionary on Historical Principles; Founded Mainly on the Materials Collected by The Philological Society*; the 352-page volume, words from *A* to *Ant*, cost 12[s](/wiki/Shilling "Shilling") 6[d](/wiki/Penny_(British_pre-decimal_coin) "Penny (British pre-decimal coin)")[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 251 (equivalent to $82 in 2023). The total sales were only 4,000 copies.[[23]](#cite_note-Winchester2003-23): 169

The OUP saw that it would take too long to complete the work unless editorial arrangements were revised. Accordingly, new assistants were hired, and two new demands were made on Murray.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20): 32–33 The first was that he move from [Mill Hill](/wiki/Mill_Hill "Mill Hill") to [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford "Oxford") to work full-time on the project, which he did in 1885. Murray had his Scriptorium re-erected in the back garden of his new property.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xvii

Murray resisted the second demand: that if he could not meet the schedule, he must hire a second, senior editor to work in parallel to him, outside his supervision, on words from elsewhere in the alphabet. Murray did not want to share the work, feeling that he would accelerate his work pace with experience. That turned out not to be so, and [Philip Gell](/wiki/Philip_Lyttelton_Gell "Philip Lyttelton Gell") of the OUP forced the promotion of Murray's assistant [Henry Bradley](/wiki/Henry_Bradley "Henry Bradley") (hired by Murray in 1884), who worked independently in the [British Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum") in London beginning in 1888. In 1896, Bradley moved to Oxford University.[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20)

Gell continued harassing Murray and Bradley with his business concerns – containing costs and speeding production – to the point where the project's collapse seemed likely. Newspapers reported the harassment, particularly the *[Saturday Review](/wiki/Saturday_Review_(London) "Saturday Review (London)")*, and public opinion backed the editors.[[23]](#cite_note-Winchester2003-23): 182–83 Gell was fired, and the university reversed his cost policies. If the editors felt that the dictionary would have to grow larger, it would; it was an important work, and worth the time and money to finish properly.

### Further progress

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Further progress")]

Neither Murray nor Bradley lived to see it. Murray died in 1915, having been responsible for words starting with *A–D*, *H–K*, *O–P*, and *T*, nearly half the finished dictionary; Bradley died in 1923, having completed *E–G*, *L–M*, *S–Sh*, *St*, and *W–We*. By then, two additional editors had been promoted from assistant work to independent work, continuing without much trouble. [William Craigie](/wiki/William_Craigie "William Craigie") started in 1901 and was responsible for *N*, *Q–R*, *Si–Sq*, *U–V*, and *Wo–Wy*.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xix The OUP had previously thought London too far from Oxford but, after 1925, Craigie worked on the dictionary in Chicago, where he was a professor.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xix[[20]](#cite_note-Mugglestone-20) The fourth editor was [Charles Talbut Onions](/wiki/Charles_Talbut_Onions "Charles Talbut Onions"), who compiled the remaining ranges starting in 1914: *Su–Sz*, *Wh–Wo*, and *X–Z*.[[24]](#cite_note-Lex-LMugg-24)

In 1919–1920, [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien") was employed by the *OED*, researching etymologies of the *Waggle* to *Warlock* range;[[25]](#cite_note-25) later he parodied the principal editors as "The Four Wise Clerks of Oxenford" in the story *[Farmer Giles of Ham](/wiki/Farmer_Giles_of_Ham "Farmer Giles of Ham")*.[[26]](#cite_note-Considine-26)

By early 1894, a total of 11 fascicles had been published, or about one per year: four for *A–B*, five for *C*, and two for *E*.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19) Of these, eight were 352 pages long, while the last one in each group was shorter to end at the letter break (which eventually became a volume break). At this point, it was decided to publish the work in smaller and more frequent instalments: once every three months beginning in 1895 there would be a fascicle of 64 pages, priced at 2s 6d. If enough material was ready, 128 or even 192 pages would be published together. This pace was maintained until World War I forced reductions in staff.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xx Each time enough consecutive pages were available, the same material was also published in the original larger fascicles.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xx Also in 1895, the title *Oxford English Dictionary* was first used. It then appeared only on the outer covers of the fascicles; the original title was still the official one and was used everywhere else.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xx

### Completion of first edition and first supplement

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Completion of first edition and first supplement")]

The 125th and last fascicle covered words from *Wise* to the end of *W* and was published on 19 April 1928, and the full dictionary in bound volumes followed immediately.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19): xx [William Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare") is the most-quoted writer in the completed dictionary, with *[Hamlet](/wiki/Hamlet "Hamlet")* his most-quoted work. [George Eliot](/wiki/George_Eliot "George Eliot") (Mary Ann Evans) is the most-quoted female writer. Collectively, the [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible") is the most-quoted work (in many translations); the most-quoted single work is *[Cursor Mundi](/wiki/Cursor_Mundi "Cursor Mundi")*.[[7]](#cite_note-facts2004-7)

Additional material for a given letter range continued to be gathered after the corresponding fascicle was printed, with a view towards inclusion in a supplement or revised edition. A one-volume supplement of such material was published in 1933, with entries weighted towards the start of the alphabet where the fascicles were decades old.[[19]](#cite_note-Craigie-19) The supplement included at least one word (*bondmaid*) accidentally omitted when its slips were misplaced;[[27]](#cite_note-27) many words and senses newly coined (famously *[appendicitis](/wiki/Appendicitis "Appendicitis")*, coined in 1886 and missing from the 1885 fascicle, which came to prominence when [Edward VII](/wiki/Edward_VII "Edward VII")'s 1902 appendicitis postponed [his coronation](/wiki/Coronation_of_Edward_VII_and_Alexandra "Coronation of Edward VII and Alexandra")[[28]](#cite_note-28)); and some previously excluded as too obscure (notoriously *[radium](/wiki/Radium "Radium")*, omitted in 1903, months before its discoverers [Pierre](/wiki/Pierre_Curie "Pierre Curie") and [Marie Curie](/wiki/Marie_Curie "Marie Curie") won the [Nobel Prize in Physics](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics "Nobel Prize in Physics")[[29]](#cite_note-29)). Also in 1933 the original fascicles of the entire dictionary were re-issued, bound into 12 volumes, under the title "*The Oxford English Dictionary*".[[30]](#cite_note-33reissue-30) This edition of 13 volumes including the supplement was subsequently reprinted in 1961 and 1970.

### Second supplement

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Second supplement")]

In 1933, Oxford had finally put the dictionary to rest; all work ended, and the quotation slips went into storage. However, the English language continued to change and, by 20 years later, the dictionary was outdated.[[31]](#cite_note-Supplement1957-1986-31)

There were three possible ways to update it. The cheapest would have been to leave the existing work alone and simply compile a new supplement of perhaps one or two volumes, but then anyone looking for a word or sense and unsure of its age would have to look in three different places. The most convenient choice for the user would have been for the entire dictionary to be re-edited and [retypeset](/wiki/Typesetting "Typesetting"), with each change included in its proper alphabetical place; but this would have been the most expensive option, with perhaps 15 volumes required to be produced. The OUP chose a middle approach: combining the new material with the existing supplement to form a larger replacement supplement.

[Robert Burchfield](/wiki/Robert_Burchfield "Robert Burchfield") was hired in 1957 to edit the second supplement;[[32]](#cite_note-32) [Charles Talbut Onions](/wiki/Charles_Talbut_Onions "Charles Talbut Onions") turned 84 that year but was still able to make some contributions as well. The work on the supplement was expected to take about seven years.[[31]](#cite_note-Supplement1957-1986-31) It actually took 29 years, by which time the new supplement *(OEDS)* had grown to four volumes, starting with *A*, *H*, *O*, and *Sea*. They were published in 1972, 1976, 1982, and 1986 respectively, bringing the complete dictionary to 16 volumes, or 17 counting the first supplement.

Burchfield emphasized the inclusion of modern-day language and, through the supplement, the dictionary was expanded to include a wealth of new words from the burgeoning fields of science and technology, as well as popular culture and colloquial speech. Burchfield said that he broadened the scope to include developments of the language in [English-speaking regions beyond the United Kingdom](/wiki/English-speaking_world "English-speaking world"), including North America, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, India, Pakistan, and the Caribbean. Burchfield also removed, for unknown reasons, many entries that had been added to the 1933 supplement.[[33]](#cite_note-33) In 2012, an analysis by lexicographer Sarah Ogilvie revealed that many of these entries were foreign [loan words](/wiki/Loan_word "Loan word"), despite Burchfield's claim that he included more such words. The proportion was estimated from a sample calculation to amount to 17% of the foreign loan words and words from regional forms of English. Some of these had only a single recorded usage, but many had multiple recorded citations, and it ran against what was thought to be the established *OED* editorial practice and a perception that he had opened up the dictionary to "World English".[[34]](#cite_note-34)[[35]](#cite_note-35)[[36]](#cite_note-36)

### Second edition

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Second edition")]

| Language | English |

| Publisher | [Oxford University Press](/wiki/Oxford_University_Press "Oxford University Press") |

| Pages | 21,730[[7]](#cite_note-facts2004-7) |
| [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") | [978-0-19-861186-8](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861186-8 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861186-8") |
| [OCLC](/wiki/OCLC_(identifier) "OCLC (identifier)") | [17648714](https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/17648714) |

| [LC Class](/wiki/LCC_(identifier) "LCC (identifier)") | PE1625 .O87 1989 |

By the time the new supplement was completed, it was clear that the full text of the dictionary would need to be computerized. This would require retyping it, but from then on it would always be accessible for computer searching—as well as for whatever new editions of the dictionary might be desired, starting with an integration of the supplementary volumes and the main text. Preparation for this process began in 1983, and editorial work started the following year under the administrative direction of Timothy J. Benbow, with [John A. Simpson](/wiki/John_Simpson_(lexicographer) "John Simpson (lexicographer)") and [Edmund S. C. Weiner](/wiki/Edmund_Weiner "Edmund Weiner") as co-editors.[[37]](#cite_note-:5-37) In 2016, Simpson published his memoir chronicling his years at the OED: *The Word Detective: Searching for the Meaning of It All at the Oxford English Dictionary – A Memoir* (New York: Basic Books).

Thus began the *New Oxford English Dictionary (NOED)* project. In the United States, more than 120 typists of the International Computaprint Corporation (now [Reed Tech](/wiki/Reed_Tech "Reed Tech")) started keying in over 350,000,000 characters, their work checked by 55 proof-readers in England.[[37]](#cite_note-:5-37) Retyping the text alone was not sufficient; all the information represented by the complex [typography](/wiki/Typography "Typography") of the original dictionary had to be retained, which was done by [marking up](/wiki/Markup_(computer_programming) "Markup (computer programming)") the content in [SGML](/wiki/SGML "SGML").[[37]](#cite_note-:5-37) A specialized [search engine](/wiki/Search_engine_(computing) "Search engine (computing)") and display software were also needed to access it. Under a 1985 agreement, some of this software work was done at the [University of Waterloo](/wiki/University_of_Waterloo "University of Waterloo"), Canada, at the *Centre for the New Oxford English Dictionary*, led by [Frank Tompa](/wiki/Frank_Tompa "Frank Tompa") and [Gaston Gonnet](/wiki/Gaston_Gonnet "Gaston Gonnet"); this search technology went on to become the basis for the [Open Text Corporation](/wiki/Open_Text_Corporation "Open Text Corporation").[[38]](#cite_note-38) Computer hardware, database and other software, development managers, and programmers for the project were donated by the British subsidiary of [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM"); the colour syntax-directed editor for the project, [LEXX](/wiki/LEXX_(text_editor) "LEXX (text editor)"),[[39]](#cite_note-39) was written by [Mike Cowlishaw](/wiki/Mike_Cowlishaw "Mike Cowlishaw") of IBM.[[40]](#cite_note-40) The [University of Waterloo](/wiki/University_of_Waterloo "University of Waterloo"), in Canada, volunteered to design the database. [A. Walton Litz](/wiki/A._Walton_Litz "A. Walton Litz"), an English professor at [Princeton University](/wiki/Princeton_University "Princeton University") who served on the Oxford University Press advisory council, was quoted in [*Time*](/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)") as saying "I've never been associated with a project, I've never even heard of a project, that was so incredibly complicated and that met every deadline."[[41]](#cite_note-Gray1989-3-27-41)

By 1989, the *NOED* project had achieved its primary goals, and the editors, working online, had successfully combined the original text, Burchfield's supplement, and a small amount of newer material, into a single unified dictionary. The word "new" was again dropped from the name, and the second edition of the *OED*, or the *OED2*, was published. The first edition [retronymically](/wiki/Retronym "Retronym") became the *OED1*.

The *Oxford English Dictionary 2* was printed in 20 volumes.[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1) Up to a very late stage, all the volumes of the first edition were started on initial letter boundaries. For the second edition, there was no attempt to start them on letter boundaries, and they were made roughly equal in size. The 20 volumes started with *A*, *B.B.C.*, *Cham*, *Creel*, *Dvandva*, *Follow*, *Hat*, *Interval*, *Look*, *Moul*, *Ow*, *Poise*, *Quemadero*, *Rob*, *Ser*, *Soot*, *Su*, *Thru*, *Unemancipated*, and *Wave*.

The content of the *OED2* is mostly just a reorganization of the earlier corpus, but the retypesetting provided an opportunity for two long-needed format changes. The [headword](/wiki/Headword "Headword") of each entry was no longer capitalized, allowing the user to readily see those words that actually require a capital letter.[[42]](#cite_note-:1-42) Murray had devised his own notation for pronunciation, there being no standard available at the time, whereas the *OED2* adopted the modern [International Phonetic Alphabet](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet "International Phonetic Alphabet").[[42]](#cite_note-:1-42)[[43]](#cite_note-43) Unlike the earlier edition, all foreign alphabets except Greek were [transliterated](/wiki/Transliteration "Transliteration").[[42]](#cite_note-:1-42)

Following page 832 of Volume XX, *Wave-Zyxt*, there is a 143-page separately paginated bibliography, a conflation of the OED 1st edition's published with the 1933 Supplement and that in Volume IV of the Supplement published in 1986.[[44]](#cite_note-44)

The British quiz show *[Countdown](/wiki/Countdown_(game_show) "Countdown (game show)")* awarded the leather-bound complete version to the [champions of each series](/wiki/List_of_Countdown_champions "List of Countdown champions") between its inception in 1982 and Series 63 in 2010.[[45]](#cite_note-45) The prize was axed[*[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*] after Series 83, completed in June 2021, as it was considered out of date.[[46]](#cite_note-46)

When the print version of the second edition was published in 1989, the response was enthusiastic. Author [Anthony Burgess](/wiki/Anthony_Burgess "Anthony Burgess") declared it "the greatest publishing event of the century", as quoted by the *[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")*.[[47]](#cite_note-47) *Time* dubbed the book "a scholarly [Everest](/wiki/Everest "Everest")",[[41]](#cite_note-Gray1989-3-27-41) and [Richard Boston](/wiki/Richard_Boston "Richard Boston"), writing for *[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")*, called it "one of the [wonders of the world](/wiki/Wonders_of_the_world "Wonders of the world")".[[48]](#cite_note-48)

### Additions series

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Additions series")]

The supplements and their integration into the second edition were a great improvement to the *OED* as a whole, but it was recognized that most of the entries were still fundamentally unaltered from the first edition. Much of the information in the dictionary published in 1989 was already decades out of date, though the supplements had made good progress towards incorporating new vocabulary. Yet many definitions contained disproven scientific theories, outdated historical information, and moral values that were no longer widely accepted.[[49]](#cite_note-:3-49)[[50]](#cite_note-50) Furthermore, the supplements had failed to recognize many words in the existing volumes as obsolete by the time of the second edition's publication, meaning that thousands of words were marked as current despite no recent evidence of their use.[[51]](#cite_note-51)

Accordingly, it was recognized that work on a third edition would have to begin to rectify these problems.[[49]](#cite_note-:3-49) The first attempt to produce a new edition came with the *Oxford English Dictionary Additions Series,* a new set of supplements to complement the *OED2* with the intention of producing a third edition from them.[[52]](#cite_note-:4-52) The previous supplements appeared in alphabetical instalments, whereas the new series had a full A–Z range of entries within each individual volume, with a complete alphabetical index at the end of all words revised so far, each listed with the volume number which contained the revised entry.[[52]](#cite_note-:4-52)

However, in the end only three *Additions* volumes were published this way, two in 1993 and one in 1997,[[53]](#cite_note-53)[[54]](#cite_note-54)[[55]](#cite_note-55) each containing about 3,000 new definitions.[[7]](#cite_note-facts2004-7) The possibilities of the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web") and new computer technology in general meant that the processes of researching the dictionary and of publishing new and revised entries could be vastly improved. New text search databases offered vastly more material for the editors of the dictionary to work with, and with publication on the Web as a possibility, the editors could publish revised entries much more quickly and easily than ever before.[[56]](#cite_note-Simpson2011-56) A new approach was called for, and for this reason it was decided to embark on a new, complete revision of the dictionary.

* *Oxford English Dictionary Additions Series* Volume 1 ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-19-861292-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861292-6 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861292-6")): Includes over 20,000 illustrative quotations showing the evolution of each word or meaning.

:   * ?th impression (1994-02-10)

* *Oxford English Dictionary Additions Series* Volume 2 ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-19-861299-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861299-5 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861299-5"))

:   * ?th impression (1994-02-10)

* *Oxford English Dictionary Additions Series* Volume 3 ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-19-860027-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-860027-5 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-860027-5")): Contains 3,000 new words and meanings from around the English-speaking world. Published by Clarendon Press.

### Third edition

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Third edition")]

Beginning with the launch of the first *OED Online* site in 2000, the editors of the dictionary began a major revision project to create a completely revised third edition of the dictionary (*OED3*), expected to be completed in 2037[[57]](#cite_note-deadline2037-57)[[58]](#cite_note-58)[[59]](#cite_note-59) at a projected cost of circa [£](/wiki/Pounds_sterling "Pounds sterling")34 million.[[60]](#cite_note-OED_History-60)[[1]](#cite_note-Dickson-1)

Revisions were started at the letter *M*, with new material appearing every three months on the *OED Online* website. The editors chose to start the revision project from the middle of the dictionary in order that the overall quality of entries be made more even, since the later entries in the *OED1* generally tended to be better than the earlier ones. However, in March 2008, the editors announced that they would alternate each quarter between moving forward in the alphabet as before and updating "key English words from across the alphabet, along with the other words which make up the alphabetical cluster surrounding them".[[61]](#cite_note-61) With the relaunch of the *OED Online* website in December 2010, alphabetical revision was abandoned altogether.[[62]](#cite_note-62)

The revision is expected roughly to double the dictionary in size.[[4]](#cite_note-Simpson-4)[[63]](#cite_note-:2-63) Apart from general updates to include information on new words and other changes in the language, the third edition brings many other improvements, including changes in formatting and stylistic conventions for easier reading and computerized searching, more etymological information, and a general change of focus away from individual words towards more general coverage of the language as a whole.[[56]](#cite_note-Simpson2011-56)[[64]](#cite_note-64) While the original text drew its quotations mainly from literary sources such as novels, plays, and poetry, with additional material from newspapers and academic journals, the new edition will reference more kinds of material that were unavailable to the editors of previous editions, such as wills, inventories, account books, diaries, journals, and letters.[[63]](#cite_note-:2-63)

[John Simpson](/wiki/John_Simpson_(lexicographer) "John Simpson (lexicographer)") was the first chief editor of the *OED3*. He retired in 2013 and was replaced by [Michael Proffitt](/wiki/Michael_Proffitt "Michael Proffitt"), who is the eighth chief editor of the dictionary.[[65]](#cite_note-65)

The production of the new edition exploits computer technology, particularly since the inauguration in June 2005 of the "Perfect [All-Singing All-Dancing](/wiki/All_singing,_all_dancing_(idiom) "All singing, all dancing (idiom)") [Editorial](/wiki/Text_editor "Text editor") and [Notation](/wiki/Annotation "Annotation") [Application](/wiki/Application_software "Application software")", or "Pasadena". With this [XML](/wiki/XML "XML")-based system, lexicographers can spend less effort on presentation issues such as the numbering of definitions. This system has also simplified the use of the quotations database, and enabled staff in New York to work directly on the dictionary in the same way as their Oxford-based counterparts.[[66]](#cite_note-66)

Other important computer uses include internet searches for evidence of current usage and email submissions of quotations by readers and the general public.[[67]](#cite_note-67)

#### New entries and words

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: New entries and words")]

*Wordhunt* was a 2005 appeal to the general public for help in providing citations for 50 selected recent words, and produced [antedatings](/wiki/Antedating_(lexicography) "Antedating (lexicography)") for many. The results were reported in a BBC TV series, *[Balderdash and Piffle](/wiki/Balderdash_and_Piffle "Balderdash and Piffle")*. The *OED*'s readers contribute quotations: the department currently receives about 200,000 a year.[[68]](#cite_note-68)

*OED* currently contains over 500,000 entries.[[69]](#cite_note-69) The online *OED* is updated on a quarterly basis, with the addition of new words and senses, and the revision of existing entries.[[70]](#cite_note-70)

## Formats

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Formats")]

### Compact editions

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Compact editions")]

In 1971, the 13-volume *OED1* (1933) was reprinted as a two-volume *Compact Edition*, by photographically reducing each page to one-half its linear dimensions; each compact edition page held four *OED1* pages in a [four-up](/wiki/N-up "N-up") ("4-up") format. The two-volume letters were *A* and *P*; the first supplement was at the second volume's end. The *Compact Edition* included, in a small slip-case drawer, a [Bausch & Lomb](/wiki/Bausch_%26_Lomb "Bausch & Lomb") magnifying glass to help in reading reduced type. Many copies were inexpensively distributed through [book clubs](/wiki/Book_sales_club "Book sales club"). In 1987, the second supplement was published as a third volume to the *Compact Edition*.

The 20-volume *OED2* (1989) was republished in 1991 as a compact edition ([ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-19-861258-2](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861258-2 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-861258-2")). The format was re-sized to one-third of original linear dimensions, a nine-up ("9-up") format requiring a stronger magnifying glass (included), but allowing publication of a single-volume dictionary. This version includes definitions of 500,000 words, in 290,000 main entries, with 137,000 pronunciations, 249,300 etymologies, 577,000 cross-references, and 2,412,000 illustrative quotations. It is accompanied by *A User's Guide to the "Oxford English Dictionary"* by Donna Lee Berg.[[71]](#cite_note-71) After this version was published, however, book club offers commonly continued to sell the two-volume 1971 *Compact Edition*.[[26]](#cite_note-Considine-26)

* The *Compact Oxford English Dictionary* (second edition, 1991)
* Part of an entry in the 1991 compact edition, with a centimetre scale showing the very small type sizes used

### Electronic versions

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Electronic versions")]

Once the dictionary was digitized and online, it was also available to be published on [CD-ROM](/wiki/CD-ROM "CD-ROM"). The text of the first edition was made available in 1987.[[72]](#cite_note-72) Afterward, three versions of the second edition were issued. Version 1 (1992) was identical in content to the printed second edition, and the CD itself was not copy-protected. Version 2 (1999) included the *Oxford English Dictionary Additions* of 1993 and 1997. These CD-ROM editions are for [Microsoft Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows") only.

Version 3.0 was released in 2002 with additional words from the *OED3* and software improvements. Version 3.1.1 (2007) added support for hard disk installation, so that the user does not have to insert the CD to use the dictionary. It has been reported that this version will work on operating systems other than Windows, using [emulation programs](/wiki/Emulator "Emulator").[[73]](#cite_note-73)[[74]](#cite_note-74) Version 4.0 of the CD was released in June 2009 and has applications for both Windows (7 and later) and MacOS X (10.4 and later).[[75]](#cite_note-75) This version uses the CD drive for installation, running only from the hard drive.

On 14 March 2000, the *Oxford English Dictionary Online* (*OED Online*) became available to subscribers.[[76]](#cite_note-76) The online database containing the *OED2* is updated quarterly with revisions that will be included in the *OED3* (see above). The online edition is the most up-to-date version of the dictionary available. The *OED* website is not optimized for mobile devices, but the developers have stated that there are plans to provide an API to facilitate the development of interfaces for querying the *OED*.[[77]](#cite_note-77)

The price for an individual to use this edition is £100 or US$100 a year; consequently, most subscribers are large organizations such as universities. Some public libraries and companies have also subscribed, including public libraries in the United Kingdom, where access is funded by the [Arts Council](/wiki/Arts_Council_of_Great_Britain "Arts Council of Great Britain"),[[78]](#cite_note-78) and public libraries in New Zealand.[[79]](#cite_note-79)[[80]](#cite_note-80) Individuals who belong to a library which subscribes to the service are able to use the service from their own homes without charge.

## Relationship to other Oxford dictionaries

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Relationship to other Oxford dictionaries")]

The *OED*'s utility and renown as a historical dictionary have led to numerous offspring projects and other dictionaries bearing the Oxford name, though not all are directly related to the *OED* itself.

The *[Shorter Oxford English Dictionary](/wiki/Shorter_Oxford_English_Dictionary "Shorter Oxford English Dictionary"),* originally started in 1902 and completed in 1933,[[82]](#cite_note-82) is an abridgement of the full work that retains the historical focus, but does not include any words which were obsolete before 1700 except those used by [Shakespeare](/wiki/Shakespeare "Shakespeare"), [Milton](/wiki/John_Milton "John Milton"), [Spenser](/wiki/Edmund_Spenser "Edmund Spenser"), and the [King James Bible](/wiki/King_James_Bible "King James Bible").[[83]](#cite_note-83) A completely new edition was produced from the *OED2* and published in 1993,[[84]](#cite_note-84) with revisions in 2002 and 2007.

The [*Concise Oxford Dictionary*](/wiki/Concise_Oxford_English_Dictionary "Concise Oxford English Dictionary") is a different work, which aims to cover current English only, without the historical focus. The original edition, mostly based on the *OED1*, was edited by [Francis George Fowler](/wiki/Francis_George_Fowler "Francis George Fowler") and [Henry Watson Fowler](/wiki/Henry_Watson_Fowler "Henry Watson Fowler") and published in 1911, before the main work was completed.[[85]](#cite_note-85) Revised editions appeared throughout the twentieth century to keep it up to date with changes in English usage.

*The Pocket Oxford Dictionary of Current English* was originally conceived by F. G. Fowler and H. W. Fowler to be compressed, compact, and concise. Its primary source is the Oxford English Dictionary, and it is nominally an abridgement of the Concise Oxford Dictionary. It was first published in 1924.[[86]](#cite_note-86)

In 1998 the *[New Oxford Dictionary of English](/wiki/New_Oxford_Dictionary_of_English "New Oxford Dictionary of English")* (*NODE*) was published. While also aiming to cover current English, *NODE* was not based on the *OED*. Instead, it was an entirely new dictionary produced with the aid of [corpus linguistics](/wiki/Corpus_linguistics "Corpus linguistics").[[87]](#cite_note-87) Once *NODE* was published, a similarly brand-new edition of the *Concise Oxford Dictionary* followed, this time based on an abridgement of *NODE* rather than the *OED*; *NODE* (under the new title of the *Oxford Dictionary of English*, or *ODE*) continues to be principal source for Oxford's product line of current-English dictionaries, including the *[New Oxford American Dictionary](/wiki/New_Oxford_American_Dictionary "New Oxford American Dictionary")*, with the *OED* now only serving as the basis for scholarly historical dictionaries.

## Spelling

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Spelling")]

Main article: [Oxford spelling](/wiki/Oxford_spelling "Oxford spelling")

The *OED* lists British headword spellings (e.g., *labour*, *centre*) with variants following (*labor*, *center*, etc.). For the suffix more commonly spelt *-ise* in British English, [OUP](/wiki/OUP "OUP") policy dictates a preference for the spelling *-ize*, e.g., *realize* vs. *realise* and *globalization* vs. *globalisation*. The rationale is etymological, in that the English suffix is mainly derived from the Greek suffix *-ιζειν*, (*-izein*), or the Latin *-izāre*.[[88]](#cite_note-88) However, *-ze* is also sometimes treated as an [Americanism](/wiki/American_English#Morphology "American English") insofar as the *-ze* suffix has crept into words where it did not originally belong, as with *analyse* (British English), which is spelt *analyze* in American English.[[89]](#cite_note-89)[[90]](#cite_note-90)

## Reception and criticism

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Reception and criticism")]

British prime minister [Stanley Baldwin](/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin "Stanley Baldwin") described the *OED* as a "national treasure".[[91]](#cite_note-91) Author [Anu Garg](/wiki/Anu_Garg "Anu Garg"), founder of Wordsmith.org, has called it a "lex icon".[[92]](#cite_note-92) [Tim Bray](/wiki/Tim_Bray "Tim Bray"), co-creator of Extensible Markup Language ([XML](/wiki/XML "XML")), credits the *OED* as the developing inspiration of that [markup language](/wiki/Markup_language "Markup language").[[93]](#cite_note-93)

However, despite its claims of authority,[[60]](#cite_note-OED_History-60) the dictionary has been criticized since the 1960s because of its scope, its claims to authority, its British-centredness and relative neglect of World Englishes,[[94]](#cite_note-94) its implied but unacknowledged focus on literary language and, above all, its influence. The *OED*, as a commercial product, has always had to steer a line between scholarship and marketing. In his review of the 1982 supplement,[[95]](#cite_note-95) University of Oxford linguist [Roy Harris](/wiki/Roy_Harris_(linguist) "Roy Harris (linguist)") writes that criticizing the *OED* is extremely difficult because "one is dealing not just with a dictionary but with a national institution", one that "has become, like the English monarchy, virtually immune from criticism in principle". He further notes that [neologisms](/wiki/Neologism "Neologism") from respected "literary" authors such as [Samuel Beckett](/wiki/Samuel_Beckett "Samuel Beckett") and [Virginia Woolf](/wiki/Virginia_Woolf "Virginia Woolf") are included, whereas those found in newspapers or other less "respectable" sources hold less sway, regardless of their usefulness. He writes that the *OED*'s "[b]lack-and-white lexicography is also black-and-white in that it takes it upon itself to pronounce authoritatively on the rights and wrongs of usage", faulting the dictionary's [prescriptive](/wiki/Prescriptive_grammar "Prescriptive grammar") rather than [descriptive](/wiki/Descriptive_grammar "Descriptive grammar") usage.

To Harris, this prescriptive classification of certain usages as "erroneous" and the complete omission of various forms and usages cumulatively represent the "social bias[es]" of the (presumably well-educated and wealthy) compilers. However, the *Guide to the Third Edition of the OED* has stated that "*Oxford English Dictionary* is not an arbiter of proper usage, despite its widespread reputation to the contrary" and that the dictionary "is intended to be descriptive, not prescriptive".[[96]](#cite_note-96) The identification of "erroneous and catachrestic" usages is being removed from third edition entries, sometimes in favour of usage notes describing the attitudes to language which have previously led to these classifications.[[97]](#cite_note-Brewer2005-97) Another avenue of criticism is the dictionary's non-inclusion of [etymologies](/wiki/Etymology "Etymology") for words of [AAVE](/wiki/AAVE "AAVE") or African language origin such as *[jazz](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jazz "wikt:jazz")*, *[dig](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dig#Etymology_2 "wikt:dig")* or *[badmouth](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/badmouth "wikt:badmouth")* (the latter two are possibly of [Wolof](/wiki/Wolof_language "Wolof language") and [Mandinka](/wiki/Mandinka_language "Mandinka language") languages, respectively).[[98]](#cite_note-98)[[99]](#cite_note-99) As of 2022, OUP is preparing a specialized *Oxford Dictionary of African American English* in collaboration with [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University")'s [Hutchins Center for African and African American Research](/wiki/Hutchins_Center_for_African_and_African_American_Research "Hutchins Center for African and African American Research"), with literary critic [Henry Louis Gates Jr.](/wiki/Henry_Louis_Gates_Jr. "Henry Louis Gates Jr.") being the project's editor-in-chief.[[100]](#cite_note-100)[[101]](#cite_note-101)

Harris also faults the editors' "donnish conservatism" and their adherence to prudish [Victorian morals](/wiki/Victorian_morals "Victorian morals"), citing as an example the non-inclusion of "various centuries-old '[four-letter words](/wiki/Four-letter_words "Four-letter words")'" until 1972. However, no English dictionary included such [profanity](/wiki/Profanity "Profanity"), for fear of possible prosecution under British obscenity laws, until after the conclusion of the [*Lady Chatterley's Lover* obscenity trial](/wiki/R_v_Penguin_Books_Ltd. "R v Penguin Books Ltd.") in 1960. The *[Penguin English Dictionary](/wiki/Penguin_English_Dictionary "Penguin English Dictionary")* of 1965 was the first dictionary that included the word *[fuck](/wiki/Fuck "Fuck")*.[[102]](#cite_note-102) [Joseph Wright](/wiki/Joseph_Wright_(linguist) "Joseph Wright (linguist)")'s *English Dialect Dictionary* had included *[shit](/wiki/Shit "Shit")* in 1905.[[103]](#cite_note-103)

The *OED*'s claims of authority have also been questioned by linguists such as Pius ten Hacken, who notes that the dictionary actively strives toward definitiveness and authority but can only achieve those goals in a limited sense, given the difficulties of defining the scope of what it includes.[[104]](#cite_note-104)

Founding editor James Murray was also reluctant to include scientific terms, despite their documentation, unless he felt that they were widely enough used. In 1902, he declined to add the word *[radium](/wiki/Radium "Radium")* to the dictionary.[[105]](#cite_note-105)

## Research using the OED

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Research using the OED")]

The *OED* has been used to support research in fields such as linguistics, psycholinguistics, and psychology. Examples include the extension of word meanings via metaphor,[[106]](#cite_note-106) the evolution of measurement terms like "foot" from concrete to abstract meanings,[[107]](#cite_note-107) and the identification of systematic patterns in [word blends](/wiki/Blend_word "Blend word") (e.g., "brunch" from a blend of "breakfast" and "lunch").[[108]](#cite_note-108)

## The *OED* in popular culture

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Oxford_English_Dictionary&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: The OED in popular culture")]

The 2020 novel *[The Dictionary of Lost Words](/wiki/The_Dictionary_of_Lost_Words "The Dictionary of Lost Words")* by [Pip Williams](/wiki/Pip_Williams_(author) "Pip Williams (author)") centres on the creation of the *OED*, the fictional narrator spending much time in the Scriptorium as a child, the daughter of a fictional widowed lexicographer, and later becoming an assistant there. It has been adapted for the stage, and a television series is planned.[[109]](#cite_note-109)

Appearance

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Tutorial for new editors

Introduction to Wikipedia

**[Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia") is made by [people like **you**](/wiki/Special:RecentChanges "Special:RecentChanges").**

This page takes you through a set of tutorials aimed at *complete newcomers* who wish to contribute. It covers all the basics, and each tutorial takes only a few minutes, so you can become a proficient [Wikipedian](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedians "Wikipedia:Wikipedians") quickly.

**Las Palmas Naval Base**, also known as **Arsenal of Las Palmas**, is a [military base](/wiki/Military_base "Military base") and [arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal "Arsenal") of the [Spanish Navy](/wiki/Spanish_Navy "Spanish Navy") located in the city of [Las Palmas](/wiki/Las_Palmas "Las Palmas"), [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"). It is the largest military base of the Spanish Navy on the [African continent](/wiki/African_continent "African continent").

## History

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Las_Palmas_Naval_Base&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]

In 1922 the Association of Fruit Exporters of Las Palmas began the construction of a dock on the ruins of the Royal Castle of Santa Catalina. During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), because of the continuous presence of warships of the [belligerent](/wiki/Belligerent "Belligerent") countries, the [Spanish State](/wiki/Spanish_State "Spanish State") took the decision to establish a permanent naval base in the [Canary Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands "Canary Islands"). In 1941 it was temporarily expropriated by the [government](/wiki/Government_of_Spain "Government of Spain").

In 1948, the Arsenal of Las Palmas was formally established at the Nuestra Señora del Pino dock, the Air Force's [Seaplane](/wiki/Seaplane "Seaplane") Base. More land was later purchased, allowing the construction of several buildings, named after the first Chief of the Arsenal.

During the 1950s two docks were constructed to accommodate [submarines](/wiki/Submarines "Submarines"). In 2000, the [Spanish Navy Marines Corps](/wiki/Spanish_Navy_Marines "Spanish Navy Marines") of Canaries moved from the Manuel Lois Barracks to the Arsenal, where several buildings were converted to accommodate the necessary offices and storerooms.[[2]](#cite_note-2)

Appearance

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Main help page for Wikipedia

This page provides **help with the most common questions about [Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia")**.

Use the search box below, or browse the **[Help menu](/wiki/Help:Menu "Help:Menu")** or the **[Help directory](/wiki/Help:Directory "Help:Directory")** to search Wikipedia's help pages.

For interactive assistance related to using and editing Wikipedia, see the **[help desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Help_desk "Wikipedia:Help desk")** and the **[Teahouse](/wiki/Wikipedia:TH/Q "Wikipedia:TH/Q")**.

## **Read** or **find** an article

The **[Readers' FAQ](/wiki/Wikipedia:FAQ/Readers "Wikipedia:FAQ/Readers")** and our **[about page](/wiki/Wikipedia:About "Wikipedia:About")** contain the most commonly sought information about Wikipedia.

For simple searches, there is a search bar at the top of every page. Type what you are looking for in the box. Suggested matches will appear in a dropdown list. Select any page in the list to go to that page. Or, select the "Search" button, or press `↵ Enter`, to go to a full search result. For advanced searches, see **[Help:Searching](/wiki/Help:Searching "Help:Searching")**.

There are other ways to browse and explore Wikipedia articles; many can be found at **[Wikipedia:Contents](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contents "Wikipedia:Contents")**. See our **[disclaimer](/wiki/Wikipedia:General_disclaimer "Wikipedia:General disclaimer")** for cautions about Wikipedia's limitations.

For **[mobile access](/wiki/Help:Mobile_access "Help:Mobile access")**, press the [**mobile view**](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Contents) link at the very bottom of every [**desktop view**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Contents) page.

## **Edit** an article

Contributing is easy: see **[how to edit a page](/wiki/Help:Editing "Help:Editing")**. For a quick summary on participating, see **[contributing to Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contributing_to_Wikipedia "Wikipedia:Contributing to Wikipedia")**, and for a friendly tutorial, see **[our introduction](/wiki/Help:Introduction "Help:Introduction")**. For a listing of introductions and tutorials by topic, see **[getting started](/wiki/Help:Getting_started "Help:Getting started")**. The **[Simplified Manual of Style](/wiki/Wikipedia:SMOS "Wikipedia:SMOS")** and **[Cheatsheet](/wiki/Help:Cheatsheet "Help:Cheatsheet")** can remind you of basic [wiki markup](/wiki/Help:Wikitext "Help:Wikitext").

**[Be bold](/wiki/Wikipedia:Be_bold "Wikipedia:Be bold")** in improving articles! When adding facts, please **[provide references](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing/1")** so others may verify them. If you are affiliated with the article subject, please see our **[conflict of interest guideline](/wiki/Wikipedia:Conflict_of_interest "Wikipedia:Conflict of interest")**.

The **[simple guide to vandalism cleanup](/wiki/Help:Simple_guide_to_vandalism_cleanup "Help:Simple guide to vandalism cleanup")** can help you undo malicious edits.

If you're looking for places you can help out, the **[Task Center](/wiki/Wikipedia:Task_Center "Wikipedia:Task Center")** is the place to go, or check out what else is happening at the **[community portal](/wiki/Wikipedia:Community_portal "Wikipedia:Community portal")**. You can practice editing and experiment in a **[sandbox](/wiki/Wikipedia:Sandbox "Wikipedia:Sandbox")**your **[sandbox](/wiki/Special:MyPage/sandbox "Special:MyPage/sandbox")**.

## **Report a problem** with an article

If there is a problem with an article about yourself, a family member, a friend or a colleague, please read **[Biographies of living persons/Help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons/Help "Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons/Help")**.

If you spot a problem with an article, you can fix it directly, by clicking on the "Edit" link at the top of that page. **[See the "edit an article" section of this page](#edit-heading)** for more information.

If you don't feel ready to fix the article yourself, post a message on the article's **[talk page](/wiki/Wikipedia:Talk_page_guidelines "Wikipedia:Talk page guidelines")**. This will bring the matter to the attention of others who work on that article. There is a "Talk" link at the beginning of *every* article page.

You can **[contact us](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us_-_Readers "Wikipedia:Contact us - Readers")**. If it's an article about you or your organization, see **[Contact us – Subjects](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us_-_Subjects "Wikipedia:Contact us - Subjects")**.

## **Create a new article** or **upload media**

Check **[Your first article](/wiki/Wikipedia:Your_first_article "Wikipedia:Your first article")** to see if your topic is appropriate, then the **[Article wizard](/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_wizard "Wikipedia:Article wizard")** will walk you through creating the article.

Once you have created an article, see **[Writing better articles](/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles "Wikipedia:Writing better articles")** for guidance on how to improve it and what to include (like reference **[citations](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")**).

For contributing images, audio or video files, see the **[Introduction to uploading images](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_uploading_images/1 "Help:Introduction to uploading images/1")**. Then the **[Upload wizard](/wiki/Wikipedia:File_Upload_Wizard "Wikipedia:File Upload Wizard")** will guide you through that process.

## **FAQ** and **interactive help**

Answers to common problems can be found at **[frequently asked questions](/wiki/Wikipedia:FAQ "Wikipedia:FAQ")**.

Or check out **[where to ask questions or make comments](/wiki/Wikipedia:Questions "Wikipedia:Questions")**.

New users should seek help at the **[Teahouse](/wiki/Wikipedia:Teahouse "Wikipedia:Teahouse")** if they're having problems while editing Wikipedia.

More complex questions can be posed at the **[Help desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Help_desk "Wikipedia:Help desk")**. Volunteers will respond as soon as they're able.

Or [**ask for help on your talk page**](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:MyTalk&action=edit&section=new&preload=Help:Contents/helpmepreload&preloadtitle=Help+me%21) and a volunteer will visit you there!

You can get live help with editing in the **[help chatroom](/wiki/Wikipedia:IRC_help_disclaimer "Wikipedia:IRC help disclaimer")**.

For help with technical issues, ask at the **[Village pump](/wiki/Wikipedia:Village_pump_(technical) "Wikipedia:Village pump (technical)")**.

## **Factual questions**

If **[searching Wikipedia](/wiki/Special:Search "Special:Search")** has not answered your question (*for example, questions like "Which country has the world's largest fishing fleet?"*), try the **[Reference Desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk "Wikipedia:Reference desk")**. Volunteers there will attempt to answer your questions on any topic, or point you toward the information you need.

## **Directories**

* **[Directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:Directory "Wikipedia:Directory")**: main list of directories and indexes.

### Help related

* **[Help directory](/wiki/Help:Directory "Help:Directory")**: for informative, instructional and consultation pages.
* **[Request directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:Request_directory "Wikipedia:Request directory")**: for services and assistance that can be requested on Wikipedia.

### Protocols and conventions

* **[Policy directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:List_of_policies "Wikipedia:List of policies")**: official policies for "English Wikipedia".
* **[Guideline directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:List_of_guidelines "Wikipedia:List of guidelines")**: official guidelines for "English Wikipedia".
* **[Manual of Style directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Contents "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Contents")**: pages related to the style manual of Wikipedia articles.

### Community related

* **[Departments](/wiki/Wikipedia:Department_directory "Wikipedia:Department directory")**: for the different divisions of Wikipedia.
* **[Editor's index](/wiki/Wikipedia:Editor%27s_index_to_Wikipedia "Wikipedia:Editor's index to Wikipedia")**: for everything an editor needs to know to work on Wikipedia.
* **[Essay directory](/wiki/Wikipedia:Essay_directory "Wikipedia:Essay directory")**: for Wikipedia namespace essays.
* **[Dashboard](/wiki/Wikipedia:Dashboard "Wikipedia:Dashboard")**: for current discussions taking place throughout Wikipedia.
* **[WikiProjects](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Council/Directory "Wikipedia:WikiProject Council/Directory")**: for people who want to work together as a team to improve Wikipedia.

### MediaWiki software

* **[Wikitext](/wiki/Help:Wikitext "Help:Wikitext")**: for the syntax used by Wikipedia to format a page.
* **[HTML](/wiki/Help:HTML_in_wikitext "Help:HTML in wikitext")**: for HTML5 elements, or tags and their attribute.
* **[Templates](/wiki/Wikipedia:Template_index "Wikipedia:Template index")**: for templates used within Wikipedia.

## **Help** by topic

* **[Help Menu](/wiki/Help:Menu "Help:Menu")**: for searching by subject matter.
* **[Navigating Wikipedia](/wiki/Help:Menu/Navigating_Wikipedia "Help:Menu/Navigating Wikipedia")**: for searching and browsing the encyclopedia.
* **[Joining Wikipedia](/wiki/Help:Menu/Joining_Wikipedia "Help:Menu/Joining Wikipedia")**: how to get involved.
* **[Editing Wikipedia](/wiki/Help:Menu/Editing_Wikipedia "Help:Menu/Editing Wikipedia")**: has general help for editors.
* **[Links and references](/wiki/Help:Menu/Links "Help:Menu/Links")**: has help for creating links, or dealing with references
* **[Images and media](/wiki/Help:Menu/Images_and_media "Help:Menu/Images and media")**: how to use images, videos and sound files.
* **[Keeping track of changes](/wiki/Help:Menu/Tracking_changes "Help:Menu/Tracking changes")**: how to track the evolution of a page, or follow a user.
* **[Policies and guidelines](/wiki/Help:Menu/Policies_and_guidelines "Help:Menu/Policies and guidelines")**: for community standards.
* **[Asking questions](/wiki/Help:Menu/Asking_questions "Help:Menu/Asking questions")**: volunteers will attempt to answer.
* **[The Wikipedia community](/wiki/Help:Menu/The_Wikipedia_community "Help:Menu/The Wikipedia community")**: how to submit or debate a proposal.
* **[Resources and lists](/wiki/Help:Menu/Resources_and_lists "Help:Menu/Resources and lists")**: has resources for editors.
* **[Account settings](/wiki/Help:Menu/Account_settings_and_maintenance "Help:Menu/Account settings and maintenance")**: has tips and tools for registered users.
* **[Technical information](/wiki/Help:Menu/Technical_information "Help:Menu/Technical information")**: has tools for advanced users, and troubleshooting.
* **[Site map](/wiki/Help:Menu/Site_map "Help:Menu/Site map")**: is the above thirteen pages on one single page.

## **Tip** of the day

**Troubleshooting Wikipedia's look and feel with skins**

Wikipedia should function and look right in any [web browser](/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser"). However, depending on the layout of an individual page and the [Wikipedia skin](/wiki/Wikipedia:Skin "Wikipedia:Skin") set in your [User preferences](/wiki/Special:Preferences "Special:Preferences"), a page layout might be broken in your browser. If the problem occurs on a single page, edit the page to fix it yourself. If you cannot fix it, put a message on the [Talk page](/wiki/Wikipedia:Talk_page_guidelines "Wikipedia:Talk page guidelines") for the page (a [screenshot](/wiki/Screenshot "Screenshot") always helps!). If the problem occurs on all pages, try a different [skin](/wiki/Wikipedia:Skin "Wikipedia:Skin"). Your browser might have some minor issues. These are listed at [Wikipedia:Browser notes](/wiki/Wikipedia:Browser_notes "Wikipedia:Browser notes").

[Prior tip](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tip_of_the_day/December_28 "Wikipedia:Tip of the day/December 28") – [Tips library](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tips "Wikipedia:Tips") – [Next tip](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tip_of_the_day/December_30 "Wikipedia:Tip of the day/December 30")

Read more:

**[Help:Preferences](/wiki/Help:Preferences "Help:Preferences")**

**[Manual:Gallery of user styles](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Manual:Gallery_of_user_styles "mw:Manual:Gallery of user styles")**

*[Become a Wikipedia tipster](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_tipster "Wikipedia:Wikipedia tipster")* – [Tips library, by subject](/wiki/Wikipedia:Tips "Wikipedia:Tips")

To add this auto-updating daily tip to your user page, use **{{[totd](/wiki/Template:Totd "Template:Totd")}}**

Introduction

[Readers](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us/Readers "Wikipedia:Contact us/Readers")  
 How to report a problem with an article, or find out more information.

[Article subjects](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us/Article_subjects "Wikipedia:Contact us/Article subjects")  
 Problems with articles about you, your company, or somebody you represent.

[Licensing](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us/Licensing "Wikipedia:Contact us/Licensing")  
 How to copy Wikipedia's information, donate your own, or report unlicensed use of your information.

[Donors](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us/Donors "Wikipedia:Contact us/Donors")  
 Find out about the process, how to donate, and information about how your money is spent.

[Press and partnerships](/wiki/Wikipedia:Contact_us/Press_and_partnerships "Wikipedia:Contact us/Press and partnerships")  
 If you're a member of the press looking to contact Wikipedia, or have a business proposal for us.

[Back to main page](/wiki/Wikipedia:Main "Wikipedia:Main")

Thank you for your interest in contacting Wikipedia. Before proceeding, some important disclaimers:

1. **Wikipedia has no central editorial board.** Contributions are made by a large number of volunteers at their own discretion. Edits are neither the responsibility of the [Wikimedia Foundation](https://foundation.wikimedia.org/wiki/Home "wmf:Home") (the organisation that hosts the site) nor of its staff.
2. Generally, the agent who responds to an email request will not make edits on your behalf.
3. Disagreements with content will not be resolved via email. Use the [Edit Request Wizard](/wiki/Wikipedia:Edit_Request_Wizard "Wikipedia:Edit Request Wizard") to propose specific changes to an article.
4. Although Wikipedia was co-founded by [Jimmy Wales](/wiki/Jimmy_Wales "Jimmy Wales"), he is not personally responsible for our content.
5. If you have questions about the *concept* of Wikipedia rather than a specific problem, the [About Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia:About "Wikipedia:About") page may help.
6. If you want to ask other users for help with editing or using Wikipedia, stop by the [Teahouse](/wiki/Wikipedia:Teahouse "Wikipedia:Teahouse"), Wikipedia's [live help channel](/wiki/Wikipedia:IRC_help_disclaimer "Wikipedia:IRC help disclaimer"), or the [help desk](/wiki/Wikipedia:Help_desk "Wikipedia:Help desk") to ask someone for assistance.
7. If you disagree with an article's content, or are involved in a content dispute, see [Dispute resolution](/wiki/Wikipedia:Dispute_resolution "Wikipedia:Dispute resolution").

The links on the left should direct you to how to contact us or resolve problems. If you cannot find your issue listed there, you can email helpful, experienced volunteers at info-enwikimedia.org.

Luke Littler

*   [Luke Littler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luke_Littler "Luke Littler")_(pictured)_ wins **[the PDC World Darts Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_PDC_World_Darts_Championship "2026 PDC World Darts Championship")**.
*   The United States **[strikes targets in Venezuela](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_United_States_strikes_in_Venezuela "2026 United States strikes in Venezuela")** and captures President [Nicolás Maduro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro "Nicolás Maduro").
*   **[A fire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_Crans-Montana_bar_fire "2026 Crans-Montana bar fire")** at a bar during [New Year's Eve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve "New Year's Eve") celebrations in [Crans-Montana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crans-Montana "Crans-Montana"), Switzerland, kills 40 people.
*   Bulgaria **[adopts the euro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgaria_and_the_euro "Bulgaria and the euro")**, becoming the 21st member of the [eurozone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone").
*   Former [prime minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bangladesh "Prime Minister of Bangladesh") of Bangladesh **[Khaleda Zia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khaleda_Zia "Khaleda Zia")** dies at a hospital in [Dhaka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dhaka "Dhaka").

**Armed conflicts and attacks**

    *   Three people are killed and others are wounded in [Aleppo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleppo "Aleppo"), [Syria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syria "Syria"). The [Syrian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syrian_Armed_Forces "Syrian Armed Forces") and the [Syrian Democratic Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syrian_Democratic_Forces "Syrian Democratic Forces") blame each other for the attack. [(Reuters)](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/three-killed-aleppo-attacks-syrian-government-sdf-trade-blame-2026-01-06/)

**International relations**

*   [China–Japan relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93Japan_relations "China–Japan relations")
    *   [2025–2026 China–Japan diplomatic crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025%E2%80%932026_China%E2%80%93Japan_diplomatic_crisis "2025–2026 China–Japan diplomatic crisis")
        *   [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China") tightens [export controls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Export_control "Export control") on [dual-use technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual-use_technology "Dual-use technology") to [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan "Japan"), banning shipments that could support the [Japanese military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces "Japan Self-Defense Forces"), following diplomatic tensions over remarks related to [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan"). *   [Communications in Palestine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications_in_Palestine "Communications in Palestine")
    *   [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel "Israel") authorizes [Palestinian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestine "Palestine")[mobile operators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_network_operator "Mobile network operator")[Jawwal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawwal "Jawwal") and [Ooredoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ooredoo_Palestine "Ooredoo Palestine") to begin upgrading to [4G](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4G "4G") services in the [West Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bank "West Bank") after they sign [management contracts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management_contract "Management contract") with the [Swedish telecommunications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Sweden "Telecommunications in Sweden") firm [Ericsson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ericsson "Ericsson"). A national [state of emergency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency") is declared following the strikes. Fort Tiuna is later evacuated. [Venezuelan vice president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_Venezuela "Vice President of Venezuela")[Delcy Rodríguez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delcy_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Delcy Rodríguez") becomes [acting president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acting_president "Acting president"). *   [Serbia–United States relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Serbia–United States relations"), [United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine")
    *   The [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States "United States") issues a temporary license allowing [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia")'s majority-Russian-owned [Naftna Industrija Srbije](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naftna_Industrija_Srbije "Naftna Industrija Srbije") to resume [refinery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil_refinery "Oil refinery") operations until January 23 despite [sanctions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embargo_of_Russian_oil_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Embargo of Russian oil during the Russo-Ukrainian war") linked to the [Russo-Ukrainian war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)"). [(AFP via _Barron's_)](https://www.barrons.com/news/us-grants-temporary-licence-to-russian-controlled-serbian-oil-firm-nis-serbian-minister-f2fd201d)

*   [United States–Venezuela relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Venezuela_relations "United States–Venezuela relations"), [Operation Southern Spear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Southern_Spear "Operation Southern Spear")
    *   The United States imposes [sanctions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_government_sanctions "United States government sanctions") on four [Venezuelan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuela "Venezuela") companies in the [oil industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Venezuelan_oil_industry "History of the Venezuelan oil industry") and four [oil tankers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil_tanker "Oil tanker"). [(AP)](https://apnews.com/article/sanctions-oil-tankers-venezuela-trump-maduro-9ffee61472d248aafdc9d9bef6195c2e)

**Law and crime**

*   [2025–2026 Iranian protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025%E2%80%932026_Iranian_protests "2025–2026 Iranian protests")
    *   A [Basij](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basij "Basij") officer is killed and 13 others are injured in clashes in [Lordegan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lordegan "Lordegan"), [Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaharmahal_and_Bakhtiari_province "Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari province"), Iran, during demonstrations over [rising living costs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iranian_economic_crisis "Iranian economic crisis"). [(AP)](https://apnews.com/article/iran-protests-economy-israel-us-nuclear-8533eacbc3c502ccc5f5339ae4384399)

*   [2025 deployment of federal forces in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_deployment_of_federal_forces_in_the_United_States "2025 deployment of federal forces in the United States")
    *   [U.S. president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._president "U.S. president")[Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") announces the withdrawal of [National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Guard_(United_States) "National Guard (United States)") troops from [Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), and [Portland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon "Portland, Oregon") after [federal courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the United States") blocked or restricted the deployments. [(AFP via France 24)](https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20251231-trump-says-pulling-national-guard-from-three-cities-for-now)

*   [Deportation in the second Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deportation_in_the_second_Trump_administration "Deportation in the second Trump administration")
    *   [U.S. federal judge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._federal_judge "U.S. federal judge")[Trina Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trina_Thompson "Trina Thompson") of [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Northern_District_of_California "United States District Court for the Northern District of California") blocks the [Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_presidency_of_Donald_Trump "Second presidency of Donald Trump") from ending [temporary protected status](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporary_protected_status "Temporary protected status") for about 89,000 [migrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the United States") from [Honduras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honduras "Honduras"), [Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"), and [Nicaragua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua"), ruling that the terminations may be motivated by [racial hostility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism_in_the_United_States "Racism in the United States"). [(Reuters)](https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/us-judge-blocks-trump-move-end-protected-status-thousands-honduras-nepal-2025-12-31/)

*   At least three [informal miners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informal_miner "Informal miner") are killed in a shooting in [Pataz District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pataz_District "Pataz District"), [Department of La Libertad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Department_of_La_Libertad "Department of La Libertad"), [Peru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peru "Peru"). Two people are arrested. [(Reuters)](https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/three-killed-7-missing-new-years-eve-attack-informal-miners-peru-2026-01-01/)
