From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

(Redirected from [Wikipedia:File Upload Wizard](/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:File_Upload_Wizard&redirect=no "Wikipedia:File Upload Wizard"))

Wikimedia file upload wizard

[Shortcut](/wiki/Wikipedia:Shortcut "Wikipedia:Shortcut")

* [WP:FUW](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:FUW&redirect=no)[WP:FUW](/wiki/Wikipedia:FUW "Wikipedia:FUW")

Thank you for offering to contribute an image or other media file for use on Wikipedia. This wizard will guide you through a questionnaire prompting you for the appropriate copyright and sourcing information for each file. Please ensure you understand [copyright](/wiki/Wikipedia:Copyrights "Wikipedia:Copyrights") and the [image use policy](/wiki/Wikipedia:Image_use_policy "Wikipedia:Image use policy") before proceeding.

[Upload your own or a freely-licensed file](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:UploadWizard "commons:Special:UploadWizard")

Uploads to [Wikimedia Commons](/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikimedia_Commons "Wikipedia:Wikimedia Commons")

[Upload a non-free file](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:File_upload_wizard&withJS=MediaWiki:FileUploadWizard.js&withCSS=MediaWiki:FileUploadWizard.css)

Uploads locally to the English Wikipedia; must comply with the [non-free content](/wiki/Wikipedia:Non-free_content "Wikipedia:Non-free content") criteria

**You do not have JavaScript enabled**

Sorry, in order to use this uploading script, JavaScript must be enabled. You can still use the plain [Special:Upload](/wiki/Special:Upload "Special:Upload") page to upload files to the English Wikipedia without JavaScript.

**You are not currently logged in.**

Sorry, in order to use this uploading script and to upload files, you need to be logged in with your named account. Please **[log in](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:UserLogin&returnto=Wikipedia%3AFile+Upload+Wizard&returntoquery=withJS%3DMediaWiki%253AFileUploadWizard.js)** and then try again.

**Your account has not become confirmed yet.**

Sorry, in order to upload files on the English Wikipedia, you need to have a [confirmed account](/wiki/Wikipedia:AUTOCONFIRM "Wikipedia:AUTOCONFIRM"). Normally, your account will become confirmed automatically once you have made 10 edits and four days have passed since you created it.

You may already be able to upload files on the [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/ "commons:"), but you can't do it on the English Wikipedia just yet. If the file you want to upload has a free license, please go to Commons and upload it there.

**Important note:** if you don't want to wait until you are autoconfirmed, you may ask somebody else to upload a file for you at [Wikipedia:Files for upload](/wiki/Wikipedia:Files_for_upload "Wikipedia:Files for upload").

In very rare cases an administrator may make your account confirmed manually through a request at [Wikipedia:Requests for permissions/Confirmed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Requests_for_permissions/Confirmed "Wikipedia:Requests for permissions/Confirmed").

## Step 1: Choose your file

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| File: | Choose a file from your computer. Maximum file size: 100 MB. Permitted file types: png, gif, jpg, jpeg, xcf, pdf, mid, mp3, mpeg, mpg, ogg, ogv, opus, svg, djvu, tiff, tif, oga, flac, wav, wave, webm, webp. |

## Step 2: Describe your file

|  |
| --- |
| Please provide a clear, descriptive name by which your file will be known on Wikipedia. |
|  | This name must be unique across the whole of Wikipedia, so please make it informative and easy to recognize. It's no problem to use a fairly long name. It may also include spaces, commas and most other punctuation marks. Please also note that file names are case sensitive (with the exception of the first letter). **Good:** "City of London, skyline from London City Hall, Oct 2008.jpg". **Bad**: "Skyline.jpg", "DSC0001234.jpg". |

Sorry, a few special characters and character combinations cannot be used in the filename for technical reasons. This goes especially for **# < > [ ] | : { } /** and **~~~**. Your filename has been modified to avoid these. Please check if it is okay now.

The filename you chose seems to be very short, or overly generic. Please don't use:

* Titles that consist only of very generic descriptive words (e.g. "Sunset.jpg", "Townhall.jpg")
* Titles that consist only of a person's first or last name, when that name is likely to be shared by many others (e.g. "John.jpg", "Miller.jpg")
* Titles that consist of mere numbers, of the kind often produced by digital cameras ("DSC\_001234", "IMGP0345"), or random strings like those sometimes found on the web ("30996951316264l.jpg")

**A file of this name already exists on Commons!**

If you upload your file with this name, you will be masking the existing file and make it inaccessible. Your new file will be displayed everywhere the existing file was previously used.

This should not be done, except in very rare exceptional cases.

Please don't upload your file under this name, unless you seriously know what you are doing. Choose a different name for your new file instead.

If you want to replace the existing file with an uncontroversial, improved version of the same work, please go to Commons and upload it there, not here on the English Wikipedia's local wiki.

**A file of this name already exists.**

If you upload your file with this name, you will be overwriting the existing file. Your new file will be displayed everywhere the existing file was previously used. Please don't do this, unless you have a good reason to:

|  | **No**, I don't want to overwrite the existing file. I will choose a different name for my new file instead. |
|  | **Yes**, I want to overwrite the existing file. My file is merely a new, improved and uncontentious version of the same work. The old description page, including the source and copyright information, will still be correct for the new version and can remain the same. |
|  | **Yes**, I want to overwrite the existing file, and I will use this wizard to add a new description and new source information for it. The previous version was my own, or else I have made sure the previous uploader(s) don't object to this replacement. |

|  |

| Please provide a brief description of the contents of this file. This will be stored and displayed as part of the file description page. It is important that other editors are able to understand what this file is about. |
|  | What does this file show? What is it a photo/diagram/recording of? It will be helpful if you also add a [wikilink](/wiki/Wikipedia:Cheatsheet#Internal_link "Wikipedia:Cheatsheet") to the article where you want to use it. |

Even if you think it would make for a great addition to an article. We really take these copyright rules very seriously on Wikipedia. Note that media is *assumed* to be fully-copyrighted unless shown otherwise; the burden is on the uploader.  In particular, please don't upload:   * any file you simply found on some website, without knowing who its author or copyright owner is. * any file you found somewhere, even if you have good reason to believe it has a copyright owner who would not mind us using it, but you don't have an explicit licensing statement from them. * any file that was released for publicity purposes by its owners but doesn't have a fully-free license for free re-use for all purposes. * any file credited to a commercial image agency, such as Reuters, AP or Getty Images. Such files normally cannot be used even under the "Fair Use" rules, except in rare cases. * any file that is licensed for use exclusively on Wikipedia, or is free except that the free license excludes commercial use.   If you are in any doubt, please ask some experienced editors for advice before uploading. People will be happy to assist you at [Wikipedia:Media copyright questions](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_copyright_questions "Wikipedia:Media copyright questions"). Thank you. |

## Upload in process

Your file is being uploaded.

This might take a minute or two, depending on the size of the file and the speed of your internet connection.

Once uploading is completed, you will find your new file at this link:

## File successfully uploaded

Your file has been uploaded successfully and can now be found here:

**[File:Example.jpg](/wiki/File:Example.jpg "File:Example.jpg")**

Please follow the link and check that the image description page has all the information you meant to include.

If you want to change the description, just go to the image page, click the "edit" tab at the top of the page and edit just as you would edit any other page. Do not go through this upload form again, unless you want to replace the actual file with a new version.

To insert this file into an article, you may want to use code similar to the following:

```
Example.jpg
```

If you wish to make a link to the file in text, without actually showing the image, for instance when discussing the image on a talk page, you can use the following (mark the ":" after the initial brackets!):

```
Example.jpg
```

See [Wikipedia:Picture tutorial](/wiki/Wikipedia:Picture_tutorial "Wikipedia:Picture tutorial") for more detailed help on how to insert and position images in pages.

**English** is a [West Germanic language](/wiki/West_Germanic_languages "West Germanic languages") that emerged in [early medieval England](/wiki/History_of_Anglo-Saxon_England "History of Anglo-Saxon England") and has since become a global [lingua franca](/wiki/Lingua_franca "Lingua franca").[[4]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Routes_of_English-4)[[5]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a6-5)[[6]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWardhaugh201055-6) The namesake of the language is the [Angles](/wiki/Angles_(tribe) "Angles (tribe)"), one of the [Germanic peoples](/wiki/Germanic_peoples "Germanic peoples") who [migrated to Britain](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_settlement_of_Britain "Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain") after the [end of Roman rule](/wiki/End_of_Roman_rule_in_Britain "End of Roman rule in Britain"). English is the [most spoken language](/wiki/List_of_languages_by_total_number_of_speakers "List of languages by total number of speakers") in the world, primarily due to the global influences of the former [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") (succeeded by the [Commonwealth of Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations")) and the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). It is the most widely learned [second language](/wiki/Second_language "Second language") in the world, with more second-language speakers than native speakers. However, English is only the [third-most spoken native language](/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers "List of languages by number of native speakers"), after [Mandarin Chinese](/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese "Mandarin Chinese") and [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language").[[3]](#cite_note-Ethnologue26-3)

English is either the official language, or one of the official languages, in [57 sovereign states and 30 dependent territories](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_where_English_is_an_official_language "List of countries and territories where English is an official language"), making it the most geographically widespread language in the world. In the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the United States, [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), and [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), it is the dominant language for historical reasons without being explicitly defined by law.[[7]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b108–109-7) It is a [co-official language of the United Nations](/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations "Official languages of the United Nations"), the [European Union](/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union "Languages of the European Union"), and many other international and regional organisations. It has also become the [de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto") lingua franca of diplomacy, [science](/wiki/Languages_of_science "Languages of science"), technology, international trade, [logistics](/wiki/Logistics "Logistics"), tourism, aviation, entertainment, and the [Internet](/wiki/Languages_used_on_the_Internet "Languages used on the Internet").[[8]](#cite_note-8) *[Ethnologue](/wiki/Ethnologue "Ethnologue")* estimated that there were over 1.4 billion speakers worldwide as of 2021[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=English_language&action=edit).[[3]](#cite_note-Ethnologue26-3)

[Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") emerged from a group of West Germanic dialects spoken by the [Anglo-Saxons](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons"). Early inscriptions were written with [runes](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_runes "Anglo-Saxon runes") before a [Latin-based alphabet](/wiki/Old_English_Latin_alphabet "Old English Latin alphabet") was adopted for longer texts. Late Old English borrowed some grammar and core vocabulary from [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse "Old Norse"), a [North Germanic language](/wiki/North_Germanic_languages "North Germanic languages").[[9]](#cite_note-Finkenstaedt1973-9)[[10]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBammesberger199230-10)[[11]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech200639-11) An evolution of the Latin alphabet, the [English alphabet](/wiki/English_alphabet "English alphabet"), fully supplanted the runic alphabet by the [High Middle Ages](/wiki/High_Middle_Ages "High Middle Ages"), coinciding with the emergence of [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English") in [England under Norman control](/wiki/England_in_the_High_Middle_Ages "England in the High Middle Ages"). Middle English borrowed vocabulary extensively from [French dialects](/wiki/Langues_d%27o%C3%AFl "Langues d'oïl"), which are the source of approximately [28 per cent of Modern English words](/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_French_origin "List of English words of French origin"), and from [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"), which is [the source of an additional 28 per cent](/wiki/List_of_Latin_words_with_English_derivatives "List of Latin words with English derivatives").[[12]](#cite_note-12) While Latin and the [Romance languages](/wiki/Romance_languages "Romance languages") are thus the source for a majority of its lexicon taken as a whole, [English's grammar](/wiki/English_grammar "English grammar") and [phonology](/wiki/English_phonology "English phonology") remain Germanic, as does most of its basic everyday vocabulary. Finally, Middle English transformed, in part through the [Great Vowel Shift](/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift "Great Vowel Shift"), into [Modern English](/wiki/Modern_English "Modern English"), which exists on a [dialect continuum](/wiki/Dialect_continuum "Dialect continuum") with [Scots](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language"); it is next-most closely related to [Low Saxon](/wiki/Low_German "Low German") and [Frisian](/wiki/Frisian_languages "Frisian languages").

## Classification

English is a member of the [Indo-European language family](/wiki/Indo-European_language_family "Indo-European language family"), belonging to the [West Germanic](/wiki/West_Germanic "West Germanic") branch of [Germanic languages](/wiki/Germanic_languages "Germanic languages").[[13]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBammesberger199229–30-13) Owing to their descent from a shared ancestor language known as *[Proto-Germanic](/wiki/Proto-Germanic "Proto-Germanic")*, English and other Germanic languages – which include [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language"), [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"), and [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language")[[14]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDurrell2006-14) – have characteristic features in common, including a division of verbs into [strong](/wiki/Germanic_strong_verb "Germanic strong verb") and [weak](/wiki/Germanic_weak_verb "Germanic weak verb") classes, the use of [modal verbs](/wiki/Modal_verb "Modal verb"), and sound changes affecting [Proto-Indo-European](/wiki/Proto-Indo-European "Proto-Indo-European") consonants known as [Grimm's](/wiki/Grimm%27s_law "Grimm's law") and [Verner's laws](/wiki/Verner%27s_law "Verner's law").[[15]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönigvan_der_Auwera1994-15)

[Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") was one of several [Ingvaeonic languages](/wiki/Ingvaeonic_languages "Ingvaeonic languages"), which emerged from a [dialect continuum](/wiki/Dialect_continuum "Dialect continuum") spoken by West Germanic peoples during the 5th century in [Frisia](/wiki/Frisia "Frisia"), on the coast of the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea"). Old English emerged among the Ingvaeonic speakers on the [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles") following their migration there, while the other Ingvaeonic languages ([Frisian](/wiki/Frisian_languages "Frisian languages") and [Old Low German](/wiki/Old_Low_German "Old Low German")) developed in parallel on the continent.[[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBazelmans2009325–326-16) Old English evolved into [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English"), which in turn evolved into Modern English.[[17]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinson1992-17) Particular dialects of Old and Middle English also developed into other [Anglic languages](/wiki/Anglic_languages "Anglic languages"), including [Scots](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language")[[18]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine198256–65-18) and the extinct [Fingallian](/wiki/Fingallian "Fingallian") and [Yola dialects](/wiki/Yola_dialect "Yola dialect") of Ireland.[[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarry198286–87-19)

English was isolated from other Germanic languages on the continent and diverged considerably in [vocabulary](/wiki/Lexis_(linguistics) "Lexis (linguistics)"), [syntax](/wiki/Syntax "Syntax"), and [phonology](/wiki/Phonology "Phonology") as a result. It is not [mutually intelligible](/wiki/Mutually_intelligible "Mutually intelligible") with any continental Germanic language – though some, such as Dutch and Frisian, show strong affinities with it, especially in its earlier stages.[[20]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarbert2006-20)[*[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*] English and Frisian [were traditionally considered more closely related to one another](/wiki/Anglo-Frisian_languages "Anglo-Frisian languages") than they were to other West Germanic languages, but most modern scholarship does not recognise a particular affinity between them.[[21]](#cite_note-21) Though they exhibited similar sound changes not otherwise found around the North Sea at that time, the specific changes appeared in English and Frisian at different times – a pattern uncharacteristic for languages sharing a unique phylogenetic ancestor.[[22]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVersloot2017341–342-22)[[23]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStiles20185–6-23)

## History

Main article: [History of English](/wiki/History_of_English "History of English")

### Proto-Germanic to Old English

[Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") (also called *Anglo-Saxon*) was the earliest form of the English language, spoken from c. 450 to c. 1150. Old English developed from a set of [West Germanic](/wiki/West_Germanic "West Germanic") dialects, sometimes identified as [Anglo-Frisian](/wiki/Anglo-Frisian "Anglo-Frisian") or [North Sea Germanic](/wiki/North_Sea_Germanic "North Sea Germanic"), that were originally spoken along the coasts of [Frisia](/wiki/Frisia "Frisia"), Lower Saxony and southern [Jutland](/wiki/Jutland "Jutland") by Germanic peoples known to the historical record as the [Angles](/wiki/Angles_(tribe) "Angles (tribe)"), [Saxons](/wiki/Saxons "Saxons"), and [Jutes](/wiki/Jutes "Jutes").[[25]](#cite_note-25) From the 5th century, the Anglo-Saxons [settled Britain](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_settlement_of_Britain "Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain") as [the Roman economy and administration collapsed](/wiki/End_of_Roman_rule_in_Britain "End of Roman rule in Britain"). By the 7th century, Old English [had become dominant in Britain](/wiki/Celtic_language_decline_in_England "Celtic language decline in England") – replacing the [Common Brittonic](/wiki/Common_Brittonic "Common Brittonic") and [British Latin](/wiki/British_Latin "British Latin") previously spoken during the [Roman occupation](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain"),[[26]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollingwoodMyres1936-26)[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddolLeithSwann_et_al.2007-27)[[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlenchSpriggs1999-28) which ultimately left little influence on English. *England* and *English* (originally *Ænglaland* and *Ænglisc*) are both named after the Angles.[[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBosworthToller1921-29)

Old English was divided into two Anglian dialects ([Mercian](/wiki/Mercian_dialect "Mercian dialect") and [Northumbrian](/wiki/Northumbrian_Old_English "Northumbrian Old English")) and two Saxon dialects ([Kentish](/wiki/Kentish_Old_English "Kentish Old English") and [West Saxon](/wiki/West_Saxon_dialect "West Saxon dialect")).[[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell19594-30) Through the influence exerted by the kingdom of [Wessex](/wiki/Wessex "Wessex"), and the educational reforms instated by [King Alfred](/wiki/King_Alfred "King Alfred") during the 9th century, the West Saxon dialect became the [standard written variety](/wiki/Standard_language "Standard language").[[31]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEToon1992Chapter:_Old_English_Dialects-31) The epic poem *[Beowulf](/wiki/Beowulf "Beowulf")* is written in West Saxon, and the earliest English poem, *[Cædmon's Hymn](/wiki/C%C3%A6dmon%27s_Hymn "Cædmon's Hymn")*, is written in Northumbrian.[[32]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonoghue2008-32) Modern English developed mainly from Mercian, but the [Scots language](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language") developed from Northumbrian. During the earliest period of Old English, a few short inscriptions were made using a [runic alphabet](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_runes "Anglo-Saxon runes").[[33]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGneuss201323-33) By the 7th century, a [Latin alphabet](/wiki/Old_English_Latin_alphabet "Old English Latin alphabet") had been adopted. Written with [half-uncial](/wiki/Half-uncial "Half-uncial") [letterforms](/wiki/Letterform "Letterform"), it included the runic letters *[wynn](/wiki/Wynn "Wynn")* ⟨*ƿ*⟩ and *[thorn](/wiki/Thorn_(letter) "Thorn (letter)")* ⟨*þ*⟩, and the modified Latin letters *[eth](/wiki/Eth "Eth")* ⟨*ð*⟩, and *[ash](/wiki/%C3%86 "Æ")* ⟨*æ*⟩.[[33]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGneuss201323-33)[[34]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoggDenison2006a30–31-34)

Old English is markedly different from Modern English, such that 21st-century English speakers are entirely unable to understand Old English without special training. Its grammar was similar to that of modern German: [nouns, adjectives, pronouns, and verbs](/wiki/Old_English_grammar "Old English grammar") had many more [inflectional endings and forms](/wiki/Inflectional_morphology "Inflectional morphology"), and word order was [much freer](/wiki/Free_word_order "Free word order") than in Modern English. Modern English has [case forms](/wiki/Grammatical_case "Grammatical case") in pronouns (*he*, *him*, *his*) and has a few verb inflections (*speak*, *speaks*, *speaking*, *spoke*, *spoken*), but Old English had case endings in nouns as well, and verbs had more [person](/wiki/Grammatical_person "Grammatical person") and [number](/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical number") endings.[[35]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHogg1992a-35)[[36]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2009-36)[[37]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrask2010-37)

### Influence of Old Norse

Between the 8th and 11th centuries, the English spoken in some regions [underwent significant changes](/wiki/Middle_English#Transition_from_Old_English "Middle English") due to contact with [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse "Old Norse"), a [North Germanic](/wiki/North_Germanic "North Germanic") language. Several waves of Norsemen colonising the northern British Isles in the 8th and 9th centuries put Old English speakers in constant contact with Old Norse. Norse influence was strongest in the north-eastern varieties of Old English spoken in the [Danelaw](/wiki/Danelaw "Danelaw") surrounding York; today these features are still particularly present in Scots and [Northern English](/wiki/English_language_in_Northern_England "English language in Northern England"). The centre of Norse influence was [Lindsey](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lindsey "Kingdom of Lindsey"), located in the [Midlands](/wiki/Midlands "Midlands"). After Lindsey was incorporated into the Anglo-Saxon polity in 920, English spread extensively throughout the region. An element of Norse influence that continues in all English varieties today is the third person pronoun group beginning with *th-* (*they*, *them*, *their*) which replaced the Anglo-Saxon pronouns with *h-* (*hie, him, hera*).[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomasonKaufman1988284–290-38)

Other [Norse loanwords](/wiki/List_of_English_words_of_Old_Norse_origin "List of English words of Old Norse origin") include *give*, *get*, *sky*, *skirt*, *egg*, and *cake*, typically displacing a native Anglo-Saxon equivalent. Old Norse in this era retained considerable mutual intelligibility with some dialects of Old English, particularly northern ones.[[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKastovsky1992320,_332-39)

### Middle English

Further information: [Influence of French on English](/wiki/Influence_of_French_on_English "Influence of French on English")

> *Englischmen þeyz hy hadde fram þe bygynnyng þre manner speche, Souþeron, Northeron, and Myddel speche in þe myddel of þe lond, ... Noþeles by comyxstion and mellyng, furst wiþ Danes, and afterward wiþ Normans, in menye þe contray longage ys asperyed, and som vseþ strange wlaffyng, chyteryng, harryng, and garryng grisbytting.*
>
> [Although, from the beginning, Englishmen had three manners of speaking, southern, northern and midlands speech in the middle of the country, ... Nevertheless, through intermingling and mixing, first with Danes and then with Normans, amongst many the country language has arisen, and some use strange stammering, chattering, snarling, and grating gnashing.]

[John Trevisa](/wiki/John_Trevisa "John Trevisa"), c. 1385[[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHogg2006360–361-40)

The [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English") period is often defined as beginning with the [Norman Conquest](/wiki/Norman_Conquest "Norman Conquest") in 1066. During the centuries that followed, English was heavily influenced by the form of [Old French](/wiki/Old_French "Old French") spoken by the new Norman ruling class that had migrated to England (known as [Old Norman](/wiki/Old_Norman "Old Norman")). Over the following decades of contact, members of the middle and upper classes, whether native English or Norman, became increasingly bilingual. By 1150 at the latest, bilingual speakers represented a majority of the English aristocracy, and monolingual French speakers were nearly non-existent.[[41]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETownend201281–82-41) The French spoken by the Norman elite in England eventually developed into the [Anglo-Norman language](/wiki/Anglo-Norman_language "Anglo-Norman language").[[42]](#cite_note-42) The division between Old to Middle English can also be placed during the composition of the *[Ormulum](/wiki/Ormulum "Ormulum")* (c. late 12th century), a work by the [Augustinian](/wiki/Augustinians "Augustinians") canon [Orrm](/wiki/Orrm "Orrm") which highlights blending of Old English and Anglo-Norman elements in the language for the first time.[[43]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETownend201299–100-43)[[44]](#cite_note-44)

As the lower classes, who represented the vast majority of the population, remained monolingual English speakers, a primary influence of Norman was as a lexical superstratum, introducing a wide range of [loanwords](/wiki/Loanword "Loanword") related to politics, legislation and prestigious social domains.[[11]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech200639-11) For instance, the French word *trône* appears for the first time, from which the English word *throne* is derived.[[45]](#cite_note-45) Middle English also greatly simplified the inflectional system, probably in order to reconcile Old Norse and Old English, which were inflectionally different but morphologically similar. The distinction between nominative and accusative cases was lost except in personal pronouns, the instrumental case was dropped, and the use of the genitive case was limited to indicating [possession](/wiki/Possession_(linguistics) "Possession (linguistics)"). The inflectional system regularised many irregular inflectional forms,[[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass1992103–123-46) and gradually simplified the system of agreement, making word order less flexible.[[47]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischervan_der_Wurff2006111–113-47)

Middle English literature includes [Geoffrey Chaucer](/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer "Geoffrey Chaucer")'s *[Canterbury Tales](/wiki/Canterbury_Tales "Canterbury Tales")* (c. 1400), and [Thomas Malory](/wiki/Thomas_Malory "Thomas Malory")'s **[Le Morte d'Arthur](/wiki/Le_Morte_d%27Arthur "Le Morte d'Arthur")** (1485). In the Middle English period, the use of regional dialects in writing proliferated, and dialect traits were even used for effect by authors such as Chaucer.[[48]](#cite_note-48) In [the first translation](/wiki/Wycliffe%27s_Bible "Wycliffe's Bible") of the entire Bible into English by [John Wycliffe](/wiki/John_Wycliffe "John Wycliffe") (1382), Matthew 8:20 reads: "Foxis han dennes, and briddis of heuene han nestis."[[49]](#cite_note-49) Here the plural suffix *-n* on the verb *have* is still retained, but none of the case endings on the nouns are present.

### Early Modern English

The period of [Early Modern English](/wiki/Early_Modern_English "Early Modern English"), lasting between 1500 and 1700, was characterised by the [Great Vowel Shift](/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift "Great Vowel Shift") (1350–1700), inflectional simplification, and linguistic standardisation. The Great Vowel Shift affected the stressed long vowels of Middle English. It was a [chain shift](/wiki/Chain_shift "Chain shift"), meaning that each shift triggered a subsequent shift in the vowel system. [Mid](/wiki/Mid_vowel "Mid vowel") and [open vowels](/wiki/Open_vowel "Open vowel") were [raised](/wiki/Raising_(sound_change) "Raising (sound change)"), and [close vowels](/wiki/Close_vowel "Close vowel") were [broken](/wiki/Vowel_breaking "Vowel breaking") into [diphthongs](/wiki/Diphthong "Diphthong"). For example, the word *bite* was originally pronounced as the word *beet* is today, and the second vowel in the word *about* was pronounced as the word *boot* is today. The Great Vowel Shift explains many irregularities in spelling since English retains many spellings from Middle English, and it also explains why English vowel letters have very different pronunciations from the same letters in other languages.[[50]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass2000a-50)[[51]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGörlach199166–70-51)

English began to rise in prestige, relative to Norman French, during the reign of [Henry V](/wiki/Henry_V_of_England "Henry V of England"). Around 1430, the [Court of Chancery](/wiki/Court_of_Chancery "Court of Chancery") in [Westminster](/wiki/Westminster "Westminster") began using English in its [official documents](/wiki/Writ "Writ"), and a new standard form of Middle English, known as [Chancery Standard](/wiki/Chancery_Standard "Chancery Standard"), developed from the dialects of London and the [East Midlands](/wiki/East_Midlands_English "East Midlands English"). In 1476, [William Caxton](/wiki/William_Caxton "William Caxton") introduced the [printing press](/wiki/Printing_press "Printing press") to England and began publishing the first printed books in London, expanding the influence of this form of English.[[52]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevalainenTieken-Boon_van_Ostade2006274–279-52)

Literature in Early Modern English includes the works of [William Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare") and the 1611 [King James Version](/wiki/King_James_Version "King James Version") (KJV) of the Bible. Even after the vowel shift the language still sounded different from Modern English: for example, the [consonant clusters](/wiki/Consonant_cluster "Consonant cluster") /kn ɡn sw/ in *knight*, *gnat*, and *sword* were still pronounced. Many of the grammatical features that a modern reader of Shakespeare might find quaint or archaic represent the distinct characteristics of Early Modern English.[[53]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECercignani1981-53) Matthew 8:20 in the KJV reads: "The Foxes have holes and the birds of the ayre have nests."[[54]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass200646–47-54) This exemplifies the loss of case and its effects on sentence structure (replacement with subject–verb–object word order, and the use of *of* instead of the non-possessive genitive), and the introduction of loanwords from French (*ayre*) and word replacements (*bird*, originally meaning 'nestling', which had replaced Old English *fugol*).[[54]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass200646–47-54)

### Spread of Modern English

By the late 18th century, the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") had spread English through its colonies and geopolitical dominance. Commerce, science and technology, diplomacy, art, and formal education all contributed to English becoming the first truly global language. English also facilitated worldwide international communication.[[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHow_English_evolved_into_a_global_language2010-55)[[4]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Routes_of_English-4) English was adopted in parts of North America, parts of Africa, Oceania, and many other regions. When they obtained political independence, some of the newly independent states that had multiple [indigenous languages](/wiki/Indigenous_language "Indigenous language") opted to continue using English as the official language to avoid the political and other difficulties inherent in promoting any one indigenous language above the others.[[56]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine2006586-56)[[57]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMufwene2006614-57)[[58]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup201381–86-58) In the 20th century the growing economic and cultural influence of the United States and its status as a superpower following the Second World War has, along with worldwide broadcasting in English by the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")[[59]](#cite_note-59) and other broadcasters, caused the language to spread across the planet much faster.[[60]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-60)[[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-61) In the 21st century, English is more widely spoken and written than any language has ever been.[[62]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCrumMacNeilCran20039–10-62)

As Modern English developed, explicit norms for standard usage were published, and spread through official media such as public education and state-sponsored publications. In 1755, [Samuel Johnson](/wiki/Samuel_Johnson "Samuel Johnson") published his *[Dictionary of the English Language](/wiki/Dictionary_of_the_English_Language "Dictionary of the English Language")*, which introduced standard spellings of words and usage norms. In 1828, [Noah Webster](/wiki/Noah_Webster "Noah Webster") published the *[American Dictionary of the English language](/wiki/Webster%27s_Dictionary "Webster's Dictionary")* to try to establish a norm for speaking and writing American English that was independent of the British standard. Within Britain, non-standard or lower class dialect features were increasingly stigmatised, leading to the quick spread of the prestige varieties among the middle classes.[[63]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1999a-63)

In modern English, the loss of grammatical case is almost complete (it is now found only in pronouns, such as *he* and *him*, *she* and *her*, *who* and *whom*), and [subject–verb–object word order](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object_word_order "Subject–verb–object word order") is mostly fixed.[[63]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1999a-63) Some changes, such as the use of [*do*-support](/wiki/Do-support "Do-support"), have become universalised. (Earlier English did not use the word *do* as a general auxiliary as Modern English does; at first it was only used in question constructions, and even then was not obligatory.[[64]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1999a2) Now, *do*-support with the verb *have* is becoming increasingly standardised.) The use of progressive forms in *-ing*, appears to be spreading to new constructions, and forms such as "had been being built" are becoming more common. Regularisation of irregular forms also slowly continues (e.g. *dreamed* instead of *dreamt*), and analytical alternatives to inflectional forms are becoming more common (e.g. *more polite* instead of *politer*). British English is also undergoing change under the influence of American English, fuelled by the strong presence of American English in the media.[[65]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeechHundtMairSmith200918–19-65)[[66]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMairLeech2006-66)[[67]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair2006-67)

## Geographical distribution

See also: [List of countries and territories where English is an official language](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_where_English_is_an_official_language "List of countries and territories where English is an official language"), [List of countries by English-speaking population](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_English-speaking_population "List of countries by English-speaking population"), and [English-speaking world](/wiki/English-speaking_world "English-speaking world")

As of 2016[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=English_language&action=edit), 400 million people spoke English as their [first language](/wiki/First_language "First language"), and 1.1 billion spoke it as a second language.[[69]](#cite_note-69) English is the [largest language by number of speakers](/wiki/List_of_languages_by_total_number_of_speakers "List of languages by total number of speakers"), spoken by communities on every continent.[[70]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b106-70) Estimates of [second language](/wiki/Second_language "Second language") and foreign-language speakers vary greatly depending on how proficiency is defined, from 470 million to more than 1 billion.[[7]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b108–109-7) In 2003, [David Crystal](/wiki/David_Crystal "David Crystal") estimated that non-native speakers outnumbered native speakers by a ratio of three-to-one.[[71]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a69-71)

### Three circles model

[Braj Kachru](/wiki/Braj_Kachru "Braj Kachru") has categorised countries into the [Three Circles of English](/wiki/Three_Circles_of_English "Three Circles of English")  model, according to how the language historically spread in each country, how it is acquired by the populace, and the range of uses it has there – with a country's classification able to change over time.[[72]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006196-72)[[73]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech20062-73)

"Inner-circle" countries have large communities of native English speakers; these include the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, Canada, Ireland, and New Zealand, where the majority speaks English – and South Africa, where a significant minority speaks English. The countries with the most native English speakers are, in descending order, the United States (at least 231 million),[[74]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2013Table_1-74) the United Kingdom (60 million),[[75]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOffice_for_National_Statistics2013Key_Points-75)[[76]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Records_of_Scotland2013-76)[[77]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthern_Ireland_Statistics_and_Research_Agency2012Table_KS207NI:_Main_Language-77) Canada (19 million),[[78]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_Canada2014-78) Australia (at least 17 million),[[79]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAustralian_Bureau_of_Statistics2013-79) South Africa (4.8 million),[[80]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_South_Africa2012Table_2.5_Population_by_first_language_spoken_and_province_(number)-80) Ireland (4.2 million), and New Zealand (3.7 million).[[81]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_New_Zealand2014-81) In these countries, children of native speakers learn English from their parents, and local people who speak other languages and new immigrants learn English to communicate in their neighbourhoods and workplaces.[[82]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-82) Inner-circle countries are the base from which English spreads to other regions of the world.[[72]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006196-72)

"Outer-circle" countries – such as the Philippines,[[83]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERubino2006-83) Jamaica,[[84]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPatrick2006a-84) India, Pakistan, Singapore,[[85]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELimAnsaldo2006-85) Malaysia, and Nigeria[[86]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConnell2006-86)[[87]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchneider2007-87) – have much smaller proportions of native English speakers, but use of English as a second language in education, government, or domestic business is significant, and its use for instruction in schools and official government operations is routine.[[88]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085-88) These countries have millions of native speakers on dialect continua, which range from [English-based creole languages](/wiki/English-based_creole_languages "English-based creole languages") to standard varieties of English used in inner-circle countries. They have many more speakers who acquire English as they grow up through day-to-day use and exposure to English-language broadcasting, especially if they attend schools where English is the language of instruction. Varieties of English learned by non-native speakers born to English-speaking parents may be influenced, especially in their grammar, by the other languages spoken by those learners – with most including words rarely used by native speakers in inner-circle countries, as well as grammatical and phonological differences from inner-circle varieties.[[82]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-82)

"Expanding-circle" countries are where English is taught as a foreign language[[89]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20084-89) – though the character of English as a first, second, or foreign language in a given country is often debatable, and may change over time.[[88]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085-88) For example, in countries like the Netherlands, an overwhelming majority of the population can speak English,[[90]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropean_Commission2012-90) and it is often used in higher education and to communicate with foreigners.[[91]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006197-91)

### Pluricentric English

English is a [pluricentric language](/wiki/Pluricentric_language "Pluricentric language"), which means that no one national authority sets the standard for use of the language.[[92]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20082-92)[[93]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1999-93)[[94]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaughCable2002-94)[[95]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20088–9-95) Spoken English, including English used in broadcasting, generally follows national pronunciation standards that are established by custom rather than by regulation. International broadcasters are usually identifiable as coming from one country rather than another through their [accents](/wiki/Accent_(sociolinguistics) "Accent (sociolinguistics)"),[[96]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill2006-96) but newsreader scripts are also composed largely in international [standard written English](/wiki/Standard_written_English "Standard written English"). The norms of standard written English are maintained purely by the consensus of educated English speakers around the world, without any oversight by any government or international organisation.[[97]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmmon20081537–1539-97)

American listeners readily understand most British broadcasting, and British listeners readily understand most American broadcasting. Most English speakers around the world can understand radio programmes, television programmes, and films from many parts of the [English-speaking world](/wiki/English-speaking_world "English-speaking world").[[98]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech2006122-98) Both standard and non-standard varieties of English can include both formal or informal styles, distinguished by word choice and syntax and use both technical and non-technical registers.[[99]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085–6-99)

The settlement history of the English-speaking inner circle countries outside Britain helped level dialect distinctions and produce [koiné](/wiki/Koin%C3%A9 "Koiné") forms of English in South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand.[[100]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeumert2006130-100) The majority of immigrants to the United States without British ancestry rapidly adopted English after arrival. Now the majority of the United States population are monolingual English speakers.[[74]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2013Table_1-74)[[101]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeumert2006131-101)

* Australia has no official languages at the federal or state level.[[102]](#cite_note-102)
* In Canada, English and French share an [official status](/wiki/Official_Languages_Act_(Canada) "Official Languages Act (Canada)") at the federal level.[[103]](#cite_note-103)[[104]](#cite_note-104) English has official or co-official status in six provinces and three territories, while three provinces have none and Quebec's only official language is French.[[105]](#cite_note-105)
* English is the official second language of Ireland, while Irish is the first.[[106]](#cite_note-106)
* While New Zealand is majority English-speaking, its two official languages are [Māori](/wiki/Maori_Language_Act_1987 "Maori Language Act 1987")[[107]](#cite_note-107) and [New Zealand Sign Language](/wiki/New_Zealand_Sign_Language#Official_language_status "New Zealand Sign Language").[[108]](#cite_note-108)
* The United Kingdom does not have an official language. In Wales and Northern Ireland, English is co-official alongside [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_Language_Act_1993 "Welsh Language Act 1993")[[109]](#cite_note-109) and [Irish](/wiki/Identity_and_Language_(Northern_Ireland)_Act_2022 "Identity and Language (Northern Ireland) Act 2022")[[110]](#cite_note-110) respectively. Neither Scotland nor England have an official language.
* In the United States, English was designated the official language of the country by [Executive Order 14224](/wiki/Executive_Order_14224 "Executive Order 14224") in 2025.[[111]](#cite_note-111) English has additional official or co-official status at the state level in 32 states, and all 5 territories;[[112]](#cite_note-112) 18 states and the District of Columbia have no official language.

### English as a global language

Main article: [English as a lingua franca](/wiki/English_as_a_lingua_franca "English as a lingua franca")

See also: [Foreign-language influences in English](/wiki/Foreign-language_influences_in_English "Foreign-language influences in English") and [Study of global communication](/wiki/Study_of_global_communication "Study of global communication")

Modern English is sometimes described as the first global [lingua franca](/wiki/Lingua_franca "Lingua franca"),[[60]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-60)[[115]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeierkord2006165-115) or as the first [world language](/wiki/World_language "World language").[[116]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006690–691-116)[[117]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup2013-117) English is the world's most widely used language in newspaper publishing, book publishing, international telecommunications, scientific publishing, international trade, mass entertainment, and diplomacy.[[117]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup2013-117) Parity with French as a language of diplomacy had been achieved by [Treaty of Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") negotiations in 1919.[[118]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillipson200447-118) By the time the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") was founded at the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), English had become pre-eminent;[[119]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConradRubal-Lopez1996261-119) it is one of six official languages of the United Nations.[[120]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations2010-120) and is now the main worldwide language of diplomacy and international relations.[[121]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichter201229-121) Many other worldwide international organisations, including the [International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee"), specify English as a working language or official language of the organisation. Many regional international organisations, such as the [European Free Trade Association](/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association "European Free Trade Association") (EFTA), [Association of Southeast Asian Nations](/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations "Association of Southeast Asian Nations") (ASEAN),[[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-61) and [Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation](/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation "Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation") (APEC) use English as their sole working language, despite most members not being countries with a majority of native English speakers. While the EU allows member states to designate any of the national languages as an official language of the Union, in practice English is the main working language of EU organisations.[[122]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmmon2006321-122) English serves as the basis for the required [controlled natural languages](/wiki/Controlled_natural_language "Controlled natural language")[[123]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWojcik2006139-123) [Seaspeak](/wiki/Seaspeak "Seaspeak") and Airspeak, used as [international languages](/wiki/International_auxiliary_language "International auxiliary language") of seafaring[[124]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Maritime_Organization2011-124) and aviation.[[125]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Civil_Aviation_Organization2011-125)

English is the most frequently taught foreign language in the world.[[60]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-60)[[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-61) Most people learning English do so for practical reasons, as opposed to ideological reasons.[[126]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006195-126) In EU countries, English is the most widely spoken foreign language in 19 of the 25 member states where it is not an official language (that is, the countries other than Ireland and [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta")). In a 2012 official Eurobarometer poll (conducted when the UK was still a member of the EU), 38 per cent of the EU respondents outside the countries where English is an official language said they could speak English well enough to have a conversation in that language. The next most commonly mentioned foreign language, French (which is the most widely known foreign language in the UK and Ireland), could be used in conversation by 12 per cent of respondents.[[127]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropean_Commission201221,_19-127) The global influence of English has led to concerns about [language death](/wiki/Language_death "Language death"),[[128]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2000-128) and to claims of [linguistic imperialism](/wiki/Linguistic_imperialism "Linguistic imperialism"),[[129]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJambor2007-129) and has provoked resistance to the spread of English; however, the number of speakers continues to increase because many people around the world think English provides them with better employment opportunities and increased quality of life.[[130]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech2006Chapter_12:_English_into_the_Future-130)

Working knowledge of English has become a requirement in a number of occupations and professions such as medicine[[131]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlcaraz_ArizaNavarro2006-131) and computing. Though it formerly had parity with French and German in scientific research, English now dominates the field.[[132]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGordin2015-132) Its importance in scientific publishing is such that over 80 per cent of scientific journal articles indexed by *Chemical Abstracts* in 1998 were written in English, as were 90 per cent of all articles in natural science publications by 1996, and 82 per cent of articles in humanities publications by 1995.[[133]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006694–695-133)

As decolonisation proceeded throughout the British Empire in the 1950s and 1960s, former colonies often did not reject English but rather continued to use it as independent countries setting their own language policies.[[57]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMufwene2006614-57)[[58]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup201381–86-58)[[134]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMesthrie2010594-134) For example, English is one of the official languages of India. Many Indians have shifted from associating the language with colonialism to associating it with economic progress.[[135]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnnamalai2006-135) English is widely used in media and literature, with India being the third-largest publisher of English-language books in the world, after the US and UK.[[136]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESailaja20092–9-136) However, less than 5 per cent of the population speak English fluently, with the country's native English speakers numbering in the low hundreds of thousands.[[137]](#cite_note-137)[[138]](#cite_note-138) In 2004, David Crystal claimed India had the largest population of people able to speak or understand English in the world,[[139]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2004-139) though most scholars estimate the US remains home to a larger English-speaking population.[[140]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2010-140) Many English speakers in Africa have become part of an "Afro-Saxon" language community that unites Africans from different countries.[[141]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMazruiMazrui1998-141) Regarding its future development, it is considered most likely that English will continue to function as a [koiné](/wiki/Koin%C3%A9 "Koiné") language, with a standard form that unifies speakers around the world.[[142]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2006-142)

## Phonology

This section contains **[phonetic transcriptions](/wiki/Phonetic_transcription "Phonetic transcription") in the [International Phonetic Alphabet](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet "International Phonetic Alphabet") (IPA)**. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see [Help:IPA](/wiki/Help:IPA "Help:IPA").

[English phonology](/wiki/English_phonology "English phonology") and [phonetics](/wiki/Phonetics "Phonetics") differ from one dialect to another, usually without interfering with mutual communication. Phonological variation affects the inventory of [phonemes](/wiki/Phoneme "Phoneme") (speech sounds that distinguish meaning), and phonetic variation consists in differences in pronunciation of the phonemes.[[143]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolfram2006334–335-143) This overview mainly describes [Received Pronunciation](/wiki/Received_Pronunciation "Received Pronunciation") (RP) and [General American](/wiki/General_American "General American") (GA), the [standard varieties](/wiki/Standard_varieties "Standard varieties") of the United Kingdom and the United States respectively.[[144]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrHoneybone2007-144)[[145]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBermúdez-OteroMcMahon2006-145)[[146]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacMahon2006-146)

### Consonants

Most English dialects share the same 24 consonant phonemes (or 26, if marginal /x/ and glottal stop /ʔ/ are included). The consonant inventory shown below is valid for [California English](/wiki/California_English "California English"),[[147]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Phonetic_Association199941–42-147) and for RP.[[148]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994534-148)

Consonant phonemes

| [Bilabial](/wiki/Bilabial "Bilabial") | [Labiodental](/wiki/Labiodental "Labiodental") | [Dental](/wiki/Dental_consonant "Dental consonant") | [Alveolar](/wiki/Alveolar_consonant "Alveolar consonant") | [Post- alveolar](/wiki/Postalveolar_consonant "Postalveolar consonant") | [Palatal](/wiki/Palatal_consonant "Palatal consonant") | [Velar](/wiki/Velar_consonant "Velar consonant") | [Glottal](/wiki/Glottal_consonant "Glottal consonant") |
| [Nasal](/wiki/Nasal_consonant "Nasal consonant") | [m](/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_nasal "Voiced bilabial nasal") |  |  | [n](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_nasal "Voiced alveolar nasal") |  |  | [ŋ](/wiki/Voiced_velar_nasal "Voiced velar nasal") |  |
| [Plosive](/wiki/Plosive "Plosive") | [p](/wiki/Voiceless_bilabial_plosive "Voiceless bilabial plosive") | [b](/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_plosive "Voiced bilabial plosive") |  |  | [t](/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_plosive "Voiceless alveolar plosive") | [d](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_plosive "Voiced alveolar plosive") |  |  | [k](/wiki/Voiceless_velar_plosive "Voiceless velar plosive") | [ɡ](/wiki/Voiced_velar_plosive "Voiced velar plosive") | ([ʔ](/wiki/Glottal_stop "Glottal stop")) |  |
| [Affricate](/wiki/Affricate "Affricate") |  |  |  |  | [tʃ](/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_affricate "Voiceless postalveolar affricate") | [dʒ](/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_affricate "Voiced postalveolar affricate") |  |  |  |
| [Fricative](/wiki/Fricative "Fricative") |  | [f](/wiki/Voiceless_labiodental_fricative "Voiceless labiodental fricative") | [v](/wiki/Voiced_labiodental_fricative "Voiced labiodental fricative") | [θ](/wiki/Voiceless_dental_fricative "Voiceless dental fricative") | [ð](/wiki/Voiced_dental_fricative "Voiced dental fricative") | [s](/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_fricative "Voiceless alveolar fricative") | [z](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_fricative "Voiced alveolar fricative") | [ʃ](/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_fricative "Voiceless postalveolar fricative") | [ʒ](/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_fricative "Voiced postalveolar fricative") |  | ([x](/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative "Voiceless velar fricative")) |  | [h](/wiki/Voiceless_glottal_fricative "Voiceless glottal fricative") |  |
| [Approximant](/wiki/Approximant "Approximant") | [Median](/wiki/Median_consonant "Median consonant") |  |  |  |  | [ɹ](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_approximant "Voiced alveolar approximant") | [j](/wiki/Voiced_palatal_approximant "Voiced palatal approximant") | [w](/wiki/Voiced_labial%E2%80%93velar_approximant "Voiced labial–velar approximant") |  |
| [Lateral](/wiki/Lateral_consonant "Lateral consonant") |  |  |  | [l](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_lateral_approximant "Voiced alveolar lateral approximant") |  |  |  |  |

For pairs of [obstruents](/wiki/Obstruent "Obstruent") (stops, affricates, and fricatives) such as /p b/, /tʃ dʒ/, and /s z/, the first is [fortis](/wiki/Fortis_and_lenis "Fortis and lenis") (strong) and the second is lenis (weak). Fortis obstruents, such as /p tʃ s/ are pronounced with more muscular tension and breath force than lenis consonants, such as /b dʒ z/, and are always [voiceless](/wiki/Voiceless "Voiceless"). Lenis consonants are partly [voiced](/wiki/Voiced "Voiced") at the beginning and end of utterances, and fully voiced between vowels. Fortis stops such as /p/ have additional articulatory or acoustic features in most dialects: they are [aspirated](/wiki/Aspirated_consonant "Aspirated consonant") [pʰ] when they occur alone at the beginning of a stressed syllable, often unaspirated in other cases, and often [unreleased](/wiki/Unreleased_stop "Unreleased stop") [p̚] or pre-glottalised [ʔp] at the end of a syllable. In a single-syllable word, a vowel before a fortis stop is shortened: e.g. *nip* has a noticeably shorter vowel (phonetically, not phonemically) than *nib* [nɪˑb̥] ([see below](#Vowels)).[[149]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollinsMees200347–53-149)

* Lenis stops: *bin* [b̥ɪˑn], *about* [əˈbaʊt], *nib* [nɪˑb̥]
* Fortis stops: *pin* [pʰɪn]; *spin* [spɪn]; *happy* [ˈhæpi]; *nip* [nɪp̚] or [nɪʔp]

In RP, the lateral approximant /l/ has two main [allophones](/wiki/Allophone "Allophone") (pronunciation variants): the clear or plain [l], as in *light*, and the dark or [velarised](/wiki/Velarised_alveolar_lateral_approximant "Velarised alveolar lateral approximant") [ɫ], as in *full*.[[150]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200813-150) GA has dark *l* in most cases.[[151]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200841-151)

* Clear *l*: RP *light* [laɪt]
* Dark *l*: RP and GA *full* [fʊɫ], GA *light* [ɫaɪt]

All [sonorants](/wiki/Sonorant "Sonorant") (liquids /l, r/ and nasals /m, n, ŋ/) devoice when following a voiceless obstruent, and they are syllabic when following a consonant at the end of a word.[[152]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201056–59-152)

* Voiceless sonorants: *clay* [kl̥eɪ̯]; *snow* RP [sn̥əʊ̯], GA [sn̥oʊ̯]
* Syllabic sonorants: *paddle* [ˈpad.l̩], *button* [ˈbʌt.n̩]

The pronunciation of vowels varies a great deal between dialects and is one of the most detectable aspects of a speaker's accent. The accompanying table below lists the vowel [phonemes](/wiki/Phoneme "Phoneme") in RP and GA, with example words from [lexical sets](/wiki/Lexical_set "Lexical set"). The vowels are represented with symbols from the [International Phonetic Alphabet](/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet "International Phonetic Alphabet"); those given for RP are standard in British dictionaries and other publications.[[153]](#cite_note-153)

In RP, vowel length is phonemic; [long vowels](/wiki/Long_vowels "Long vowels") are marked with a [triangular colon](/wiki/Triangular_colon "Triangular colon") ⟨ː⟩ in the table above, such as the vowel of *need* [niːd] as opposed to *bid* [bɪd].[[154]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGiegerich199256–57-154) In GA, vowel length is non-distinctive.[[155]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECohen201280-155)

In both RP and GA, vowels are phonetically [shortened before fortis consonants](/wiki/Clipping_(phonetics) "Clipping (phonetics)") in the same [syllable](/wiki/Syllable "Syllable"), like /t tʃ f/, but not before lenis consonants like /d dʒ v/ or in open syllables: thus, the vowels of *rich* [rɪtʃ], *neat* [nit], and *safe* [seɪ̯f] are noticeably shorter than the vowels of *ridge* [rɪˑdʒ], *need* [niˑd], and *save* [seˑɪ̯v], and the vowel of *light* [laɪ̯t] is shorter than that of *lie* [laˑɪ̯]. Because lenis consonants are frequently voiceless at the end of a syllable, vowel length is an important cue as to whether the following consonant is lenis or fortis.[[156]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollinsMees200346–50-156)

The vowel /ə/ only occurs in unstressed syllables and is more open in quality in stem-final positions.[[157]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECruttenden2014138-157)[[158]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlemmingJohnson2007-158) Some dialects do not contrast /ɪ/ and /ə/ in unstressed positions, such that *rabbit* and *abbot* rhyme and *Lenin* and *Lennon* are homophonous, a dialectal feature called the [weak vowel merger](/wiki/Weak_vowel_merger "Weak vowel merger").[[159]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells1982167-159) GA /ɜr/ and /ər/ are realised as an [*r*-coloured vowel](/wiki/R-colored_vowel "R-colored vowel") [ɚ], as in *further* [ˈfɚðɚ] (phonemically /ˈfɜrðər/), which in RP is realised as [ˈfəːðə] (phonemically /ˈfɜːðə/).[[160]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells1982121-160)

### Phonotactics

An English syllable includes a syllable nucleus consisting of a vowel sound. Syllable onset and coda (start and end) are optional. A syllable can start with up to three consonant sounds, as in *sprint* /sprɪnt/, and end with up to five, as in (for some dialects) *angsts* /aŋksts/. This gives an English syllable a structure of (CCC)V(CCCCC) – where C represents a consonant and V a vowel. The word *strengths* /strɛŋθs/ is thus close to the most complex syllable possible in English. The consonants that may appear together in onsets or codas are restricted, as is the order in which they may appear. Onsets can only have four types of consonant clusters: a stop and approximant, as in *play*; a voiceless fricative and approximant, as in *fly* or *sly*; *s* and a voiceless stop, as in *stay*; and *s*, a voiceless stop, and an approximant, as in *string*.[[161]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201060-161) Clusters of nasal and stop are only allowed in codas. Clusters of obstruents always agree in voicing, and clusters of [sibilants](/wiki/Sibilant "Sibilant") and of [plosives](/wiki/Plosive "Plosive") with the same point of articulation are prohibited. Several consonants have limited distributions: /h/ can only occur in syllable-initial position, and /ŋ/ only in syllable-final position.[[162]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994537–538-162)

### Stress, rhythm, and intonation

See also: [Stress and vowel reduction in English](/wiki/Stress_and_vowel_reduction_in_English "Stress and vowel reduction in English"), [Intonation (linguistics) § English](/wiki/Intonation_(linguistics)#English "Intonation (linguistics)"), and [English prosody](/wiki/English_prosody "English prosody")

[Stress](/wiki/Stress_(linguistics) "Stress (linguistics)") plays an important role in English. Certain [syllables](/wiki/Syllable "Syllable") are stressed, while others are unstressed. Stress is a combination of duration, intensity, vowel quality, and sometimes changes in pitch. Stressed syllables are pronounced longer and louder than unstressed syllables, and vowels in unstressed syllables are frequently [reduced](/wiki/Vowel_reduction "Vowel reduction") while vowels in stressed syllables are not.[[163]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Phonetic_Association199942-163)

Stress in English is [phonemic](/wiki/Phonemic "Phonemic"). For instance, the word *contract* is stressed on the first syllable ([/ˈkɒntrækt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*KON-trakt*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) when used as a noun, but on the last syllable ([/kənˈtrækt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*kən-TRAKT*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")) for most meanings (for example, "reduce in size") when used as a verb.[[164]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Learner's_Dictionary2015Entry_)[[165]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMerriam_Webster2015Entry_)[[166]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacquarie_Dictionary2015Entry_) Here stress is connected to [vowel reduction](/wiki/Vowel_reduction "Vowel reduction"): in the noun "contract" the first syllable is stressed and has the unreduced vowel /ɒ/, but in the verb "contract" the first syllable is unstressed and its vowel is reduced to /ə/. Stress is also used to distinguish between words and phrases, so that a compound word receives a single stress unit, but the corresponding phrase has two: e.g. "a burnout" ([/ˈbɜːrnaʊt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")) versus "to burn out" ([/ˈbɜːrn ˈaʊt/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")), and "a hotdog" ([/ˈhɒtdɒɡ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")) versus "a hot dog" ([/ˈhɒt ˈdɒɡ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")).[[167]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201066-167)

In terms of [rhythm](/wiki/Rhythm "Rhythm"), English is generally described as a [stress-timed](/wiki/Stress-timed "Stress-timed") language, meaning that the amount of time between stressed syllables tends to be equal.[[168]](#cite_note-168) Stressed syllables are pronounced longer, but unstressed syllables (syllables between stresses) are shortened. Vowels in unstressed syllables are shortened as well, and vowel shortening causes changes in [vowel quality](/wiki/Vowel_quality "Vowel quality"): [vowel reduction](/wiki/Vowel_reduction "Vowel reduction").[[169]](#cite_note-169)

### Regional variation

Phonological features in Standard English varieties[[170]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20024–6-170)

Dialects and low vowels

| THOUGHT | /ɔː/ | /ɔ/ or /ɑ/ | /ɑ/ | [*cot*–*caught* merger](/wiki/Cot%E2%80%93caught_merger "Cot–caught merger") |
| CLOTH | /ɒ/ | [*lot*–*cloth* split](/wiki/Lot%E2%80%93cloth_split "Lot–cloth split") |
