Varieties of English vary the most in pronunciation of vowels. The best-known national varieties used as standards for education in non-English-speaking countries are British (BrE) and American (AmE). Countries such as [Canada](/wiki/Canadian_English "Canadian English"), [Australia](/wiki/Australian_English "Australian English"), [Ireland](/wiki/Hiberno-English "Hiberno-English"), [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_English "New Zealand English") and [South Africa](/wiki/South_African_English "South African English") have their own standard varieties which are less often used as standards for education internationally.[[170]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20024–6-170)

English has undergone many [historical sound changes](/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English "Phonological history of English"), some of them affecting all varieties, and others affecting only a few. Most standard varieties are affected by the [Great Vowel Shift](/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift "Great Vowel Shift"), which changed the pronunciation of long vowels, but a few dialects have slightly different results. In North America, a number of chain shifts such as the [Northern Cities Vowel Shift](/wiki/Northern_Cities_Vowel_Shift "Northern Cities Vowel Shift") and [Canadian Shift](/wiki/Canadian_Shift "Canadian Shift") have produced very different vowel landscapes in some regional accents.[[171]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass199290,_118,_610Lass200080,_656-171)

Some dialects have fewer or more consonant phonemes and [phones](/wiki/Phone_(phonetics) "Phone (phonetics)") than the standard varieties. Some conservative varieties like Scottish English have a [voiceless](/wiki/Voiceless "Voiceless") [[ʍ](/wiki/Voiceless_labial%E2%80%93velar_fricative "Voiceless labial–velar fricative")] sound in *whine* that contrasts with the voiced [w] in *wine*, but most other dialects pronounce both words with voiced [w], a dialect feature called [*wine*–*whine* merger](/wiki/Wine%E2%80%93whine_merger "Wine–whine merger"). The voiceless velar fricative sound /x/ is found in Scottish English, which distinguishes *loch* /lɔx/ from *lock* /lɔk/. Accents like [Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney") with "[*h*-dropping](/wiki/H-dropping "H-dropping")" lack the glottal fricative /h/, and dialects with [*th*-stopping](/wiki/Th-stopping "Th-stopping") and [*th*-fronting](/wiki/Th-fronting "Th-fronting") like [African-American Vernacular](/wiki/African-American_Vernacular_English "African-American Vernacular English") and [Estuary English](/wiki/Estuary_English "Estuary English") do not have the dental fricatives /θ, ð/, but replace them with dental or alveolar stops /t, d/ or labiodental fricatives /f, v/.[[172]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoach200953-172)[[173]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGiegerich199236-173) Other changes affecting the phonology of local varieties are processes such as [*yod*-dropping](/wiki/Yod-dropping "Yod-dropping"), [*yod*-coalescence](/wiki/Yod-coalescence "Yod-coalescence"), and reduction of consonant clusters.[[174]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells1982-174)[*[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*]

GA and RP vary in their pronunciation of historical /r/ after a vowel at the end of a syllable (in the [syllable coda](/wiki/Syllable_coda "Syllable coda")). GA is a [rhotic dialect](/wiki/Rhotic_dialect "Rhotic dialect"), meaning that it pronounces /r/ at the end of a syllable, but RP is non-rhotic, meaning that it loses /r/ in that position. English dialects are classified as rhotic or non-rhotic depending on whether they elide /r/ like RP or keep it like GA.[[175]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass2000114-175)

There is complex dialectal variation in words with the [open front](/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English_short_A "Phonological history of English short A") and [open back vowels](/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English_low_back_vowels "Phonological history of English low back vowels") /æ ɑː ɒ ɔː/. These four vowels are only distinguished in RP, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa. In GA, these vowels merge to three /æ ɑ ɔ/,[[176]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells1982xviii–xix-176) and in Canadian English, they merge to two /æ ɑ/.[[177]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells1982493-177)

## Grammar

Typical for an Indo-European language, [English grammar](/wiki/English_grammar "English grammar") follows [accusative](/wiki/Nominative%E2%80%93accusative_alignment "Nominative–accusative alignment") [morphosyntactic alignment](/wiki/Morphosyntactic_alignment "Morphosyntactic alignment"). Unlike other Indo-European languages, English has largely abandoned the inflectional [case system](/wiki/Case_system "Case system") in favour of [analytic](/wiki/Analytic_language "Analytic language") constructions. Only the [personal pronouns](/wiki/Personal_pronoun "Personal pronoun") retain morphological case more strongly than any other [word class](/wiki/Word_class "Word class"). English distinguishes at least seven major word classes: verbs, nouns, adjectives, adverbs, determiners (including articles), prepositions, and conjunctions. Some analyses add pronouns as a class separate from nouns, and subdivide conjunctions into [subordinators](/wiki/English_subordinators "English subordinators") and [coordinators](/wiki/English_coordinators "English coordinators"), and add the class of interjections.[[178]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200222-178) English also has a rich set of [auxiliary verbs](/wiki/Auxiliary_verb "Auxiliary verb"), such as *have* and *do*, expressing the categories of mood and aspect. Questions are marked by [*do*-support](/wiki/Do-support "Do-support"), [*wh*-movement](/wiki/Wh-movement "Wh-movement") (fronting of question words beginning with *wh*-) and word order [inversion](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93auxiliary_inversion "Subject–auxiliary inversion") with some verbs.[[179]](#cite_note-Carter2016-179)

Some traits typical of Germanic languages persist in English, such as the distinction between irregularly inflected [strong](/wiki/Strong_inflection "Strong inflection") stems inflected through [ablaut](/wiki/Ablaut "Ablaut") (i.e. changing the vowel of the stem, as in the pairs *speak* / *spoke* and *foot* / *feet*) and weak stems inflected through affixation (such as *love* / *loved*, *hand* / *hands*).[[180]](#cite_note-Baugh2012-180) Vestiges of the case and gender system are found in the pronoun system (*he* / *him*, *who* / *whom*); similarly, traces of more complex verb conjugation are seen in the inflection of the [copula](/wiki/Copula_(linguistics) "Copula (linguistics)") verb *to be*.[[180]](#cite_note-Baugh2012-180)

The seven word classes are exemplified in this sample sentence:[[181]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAartsHaegeman2006118-181)

|  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| *The* | *chairman* | *of* | *the* | *committee* | *and* | *the* | *loquacious* | *politician* | *clashed* | *violently* | *when* | *the* | *meeting* | *started*. |
| Det. | Noun | Prep. | Det. | Noun | Conj. | Det. | Adj. | Noun | Verb | Advb. | Conj. | Det. | Noun | Verb |

### Nouns and noun phrases

[English nouns](/wiki/English_nouns "English nouns") are only inflected for number and possession. New nouns can be formed through derivation or compounding. They are semantically divided into [proper nouns](/wiki/Proper_noun "Proper noun") (names) and common nouns. Common nouns are in turn divided into concrete and abstract nouns, and grammatically into [count nouns](/wiki/Count_noun "Count noun") and [mass nouns](/wiki/Mass_noun "Mass noun").[[182]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPayneHuddleston2002-182)

Most count nouns are inflected for plural number through the use of the plural [suffix](/wiki/Suffix "Suffix") -*s*, but a few nouns have irregular plural forms. Mass nouns can only be pluralised through the use of a count noun classifier, e.g. "one loaf of bread", "two loaves of bread".[[183]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200256–57-183)

Regular plural formation:

* Singular: *cat*, *dog*
* Plural: *cats*, *dogs*

Irregular plural formation:

* Singular: *man*, *woman*, *foot*, *fish*, *ox*, *knife*, *mouse*
* Plural: *men*, *women*, *feet*, *fish*, *oxen*, *knives*, *mice*

Possession can be expressed either by the possessive [enclitic](/wiki/Enclitic "Enclitic") -*s* (also traditionally called a genitive suffix), or by the preposition *of*. Historically the -*s* possessive has been used for [animate nouns](/wiki/Animacy "Animacy"), whereas the *of* possessive has been reserved for inanimate nouns. Today this distinction is less clear, and many speakers use -*s* also with inanimates. Orthographically the possessive -*s* is separated from a singular noun with an apostrophe. If the noun is plural formed with -*s* the apostrophe follows the -*s*.[[179]](#cite_note-Carter2016-179)

Possessive constructions:

* With -*s*: "The woman's husband's child"
* With *of*: "The child of the husband of the woman"

Nouns can form [noun phrases](/wiki/Noun_phrase "Noun phrase") (NPs) where they are the syntactic head of the words that depend on them such as determiners, quantifiers, conjunctions or adjectives.[[184]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200255-184) Noun phrases can be short, such as *the man*, composed only of a determiner and a noun. They can also include modifiers such as adjectives (e.g. *red*, *tall*, *all*) and specifiers such as determiners (e.g. *the*, *that*). But they can also tie together several nouns into a single long NP, using conjunctions such as *and*, or prepositions such as *with*, e.g. "the tall man with the long red trousers and his skinny wife with the spectacles" (this NP uses conjunctions, prepositions, specifiers, and modifiers). Regardless of length, an NP functions as a syntactic unit.[[179]](#cite_note-Carter2016-179) For example, the possessive enclitic can, in cases which do not lead to ambiguity, follow the entire noun phrase, as in "The President of India's wife", where the enclitic follows *India* and not *President*.

The class of determiners is used to specify the noun they precede in terms of [definiteness](/wiki/Definiteness "Definiteness"), where *the* marks a definite noun and *a* or *an* an indefinite one. A definite noun is assumed by the speaker to be already known by the interlocutor, whereas an indefinite noun is not specified as being previously known. Quantifiers, which include *one*, *many*, *some* and *all*, are used to specify the noun in terms of quantity or number. The noun must agree with the number of the determiner, e.g. *one man* (sg.) but *all men* (pl.). Determiners are the first constituents in a noun phrase.[[185]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200254–55-185)

#### Adjectives

[English adjectives](/wiki/English_adjectives "English adjectives") are words such as *good*, *big*, *interesting*, and *Canadian* that most typically modify nouns, [denoting](/wiki/Denotation "Denotation") characteristics of their [referents](/wiki/Referent "Referent") (e.g. "a *red* car"). As modifiers, they come before the nouns they modify and after determiners.[[186]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200257-186) English adjectives also function as predicative complements (e.g. "the child is *happy*").[[187]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002530-187)

In Modern English, adjectives are not inflected so as to [agree](/wiki/Agreement_(linguistics) "Agreement (linguistics)") in form with the noun they modify, as in most other Indo-European languages. For example, in the phrases "the slender boy", and "many slender girls", the adjective *slender* does not change form to agree with either the number or gender of the noun.[[188]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002528-188)

Some adjectives are inflected for [degree of comparison](/wiki/Degree_of_comparison "Degree of comparison"), with the positive degree unmarked, the suffix -*er* marking the comparative, and -*est* marking the superlative: "a small boy", "the boy is smaller than the girl", "that boy is the smallest". Some adjectives have irregular [suppletive](/wiki/Suppletive "Suppletive") comparative and superlative forms, such as *good*, *better*, and *best*. Other adjectives have comparatives formed by [periphrastic constructions](/wiki/Periphrasis "Periphrasis"), with the adverb *more* marking the comparative, and *most* marking the superlative: *happier* or *more happy*, *the happiest* or *most happy*.[[189]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994540-189) There is some variation among speakers regarding which adjectives use inflected or periphrastic comparison, and some studies have shown a tendency for the periphrastic forms to become more common at the expense of the inflected form.[[190]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair2006148–149-190)

#### Determiners

[English determiners](/wiki/English_determiners "English determiners") are words such as *the*, *each*, *many*, *some*, and *which*, occurring most typically in noun phrases before the head nouns and any modifiers and marking the noun phrase as [definite](/wiki/Definite "Definite") or indefinite.[[191]](#cite_note-191) They often agree with the noun in [number](/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical number"). They do not typically inflect for degree of comparison.

#### Pronouns, case, and person

[English pronouns](/wiki/English_pronouns "English pronouns") conserve many traits of case and gender inflection. The personal pronouns retain a difference between subjective and objective case in most persons (*I*/*me*, *he*/*him*, *she*/*her*, *we*/*us*, *they*/*them*) as well as an animateness distinction in the third person singular (distinguishing *it* from the three sets of animate third person singular pronouns) and an optional gender distinction in the animate third person singular (distinguishing between feminine [*she*/*her*](/wiki/She/her "She/her"), [epicene](/wiki/Epicene "Epicene") [*they*/*them*](/wiki/They/them "They/them"), and masculine [*he*/*him*](/wiki/He/him "He/him").[[192]](#cite_note-OEDthey-192)[[193]](#cite_note-193) The [subjective case](/wiki/Subjective_case "Subjective case") corresponds to the Old English [nominative case](/wiki/Nominative_case "Nominative case"), and the [objective case](/wiki/Objective_case "Objective case") is used in the sense both of the previous [accusative case](/wiki/Accusative_case "Accusative case") (for a patient, or direct object of a transitive verb), and of the Old English dative case (for a recipient or [indirect object](/wiki/Indirect_object "Indirect object") of a transitive verb).[[194]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeech200669)[[195]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Dwyer2006) The subjective is used when the pronoun is the subject of a finite clause, otherwise the objective is used.[[196]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenbaumNelson2002-196) While grammarians such as [Henry Sweet](/wiki/Henry_Sweet "Henry Sweet")[[197]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweet201452) and [Otto Jespersen](/wiki/Otto_Jespersen "Otto Jespersen")[[198]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJespersen2007173–185-198) noted that the English cases did not correspond to the traditional Latin-based system, some contemporary grammars, including *[The Cambridge Grammar of the English Language](/wiki/The_Cambridge_Grammar_of_the_English_Language "The Cambridge Grammar of the English Language")*, retain traditional *nominative* and *accusative* labels for the cases.[[199]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002-199)

Possessive pronouns exist in dependent and independent forms; the dependent form functions as a determiner specifying a noun (as in *my chair*), while the independent form can stand alone as if it were a noun (e.g. "the chair is mine").[[200]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002425–426-200) Grammatical person in English no longer distinguishes between formal and informal pronouns of address, with the second person singular familiar pronoun *[thou](/wiki/Thou "Thou")* that previously existed in the language having fallen almost entirely out of use by the 18th century.[[201]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcMahon2012182-201)

Both the second and third persons share pronouns between the plural and singular:

* Plural and singular are always identical (*you*, *your*, *yours*) in the second person (except in the reflexive form: *yourself*/*yourselves*) in most dialects. Some dialects have introduced innovative second person plural pronouns, such as *y'all* (found in [Southern American English](/wiki/Southern_American_English "Southern American English") and [African-American Vernacular English](/wiki/African-American_Vernacular_English "African-American Vernacular English")), *youse* (found in [Australian English](/wiki/Australian_English "Australian English")), or *ye* (in [Hiberno-English](/wiki/Hiberno-English "Hiberno-English")).
* In the third person, the *they*/*them* series of pronouns (*they*, *them*, *their*, *theirs*, *themselves*) are used in both plural and singular, and are the only pronouns available for the plural. In the singular, the [*they*/*them*](/wiki/They/them "They/them") series (sometimes with the addition of the singular-specific reflexive form *themself*) serve as a [gender-neutral](/wiki/Gender-neutral "Gender-neutral") set of pronouns. These pronouns are becoming more accepted, especially as part of the [LGBTQ culture](/wiki/LGBTQ_culture "LGBTQ culture").[[192]](#cite_note-OEDthey-192)[[202]](#cite_note-202)[[203]](#cite_note-203)

English personal pronouns

| Person | Subjective case | Objective case | Dependent possessive | Independent possessive | Reflexive |
| 1st, singular | *I* | *me* | *my* | *mine* | *myself* |
| 2nd, singular | *you* | *you* | *your* | *yours* | *yourself* |
| 3rd, singular | *he/she/it/[they](/wiki/Singular_they "Singular they")* | *him/her/it/them* | *his/her/its/their* | *his/hers/its/theirs* | *himself/herself/itself/themself/themselves* |
| 1st, plural | *we* | *us* | *our* | *ours* | *ourselves* |
| 2nd, plural | *you* | *you* | *your* | *yours* | *yourselves* |
| 3rd, plural | *they* | *them* | *their* | *theirs* | *themselves* |

Pronouns are used to refer to entities [deictically](/wiki/Deixis "Deixis") or [anaphorically](/wiki/Anaphoric_reference "Anaphoric reference"). A deictic pronoun points to some person or object by identifying it relative to the speech situation – for example, the pronoun *I* identifies the speaker, and the pronoun *you*, the addressee. Anaphoric pronouns such as *that* refer back to an entity already mentioned or assumed by the speaker to be known by the audience, for example in the sentence "I already told you that". The reflexive pronouns are used when the oblique argument is identical to the subject of a phrase (e.g. "he sent it to himself" or "she braced herself for impact").[[204]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002426-204)

#### Prepositions

Prepositional phrases (PP) are phrases composed of a preposition and one or more nouns, e.g. "with the dog", "for my friend", "to school", "in England".[[205]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200258-205) [English prepositions](/wiki/English_prepositions "English prepositions") have a wide range of uses – including describing movement, place, and other relations between entities, as well as functions that are syntactic in nature, like introducing complement clauses and oblique arguments of verbs.[[205]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200258-205) For example, in the phrase "I gave it to him", the preposition *to* marks the indirect object of the verb *to give*. Traditionally words were only considered prepositions if they governed the case of the noun they preceded, for example causing the pronouns to use the objective rather than subjective form, "with her", "to me", "for us". But some contemporary grammars no longer consider government of case to be the defining feature of the class of prepositions, rather defining prepositions as words that can function as the heads of prepositional phrases.[[206]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002598–600-206)

### Verbs and verb phrases

[English verbs](/wiki/English_verbs "English verbs") are inflected for tense and aspect and marked for agreement with a third person present singular subject. Only the copula verb *to be* is still inflected for agreement with the plural and first and second person subjects.[[189]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994540-189) Auxiliary verbs such as *have* and *be* are paired with verbs in the [infinitive](/wiki/Infinitive "Infinitive"), past, or progressive forms. They form [complex](/wiki/Periphrasis "Periphrasis") tenses, aspects, and moods. Auxiliary verbs differ from other verbs in that they can be followed by the negation, and in that they can occur as the first constituent in a question sentence.[[207]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200251-207)[[208]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994541-208)

Most verbs have six inflectional forms. The primary forms are a plain present, a third person singular present, and a preterite (past) form. The secondary forms are a plain form used for the infinitive, a gerund-participle and a past participle.[[209]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200250-209) The verb *to be* – which among other uses in English functions as the primary auxiliary verb indicating the [imperfective aspect](/wiki/Imperfective_aspect "Imperfective aspect") (e.g. "I *am* going"), as well as the [copula](/wiki/Copula_(linguistics) "Copula (linguistics)")[[210]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeters2004) – is the only verb to retain some of its original conjugation, and takes different inflectional forms depending on the subject. The first person present form is *am*, the third person singular form is *is*, and the form *are* is used in the second person singular and all three plurals. The only verb past participle is *been* and its gerund-participle is *being*.[[211]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200275,_91,_113–114-211)

English inflectional forms

| Inflection | Strong | Regular |
| Plain present | *take* | *love* |
| 3rd person sg. present | *takes* | *loves* |
| Preterite | *took* | *loved* |
| Plain (infinitive) | *take* | *love* |
| Gerund–participle | *taking* | *loving* |
| Past participle | *taken* | *loved* |

#### Tense, aspect, and mood

English has two primary tenses, past (preterite) and non-past. The preterite is inflected by using the preterite form of the verb, which for the regular verbs includes the suffix *-ed*, and for the strong verbs either the suffix *-t* or a change in the stem vowel. The non-past form is unmarked except in the third person singular, which takes the suffix *-s*.[[207]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200251-207)

| Present | Preterite |
| --- | --- |
| First person | *I run* | *I ran* |
| Second person | *You run* | *You ran* |
| Third person | *John runs* | *John ran* |

English does not have future verb forms.[[212]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002208–210-212) The future tense is expressed periphrastically with one of the auxiliary verbs *will* or *shall*.[[213]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200251–52-213) Many varieties also use a [near future](/wiki/Near_future_tense "Near future tense") constructed with the [phrasal verb](/wiki/Phrasal_verb "Phrasal verb") "be going to" ([going-to future](/wiki/Going-to_future "Going-to future")).[[214]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002210–211-214)

| Future |
| --- |
| First person | "I will run" |
| Second person | "You will run" |
| Third person | "John will run" |

Further aspectual distinctions are shown by auxiliary verbs, primarily *have* and *be*, which show the contrast between a perfect and non-perfect past tense ("I have run" vs. "I was running"), and compound tenses such as preterite perfect ("I had been running") and present perfect ("I have been running").[[215]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200250–51-215)

For the expression of mood, English uses a number of modal auxiliaries, such as *can*, *may*, *will*, *shall* and the past tense forms *could*, *might*, *would*, *should*. There are also [subjunctive](/wiki/English_subjunctive "English subjunctive") and [imperative moods](/wiki/Imperative_mood "Imperative mood"), both based on the plain form of the verb (i.e. without the third person singular *-s*), for use in subordinate clauses (e.g. subjunctive: "It is important that he run every day"; imperative *Run!*).[[213]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200251–52-213)

An infinitive form, that uses the plain form of the verb and the preposition *to*, is used for verbal clauses that are syntactically subordinate to a finite verbal clause. Finite verbal clauses are those that are formed around a verb in the present or preterite form. In clauses with auxiliary verbs, they are the finite verbs and the main verb is treated as a subordinate clause.[[216]](#cite_note-216) For example, "he has to go" where only the auxiliary verb *have* is inflected for time and the main verb *to go* is in the infinitive, or in a complement clause such as "I saw him leave", where the main verb is *see*, which is in a preterite form, and *leave* is in the infinitive.

#### Phrasal verbs

English also makes frequent use of constructions traditionally called [phrasal verbs](/wiki/Phrasal_verb "Phrasal verb"), verb phrases that are made up of a verb root and a preposition or particle that follows the verb. The phrase then functions as a single predicate. In terms of intonation the preposition is fused to the verb, but in writing it is written as a separate word. Examples of phrasal verbs are "to get up", "to ask out", "to get together", and "to put up with". The phrasal verb frequently has a highly [idiomatic](/wiki/English-language_idioms "English-language idioms") meaning that is more specialised and restricted than what can be simply extrapolated from the combination of verb and preposition complement (e.g. *lay off* meaning *terminate someone's employment*).[[217]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDixon1982-217) Some grammarians do not consider this type of construction to form a syntactic constituent and hence refrain from using the term "phrasal verb". Instead, they consider the construction simply to be a verb with a prepositional phrase as its syntactic complement, e.g. "he woke up in the morning" and "he ran up in the mountains" are syntactically equivalent.[[218]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002274-218)

#### Adverbs

The function of adverbs is to modify the action or event described by the verb by providing additional information about the manner in which it occurs.[[179]](#cite_note-Carter2016-179) Many [English adverbs](/wiki/English_adverbs "English adverbs") are derived from adjectives by appending the suffix *-ly*. For example, in the phrase "the woman walked quickly", the adverb *quickly* is derived from the adjective *quick*. Some commonly used adjectives have irregular adverbial forms, such as *good*, which has the adverbial form *well*.[[219]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002565–566-219)

### Syntax

Modern English syntax is moderately [analytic](/wiki/Isolating_language "Isolating language").[[220]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcArthur199264,_610–611-220) It has developed features such as [modal verbs](/wiki/English_modal_verb "English modal verb") and [word order](/wiki/Word_order "Word order") as resources for conveying meaning. [Auxiliary verbs](/wiki/Auxiliary_verb "Auxiliary verb") mark constructions such as questions, negative polarity, the [passive voice](/wiki/Grammatical_voice "Grammatical voice") and progressive [aspect](/wiki/Grammatical_aspect "Grammatical aspect").[[221]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum20021209–1219-221)

#### Basic constituent order

English has moved from the Germanic [verb-second (V2) word order](/wiki/V2_word_order "V2 word order") to being almost exclusively [subject–verb–object](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object "Subject–verb–object") (SVO).[[222]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994553-222) The combination of SVO order and use of auxiliary verbs often creates clusters of two or more verbs at the centre of the sentence, such as "he had been hoping to try opening it".[[223]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMüller2020666-223)

In most sentences, English only marks grammatical relations through word order.[[224]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994550-224) The subject constituent precedes the verb and the object constituent follows it. The grammatical roles of each constituent are marked only by the position relative to the verb:

|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
| *The dog* | *bites* | *the man* |
| S | V | O |
| *The man* | *bites* | *the dog* |
| S | V | O |

An exception is found in sentences where one of the constituents is a pronoun, in which case it is doubly marked, both by word order and by case inflection, where the subject pronoun precedes the verb and takes the subjective case form, and the object pronoun follows the verb and takes the objective case form.[[225]](#cite_note-225) The example below demonstrates this double marking in a sentence where both object and subject are represented with a third person singular masculine pronoun:

|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
| *He* | *hit* | *him* |
| S | V | O |

[Indirect objects](/wiki/Indirect_object "Indirect object") (IO) of ditransitive verbs can be placed either as the first object in a double object construction (S V IO O), such as "I gave *Jane* the book" or in a prepositional phrase, such as "I gave the book *to Jane*".[[226]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994551-226)

#### Clause syntax

Main article: [English clause syntax](/wiki/English_clause_syntax "English clause syntax")

English sentences may be composed of one or more clauses, that may in turn be composed of one or more phrases (e.g. noun phrases, verb phrases, prepositional phrases). A clause is built around a verb and includes its constituents, such as any noun or prepositional phrases. Within a sentence, there is always at least one main clause (or matrix clause) whereas other clauses are subordinate to a main clause. Subordinate clauses may function as arguments of the verb in the main clause. For example, in the phrase "I think (that) you are lying", the main clause is headed by the verb *think*, the subject is *I*, but the object of the phrase is the subordinate clause "(that) you are lying". The subordinating conjunction *that* shows that the clause that follows is a subordinate clause, but it is often omitted.[[227]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller200260–69-227) [Relative clauses](/wiki/Relative_clause "Relative clause") are clauses that function as a modifier or specifier to some constituent in the main clause: For example, in the sentence "I saw the letter that you received today", the relative clause "that you received today" specifies the meaning of the word *letter*, the object of the main clause. Relative clauses can be introduced by the pronouns *who*, *whose*, *whom*, and *which* as well as by *that* (which can also be omitted).[[228]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994545-228) In contrast to many other Germanic languages there are no major differences between word order in main and subordinate clauses.[[229]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994557-229)

#### Auxiliary verb constructions

[English auxiliary verbs](/wiki/English_auxiliary_verbs "English auxiliary verbs") are relied upon for many functions, including the expression of tense, aspect, and mood. Auxiliary verbs form main clauses, and the main verbs function as heads of a subordinate clause of the auxiliary verb. For example, in the sentence "the dog did not find its bone", the clause "find its bone" is the complement of the negated verb *did not*. [Subject–auxiliary inversion](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93auxiliary_inversion "Subject–auxiliary inversion") is used in many constructions, including focus, negation, and interrogative constructions.[[230]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum200294–98-230)

The verb *do* can be used as an auxiliary even in simple declarative sentences, where it usually serves to add emphasis, as in "I *did* shut the fridge." However, in the negated and inverted clauses referred to above, it is used because the rules of English syntax permit these constructions only when an auxiliary is present. Modern English does not allow the addition of the negating adverb *not* to an ordinary [finite](/wiki/Finite_verb "Finite verb") lexical verb, as in \*"I know not" – it can only be added to an auxiliary (or [copular](/wiki/Copular_verb "Copular verb")) verb, hence if there is no other auxiliary present when negation is required, the auxiliary *do* is used, to produce a form like "I do not (don't) know." The same applies in clauses requiring inversion, including most questions – inversion must involve the subject and an auxiliary verb, so it is not possible to say \*"Know you him?"; grammatical rules require "Do you know him?"[[231]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002114-231)

Negation is done with the adverb *not*, which precedes the main verb and follows an auxiliary verb. A contracted form of not -*n't* can be used as an enclitic attaching to auxiliary verbs and to the copula verb *to be*. Just as with questions, many negative constructions require the negation to occur with *do*-support, thus in Modern English "I don't know him" is the correct answer to the question "Do you know him?", but not \*"I know him not", although this construction may be found in older English.[[232]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum2002786–790-232)

Passive constructions also use auxiliary verbs. A passive construction rephrases an active construction in such a way that the object of the active phrase becomes the subject of the passive phrase, and the subject of the active phrase is either omitted or demoted to a role as an oblique argument introduced in a prepositional phrase. They are formed by using the past participle either with the auxiliary verb *to be* or *to get*, although not all varieties of English allow the use of passives with *get*. For example, putting the sentence "she sees him" into the passive becomes "he is seen (by her)", or "he gets seen (by her)".[[233]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller200226–27-233)

#### Questions

Both [yes/no questions](/wiki/Yes/no_question "Yes/no question") and [*wh*-questions](/wiki/Wh-question "Wh-question") in English are mostly formed using [subject–auxiliary inversion](/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93auxiliary_inversion "Subject–auxiliary inversion") ("Am I going tomorrow?", "Where can we eat?"), which may require *do*-support ("Do you like her?", "Where did he go?"). In most cases, [interrogative words](/wiki/Interrogative_word "Interrogative word") (or wh*-words*) – which include *who*, *what*, *when*, *where*, *why*, and *how* – appear in a [fronted position](/wiki/Wh-movement "Wh-movement"). For example, in the question "What did you see?", the word *what* appears as the first constituent despite being the [grammatical object](/wiki/Grammatical_object "Grammatical object") of the sentence. When the *wh*-word is the subject or forms part of the subject, no inversion occurs (e.g. "Who saw the cat?"). [Prepositional phrases](/wiki/Prepositional_phrases "Prepositional phrases") can also be fronted when they are the questions theme (e.g. "To whose house did you go last night?"). The personal interrogative pronoun *[who](/wiki/Who_(pronoun) "Who (pronoun)")* is the only interrogative pronoun to still show inflection for case, with the variant *whom* serving as the objective case form, although this form may be going out of use in many contexts.[[234]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum20027–8-234)

#### Discourse level syntax

While English is a subject-prominent language, at the discourse level it tends to use a [topic–comment](/wiki/Topic%E2%80%93comment "Topic–comment") structure, where the known information (topic) precedes the new information (comment). Because of the strict SVO syntax, the topic of a sentence generally has to be the grammatical subject of the sentence. In cases where the topic is not the grammatical subject of the sentence, it is often promoted to subject position through syntactic means. One way of doing this is through a passive construction, "the girl was stung by the bee". Another way is through a [cleft sentence](/wiki/Cleft_sentence "Cleft sentence") where the main clause is demoted to be a complement clause of a copula sentence with a [dummy subject](/wiki/Dummy_subject "Dummy subject") such as *it* or *there*, e.g. "it was the girl that the bee stung", "there was a girl who was stung by a bee".[[235]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum20021365–1370-235) Dummy subjects are also used in constructions where there is no grammatical subject such as with impersonal verbs (e.g. "it is raining") or in existential clauses ("there are many cars on the street"). Through the use of these complex sentence constructions with informationally vacuous subjects, English is able to maintain both a topic–comment sentence structure and a SVO syntax.[[236]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeters2004)

[Focus constructions](/wiki/Focus_(linguistics) "Focus (linguistics)") emphasise a particular piece of new or salient information within a sentence, generally through allocating the main sentence level stress on the focal constituent. For example, "the girl was stung by *a bee*" (emphasising it was a bee and not, for example, a wasp that stung her), or "*the girl* was stung by a bee" (contrasting with another possibility, for example that it was the boy).[[237]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum20021370-237) Topic and focus can also be established through syntactic dislocation, either preposing or postposing the item to be focused on relative to the main clause. For example, "That girl over there, she was stung by a bee", emphasises the girl by preposition, but a similar effect could be achieved by postposition, "she was stung by a bee, that girl over there", where reference to the girl is established as an afterthought.[[238]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuddlestonPullum20021366-238)

[Cohesion](/wiki/Cohesion_(linguistics) "Cohesion (linguistics)") between sentences is achieved through the use of deictic pronouns as [anaphora](/wiki/Anaphora_(linguistics) "Anaphora (linguistics)") (e.g. "that is exactly what I mean" where *that* refers to some fact known to both interlocutors, or *then* used to locate the time of a narrated event relative to the time of a previously narrated event).[[239]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHallidayHasan1976-239) [Discourse markers](/wiki/Discourse_marker "Discourse marker") such as *oh*, *so*, or *well*, also signal the progression of ideas between sentences and help to create cohesion. Discourse markers are often the first constituents in sentences. Discourse markers are also used for [stance taking](/wiki/Stance_(linguistics) "Stance (linguistics)") in which speakers position themselves in a specific attitude towards what is being said, for example, "no way is that true!" (the idiomatic marker "no way!" expressing disbelief), or "boy! I'm hungry" (the marker *boy* expressing emphasis). While discourse markers are particularly characteristic of informal and spoken registers of English, they are also used in written and formal registers.[[240]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchiffrin1988-240)

## Vocabulary

The English [lexicon](/wiki/Lexicon "Lexicon") consists of around 170,000 words (or 220,000, if counting [obsolete words](/wiki/Obsolete_word "Obsolete word")), according to an estimate based on the 1989 edition of the *[Oxford English Dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary "Oxford English Dictionary")*.[[241]](#cite_note-241) Over one-half are nouns, one-quarter are adjectives, and one-seventh are verbs. Another estimate – which includes [scientific jargon](/wiki/Scientific_jargon "Scientific jargon"), [prefixed](/wiki/Prefix "Prefix") and [suffixed](/wiki/Suffix "Suffix") words, loanwords of extremely limited use, technical [acronyms](/wiki/Acronym "Acronym"), etc. – counts around 1 million total English words.[[242]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999-242)

English borrows vocabulary quickly from many languages and other sources. Early studies of English vocabulary by [lexicographers](/wiki/Lexicography "Lexicography") (scholars who study vocabulary and compile dictionaries) were impeded by a lack of comprehensive data on actual vocabulary in use from high-quality [linguistic corpora](/wiki/Linguistic_corpora "Linguistic corpora")[[243]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeechHundtMairSmith200924–50-243) (collections of actual written texts and spoken passages). Many statements published before the end of the 20th century about the growth of English vocabulary over time, the dates of first use of various words in English, and the sources of English vocabulary will have to be corrected as new computerised analyses of linguistic corpus data become available.[[244]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999584–585-244)[[245]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKastovsky2006-245)

### Word-formation processes

English forms new words from existing words or roots in its vocabulary through a variety of processes. One of the most productive processes in English is conversion,[[246]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b129-246) using a word with a different grammatical role, for example using a noun as a verb or a verb as a noun. Another productive word-formation process is nominal compounding,[[242]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999-242)[[245]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKastovsky2006-245) producing compound words such as *babysitter* or *ice cream* or *homesick*.[[246]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b129-246)

Formation of new words, called [neologisms](/wiki/Neologism "Neologism"), based on [Greek or Latin roots](/wiki/List_of_Greek_and_Latin_roots_in_English "List of Greek and Latin roots in English") (for example *television* or *optometry*) is a highly productive process in modern European languages like English, so much so that it is often difficult to determine in which language a neologism originated. For this reason, American lexicographer [Philip Gove](/wiki/Philip_Gove "Philip Gove") attributed many such words to the "[international scientific vocabulary](/wiki/International_scientific_vocabulary "International scientific vocabulary")" (ISV) when compiling *[Webster's Third New International Dictionary](/wiki/Webster%27s_Third_New_International_Dictionary "Webster's Third New International Dictionary")* (1961). Another active word-formation process in English is that of [acronyms](/wiki/Acronym "Acronym"), which result from pronouncing abbreviations of longer phrases as single words, e.g. *[NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO")*, *[laser](/wiki/Laser "Laser")*, *[scuba](/wiki/Scuba_set "Scuba set")*.[[247]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b120–121-247)

### Word origins

Further information: [Foreign-language influences in English](/wiki/Foreign-language_influences_in_English "Foreign-language influences in English") and [Lists of English words by country or language of origin](/wiki/Lists_of_English_words_by_country_or_language_of_origin "Lists of English words by country or language of origin")

See also: [Linguistic purism in English](/wiki/Linguistic_purism_in_English "Linguistic purism in English")

English lexicon by source language[[9]](#cite_note-Finkenstaedt1973-9)[[248]](#cite_note-248)

1. French, including Anglo-Norman (28.3%)
2. Latin, including scientific and technical loans (28.2%)
3. Germanic (Old English, Old Norse, Dutch) (25.0%)
4. Greek (5.32%)
5. None given (4.03%)
6. Derived from proper names (3.28%)
7. Other (5.83%)

Throughout its history, English has been a particularly frequent borrower of loanwords from other languages.[[249]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDenningKesslerLeben20077-249) West Germanic words in use since the Anglo-Saxon period still comprise most of the language's core vocabulary, as well as most of its most frequently used words.[[250]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENation2001265-250)[[251]](#cite_note-251)[[242]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999-242) Many sentences can be constructed without loanwords, but not without core Anglo-Saxon vocabulary.[[252]](#cite_note-252) English has formal and informal [speech registers](/wiki/Register_(sociolinguistics) "Register (sociolinguistics)"); informal registers, including child-directed speech, tend to be made up predominantly of Anglo-Saxon vocabulary, while Latinate vocabulary appears more frequently in legal, scientific, and academic writing.[[253]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b124–127-253)[[254]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo199980–81-254)

Prolonged and intense contact with French has resulted in English having a very high proportion of Latinate words – with French loanwords borrowed during different stages of the language's history comprising 28 per cent of the English lexicon.[[255]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006196-255) In all periods of its history, English has also borrowed words from Latin directly,[[245]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKastovsky2006-245)[[242]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999-242) representing another 28 per cent of the lexicon.[[256]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurnley1992409–499) In turn, many of these words had originally entered Latin from Greek. Greek and Latin stems remain highly productive sources for new literary, technical, and scientific vocabulary in English.[[257]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine19994-257)

Loanwords from Old Norse primarily entered English between the 8th and 11th centuries, during the Norse colonisation of eastern and northern England, and typically displaced an Anglo-Saxon equivalent. Many represent core vocabulary – including *give*, *get*, *sky*, *skirt*, *egg*, and *cake*.[[258]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDenningKesslerLeben2007-258)[[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKastovsky1992320,_332-39)

### English loans in other languages

Main article: [Englishisation](/wiki/Englishisation "Englishisation")

English has had a strong influence on the vocabulary of other languages.[[255]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006196-255)[[259]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006692-259) The influence of English comes from such factors as opinion leaders in other countries knowing the English language, the role of English as a world lingua franca, and the large number of books and films that are translated from English into other languages.[[260]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006197-260) That pervasive use of English leads to a conclusion in many places that English is an especially suitable language for expressing new ideas or describing new technologies. Among varieties of English, it is especially American English that influences other languages.[[261]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006198-261) Some languages, such as Chinese, write words borrowed from English mostly as [calques](/wiki/Calque "Calque"), while others, such as Japanese, readily take in English loanwords written in sound-indicating script.[[262]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006202-262) Dubbed films and television programmes are an especially fruitful source of English influence on languages in Europe.[[262]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGottlieb2006202-262)

## Orthography

Since the 9th century, English has been written using the [English alphabet](/wiki/English_alphabet "English alphabet"), which uses the [Latin script](/wiki/Latin_script "Latin script"). [Anglo-Saxon runes](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_runes "Anglo-Saxon runes") were previously used to write Old English, but only in short inscriptions; the overwhelming majority of attested writings in Old English are in the [Old English Latin alphabet](/wiki/Old_English_Latin_alphabet "Old English Latin alphabet").[[33]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGneuss201323-33)

[English orthography](/wiki/English_orthography "English orthography") is multi-layered and complex, with elements of French, Latin, and Greek spelling on top of the native Germanic system.[[263]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwan2006149-263) Further complications have arisen through [sound changes](/wiki/Sound_change "Sound change") with which the orthography has not kept pace.[[50]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass2000a-50) Compared to European languages for which official organisations have promoted spelling reforms, English has spelling that is a less consistent indicator of pronunciation, and standard spellings of words that are more difficult to guess from knowing how a word is pronounced.[[264]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMountford2006-264) There are also systematic [spelling differences between British and American English](/wiki/American_and_British_English_spelling_differences "American and British English spelling differences"). These situations have prompted [proposals for spelling reform in English](/wiki/English-language_spelling_reform "English-language spelling reform").[[265]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeijt2006-265)

Although letters and speech sounds do not have a one-to-one correspondence in standard English spelling, spelling rules that take into account syllable structure, phonetic changes in derived words, and word accent are reliable for most English words.[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDanielsBright1996653-266) Moreover, standard English spelling shows etymological relationships between related words that would be obscured by a closer correspondence between pronunciation and spelling – for example, the words *photograph*, *photography*, and *photographic*,[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDanielsBright1996653-266) or the words *electricity* and *electrical*. While few scholars agree with Chomsky and Halle (1968) that conventional English orthography is "near-optimal",[[263]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwan2006149-263) there is a rationale for current English spelling patterns.[[267]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbercrombieDaniels2006-267) The standard orthography of English is the most widely used writing system in the world.[[268]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMountford2006156-268) Standard English spelling is based on a graphomorphemic segmentation of words into written clues of what meaningful units make up each word.[[269]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMountford2006157–158-269)

Readers of English can generally rely on the correspondence between spelling and pronunciation to be fairly regular for letters or [digraphs](/wiki/Digraph_(orthography) "Digraph (orthography)") used to spell consonant sounds. The letters *b*, *d*, *f*, *h*, *j*, *k*, *l*, *m*, *n*, *p*, *r*, *s*, *t*, *v*, *w*, *y*, *z* represent, respectively, the phonemes /b, d, f, h, dʒ, k, l, m, n, p, r, s, t, v, w, j, z/. The letters *c* and *g* normally represent /k/ and /ɡ/, but there is also a [soft *c*](/wiki/Soft_c "Soft c") pronounced /s/, and a [soft *g*](/wiki/Hard_and_soft_G "Hard and soft G") pronounced /dʒ/. The differences in the pronunciations of the letters *c* and *g* are often signalled by the following letters in standard English spelling. Digraphs used to represent phonemes and phoneme sequences include *ch* for /tʃ/, *sh* for /ʃ/, *th* for /θ/ or /ð/, *ng* for /ŋ/, *qu* for /kw/, and *ph* for /f/ in Greek-derived words. The single letter *x* is generally pronounced as /z/ in word-initial position and as /ks/ otherwise. There are exceptions to these generalisations, often the result of loanwords being spelled according to the spelling patterns of their languages of origin[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDanielsBright1996653-266) or residues of proposals by scholars in the early period of Modern English to follow the spelling patterns of Latin for English words of Germanic origin.[[270]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDanielsBright1996654-270)

For the vowel sounds of the English language, however, correspondences between spelling and pronunciation are more irregular. There are many more vowel phonemes in English than there are single vowel letters (*a*, *e*, *i*, *o*, *u*, *y*, and very rarely *w*). As a result, some "[long vowels](/wiki/Vowel_length#Short_and_long_vowels_in_English "Vowel length")" are often indicated by combinations of letters (like the *oa* in *boat*, the *ow* in *how*, and the *ay* in *stay*), or the historically based [silent *e*](/wiki/Silent_e "Silent e") (as in *note* and *cake*).[[267]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbercrombieDaniels2006-267)

The consequence of this complex orthographic history is that learning to read and write can be challenging in English. It can take longer for school pupils to become independently fluent readers of English than of many other languages, including Italian, Spanish, and German.[[271]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDehaene2009-271) Nonetheless, there is an advantage for learners of English reading in learning the specific sound-symbol regularities that occur in the standard English spellings of commonly used words.[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDanielsBright1996653-266) Such instruction greatly reduces the risk of children experiencing reading difficulties in English.[[272]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcGuinness1997-272)[[273]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShaywitz2003-273) Making primary school teachers more aware of the primacy of morpheme representation in English may help learners learn more efficiently to read and write English.[[274]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMountford2006159-274)

English writing also includes a system of [punctuation](/wiki/Punctuation "Punctuation") marks that is similar to those used in most alphabetic languages around the world. The purpose of punctuation is to mark meaningful grammatical relationships in sentences to aid readers in understanding a text and to indicate features important for reading a text aloud.[[275]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawler2006290-275)

## Dialects, accents, and varieties

Dialectologists identify many [English dialects](/wiki/English_dialects "English dialects"), which usually refer to regional varieties that differ from each other in terms of patterns of grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation. The pronunciation of particular areas distinguishes dialects as separate [regional accents](/wiki/Regional_accents_of_English "Regional accents of English"). The major native dialects of English are often divided by linguists into the two extremely general categories of [British English](/wiki/British_English "British English") (BrE) and [North American English](/wiki/North_American_English "North American English") (NAE).[[276]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b107-276)

The fact that English has been spoken in England for 1,500 years explains why England has a great wealth of regional dialects.[[277]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill199910-277) Within the United Kingdom, [Received Pronunciation](/wiki/Received_Pronunciation "Received Pronunciation") (RP), an educated accent associated originally with [South East England](/wiki/South_East_England "South East England"), has been traditionally used as a broadcast standard and is considered the most prestigious of British accents. The spread of RP (also known as BBC English) through the media has caused many traditional dialects of rural England to recede, as youths adopt the traits of the prestige variety instead of traits from local dialects. At the time of the 1950–61 [Survey of English Dialects](/wiki/Survey_of_English_Dialects "Survey of English Dialects"), grammar and vocabulary differed across the country, but a process of lexical attrition has led most of this variation to disappear.[[278]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill1999125-278)

Nonetheless, this attrition has mostly affected dialectal variation in grammar and vocabulary. Only 3% of the English population actually speak RP, the remainder speaking in regional accents and dialects with varying degrees of RP influence.[[279]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHughesTrudgill19963-279) There is also variability within RP, particularly along class lines between Upper and Middle-class RP speakers and between native RP speakers and speakers who adopt RP later in life.[[280]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHughesTrudgill199637-280) Within Britain, there is also considerable variation along lines of social class; some traits, though exceedingly common, are nonetheless considered "non-standard" and associated with lower-class speakers and identities. An example of this is [*h*-dropping](/wiki/H-dropping "H-dropping"), which was historically a feature of lower-class London English, particularly Cockney, and can now be heard in the local accents of most parts of England. However, it remains largely absent in broadcasting and among the upper crust of British society.[[281]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHughesTrudgill199640-281)

[English in England](/wiki/English_in_England "English in England") can be divided into four major dialect regions: South East English, South West English (also known as [West Country English](/wiki/West_Country_English "West Country English")), Midlands English and [Northern English](/wiki/English_language_in_Northern_England "English language in Northern England"). Within each of these regions, several local dialects exist: within the Northern region, there is a division between the [Yorkshire dialects](/wiki/Yorkshire_dialect "Yorkshire dialect"), the [Geordie](/wiki/Geordie "Geordie") dialect (spoken around [Newcastle](/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne "Newcastle upon Tyne"), in [Northumbria](/wiki/Northumbria_(modern) "Northumbria (modern)")) and the [Lancashire](/wiki/Lancashire_dialect "Lancashire dialect") dialects, which include the urban subdialects of [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester") ([Mancunian](/wiki/Manchester_dialect "Manchester dialect")) and [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool") ([Scouse](/wiki/Scouse "Scouse")). Having been the centre of Danish occupation during the Viking invasions of England, Northern English dialects, particularly the Yorkshire dialect, retain Norse features not found in other English varieties.[[282]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHughesTrudgill199631-282) In the [West Midlands](/wiki/West_Midlands_(region) "West Midlands (region)"), dialects such as [Black Country](/wiki/Black_Country "Black Country") ([Yam Yam](/wiki/Black_Country_dialect "Black Country dialect")), and by less extent [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham") ([Brummie](/wiki/Brummie_dialect "Brummie dialect")), preserve archaic features from Early Modern and Middle English, retaining Germanic elements such as specific grammatical structures and vocabulary.[[283]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkAsprey2013-283)

Since the 15th century, South East England varieties have centred on London, which has been the centre from which dialectal innovations have spread to other dialects. In London, the [Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney") dialect was traditionally used by the lower classes, and it was long a socially stigmatised variety. The spread of Cockney features across the South East led the media to talk of Estuary English as a new dialect, but the notion was criticised by many linguists on the grounds that London had been influencing neighbouring regions throughout history.[[284]](#cite_note-284)[[285]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoach20094-285)[[286]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill199980-286) Traits that have spread from London in recent decades include the use of [intrusive R](/wiki/Linking_and_intrusive_R "Linking and intrusive R") (*drawing* is pronounced "drawring" /ˈdrɔːrɪŋ/), [*t*-glottalisation](/wiki/T-glottalization "T-glottalization") (*Potter* is pronounced with a glottal stop as *Po'er* /ˈpɒʔə/) and [*th*-fronting](/wiki/Th-fronting "Th-fronting"), or the pronunciation of *th-* as /f/ (*thanks* pronounced "fanks") or /v/ (*bother* pronounced "bover").[[287]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill199980–81-287)

[Scots](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language") is today considered a separate language from English, but it has [its origins](/wiki/History_of_the_Scots_language "History of the Scots language") in early Northern Middle English[[288]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAitkenMcArthur197981-288) and developed and changed during its history with influence from other sources, particularly [Scottish Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic "Scottish Gaelic") and Old Norse. Scots itself has a number of regional dialects. In addition to Scots, [Scottish English](/wiki/Scottish_English "Scottish English") comprises the varieties of Standard English spoken in Scotland; most varieties are Northern English accents, with some influence from Scots.[[289]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1982-289)

In [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), various forms of English have been spoken following the [Norman invasion of the island](/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland "Norman invasion of Ireland") during the 11th century. In [County Wexford](/wiki/County_Wexford "County Wexford") and in the area surrounding [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin"), two extinct dialects known as [Forth and Bargy](/wiki/Forth_and_Bargy "Forth and Bargy") and [Fingallian](/wiki/Fingallian "Fingallian") developed as offshoots from Early Middle English and were spoken until the 19th century. Modern [Irish English](/wiki/Irish_English "Irish English"), however, has its roots in English colonisation in the 17th century. Today Irish English is divided into [Ulster English](/wiki/Ulster_English "Ulster English"), the Northern Ireland dialect with strong influence from Scots, and various dialects of the Republic of Ireland. Like Scottish and most North American accents, almost all Irish accents preserve the [rhoticity](/wiki/Rhoticity_in_English "Rhoticity in English") which has been lost in the dialects influenced by RP.[[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarry198286–87-19)[[290]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHickey2007-290)

Due to the relatively strong degree of mixing, mutual accommodation, and koinéisation that occurred during the colonial period, [North American English](/wiki/North_American_English "North American English") has traditionally been perceived as relatively homogeneous, at least in comparison with British dialects. However, modern scholars have strongly opposed this notion, arguing that North American English shows a great deal of phonetic, lexical, and geographic variability. This becomes all the more apparent considering social, ethnolinguistic, and regional varieties such as [African-American English](/wiki/African-American_English "African-American English"), [Chicano English](/wiki/Chicano_English "Chicano English"), [Cajun English](/wiki/Cajun_English "Cajun English"), or [Newfoundland English](/wiki/Newfoundland_English "Newfoundland English").[[291]](#cite_note-291) American accent variation is increasing at the regional level and decreasing at the very local level,[[292]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELabov2012-292) though most Americans still speak within a phonological continuum of similar accents,[[293]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells198234-293) known collectively as [General American English](/wiki/General_American_English "General American English") (GA), with differences hardly noticed even among Americans themselves, including [Midland](/wiki/Midland_American_English "Midland American English") and [Western American English](/wiki/Western_American_English "Western American English").[[294]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowicka2006-294)[[295]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEToon1982-295)[[296]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECassidy1982-296)

[Canadian English](/wiki/Canadian_English "Canadian English") varieties, excepting those from [Atlantic Canada](/wiki/Atlantic_Canada "Atlantic Canada") and possibly [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec"), are generally considered to belong to the GA continuum, although they often show [raising](/wiki/Canadian_raising "Canadian raising") of the vowels [/aɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") and [/aʊ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") before [voiceless consonants](/wiki/Voiceless_consonants "Voiceless consonants") and have distinct norms for writing and pronunciation as well.[[297]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoberg2010-297) [Atlantic Canadian English](/wiki/Atlantic_Canadian_English "Atlantic Canadian English"), notably distinct from [Standard Canadian English](/wiki/Standard_Canadian_English "Standard Canadian English"),[[298]](#cite_note-298) comprises [Maritime English](/wiki/Atlantic_Canadian_English#Maritimes "Atlantic Canadian English") and [Newfoundland English](/wiki/Newfoundland_English "Newfoundland English"). It was influenced mostly by British and Irish English, as well as [Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"), [Scottish Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic "Scottish Gaelic"), and [Acadian French](/wiki/Acadian_French "Acadian French").[[299]](#cite_note-299)

In most American and Canadian English dialects, [rhoticity](/wiki/Rhoticity_in_English "Rhoticity in English") (or *r*-fullness) is dominant, with non-rhoticity (or *r*-dropping) being associated with lower prestige and social class, especially since the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). This contrasts with the situation in England, where non-rhoticity has become the standard.[[300]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELabov1972-300) Varieties beyond GA which have developed distinct sound systems include the [Southern American English](/wiki/Southern_American_English "Southern American English"), [New York City English](/wiki/New_York_City_English "New York City English"), [Eastern New England English](/wiki/Eastern_New_England_English "Eastern New England English"), and [African-American Vernacular English](/wiki/African-American_Vernacular_English "African-American Vernacular English") (AAVE) groups – all of which are historically non-rhotic, save a few varieties of Southern American.

In Southern American English, the most populous grouping outside GA,[[301]](#cite_note-301) rhoticity now strongly prevails, replacing the region's [historical non-rhotic prestige](/wiki/Older_Southern_American_English "Older Southern American English").[[302]](#cite_note-302)[[303]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevineCrockett1966-303)[[304]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchönweitz2001-304) Southern accents are colloquially described as a "drawl" or "twang",[[305]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontgomery1993-305) being recognised most readily by the Southern Vowel Shift initiated by [glide-deleting](/wiki/Monophthong "Monophthong") in the /aɪ/ vowel (e.g. pronouncing *spy* almost like *spa*), the "Southern breaking" of several front pure vowels into a gliding vowel or even two syllables (e.g. pronouncing the word *press* almost like "pray-us"),[[306]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas200895–96-306) the [pin–pen merger](/wiki/Pin%E2%80%93pen_merger "Pin–pen merger"), and other distinctive phonological, grammatical, and lexical features, many of which are actually recent developments of the 19th century or later.[[307]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBailey1997-307)

Spoken primarily by working- and middle-class African Americans, [African-American Vernacular English](/wiki/African-American_Vernacular_English "African-American Vernacular English") (AAVE) is largely non-rhotic, and likely originated among enslaved Africans and African Americans influenced primarily by the non-standard [older Southern dialects](/wiki/Older_Southern_American_English "Older Southern American English"). A minority of linguists,[[308]](#cite_note-308) contrarily, propose that AAVE mostly traces back to African languages spoken by the slaves who had to develop a [pidgin](/wiki/Pidgin "Pidgin") or [English-based creole](/wiki/English-based_creole "English-based creole") to communicate with slaves of other ethnic and linguistic origins.[[309]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBailey2001-309) AAVE's important commonalities with Southern accents suggest it developed into a highly coherent and homogeneous variety in the 19th or early 20th century. AAVE is commonly stigmatised in North America as a form of "broken" or "uneducated" English, as are white Southern accents, but linguists today recognise both as fully developed varieties of English with their own norms shared by large speech communities.[[310]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2002-310)[[311]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPatrick2006b-311)

Since 1788, English has been spoken in [Oceania](/wiki/Oceania "Oceania"), and [Australian English](/wiki/Australian_English "Australian English") has developed as the first language of the vast majority of the inhabitants of the Australian continent, its standard accent being [General Australian](/wiki/General_Australian "General Australian"). The [English of neighbouring New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_English "New Zealand English") has to a lesser degree become an influential standard variety of the language.[[312]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEagleson1982-312) Australian and New Zealand English are each other's closest relatives with few differentiating characteristics, followed by [South African English](/wiki/South_African_English "South African English") and the English of South East England, all of which have similarly non-rhotic accents, aside from some accents in the [South Island](/wiki/South_Island "South Island") of New Zealand. Australian and New Zealand English stand out for their innovative vowels: many short vowels are fronted or raised, whereas many long vowels have diphthongised. Australian English also has a contrast between long and short vowels, not found in most other varieties. Australian English grammar aligns closely with British and American English; like American English, collective plural subjects take on a singular verb, e.g. "the government is" (rather than *are*).[[313]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200216–21-313)[[314]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurridge2010-314) New Zealand English uses front vowels that are often even higher than in Australian English.[[315]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200224–26-315)[[316]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaclagan2010-316)[[317]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGordonCampbellHay_et_al.2004-317)

English is an official language of the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"). Its use is ubiquitous in the country, and appears in areas including on [street signs](/wiki/Road_signs_in_the_Philippines "Road signs in the Philippines"), marquees, and government documents, and in courtrooms, public media, the entertainment industry, and the business sector. It became an important and widely spoken language in the country during the period of American rule between 1898 and 1946.[[318]](#cite_note-318) [Taglish](/wiki/Taglish "Taglish") is a prominent form of [code-switching](/wiki/Code-switching "Code-switching") between [Tagalog](/wiki/Tagalog_language "Tagalog language") and English.[[319]](#cite_note-319)

English is spoken widely in southern Africa and is an official or co-official language in several of the region's countries. In [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa"), English has been spoken since 1820, co-existing with [Afrikaans](/wiki/Afrikaans "Afrikaans") and various African languages such as the [Khoe](/wiki/Khoe_languages "Khoe languages") and [Bantu languages](/wiki/Bantu_languages "Bantu languages"). Today, about nine per cent of the South African population speaks [South African English](/wiki/South_African_English "South African English") (SAE) as a first language. SAE is a non-rhotic variety that tends to follow RP as a norm. It is one of the few non-rhotic English varieties that lack [intrusive R](/wiki/Linking_and_intrusive_R "Linking and intrusive R"). The second-language varieties of South Africa differ based on the native languages of their speakers.[[320]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELanham1982-320) Most phonological differences from RP are in the vowels.[[321]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass2002-321) Consonant differences include the tendency to pronounce /p, t, t͡ʃ, k/ without aspiration (e.g. *pin* pronounced [pɪn] rather than as [pʰɪn] as in most other varieties), while r is often pronounced as a flap [ɾ] instead of as the more common fricative.[[322]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200230–31-322)

Nigerian English is a variety of English spoken in [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria"); over 150 million Nigerians speak some form of the language.[[323]](#cite_note-323) Though traditionally based on British English, increasing United States influence during the latter 20th century has resulted in American English vocabulary entering Nigerian English. Additionally, some new words and collocations have emerged from the variety out of a need to express concepts specific to the culture of the nation (e.g. *senior wife*).[[324]](#cite_note-324)

Varieties of English are spoken throughout the former British colonial possessions in the Caribbean, including Jamaica, the [Leeward](/wiki/Leeward_Islands "Leeward Islands") and [Windward Islands](/wiki/Windward_Islands "Windward Islands"), [Trinidad and Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago "Trinidad and Tobago"), [Barbados](/wiki/Barbados "Barbados"), the [Cayman Islands](/wiki/Cayman_Islands "Cayman Islands"), and [Belize](/wiki/Belize "Belize"). Each of these areas is home both to a local variety of English and a local English-based creole, combining English and African languages. The most prominent varieties are [Jamaican English](/wiki/Jamaican_English "Jamaican English") and [Jamaican Creole](/wiki/Jamaican_Creole "Jamaican Creole"). In Central America, English-based creoles are spoken on the Caribbean coasts of Nicaragua and Panama.[[325]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawton1982-325) Residents are often fluent in both the local English variety and the local creole languages, and frequently [code-switch](/wiki/Code-switch "Code-switch") between them. The relationship between different varieties can be conceptualised as a continuum, in which more creole-like or RP-like forms function as more formal and informal registers of the language respectively.[[326]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah2002115-326)

Most Caribbean varieties are based on British English and consequently, most are non-rhotic, except for formal styles of Jamaican English which are often rhotic. Jamaican English differs from RP in its vowel inventory, which has a distinction between long and short vowels rather than tense and lax vowels as in Standard English. The diphthongs /ei/ and /ou/ are monophthongs [eː] and [oː] or even the reverse diphthongs [ie] and [uo] (e.g. *bay* and *boat* pronounced [bʲeː] and [bʷoːt]). Often word-final consonant clusters are simplified so that "child" is pronounced [t͡ʃail] and "wind" [win].[[327]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah2002117–118-327)[[328]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELawton1982256–260-328)[[329]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah2002115–116-329)

[Indian English](/wiki/Indian_English "Indian English") historically tends towards RP as an ideal, with the proximity of speakers to RP generally reflective of class distinctions. Indian English accents are marked by the pronunciation of phonemes such as /t/ and /d/ (often pronounced with retroflex articulation as [ʈ] and [ɖ]) and the replacement of /θ/ and /ð/ with dentals [t̪] and [d̪]. Sometimes Indian English speakers may also use spelling-based pronunciations where the silent ⟨h⟩ found in words such as *ghost* is pronounced as an Indian [voiced aspirated](/wiki/Voiced_aspirated "Voiced aspirated") stop [ɡʱ].[[330]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESailaja200919–24-330)

[Non-native English speakers](/wiki/English_as_a_second_or_foreign_language "English as a second or foreign language") may pronounce words differently due to having not fully mastered English pronunciation. This can happen either because they apply the [speech rules](/wiki/Phonology "Phonology") of their mother tongue to English ("interference") or through implementing strategies similar to those used in [first language acquisition](/wiki/First_language_acquisition "First language acquisition"). They may create novel pronunciations for English sounds not found in their first language.[[331]](#cite_note-331)

On 24 February 2022, [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia") invaded [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine"). The resultant conflict is the largest and deadliest war in Europe since [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). It is a major escalation of the [war between the two countries](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War") that began when Russia attacked Ukraine [in 2014](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_war#History "Russo-Ukrainian war").[[14]](#cite_note-17)[[15]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamani202374-18)[[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTED'Anieri2023i;_98-19) The fighting has caused hundreds of thousands of [military casualties](/wiki/Casualties_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "Casualties of the Russo-Ukrainian War") and tens of thousands of Ukrainian [civilian casualties](/wiki/Attacks_on_civilians_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Attacks on civilians in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"). As of December 2025, Russian troops [occupy almost 20% of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian-occupied_territories_of_Ukraine "Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine").[[17]](#cite_note-20) From a population of 41 million, about 8 million Ukrainians have been internally displaced[[18]](#cite_note-21) and 6–7 million have [fled the country](/wiki/Ukrainian_refugee_crisis "Ukrainian refugee crisis"),[[19]](#cite_note-22) creating Europe's [largest refugee crisis](/wiki/List_of_largest_refugee_crises "List of largest refugee crises") since World War II.

In late 2021, Russia [massed troops near Ukraine's borders](/wiki/Prelude_to_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Prelude to the Russian invasion of Ukraine") and [issued demands](/wiki/December_2021_Russian_ultimatum_to_NATO "December 2021 Russian ultimatum to NATO") to [the West](/wiki/Western_world "Western world"), including a ban on Ukraine ever joining [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO").[[20]](#cite_note-23)[[21]](#cite_note-v440-24) After repeatedly denying having plans to attack Ukraine, on 24 February 2022, Russian president [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") [announced](/wiki/On_conducting_a_special_military_operation "On conducting a special military operation") a "[special military operation](/wiki/Special_military_operation "Special military operation")", saying that it was to support the Russian-backed breakaway [republics of Donetsk](/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic "Donetsk People's Republic") and [Luhansk](/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic "Luhansk People's Republic"), whose [paramilitary forces](/wiki/Russian_separatist_forces_in_Ukraine "Russian separatist forces in Ukraine") had been fighting Ukraine in the [Donbas War](/wiki/War_in_Donbas "War in Donbas") since 2014. Putin espoused [irredentist](/wiki/Russian_irredentism "Russian irredentism") and [imperialist](/wiki/Russian_neo-imperialism "Russian neo-imperialism") views challenging Ukraine's legitimacy as a state, [baselessly claimed](/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine#Russian_themes "Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") that the Ukrainian government were [neo-Nazis](/wiki/Far-right_politics_in_Ukraine#Russian_disinformation "Far-right politics in Ukraine") committing [genocide](/wiki/Allegations_of_genocide_in_Donbas "Allegations of genocide in Donbas") against the [Russian minority](/wiki/Russians_in_Ukraine "Russians in Ukraine") in the [Donbas](/wiki/Donbas "Donbas"), and said that Russia's goal was to "demilitarise and denazify" Ukraine.[[22]](#cite_note-25)[[23]](#cite_note-The_Conversation:_Baseless_but_not_unprecedented-26)[[24]](#cite_note-27)[[25]](#cite_note-28)[[26]](#cite_note-i505-29) Russian air strikes and a ground [invasion](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine") were launched on a [northern front](/wiki/Northern_Ukraine_campaign "Northern Ukraine campaign") from [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus "Belarus") towards the capital [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv"), a [southern front](/wiki/Southern_Ukraine_campaign "Southern Ukraine campaign") from occupied [Crimea](/wiki/Crimea "Crimea"), and an [eastern front](/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine_campaign "Eastern Ukraine campaign") from the Donbas towards [Kharkiv](/wiki/Kharkiv "Kharkiv"). Ukraine enacted [martial law](/wiki/Martial_law_in_Ukraine "Martial law in Ukraine"), ordered [a general mobilisation](/wiki/Mobilization_in_Ukraine "Mobilization in Ukraine"), and severed diplomatic [relations with Russia](/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations "Russia–Ukraine relations").

Russian troops retreated from the north and the outskirts of Kyiv by April 2022, after encountering stiff resistance and logistical challenges.
