The [Bucha massacre](/wiki/Bucha_massacre "Bucha massacre") was uncovered after their withdrawal. Russia launched an [offensive in the Donbas](/wiki/Battle_of_Donbas_(2022) "Battle of Donbas (2022)") and captured [Mariupol](/wiki/Mariupol "Mariupol") after [a destructive siege](/wiki/Siege_of_Mariupol "Siege of Mariupol"). Russia continued to bomb military and civilian targets far from the front, and [struck Ukraine's energy grid](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure (2022–present)") during winter months. In late 2022, Ukraine launched successful counteroffensives in [the south](/wiki/2022_Kherson_counteroffensive "2022 Kherson counteroffensive") and [east](/wiki/2022_Kharkiv_counteroffensive "2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive"), liberating most of [Kharkiv Oblast](/wiki/Kharkiv_Oblast "Kharkiv Oblast"). Soon after, Russia illegally [annexed four partly-occupied provinces](/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts "Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts"). In November, Ukraine [liberated the city of Kherson](/wiki/Liberation_of_Kherson "Liberation of Kherson") and [all land west of the Dnipro river](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Kherson_Oblast "Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast"). After small but steady Russian advances in the east in the first half of 2024, Ukraine launched a cross-border [offensive into Russia's Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Kursk_campaign "Kursk campaign") in August, where [North Korean](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") soldiers were sent to help Russia. The [United Nations Human Rights Office](/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights "Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights") reports that Russia is committing severe [human rights violations](/wiki/Russian-occupied_territories_of_Ukraine#Violations_and_war_crimes "Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine") in occupied Ukraine. The direct cost of the war for Russia has been over US$450 billion.[[27]](#cite_note-DU-30)[[28]](#cite_note-mt20250114-31)[[29]](#cite_note-kpost20250115-32)

The Russian invasion was met with [international condemnation](/wiki/Reactions_to_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine"). The [United Nations General Assembly](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly "United Nations General Assembly") passed [a resolution](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_ES-11/1 "United Nations General Assembly Resolution ES-11/1") condemning the invasion and demanding a full Russian withdrawal. The [International Court of Justice](/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice "International Court of Justice") ordered Russia to halt military operations and the [Council of Europe](/wiki/Council_of_Europe "Council of Europe") expelled Russia. Many countries imposed [sanctions](/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine") on Russia and its ally Belarus while providing large-scale [humanitarian](/wiki/List_of_humanitarian_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "List of humanitarian aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War") and [military aid](/wiki/List_of_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War") to Ukraine. [Protests occurred](/wiki/Protests_against_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Protests against the Russian invasion of Ukraine") around the world, with anti-war [protesters in Russia](/wiki/2022_anti-war_protests_in_Russia "2022 anti-war protests in Russia") being met by mass arrests and greater media [censorship](/wiki/Censorship_in_Russia "Censorship in Russia"). The Russian attacks on civilians and policies in occupied territories have led to [allegations of genocide](/wiki/Allegations_of_genocide_of_Ukrainians_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "Allegations of genocide of Ukrainians in the Russo-Ukrainian War").[[30]](#cite_note-Etkind-33)[[31]](#cite_note-h710-34)[[32]](#cite_note-q611-35)[[33]](#cite_note-v008-36) War-related disruption to Ukrainian agriculture and shipping contributed to a [world food crisis](/wiki/2022%E2%80%932023_global_food_crises "2022–2023 global food crises"); war-related environmental damage has been described as [ecocide](/wiki/Ecocide#Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Ecocide"). The [International Criminal Court](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court "International Criminal Court") (ICC) opened [an investigation](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigation_in_Ukraine "International Criminal Court investigation in Ukraine") into [crimes against humanity](/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity "Crimes against humanity"), [war crimes](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "War crimes in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), [abduction of Ukrainian children](/wiki/Child_abductions_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Child abductions in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), and genocide against Ukrainians. The ICC issued [arrest warrants for Putin](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_arrest_warrants_for_Russian_leaders "International Criminal Court arrest warrants for Russian leaders") and five other Russian officials. [Peace negotiations](/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Peace negotiations in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)") have stalled. Russia has repeatedly refused calls for a ceasefire.

## Background

Further information: [Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War") and [Russia–Ukraine relations](/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations "Russia–Ukraine relations")

### Post-Soviet relations

After the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union") in 1991, Russia and Ukraine maintained cordial relations. In return for security guarantees, Ukraine signed the [Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty](/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons "Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons") in 1994 and gave up its [nuclear weapons](/wiki/Ukraine_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Ukraine and weapons of mass destruction").[[34]](#cite_note-37) Russia, the US, and UK agreed in the [Budapest Memorandum](/wiki/Budapest_Memorandum "Budapest Memorandum") to respect Ukraine's sovereignty and borders.[[35]](#cite_note-38) In 1999, Russia signed the [Charter for European Security](/wiki/Charter_for_European_Security "Charter for European Security"), affirming that every country had the right "to choose or change its security arrangements" and to join military alliances.[[36]](#cite_note-39) In 2005, Putin said that if Ukraine wanted to join NATO, "we will respect their choice".[[37]](#cite_note-40)

### Ukrainian revolution

Main article: [Revolution of Dignity](/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity "Revolution of Dignity")

In 2013, [Ukraine's parliament](/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada "Verkhovna Rada") approved finalising the [European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement](/wiki/European_Union%E2%80%93Ukraine_Association_Agreement "European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement").[[38]](#cite_note-41) Russia put pressure on Ukraine to reject the agreement and [imposed economic sanctions](/wiki/Russian_embargo_of_Ukrainian_goods "Russian embargo of Ukrainian goods") on the country.[[39]](#cite_note-42) Kremlin adviser [Sergei Glazyev](/wiki/Sergei_Glazyev "Sergei Glazyev") warned in September 2013 that if Ukraine signed the EU agreement, Russia would no longer acknowledge Ukraine's borders.[[40]](#cite_note-43)

In November, Ukrainian president [Viktor Yanukovych](/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych "Viktor Yanukovych") suddenly withdrew from signing the agreement,[[41]](#cite_note-44) choosing closer ties to Russia instead. This coerced withdrawal sparked massive protests known as [Euromaidan](/wiki/Euromaidan "Euromaidan"), culminating in the [Revolution of Dignity](/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity "Revolution of Dignity") in February 2014. Almost [100 protesters were killed](/wiki/Maidan_casualties "Maidan casualties") by state forces, most of them shot by police snipers. Despite signing [an agreement](/wiki/Agreement_on_settlement_of_political_crisis_in_Ukraine "Agreement on settlement of political crisis in Ukraine"), Yanukovych secretly fled. Ukraine's parliament then [voted to remove him](/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych#Removal_from_presidency "Viktor Yanukovych") and hold new elections.[[42]](#cite_note-b713-45)

### Russian invasion of Crimea and Donbas

Main articles: [2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine](/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine "2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine"), [2014 Russian annexation of Crimea](/wiki/2014_Russian_annexation_of_Crimea "2014 Russian annexation of Crimea"), and [War in Donbas](/wiki/War_in_Donbas "War in Donbas")

On 27 February 2014, [Russian soldiers with no insignia](/wiki/Little_green_men_(Russo-Ukrainian_War) "Little green men (Russo-Ukrainian War)") began to [occupy](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Crimea "Russian occupation of Crimea") the Ukrainian territory of Crimea,[[43]](#cite_note-46) blockading Ukrainian military bases.[[44]](#cite_note-47) Russia [annexed Crimea](/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation "Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation") in March, after a [widely-condemned and disputed referendum](/wiki/2014_Crimean_status_referendum "2014 Crimean status referendum"). Several scholars have likened the annexation to Nazi Germany's [Anschluss](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss") of Austria.[[45]](#cite_note-48)[[46]](#cite_note-49)[[47]](#cite_note-z259-50)

[Pro-Russian protests](/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine "2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine") followed in the Ukrainian cities of [Donetsk](/wiki/Donetsk "Donetsk") and [Luhansk](/wiki/Luhansk "Luhansk"), covertly funded and organized by Russia.[[48]](#cite_note-51) In April 2014, armed [Russian paramilitaries](/wiki/Russian_separatist_forces_in_Donbas "Russian separatist forces in Donbas") seized [Sloviansk](/wiki/Sloviansk "Sloviansk") and other settlements, proclaiming the [Donetsk People's Republic](/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic "Donetsk People's Republic") (DPR) and [Luhansk People's Republic](/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic "Luhansk People's Republic") (LPR) as independent. Their commander, [Igor Girkin](/wiki/Igor_Girkin "Igor Girkin"), acknowledged that this sparked the [War in Donbas](/wiki/War_in_Donbas "War in Donbas"), as Ukraine soon launched an operation to retake the territory.[[49]](#cite_note-52)[[50]](#cite_note-Unnamed_War_Sloviansk-53)[[51]](#cite_note-AJ-54) Russia covertly supported the separatists with troops, tanks and artillery.[[52]](#cite_note-55) The [International Criminal Court](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigation_in_Ukraine "International Criminal Court investigation in Ukraine") judged that the war was a national and international armed conflict involving Russia,[[53]](#cite_note-56) and the [European Court of Human Rights](/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights "European Court of Human Rights") judged that Russia controlled the DPR and LPR from 2014 onward.[[54]](#cite_note-57) Ukraine's parliament declared the Donbas region to be occupied by Russia.[[55]](#cite_note-58)

The annexation of Crimea and Donbas war sparked a wave of [Russian nationalism](/wiki/Russian_nationalism "Russian nationalism"). Analyst [Vladimir Socor](/wiki/Vladimir_Socor "Vladimir Socor") called Putin's [2014 speech](/wiki/Crimean_speech_of_Vladimir_Putin "Crimean speech of Vladimir Putin") following the annexation a "manifesto of [Greater-Russia irredentism](/wiki/Russian_irredentism "Russian irredentism")".[[56]](#cite_note-59) Putin began referring to "[Novorossiya](/wiki/Novorossiya "Novorossiya")" (New Russia), a former Russian imperial territory that covered much of southern Ukraine.[[57]](#cite_note-60) Russian-backed forces were influenced by [Russian neo-imperialism](/wiki/Russian_neo-imperialism "Russian neo-imperialism")[[58]](#cite_note-61) and sought to create a [new Novorossiya](/wiki/Novorossiya_(confederation) "Novorossiya (confederation)").[[59]](#cite_note-62)

When the conflict began in 2014, Ukraine was officially [neutral](/wiki/Neutral_country "Neutral country")[[61]](#cite_note-Atlantic_Council:_Ukrainian_neutrality-64) and said it was not seeking NATO membership.[[62]](#cite_note-65)[[63]](#cite_note-66) Following Russia's occupation of Crimea and [invasion of the Donbas](/wiki/War_in_Donbas#August_2014_invasion_by_Russian_forces "War in Donbas"), Ukraine's parliament voted in December 2014 to revoke the country's neutral status and seek [NATO membership](/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations "Ukraine–NATO relations").[[64]](#cite_note-67)[[65]](#cite_note-68)

The [Minsk agreements](/wiki/Minsk_agreements "Minsk agreements") (September 2014 and February 2015) aimed to resolve the conflict, but ceasefires and further negotiations failed.[[66]](#cite_note-69) The [West](/wiki/Western_world "Western world")'s weak response to Russian actions led Russia to believe the West would not react strongly to the 2022 invasion.[[67]](#cite_note-70)[[68]](#cite_note-71)[[69]](#cite_note-72) Several political scientists said this encouraged further Russian aggression.[[70]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamani202311-73)[[71]](#cite_note-u485-74)[[72]](#cite_note-o290-75)

### Economic aspects

Economic interests were also a motive for Russia's invasion of Ukraine and [annexation of the southeast](/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts "Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts"). Control of [lithium](/wiki/Lithium "Lithium") deposits in the Donbas and Ukraine's grain wealth would give Russia a "monopoly on the world market".[[73]](#cite_note-DD-76) In 2022, Russian General Vladimir Ovchinsky confirmed that the "Russian special operation" aimed to seize Ukrainian lithium deposits.[[27]](#cite_note-DU-30)[[74]](#cite_note-RA-77)

The US government estimates that Russia's economic losses from the war and Western sanctions will amount to around $1.3 trillion by 2025, and Russia's direct financial spending on the invasion is estimated at $250 billion (as of late 2024) – costs that Russia could not have foreseen. According to a study published in mid-2022 by Canadian think tank SecDev, Russia seized energy reserves, metals and minerals worth at least $12.4 trillion in the Donbas. The total value of raw material stocks in Ukraine is estimated at over $26 trillion.[[27]](#cite_note-DU-30)

The Russian elite, especially Russian generals, had invested assets and property in Ukraine for [money laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering "Money laundering") purposes before the invasion.[[73]](#cite_note-DD-76)

## Prelude

Main article: [Prelude to the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Prelude_to_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Prelude to the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

Further information: [Russian opposition to Ukrainian NATO membership](/wiki/Russian_opposition_to_Ukrainian_NATO_membership "Russian opposition to Ukrainian NATO membership") and [Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

### Russian military buildup and demands

There was a Russian military build-up near Ukraine's borders in March and April 2021,[[75]](#cite_note-78) and again in both Russia and Belarus from October 2021 onward.[[76]](#cite_note-79) Russia said it was only holding [military exercises](/wiki/Military_exercise "Military exercise"). Members of its government, including Putin, repeatedly denied having plans to invade Ukraine, issuing denials up until the day before the invasion.[[77]](#cite_note-denials-80)[[78]](#cite_note-Deny-81)[[79]](#cite_note-Czech-82)

While Russian troops massed on Ukraine's borders, [Russia's proxy forces](/wiki/Russian_separatist_forces_in_Ukraine "Russian separatist forces in Ukraine") launched thousands of attacks on Ukrainian troops in the Donbas.[[80]](#cite_note-83) [Observers](/wiki/OSCE_Special_Monitoring_Mission_to_Ukraine "OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine") from the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") (OSCE) reported more than 90,000 ceasefire violations throughout 2021, most in Russian-controlled territory.[[81]](#cite_note-84)

In July 2021, Putin published "[On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians](/wiki/On_the_Historical_Unity_of_Russians_and_Ukrainians "On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians")", in which he called Ukraine "historically Russian lands" and claimed there is "no historical basis" for the "idea of Ukrainian people as a nation separate from the Russians".[[82]](#cite_note-Duben-85)[[83]](#cite_note-86) Putin was accused of promoting [Russian imperialism](/wiki/Russian_imperialism "Russian imperialism"),[[84]](#cite_note-87) historical revisionism and disinformation.[[85]](#cite_note-88)[[86]](#cite_note-89)

The [December 2021 Russian ultimatum to NATO](/wiki/December_2021_Russian_ultimatum_to_NATO "December 2021 Russian ultimatum to NATO"), included demands that NATO end all activity in its Eastern European member states and ban Ukraine or any [former Soviet state](/wiki/Post-Soviet_states "Post-Soviet states") from ever joining the alliance.[[21]](#cite_note-v440-24)[[87]](#cite_note-Reuters_17_Dec_21-90)[[88]](#cite_note-FG-91) Russia's government said NATO was a threat and warned of a military response if it followed an "aggressive line".[[89]](#cite_note-92) A US official said the US was willing to discuss the proposals, but there were some that "the Russians know are unacceptable" and had already been ruled out.[[87]](#cite_note-Reuters_17_Dec_21-90) NATO secretary general [Jens Stoltenberg](/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg "Jens Stoltenberg") replied that "Russia has no veto" on whether Ukraine joins, and "has no right to establish a [sphere of influence](/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence") to try to control their neighbours".[[90]](#cite_note-93) NATO underlined that it is a [defensive alliance](/wiki/Collective_security "Collective security"), and had [co-operated with Russia](/wiki/Russia-NATO_relations "Russia-NATO relations") until the Crimea annexation.[[91]](#cite_note-NATO_myths-94)

Several Western political analysts suggested that Russia knew its "unrealistic demands" would be rejected,[[87]](#cite_note-Reuters_17_Dec_21-90) giving it a [pretext](/wiki/Pretext "Pretext") to invade.[[92]](#cite_note-95) No countries bordering Russia had joined NATO since 2004. Ukraine had not yet applied, and some NATO states would likely veto its membership.[[93]](#cite_note-96) Analysts [Taras Kuzio](/wiki/Taras_Kuzio "Taras Kuzio") and [Vladimir Socor](/wiki/Vladimir_Socor "Vladimir Socor") agree that "when Russia made its decision to invade Ukraine, that country was more remote than ever not only from NATO membership but from any track that might lead to membership".[[88]](#cite_note-FG-91) Political scientists [Michael McFaul](/wiki/Michael_McFaul "Michael McFaul") and Robert Person said Russia's occupation of Crimea and the Donbas had already blocked Ukraine's NATO membership; they suggested Putin's real aim was to subjugate Ukraine.[[94]](#cite_note-Person-McFaul1-97)

NATO offered to negotiate some of Russia's demands and to improve military [transparency](/wiki/Transparency_(behavior) "Transparency (behavior)"), as long as Russia stopped its troop buildup.[[95]](#cite_note-98) The alliance rejected Russia's demand to keep Ukraine out of NATO forever, pointing out that Russia had signed agreements affirming the right of Ukraine and other countries to join alliances.[[96]](#cite_note-ElPais-99)[[73]](#cite_note-DD-76) The US proposed that itself and Russia sign an agreement not to station missiles or troops in Ukraine.[[96]](#cite_note-ElPais-99) Putin replied that Russia's demands had been "ignored", and the Russian troop buildup continued.[[97]](#cite_note-100)

Western leaders vowed heavy sanctions should Putin invade rather than negotiate.[[98]](#cite_note-101) French president [Emmanuel Macron](/wiki/Emmanuel_Macron "Emmanuel Macron")[[99]](#cite_note-102) and German chancellor [Olaf Scholz](/wiki/Olaf_Scholz "Olaf Scholz") met Putin in February 2022 to dissuade him from invading. Putin told Scholz that Ukraine should not be an independent state.[[100]](#cite_note-103) Zelenskyy said Putin had broken agreements and could not be trusted to respect Ukrainian neutrality.[[101]](#cite_note-104) Ukraine had been a neutral country in 2014 when Russia occupied Crimea and [invaded the Donbas](/wiki/2014_Russian_invasion_of_the_Donbas "2014 Russian invasion of the Donbas").[[61]](#cite_note-Atlantic_Council:_Ukrainian_neutrality-64)[[102]](#cite_note-Chatham_House:_How_to_end_Russia's_war_on_Ukraine-105) At the [Munich Security Conference](/wiki/Munich_Security_Conference "Munich Security Conference"), Zelenskyy called for Western powers to end their "[appeasement](/wiki/Appeasement "Appeasement")" of Putin and give a timeframe for when Ukraine could join NATO.[[103]](#cite_note-106)

Shortly before the invasion, Russia's proxy forces stepped up attacks on Ukrainian forces and civilians in the Donbas.[[104]](#cite_note-BBC_19_Feb_2022-107)[[105]](#cite_note-Guardian_18_Feb_2022-108) Separatist leaders warned that Ukraine was about to launch an offensive, but they gave no evidence, and *[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")* noted it would be "exceedingly risky" for Ukraine to assault the Donbas while Russian troops were massed on its borders.[[105]](#cite_note-Guardian_18_Feb_2022-108) Ukraine and Western leaders accused Russia of staging [false flag](/wiki/False_flag "False flag") attacks and trying to provoke retaliation, to give Russia a pretext for invading.[[104]](#cite_note-BBC_19_Feb_2022-107)[[105]](#cite_note-Guardian_18_Feb_2022-108) On 17 February, Russian proxy forces [shelled a kindergarten](/wiki/Stanytsia_Luhanska_kindergarten_bombing "Stanytsia Luhanska kindergarten bombing") in Ukrainian-held territory, then blamed it on Ukraine.[[105]](#cite_note-Guardian_18_Feb_2022-108) Zelenskyy said his military would not respond to the provocations.[[104]](#cite_note-BBC_19_Feb_2022-107)

### Invasion plans

The [Royal United Services Institute](/wiki/Royal_United_Services_Institute "Royal United Services Institute") reported that Russia's plan involved defeating Ukraine within ten days and capturing or killing its government, followed by ["mopping up" operations](/wiki/Zachistka "Zachistka"); establishing [filtration camps for Ukrainians](/wiki/Russian_filtration_camps_for_Ukrainians "Russian filtration camps for Ukrainians"); setting up occupation regimes; executing people involved in the Revolution of Dignity; and annexation.[[106]](#cite_note-RUSI_invasion_plan-109)[[107]](#cite_note-KyivPost_invasion_plan-110)[[108]](#cite_note-SkyNews_invasion_plan-111) The decision to invade was reportedly made by Putin and a small group of [war hawks](/wiki/War_hawk "War hawk") or *[siloviki](/wiki/Silovik "Silovik")* in Putin's inner circle, including national security adviser [Nikolai Patrushev](/wiki/Nikolai_Patrushev "Nikolai Patrushev") and [defence minister](/wiki/Minister_of_Defence_(Russia) "Minister of Defence (Russia)") [Sergei Shoigu](/wiki/Sergei_Shoigu "Sergei Shoigu").[[109]](#cite_note-112)

After the invasion began, Ukrainian and Western analysts assessed that Putin seemed to have believed the Russian military could seize [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv") within days. This assessment led to the conclusion that "taking Kyiv in three days" had been the original goal of the invasion.[[110]](#cite_note-Sheftalovich2-113)[[111]](#cite_note-France_24-114)[[112]](#cite_note-115)

#### Putin's invasion announcement

Main article: [Putin's invasion of Ukraine speech](/wiki/Putin%27s_invasion_of_Ukraine_speech "Putin's invasion of Ukraine speech")

On 21 February, Putin [announced](/wiki/Putin%27s_recognition_of_the_Donbas_republics "Putin's recognition of the Donbas republics") that Russia recognised the [Donetsk People's Republic](/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic "Donetsk People's Republic") and [Luhansk People's Republic](/wiki/Luhansk_People%27s_Republic "Luhansk People's Republic") as independent states. The following day, Russia announced that it was sending troops into the territories as "peacekeepers",[[113]](#cite_note-116) and the [Federation Council of Russia](/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia) "Federation Council (Russia)") authorised the use of military force abroad.[[114]](#cite_note-117)

Before 5 a.m. Kyiv time on 24 February, Putin, in [another speech](/wiki/Putin%27s_invasion_of_Ukraine_speech "Putin's invasion of Ukraine speech"), announced a "[special military operation](/wiki/Special_military_operation "Special military operation")", which effectively declared war on Ukraine.[[115]](#cite_note-Meduza_Putin_announces_invasion-118)[[116]](#cite_note-119) Putin said the operation was to "protect the people" of the Russian-controlled breakaway republics. He [baselessly claimed](/wiki/Allegations_of_genocide_in_Donbas "Allegations of genocide in Donbas") that Russians in the Donbas had "been facing humiliation and genocide perpetrated by the Kyiv regime" for 8 years.[[23]](#cite_note-The_Conversation:_Baseless_but_not_unprecedented-26) Putin said Russia was being threatened: he [baselessly claimed](/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine#Russian_themes "Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") that Ukrainian officials [were neo-Nazis](/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine#Allegations_of_Nazism "Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") under Western control, that Ukraine was developing nuclear weapons, and that a hostile NATO was building up its forces and infrastructure in Ukraine.[[117]](#cite_note-Putin_declaration-120)[[118]](#cite_note-bbc22422-121) He said Russia sought the "demilitarisation and denazification" of Ukraine, and denied the legitimacy of the Ukrainian state.[[118]](#cite_note-bbc22422-121)[[119]](#cite_note-Time22222-122) Putin said he had no plans to occupy Ukraine.[[117]](#cite_note-Putin_declaration-120) The invasion began within minutes of Putin's speech.[[115]](#cite_note-Meduza_Putin_announces_invasion-118)

## Events

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)").

For a more comprehensive list, see [List of military engagements during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/List_of_military_engagements_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "List of military engagements during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)").

The invasion began at dawn on 24 February.[[115]](#cite_note-Meduza_Putin_announces_invasion-118)[[120]](#cite_note-123) It was the biggest attack on a European country and first full-scale war in Europe since World War II.[[121]](#cite_note-124) Russia launched a simultaneous ground and air attack.[[122]](#cite_note-CriticalThreats-125)[[123]](#cite_note-ISW_4MAR-126) Missiles struck targets throughout Ukraine,[[124]](#cite_note-127) and Russian troops invaded from the north, east, and south.[[125]](#cite_note-128) Russia did not officially declare war.[[126]](#cite_note-University_of_Hull_2023_u063-129) Immediately after the invasion began, Zelenskyy declared [martial law in Ukraine](/wiki/Martial_law_in_Ukraine "Martial law in Ukraine") in a video speech.[[127]](#cite_note-130) The same evening, he ordered a [general mobilisation](/wiki/2022_Ukrainian_mobilization "2022 Ukrainian mobilization") of all Ukrainian males aged 18–60,[[128]](#cite_note-Interfax_2022-131) prohibiting them from leaving the country.[[129]](#cite_note-132)

The first stage of the invasion was conducted on four fronts: one towards western [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv") from Belarus by the Russian [Eastern Military District](/wiki/Eastern_Military_District "Eastern Military District"), one deployed towards eastern Kyiv by the [Central Military District](/wiki/Central_Military_District "Central Military District") (northeastern front), comprised the [41st Combined Arms Army](/wiki/41st_Combined_Arms_Army "41st Combined Arms Army") and the [2nd Guards Combined Arms Army](/wiki/2nd_Guards_Combined_Arms_Army "2nd Guards Combined Arms Army"),[[130]](#cite_note-TR-133) one deployed towards Kharkiv, and a fourth, southern front originating in Crimea and Russia's [Rostov oblast](/wiki/Rostov_Oblast "Rostov Oblast") with an eastern axis towards Odesa and a western area of operations toward [Mariupol](/wiki/Mariupol "Mariupol").[[130]](#cite_note-TR-133) The invasion was unexpectedly met by fierce resistance.[[131]](#cite_note-134) Russia failed to take Kyiv and was repulsed in the battles of [Irpin](/wiki/Battle_of_Irpin "Battle of Irpin"), [Hostomel](/wiki/Battle_of_Hostomel "Battle of Hostomel"), and [Bucha](/wiki/Battle_of_Bucha "Battle of Bucha"). The Russians tried to encircle the capital, but defenders under [Oleksandr Syrskyi](/wiki/Oleksandr_Syrskyi "Oleksandr Syrskyi") held their ground, effectively using Western [Javelin anti-tank missiles](/wiki/FGM-148_Javelin "FGM-148 Javelin") and [Stinger anti-aircraft missiles](/wiki/FIM-92_Stinger "FIM-92 Stinger") to thin Russian supply lines and stall the offensive.[[132]](#cite_note-135)

By 7 April, Russian troops deployed to the northern front pulled back from Kyiv, to resupply and redeploy to the Donbas to reinforce the renewed invasion of southeastern Ukraine. The northeastern front was similarly withdrawn for redeployment to southeastern Ukraine.[[130]](#cite_note-TR-133)[[133]](#cite_note-news.yahoo.com-136) On 26 April, delegates from the US and 40 allied nations [met at Ramstein Air Base](/wiki/2022_Ramstein_Air_Base_meeting "2022 Ramstein Air Base meeting") in Germany to discuss [a coalition](/wiki/Ukraine_Defense_Contact_Group "Ukraine Defense Contact Group") to provide economic support, military supplies and refitting to Ukraine.[[134]](#cite_note-137) Following Putin's [Victory Day](/wiki/Victory_Day_(9_May)#In_Russia "Victory Day (9 May)") speech on 9 May, US Director of National Intelligence [Avril Haines](/wiki/Avril_Haines "Avril Haines") said no short term resolution should be expected.[[135]](#cite_note-138)

Ukraine's reliance on Western-supplied equipment constrained operational effectiveness, as supplying countries feared Ukraine would use Western-made matériel to strike targets in Russia.[[136]](#cite_note-Sabbagh-139) Experts disagreed on the future of the conflict; some suggested Ukraine should trade territory for peace,[[137]](#cite_note-140) others believed Ukraine could maintain its resistance due to Russian losses.[[138]](#cite_note-141)

### Initial invasion (24 February – 7 April 2022)

Main article: [2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine")

The invasion began on 24 February, launched out of Belarus to target Kyiv, and from the northeast against the city of Kharkiv. The southeastern front was conducted as two separate spearheads, from Crimea and the southeast against Luhansk and Donetsk.[[139]](#cite_note-142)

#### Kyiv and northern front

Further information: [Capture of Chernobyl](/wiki/Capture_of_Chernobyl "Capture of Chernobyl"), [Battle of Kyiv (2022)](/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(2022) "Battle of Kyiv (2022)"), [Bucha massacre](/wiki/Bucha_massacre "Bucha massacre"), [Siege of Chernihiv](/wiki/Siege_of_Chernihiv "Siege of Chernihiv"), [Battle of Sumy](/wiki/Battle_of_Sumy "Battle of Sumy"), and [Russian occupation of Sumy Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Sumy_Oblast "Russian occupation of Sumy Oblast")

Russian troops tried to seize [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv") quickly with a spearhead on 24 February, from Belarus south along the west bank of the [Dnipro River](/wiki/Dnipro_River "Dnipro River"), with [Spetsnaz](/wiki/Spetsnaz "Spetsnaz") infiltrating into the city supported by airborne operations and a rapid mechanised advance from the north, but failed.[[140]](#cite_note-wapo20220320-143)[[141]](#cite_note-144) The apparent intent was to encircle the city from the west, supported by two separate axes of attack along the east bank of the Dnipro: the western at [Chernihiv](/wiki/Chernihiv "Chernihiv"), and from the east at [Sumy](/wiki/Sumy "Sumy").[[122]](#cite_note-CriticalThreats-125)[[123]](#cite_note-ISW_4MAR-126) Russian forces advanced into [Chernihiv Oblast](/wiki/Chernihiv_Oblast "Chernihiv Oblast") on 24 February, besieging its administrative capital within [four days of fighting](/wiki/Siege_of_Chernihiv "Siege of Chernihiv").[[142]](#cite_note-145)[[143]](#cite_note-146) Travelling along highways, Russian forces reached [Brovary](/wiki/Brovary "Brovary"), an eastern suburb of Kyiv, on 4 March.[[123]](#cite_note-ISW_4MAR-126)[[122]](#cite_note-CriticalThreats-125)

The US contacted Zelenskyy and offered to help him flee, lest the Russian Army attempt to kidnap or kill him; Zelenskyy responded that "The fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride."[[144]](#cite_note-147) By early March, Russian advances along the west side of the Dnipro were limited by Ukrainian defences.[[123]](#cite_note-ISW_4MAR-126)[[122]](#cite_note-CriticalThreats-125) As of 5 March, [a Russian convoy](/wiki/Russian_Kyiv_Convoy "Russian Kyiv Convoy"), reportedly 64 kilometres (40 mi) long, had made little progress toward Kyiv.[[145]](#cite_note-148) Advances from Chernihiv largely halted as a [siege began there](/wiki/Siege_of_Chernihiv "Siege of Chernihiv"). Russian forces advanced on Kyiv from the northwest, capturing [Bucha](/wiki/Bucha,_Kyiv_Oblast "Bucha, Kyiv Oblast"), [Hostomel](/wiki/Hostomel "Hostomel") and [Vorzel](/wiki/Vorzel "Vorzel") by 5 March.[[146]](#cite_note-149)[[147]](#cite_note-150)[[148]](#cite_note-151) By 11 March, the lengthy convoy had largely dispersed and taken cover.[[149]](#cite_note-152) On 16 March, Ukrainian forces began a counter-offensive.[[150]](#cite_note-153) Unable to achieve a quick victory in Kyiv, Russian forces switched to [indiscriminate bombing](/wiki/Indiscriminate_attack "Indiscriminate attack") and [siege](/wiki/Siege "Siege") warfare.[[151]](#cite_note-154)[[152]](#cite_note-155)

On 25 March, a Ukrainian counter-offensive retook towns to the east and west of Kyiv.[[153]](#cite_note-156)[[154]](#cite_note-Guardian220325-157) Russian troops in the Bucha area retreated north. Ukrainian forces entered the city on 1 April, and recaptured the region around Kyiv, and uncovered evidence of [war crimes](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "War crimes in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") in [Bucha](/wiki/Bucha_massacre "Bucha massacre").[[155]](#cite_note-158)[[156]](#cite_note-159) [The Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon") confirmed on 6 April that the Russian army had left [Chernihiv Oblast](/wiki/Chernihiv_Oblast "Chernihiv Oblast");[[157]](#cite_note-160) local authorities said Russian troops had left Sumy Oblast.[[158]](#cite_note-161) NATO secretary-general Jens Stoltenberg said the Russian "retraction, resupply, and redeployment" of troops from the Kyiv area should be interpreted as an expansion of Putin's plans for concentrating his forces on eastern Ukraine.[[133]](#cite_note-news.yahoo.com-136)

#### Southern and eastern front

Further information: [Siege of Mariupol](/wiki/Siege_of_Mariupol "Siege of Mariupol"), [Odesa strikes (2022–present)](/wiki/Odesa_strikes_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Odesa strikes (2022–present)"), [Battle of Kherson](/wiki/Battle_of_Kherson "Battle of Kherson"), [Battle of Enerhodar](/wiki/Battle_of_Enerhodar "Battle of Enerhodar"), [Battle of Kharkiv (2022)](/wiki/Battle_of_Kharkiv_(2022) "Battle of Kharkiv (2022)"), [Battle of Izium](/wiki/Battle_of_Izium "Battle of Izium"), [Millerovo air base attack](/wiki/Millerovo_air_base_attack "Millerovo air base attack"), [Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Kherson_Oblast "Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast"), [Russian occupation of Zaporizhzhia Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Zaporizhzhia_Oblast "Russian occupation of Zaporizhzhia Oblast"), and [Russian occupation of Kharkiv Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Kharkiv_Oblast "Russian occupation of Kharkiv Oblast")

On 24 February, Russian attack groups moved northwest from Crimea, capturing bridges over the [Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper")[[159]](#cite_note-162) and the [North Crimean Canal](/wiki/North_Crimean_Canal "North Crimean Canal").[[160]](#cite_note-163) On 1 March, [Kherson](/wiki/Battle_of_Kherson "Battle of Kherson") was the first major city to fall to Russia.[[161]](#cite_note-164) Russian troops moved on [Mykolaiv](/wiki/Mykolaiv "Mykolaiv") and [attacked it](/wiki/Battle_of_Mykolaiv "Battle of Mykolaiv"), but were repelled.[[162]](#cite_note-165) Russian forces approached the [Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant "Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant")[[163]](#cite_note-166) and [besieged Enerhodar](/wiki/Battle_of_Enerhodar "Battle of Enerhodar"). By 25 February, Russian units had begun advancing on [Mariupol](/wiki/Mariupol "Mariupol").[[164]](#cite_note-167) Russian forces captured [Berdiansk](/wiki/Berdiansk "Berdiansk").[[165]](#cite_note-CNN-Berdyansk-168)[[166]](#cite_note-unianberdyansk-169)[[167]](#cite_note-170) On 1 March, [Denis Pushilin](/wiki/Denis_Pushilin "Denis Pushilin"), head of the DPR, announced that it had surrounded [Volnovakha](/wiki/Volnovakha "Volnovakha").[[168]](#cite_note-171)

By 18 March, Mariupol was encircled and fighting had reached the city centre, hampering efforts to evacuate civilians.[[169]](#cite_note-172) The Russians demanded surrender, and the Ukrainians refused.[[170]](#cite_note-CBC-2022-03-21-173) On 27 March, Ukrainian deputy prime minister [Olha Stefanishyna](/wiki/Olha_Stefanishyna "Olha Stefanishyna") said that "(m)ore than 85 percent of the whole town is destroyed."[[171]](#cite_note-174) Russia refused safe passage into Mariupol to 50 buses sent by the UN to evacuate civilians.[[172]](#cite_note-175)[[173]](#cite_note-176)

In the east, Russian troops [attempted to capture Kharkiv](/wiki/Battle_of_Kharkiv_(2022) "Battle of Kharkiv (2022)"),[[174]](#cite_note-177) and met strong Ukrainian resistance. [Izium](/wiki/Izium "Izium") was captured by Russian forces on 1 April[[175]](#cite_note-178) after a monthlong battle.[[176]](#cite_note-179) On 25 March, the Russian defence ministry said it would seek to occupy major cities in eastern Ukraine.[[177]](#cite_note-180)

On 3 April, following the retreat of Russian forces from Kyiv, Russia expanded its attack on southern Ukraine, with bombardment and strikes against Odesa, Mykolaiv, and the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.[[178]](#cite_note-181)[[179]](#cite_note-182) By 7 April, the renewed massing of Russian troops and tanks around Izium, [Sloviansk](/wiki/Sloviansk "Sloviansk"), and [Kramatorsk](/wiki/Kramatorsk "Kramatorsk") prompted Ukrainian officials to advise remaining residents near the eastern border to evacuate to western Ukraine.[[180]](#cite_note-183)

### Southeastern front (8 April – 5 September 2022)

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (8 April – 28 August 2022)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(8_April_%E2%80%93_28_August_2022) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (8 April – 28 August 2022)").

By 17 April, Russian progress on the southeastern front appeared impeded by Ukrainian forces in the large, heavily fortified [Azovstal Iron and Steel Works](/wiki/Azovstal_Iron_and_Steel_Works "Azovstal Iron and Steel Works") and surrounding area in Mariupol.[[181]](#cite_note-RNZM-184) On 19 April Russia launched an "eastern assault" across a 480-kilometre (300 mi) front extending from Kharkiv to Donetsk and Luhansk, with simultaneous missile attacks again directed at Kyiv and Lviv.[[182]](#cite_note-nytimes.com-185) An anonymous US Defence official called the Russian offensive "minimal at best".[[183]](#cite_note-186)

By 30 May, disparities between Russian and Ukrainian artillery were apparent, with Ukrainian artillery vastly outgunned.[[136]](#cite_note-Sabbagh-139) In response to Biden's indication that enhanced artillery would be provided to Ukraine, Putin said Russia would expand its invasion to include new cities, and ordered a missile strike against Kyiv on 6 June after not directly attacking it for weeks.[[184]](#cite_note-187) On 10 June, deputy head of the [SBU](/wiki/Security_Service_of_Ukraine "Security Service of Ukraine") Vadym Skibitsky stated that during the Sievierodonetsk campaign, the frontlines were where the future of the invasion would be decided:[[185]](#cite_note-iktgvs-188)

> This is an artillery war now, and we are losing in terms of artillery. Everything now depends on what [the west] gives us. Ukraine has one artillery piece to 10 to 15 Russian artillery pieces. Our western partners have given us about 10% of what they have.

On 29 June, US intelligence director Avril Haines said US agencies agreed the invasion will continue "for an extended period of time ... In short, the picture remains pretty grim and Russia's attitude toward the West is hardening."[[186]](#cite_note-189) On 5 July, [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") reported that extensive destruction by the invasion would cause immense financial damage to Ukraine's economy, with Ukrainian prime minister [Denys Shmyhal](/wiki/Denys_Shmyhal "Denys Shmyhal") telling a reconstruction conference that Ukraine needed $750B for a recovery plan and Russian oligarchs should contribute.[[187]](#cite_note-190)

The chief spokesman for the [Russian Ministry of Defence](/wiki/Russian_Ministry_of_Defence "Russian Ministry of Defence") [Igor Konashenkov](/wiki/Igor_Konashenkov "Igor Konashenkov") revealed that Russian troops were divided between the Army Groups "Centre" commanded by Colonel General [Aleksander Lapin](/wiki/Aleksandr_Lapin_(general) "Aleksandr Lapin (general)") and "South" commanded by Army General [Sergey Surovikin](/wiki/Sergey_Surovikin "Sergey Surovikin").[[188]](#cite_note-Novaya-191) On 20 July, Lavrov announced that Russia would respond to the increased military aid being received by Ukraine from abroad by expanding its special military operation to [Zaporizhzhia](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Oblast "Zaporizhzhia Oblast") and [Kherson](/wiki/Kherson_Oblast "Kherson Oblast") oblasts.[[189]](#cite_note-192) [Russian Ground Forces](/wiki/Russian_Ground_Forces "Russian Ground Forces") started recruiting volunteer battalions to create a new [3rd Army Corps](/wiki/3rd_Army_Corps_(Russia) "3rd Army Corps (Russia)") within the Western Military District, with a planned strength of 16,000–60,000 personnel.[[190]](#cite_note-193) Its units were deployed to the front around the September [Kharkiv counteroffensive](/wiki/2022_Kharkiv_counteroffensive "2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive"), in time to join the Russian retreat. The 3rd Army "melted away" according to *[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")*, having little impact on the battlefield along with other irregular forces.[[191]](#cite_note-194)

#### Fall of Mariupol

Further information: [Siege of Mariupol](/wiki/Siege_of_Mariupol "Siege of Mariupol")

On 13 April, Russian forces intensified their attack on the [Azovstal Iron and Steel Works](/wiki/Azovstal_Iron_and_Steel_Works "Azovstal Iron and Steel Works").[[192]](#cite_note-195) Ukrainian prime minister Denys Shmyhal said Ukrainian soldiers had vowed to ignore the ultimatum to surrender and fight to the last.[[181]](#cite_note-RNZM-184) On 20 April, Putin said the siege could be considered tactically complete, since the 500 Ukrainian troops entrenched in bunkers within the ironworks and estimated 1,000 civilians were sealed off from relief.[[193]](#cite_note-196)

After meetings with Putin and Zelenskyy, UN secretary-general Guterres on 28 April said he would attempt to organise an evacuation from Azovstal in accordance with assurances from Putin.[[194]](#cite_note-197) On 30 April, Russian troops allowed civilians to leave under UN protection.[[195]](#cite_note-198) By 3 May, after allowing 100 civilians to depart, Russian troops renewed their bombardment.[[196]](#cite_note-199) On 6 May, *[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")* reported that Russia had used thermobaric bombs against the remaining soldiers. Zelenskyy authorised the commander of the steel factory to surrender as necessary.[[197]](#cite_note-200) On 7 May, all civilians were evacuated.[[198]](#cite_note-201)

After the last civilians evacuated, 2,000 Ukrainian soldiers remained barricaded there, 700 were injured. They communicated a plea for a military corridor to evacuate, as they expected execution if they surrendered.[[199]](#cite_note-202) Reports of dissent on 8 May indicated that the commander of the [Ukrainian marines](/wiki/Ukrainian_Marine_Corps "Ukrainian Marine Corps") had made an unauthorised acquisition of tanks, munitions, and personnel, broke out from the position and fled. The remaining soldiers spoke of a weakened defence as a result, which allowed progress to advancing Russian attacks.[[200]](#cite_note-203) [Ilia Somolienko](/wiki/Illia_Samoilenko_(officer) "Illia Samoilenko (officer)"), deputy commander of the remaining Ukrainian troops, said: "We are basically here dead men. Most of us know this and it's why we fight so fearlessly."[[201]](#cite_note-204)

On 16 May, the Ukrainian General staff announced that the Mariupol garrison had "fulfilled its combat mission" and final evacuations had begun. 264 service members were evacuated to Olenivka under Russian control, while 53 who were seriously injured were taken to a hospital in [Novoazovsk](/wiki/Novoazovsk "Novoazovsk"), controlled by Russia.[[202]](#cite_note-nytimes16-205)[[203]](#cite_note-206) Following the evacuation, Russian and DPR forces fully controlled Mariupol. Russia press secretary Dmitry Peskov said Putin had guaranteed that the fighters who surrendered would be treated "in accordance with international standards" while Zelenskyy said that "the work of bringing the boys home continues..."[[204]](#cite_note-reutersmay17-207)

#### Fall of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk

Main article: [Battle of Donbas (2022)](/wiki/Battle_of_Donbas_(2022) "Battle of Donbas (2022)")

Further information: [Battle of Popasna](/wiki/Battle_of_Popasna "Battle of Popasna"), [Kramatorsk railway station attack](/wiki/Kramatorsk_railway_station_attack "Kramatorsk railway station attack"), [Battle of Sievierodonetsk (2022)](/wiki/Battle_of_Sievierodonetsk_(2022) "Battle of Sievierodonetsk (2022)"), and [Battle of Lysychansk](/wiki/Battle_of_Lysychansk "Battle of Lysychansk")

A Russian missile attack on [Kramatorsk railway station](/wiki/Kramatorsk_railway_station "Kramatorsk railway station") on 8 April killed at least 61[[205]](#cite_note-z362-208) and injuring 87 to 300.[[206]](#cite_note-209) On 11 April, Zelenskyy said Ukraine expected a new Russian offensive in the east.[[207]](#cite_note-210) American officials said Russia had withdrawn or been repulsed elsewhere, and was preparing a retraction, resupply, and redeployment to the southeastern Ukraine front.[[208]](#cite_note-211)[[209]](#cite_note-212) Military satellites photographed Russian convoys of infantry and mechanised units deploying south from Kharkiv to Izium on 11 April, apparently part of the planned Russian redeployment.[[210]](#cite_note-213)

On 18 April, with Mariupol overtaken by Russian forces, the Ukrainian government announced that the second phase of the reinforced invasion of the Donetsk, Luhansk and Kharkiv oblasts had intensified with expanded invasion forces occupying the Donbas.[[211]](#cite_note-214) On 22 May, the BBC reported that after the fall of Mariupol, Russia had intensified offensives in Luhansk and Donetsk while concentrating missile attacks and intense artillery fire on Sievierodonetsk, the largest city under Ukrainian control in Luhansk Oblast.[[212]](#cite_note-215) On 23 May, Russian forces were reported entering [Lyman](/wiki/Lyman,_Ukraine "Lyman, Ukraine"), capturing the city by 26 May.[[213]](#cite_note-216)[[214]](#cite_note-217) Ukrainian forces were reported leaving [Sviatohirsk](/wiki/Sviatohirsk "Sviatohirsk").[[215]](#cite_note-RID_Rivista_Italiana_Difesa-218) By 24 May, Russian forces captured [Svitlodarsk](/wiki/Svitlodarsk "Svitlodarsk").[[216]](#cite_note-Svitlodarsk24522-219) On 30 May, Reuters reported that Russian troops had breached the outskirts of Sievierodonetsk.[[217]](#cite_note-220) By 2 June, *The Washington Post* reported that Sievierodonetsk was on the brink of capitulation with over 80% in the hands of Russian troops.[[218]](#cite_note-221) On 3 June, Ukrainian forces reportedly began a counter-attack in Sievierodonetsk. By 4 June, Ukrainian government sources claimed 20% or more of the city had been recaptured.[[219]](#cite_note-222)

Ukrainian authorities estimated that 800 Ukrainian civilians were besieged at the [Azot](/wiki/Azot_(Sievierodonetsk) "Azot (Sievierodonetsk)") chemical factory in Sievierodonetsk; Russian-backed separatists said it sheltered 300–400 soldiers.[[220]](#cite_note-223)[[221]](#cite_note-224) With the Ukrainian defences of Sievierodonetsk faltering, Russian troops began intensifying their attack on the neighbouring city of [Lysychansk](/wiki/Lysychansk "Lysychansk").[[222]](#cite_note-225) On 20 June it was reported that Russian troops continued to tighten their grip on Sievierodonetsk by capturing surrounding villages.[[223]](#cite_note-226)

On 24 June, [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN") reported that, amid scorched-earth tactics by advancing Russian troops, Ukraine's armed forces were ordered to evacuate Sievierodonetsk; several hundred civilians taking refuge in the Azot chemical plant were left behind, with some comparing their plight to those in Mariupol.[[224]](#cite_note-227) On 3 July, the Russian defence ministry claimed Lysychansk had been captured and occupied.[[225]](#cite_note-228) On 4 July, *The Guardian* reported that after the fall of the Luhansk oblast, Russian troops would continue their invasion into the adjacent [Donetsk Oblast](/wiki/Donetsk_Oblast "Donetsk Oblast") to attack the cities of Sloviansk and [Bakhmut](/wiki/Bakhmut "Bakhmut").[[226]](#cite_note-229)

#### Zaporizhzhia front

See also: [Russian occupation of Zaporizhzhia Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Zaporizhzhia_Oblast "Russian occupation of Zaporizhzhia Oblast")

Russian forces continued to fire missiles and drop bombs on [Dnipro](/wiki/Dnipro "Dnipro") and [Zaporizhzhia](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia "Zaporizhzhia").[[182]](#cite_note-nytimes.com-185) Russian missiles destroyed the [Dnipro International Airport](/wiki/Dnipro_International_Airport "Dnipro International Airport") on 10 April.[[227]](#cite_note-230) On 2 May, the UN, reportedly with the cooperation of Russian troops, evacuated about 100 survivors from the siege of Mariupol.[[228]](#cite_note-231) On 28 June, Reuters reported that a Russian missile attack on [Kremenchuk](/wiki/Kremenchuk "Kremenchuk"), detonated in a mall, had killed at least 18. France's Macron called it a "war crime".[[229]](#cite_note-232)

The president of Ukrainian nuclear agency [Energoatom](/wiki/Energoatom "Energoatom") called the situation at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant "extremely tense", saying that it was being operated by Ukrainian staff but controlled by up to 500 Russian soldiers, with Russia shelling nearby areas and storing weapons at the plant.[[230]](#cite_note-233) Russia agreed on 19 August to allow IAEA inspectors access to the plant after a call from Macron to Putin. As of July 2023, access to the plant remained limited.[[231]](#cite_note-234)

Russia reported that 12 attacks with explosions from 50 artillery shells had been recorded by 18 August at the plant and the company town of [Enerhodar](/wiki/Enerhodar "Enerhodar").[[232]](#cite_note-nei-20220822-235) [Tobias Ellwood](/wiki/Tobias_Ellwood "Tobias Ellwood"), chair of the UK's [Defence Select Committee](/wiki/Defence_Select_Committee "Defence Select Committee"), and US congressman [Adam Kinzinger](/wiki/Adam_Kinzinger "Adam Kinzinger") said that radiation leaks would be a breach of the [North Atlantic Treaty](/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty "North Atlantic Treaty"), under which an attack on a member of NATO is an attack on them all.[[233]](#cite_note-236)[[234]](#cite_note-237)

### Russian annexations and occupation losses (6 September – 11 November 2022)

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (29 August – 11 November 2022)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(29_August_%E2%80%93_11_November_2022) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (29 August – 11 November 2022)").

On 6 September 2022, Ukrainian forces launched a surprise [counteroffensive in the Kharkiv region](/wiki/2022_Kharkiv_counteroffensive "2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive"), beginning near [Balakliia](/wiki/Balakliia "Balakliia"), led by [General Syrskyi](/wiki/Oleksandr_Syrskyi "Oleksandr Syrskyi").[[235]](#cite_note-RO-238) An emboldened Kyiv launched a counteroffensive 12 September around Kharkiv successful enough to make Russia admit losing key positions and for *The New York Times* to say that it dented the image of a "Mighty Putin". Kyiv sought more arms from the West to sustain the counteroffensive.[[236]](#cite_note-239) On 21 September 2022, Vladimir Putin announced [a partial mobilisation](/wiki/2022_Russian_mobilization "2022 Russian mobilization") and Minister of Defence [Sergei Shoigu](/wiki/Sergei_Shoigu "Sergei Shoigu") said 300,000 reservists would be called.[[237]](#cite_note-France_24_2022-240) He also said that his country would use "all means" to "defend itself". Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to Zelenskyy, said that the decision was predictable and that it was an attempt to justify "Russia's failures".[[238]](#cite_note-gazetapl_2022_pd-241) British Foreign Office Minister Gillian Keegan called the situation an "escalation",[[239]](#cite_note-Ellyatt_2022_esc-242) while former Mongolian president [Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj](/wiki/Tsakhiagiin_Elbegdorj "Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj") accused Russia of using Russian Mongols as "cannon fodder".[[240]](#cite_note-243)

#### Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts

Main article: [Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts](/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts "Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts")

In late September 2022, Russian-installed officials in Ukraine organised [referendums](/wiki/2022_annexation_referendums_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "2022 annexation referendums in Russian-occupied Ukraine") on the annexation of the Donetsk People's Republic and the Luhansk People's Republic, as well as the Russian-appointed military administrations of Kherson Oblast and Zaporizhzhia Oblast. Denounced by Ukraine's government and allies, including the UK, US, and France, as [sham elections](/wiki/Sham_election "Sham election"), official results showed overwhelming majorities in favour of annexation.[[241]](#cite_note-244)

On 30 September 2022, Vladimir Putin announced the annexation of Ukraine's Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia oblasts in an address to the [Russian parliament](/wiki/Federal_Assembly_(Russia) "Federal Assembly (Russia)").[[242]](#cite_note-245) Ukraine, the United States, the European Union and the United Nations all denounced the annexation as illegal.[[243]](#cite_note-246)

#### Kherson counteroffensive

Main articles: [2022 Kherson counteroffensive](/wiki/2022_Kherson_counteroffensive "2022 Kherson counteroffensive") and [Liberation of Kherson](/wiki/Liberation_of_Kherson "Liberation of Kherson")

On 29 August, Zelenskyy announced the start of a full-scale counteroffensive in the southeast to retake Russian-occupied territory in the Kherson and Mykolaiv regions.[[244]](#cite_note-247) By 4 September, Ukrainian forces had retaken the village of [Vysokopillia](/wiki/Vysokopillia "Vysokopillia").[[245]](#cite_note-248) Ukrainian attacks also continued along the southern frontline, though reports about territorial changes were largely unverifiable.[[246]](#cite_note-249)

In October, Ukrainian forces pushed further south towards the city of Kherson, taking control of 1,170 square kilometres (450 sq mi), with fighting extending to [Dudchany](/wiki/Dudchany "Dudchany").[[247]](#cite_note-250)[[248]](#cite_note-251) On 9 November, defence minister Shoigu ordered Russian forces to leave part of Kherson Oblast, including the city of [Kherson](/wiki/Liberation_of_Kherson "Liberation of Kherson"), and move to the eastern bank of the Dnieper.[[249]](#cite_note-252) On 11 November, Ukrainian troops entered Kherson, as Russia completed its withdrawal. This meant that Russian forces no longer had a foothold on the west bank of the Dnieper.[[250]](#cite_note-253)

#### Kharkiv counteroffensive

Main article: [2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive](/wiki/2022_Kharkiv_counteroffensive "2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive")

Retained by Ukraine  
   Retaken by Ukraine  
   Occupied by Russia  
Map of the Kharkiv front as of 3 January 2026

Ukrainian forces launched another surprise counteroffensive on 6 September in the Kharkiv Oblast near [Balakliia](/wiki/Balakliia "Balakliia") led by General Syrskyi.[[235]](#cite_note-RO-238) By 7 September, Ukrainian forces had advanced 20 kilometres (12 mi) into Russian-occupied territory and claimed to have recaptured approximately 400 square kilometres (150 sq mi). Russian commentators said this was likely due to the relocation of Russian forces to Kherson.[[251]](#cite_note-254) On 8 September, Ukrainian forces captured Balakliia and advanced to within 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) of [Kupiansk](/wiki/Kupiansk "Kupiansk").[[252]](#cite_note-255) Military analysts said Ukrainian forces appeared to be moving towards Kupiansk, a major railway hub, with the aim of cutting off the Russian forces at Izium from the north.[[253]](#cite_note-256)

On 9 September, the [Russian occupation administration of Kharkiv Oblast](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Kharkiv_Oblast "Russian occupation of Kharkiv Oblast") announced it would "evacuate" the civilian populations of Izium, Kupiansk and [Velykyi Burluk](/wiki/Velykyi_Burluk "Velykyi Burluk"). The [Institute for the Study of War](/wiki/Institute_for_the_Study_of_War "Institute for the Study of War") (ISW) said it believed Kupiansk would likely fall in the next 72 hours,[[254]](#cite_note-257) while Russian reserve units were sent to the area by both road and helicopter.[[255]](#cite_note-258) On the morning of 10 September, photos emerged claiming to depict Ukrainian troops raising the Ukrainian flag in the centre of Kupiansk,[[256]](#cite_note-kupiansk-euromaidanpress-259) and the ISW said Ukrainian forces had captured approximately 2,500 square kilometres (970 sq mi).[[257]](#cite_note-isw20220909-260) Reuters reported that Russian positions in northeast Ukraine had "collapsed" in the face of the Ukrainian assault, with Russian forces forced to withdraw from their base at Izium after being cut off by the capture of Kupiansk.[[258]](#cite_note-261)

By 15 September, an assessment by the [UK Ministry of Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom) "Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)") confirmed that Russia had either lost or withdrawn from almost all of their positions west of the [Oskil river](/wiki/Oskil_(river) "Oskil (river)"), abandoning high-value military assets.[[259]](#cite_note-262) The offensive continued pushing east and by 1 October, Ukrainian forces [had liberated Lyman](/wiki/Second_battle_of_Lyman "Second battle of Lyman").[[260]](#cite_note-263)

### Winter stalemate, attrition campaign and first military surge (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)

Further information: [Russian winter offensive in Ukraine (2022–2023)](/wiki/Russian_winter_offensive_in_Ukraine_(2022%E2%80%932023) "Russian winter offensive in Ukraine (2022–2023)"), [Battle of Vuhledar](/wiki/Battle_of_Vuhledar "Battle of Vuhledar"), [Battle of Marinka (2022–2023)](/wiki/Battle_of_Marinka_(2022%E2%80%932023) "Battle of Marinka (2022–2023)"), and [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(12_November_2022_%E2%80%93_7_June_2023) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)")

After the end of the twin Ukrainian counteroffensives, the fighting semi-deadlocked during the winter,[[261]](#cite_note-TakesStock-264) with heavy casualties but reduced motion of the frontline.[[262]](#cite_note-265) Russia launched a self-proclaimed winter offensive in eastern Ukraine, but the campaign stalled with limited gains.[[261]](#cite_note-TakesStock-264)[[263]](#cite_note-aground-266) Analysts blamed the failure on Russia's lack of "trained men" and supply problems with artillery ammunition, among other problems.[[261]](#cite_note-TakesStock-264)[[263]](#cite_note-aground-266) Near the end of May, [Mark Galeotti](/wiki/Mark_Galeotti "Mark Galeotti") assessed that "after Russia's abortive and ill-conceived winter offensive, which squandered its opportunity to consolidate its forces, Ukraine is in a relatively strong position."[[264]](#cite_note-267)

On 7 February, *The New York Times* reported that Russians had newly mobilised nearly 200,000 soldiers to participate in the offensive in the Donbas.[[265]](#cite_note-268) The Russian private military company Wagner Group took on greater prominence in the war,[[266]](#cite_note-269) leading "grinding advances" in [Bakhmut](/wiki/Battle_of_Bakhmut "Battle of Bakhmut") with tens of thousands of recruits from [prison battalions](/wiki/Penal_military_unit "Penal military unit") taking part in "near suicidal" assaults on Ukrainian positions.[[263]](#cite_note-aground-266)

In late January 2023, fighting intensified in southern Zaporizhzhia Oblast, with both sides suffering heavy casualties.[[267]](#cite_note-270) In nearby southern parts of Donetsk Oblast, an [intense, three-week Russian assault](/wiki/Battle_of_Vuhledar "Battle of Vuhledar") near the coal-mining town of [Vuhledar](/wiki/Vuhledar "Vuhledar") was called the largest tank battle of the war to date, and ended in disaster for Russian forces, who lost "at least 130 tanks and armored personnel carriers" according to Ukrainian commanders. The [British Ministry of Defence](/wiki/British_Ministry_of_Defence "British Ministry of Defence") stated that "a whole Russian brigade was effectively annihilated."[[268]](#cite_note-271)[[269]](#cite_note-TankKramer-272)

In late 2022, as Russian casualties exceeded 50,000, the Russian army introduced [barrier troops](/wiki/Barrier_troops "Barrier troops"). The UK defence ministry stated that these are units that threaten to shoot their own retreating soldiers to compel offensives. In March 2023, Russian soldiers filmed a video addressed to Putin where they stated that after suffering casualties, they attempted to return to their headquarters but their superiors denied them evacuation and barrier troops were placed behind them threatening to "destroy them".[[270]](#cite_note-Sauer_2023_a785-273) In particular, [Storm-Z](/wiki/Storm-Z "Storm-Z") units have been reported to be "kept in line" by barrier troops.[[271]](#cite_note-Axe_2024_h250-274)

### Battle of Bakhmut

Main article: [Battle of Bakhmut](/wiki/Battle_of_Bakhmut "Battle of Bakhmut")

Following defeat in Kherson and Kharkiv, Russian and Wagner forces focused on taking Bakhmut and breaking the half-year-long stalemate there since the start of the war. Russian forces sought to encircle the city, attacking from the north via [Soledar](/wiki/Soledar "Soledar"). After taking heavy casualties, Russian and Wagner forces [took control of Soledar](/wiki/Battle_of_Soledar "Battle of Soledar") on 16 January 2023.[[272]](#cite_note-275)[[273]](#cite_note-276) By early February 2023, Bakhmut was facing attacks from north, south and east, with the sole Ukrainian supply lines coming from [Chasiv Yar](/wiki/Chasiv_Yar "Chasiv Yar") to the west.[[274]](#cite_note-277)

On 4 March, Bakhmut's deputy mayor told news services that there was street fighting in the city.[[275]](#cite_note-278) On 20 May 2023, the Wagner Group claimed full control over Bakhmut, and a victory in the battle was officially declared by Russia the next day,[[276]](#cite_note-279) following which Wagner forces retreated from the city in place of regular Russian units.[[277]](#cite_note-280)

### 2023 Ukrainian counteroffensives (8 June 2023 – 1 December 2023)

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (8 June 2023 – 31 August 2023)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(8_June_2023_%E2%80%93_31_August_2023) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (8 June 2023 – 31 August 2023)") and [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 September – 30 November 2023)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_September_%E2%80%93_30_November_2023) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 September – 30 November 2023)").

Further information: [2023 Ukrainian counteroffensive](/wiki/2023_Ukrainian_counteroffensive "2023 Ukrainian counteroffensive")

In June 2023, Ukrainian forces launched counteroffensives on multiple fronts.[[278]](#cite_note-281)[[279]](#cite_note-282) Efforts faced stiff Russian resistance.[[280]](#cite_note-283) By 12 June, Ukraine reported advances and liberated settlements.[[281]](#cite_note-284) On 24 June, the [Wagner Group rebellion](/wiki/Wagner_Group_rebellion "Wagner Group rebellion") briefly unfolded before a peace deal.[[282]](#cite_note-285) In late June, Ukraine reclaimed territory in Donbas and made gains in Kherson Oblast.[[283]](#cite_note-286) Russia heavily mined areas, making Ukraine the most mined country in the world.[[284]](#cite_note-287) Following Russia leaving the Black Sea Grain Initiative, Ukraine targeted Russian ships.[[285]](#cite_note-288) In September 2023, Russian strikes hit Ukrainian energy facilities.[[286]](#cite_note-289) The US announced sending long-range ATACMS missiles[[287]](#cite_note-290) and Ukraine struck the Sevastopol naval base.[[288]](#cite_note-291)[[289]](#cite_note-292)

In October–December 2023, Ukrainian forces crossed the [Dnipro River](/wiki/Dnipro_River "Dnipro River") despite heavy losses. On 1 December 2023, Zelenskyy stated that the Ukrainian counter-offensive was unsuccessful.[[290]](#cite_note-failedTelegraph-293) Zelenskyy stated it would be easier to regain Crimea than the Donbas, because the latter is heavily militarised and has much pro-Russian sentiment.[[291]](#cite_note-294) In December 2023, media outlets described the Ukrainian counteroffensive as having failed to regain significant territory or meet any of its objectives.[[290]](#cite_note-failedTelegraph-293)[[292]](#cite_note-failedNYT-295)[[293]](#cite_note-failedWPT1-296)

### Battle of Avdiivka

Main article: [Battle of Avdiivka (2023–2024)](/wiki/Battle_of_Avdiivka_(2023%E2%80%932024) "Battle of Avdiivka (2023–2024)")

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 December 2023 – 31 March 2024)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_December_2023_%E2%80%93_31_March_2024) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (1 December 2023 – 31 March 2024)").

In October 2023, it was reported that there were growing mutinies among Russian troops due to the extensive losses in Russian offensives around [Avdiivka](/wiki/Avdiivka "Avdiivka"), with a lack of artillery, food, water and poor command also being reported.[[294]](#cite_note-Cole_2023_r879-297) By November, British intelligence said that recent weeks had "likely seen some of the highest Russian casualty rates of the war so far."[[295]](#cite_note-France_24_2023_a290-298)

On 17 February 2024, [Russia captured Avdiivka](/wiki/Battle_of_Avdiivka_(2023%E2%80%932024) "Battle of Avdiivka (2023–2024)"), a longtime stronghold for Ukraine that had been described as a "gateway" to nearby [Donetsk](/wiki/Donetsk "Donetsk").[[296]](#cite_note-Avdiivka_BBCW-299)[[297]](#cite_note-Avdiivka_TGW-300)[[298]](#cite_note-17Feb24NYT-301) Described by *Forbes* journalist David Axe as a pyrrhic Russian victory, the Russian 2nd and 41st Combined Arms Armies ended up with 16,000 men killed, tens of thousands wounded and around 700 vehicles lost.[[299]](#cite_note-Axe_2024_u665-302)

Ukraine's shortage of ammunition caused by political deadlock in the US Congress and a lack of production capacity in Europe contributed to the Ukrainian withdrawal from Avdiivka, and was "being felt across the front" according to *[Time](/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")*. The shortage resulted in Ukraine having to ration its units to fire only 2,000 rounds per day, compared to an estimated 10,000 rounds fired daily by Russia.[[300]](#cite_note-Watling_2024_x516-303)

### Russian offensives and Ukrainian incursion (April 2024 – present)

See also: [Eastern front of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present) § Russian general offensive (April 2024–present)](/wiki/Eastern_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present)#Russian_general_offensive_(April_2024–present) "Eastern front of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 April – 31 July 2024)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(1_April_%E2%80%93_31_July_2024) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 April – 31 July 2024)"), [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 August – 31 December 2024)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(1_August_%E2%80%93_31_December_2024) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 August – 31 December 2024)"), [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 January 2025 – 31 May 2025)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(1_January_2025_%E2%80%93_31_May_2025) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 January 2025 – 31 May 2025)"), [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 June 2025 – 31 August 2025)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_31_August_2025) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 June 2025 – 31 August 2025)"), and [Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 September 2025 – present)](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(1_September_2025_%E2%80%93_present) "Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (1 September 2025 – present)").

#### Russian spring and summer offensives

Main articles: [Battle of Ocheretyne](/wiki/Battle_of_Ocheretyne "Battle of Ocheretyne") and [Northern Kharkiv front of the Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Northern_Kharkiv_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "Northern Kharkiv front of the Russo-Ukrainian War")

On 10 May 2024, Russia began a [renewed offensive](/wiki/Northern_Kharkiv_front_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War_(2024%E2%80%93present) "Northern Kharkiv front of the Russo-Ukrainian War (2024–present)") in [Kharkiv Oblast](/wiki/Kharkiv_Oblast "Kharkiv Oblast"). Russia captured a dozen villages; Ukraine had evacuated more than 11,000 people from the region since the start of the offensive by 25 May. Ukraine said on 17 May that its forces had slowed the Russian advance, and by 25 May Zelenskyy said that Ukrainian forces had secured "combat control" of areas where Russian troops entered the northeastern Kharkiv Oblast. Russian officials said that they were "advancing in every direction" and that the goal was to create a "buffer zone" for embattled border regions.[[301]](#cite_note-c973-304)[[302]](#cite_note-k589-305) The White House said on 7 June that the offensive had stalled and was unlikely to advance further.[[303]](#cite_note-k069-306)

Following the battle of Avdiivka, Russian forces advanced northwest of it to form a salient, [capturing Ocheretyne](/wiki/Battle_of_Ocheretyne "Battle of Ocheretyne") in late April[[304]](#cite_note-307)[[305]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-05-04-308) and further expanding the salient in the succeeding months.[[306]](#cite_note-309) Russian forces also launched an [offensive towards Chasiv Yar](/wiki/Battle_of_Chasiv_Yar "Battle of Chasiv Yar") in early April,[[307]](#cite_note-310) and by early July had captured its easternmost district.[[308]](#cite_note-311)[[309]](#cite_note-312) Another [offensive](/wiki/Battle_of_Toretsk "Battle of Toretsk") in the direction of [Toretsk](/wiki/Toretsk "Toretsk") was launched on 18 June,[[310]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-07-18-313) with the goal of capturing the city,[[311]](#cite_note-314) and according to Ukrainian military observer and spokesperson Nazar Voloshyn, flanking Chasiv Yar from the south.[[312]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-06-21-315) Russian forces advanced to expand the salient northwest of Avdiivka in July, and on 19 July 2024, made a breakthrough allowing them to [advance towards](/wiki/Pokrovsk_offensive "Pokrovsk offensive") the operationally significant city of [Pokrovsk](/wiki/Pokrovsk "Pokrovsk").[[313]](#cite_note-316)[[314]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-07-19-317)

#### Ukrainian offensive into Russia

Main article: [Kursk campaign](/wiki/Kursk_campaign "Kursk campaign")

On 6 August 2024, Ukraine launched their first direct offensive into Russian territory, the largest of any pro-Ukrainian incursion since the invasion's inception, into the bordering [Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Kursk_Oblast "Kursk Oblast").[[315]](#cite_note-318) The main axis of the initial advance centred in the direction of [Sudzha](/wiki/Sudzha "Sudzha"), 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) from the border,[[316]](#cite_note-319) which was reported by President Zelenskyy to have been captured on 15 August.[[317]](#cite_note-320) Ukraine, taking advantage of the lack of experienced units and defences along the border with Kursk Oblast, was able to quickly seize territory in the opening days of the incursion.[[318]](#cite_note-321) The incursion caused Russia to divert thousands of troops from occupied Ukrainian territory to counter the threat,[[319]](#cite_note-k052-322)[[320]](#cite_note-wapo831-323) though not from Donetsk Oblast.[[320]](#cite_note-wapo831-323)

Despite repeated deadlines set by Putin to push out Ukrainian troops, Russian forces had not done so by the end of January 2025, with advances in Donetsk Oblast being prioritised over the Kursk salient. However, by February 2025, Russian forces in Donetsk Oblast were described by the ISW as not being fully protected from the theatre-wide impacts of the incursion, with troops, armoured vehicles, artillery, and air defence systems being pulled away from Ukrainian sectors to reinforce the Russian forces in Kursk.[[321]](#cite_note-y851-324)[[322]](#cite_note-g362-325)

By the summer of 2025, Ukrainian forces had been mostly repelled from the area.[[323]](#cite_note-326)

#### Late 2024 and 2025 Russian advances

Main articles: [Velyka Novosilka offensive](/wiki/Velyka_Novosilka_offensive "Velyka Novosilka offensive"), [Battle of Kurakhove](/wiki/Battle_of_Kurakhove "Battle of Kurakhove"), [Battle of Toretsk](/wiki/Battle_of_Toretsk "Battle of Toretsk"), [Pokrovsk offensive](/wiki/Pokrovsk_offensive "Pokrovsk offensive"), [Kupiansk offensive](/wiki/Kupiansk_offensive "Kupiansk offensive"), and [Battle of Chasiv Yar](/wiki/Battle_of_Chasiv_Yar "Battle of Chasiv Yar")

Russian troops continued advancing in eastern Ukraine at a faster pace than prior to the Kursk offensive,[[325]](#cite_note-Miller-328) including towards the operationally important city of [Pokrovsk](/wiki/Pokrovsk "Pokrovsk"), where their forces had instead been increased.[[326]](#cite_note-329)[[327]](#cite_note-330)[[328]](#cite_note-331)

In late August 2024, Russian forces seized [Novohrodivka](/wiki/Novohrodivka "Novohrodivka"), southeast of Pokrovsk, bringing them within 8 kilometres of the city,[[325]](#cite_note-Miller-328) while [capturing Krasnohorivka](/wiki/Battle_of_Krasnohorivka "Battle of Krasnohorivka")[[329]](#cite_note-ISW_2024-09-10-332) and [Ukrainsk](/wiki/Ukrainsk "Ukrainsk")[[330]](#cite_note-NYT918-333) in early September.[[330]](#cite_note-NYT918-333) In late September, a Russian assault on the long-held city of [Vuhledar began](/wiki/Battle_of_Vuhledar "Battle of Vuhledar");[[331]](#cite_note-334) after it fell on 1 October, the city with a pre-war population of about 14,000 was described as a "sprawling ruin".[[332]](#cite_note-vuhledar101-335)[[333]](#cite_note-j026-336)

On 30 October, Ukrainian Major General [Dmytro Marchenko](/wiki/Dmytro_Marchenko "Dmytro Marchenko") was reported to have said "our front has crumbled" due to a dwindling ammunition supply, problems with military recruitment, and poor leadership. He said [Zelensky's victory plan](/wiki/Victory_Plan_for_Ukraine "Victory Plan for Ukraine") was too heavily focused on Western support. Briefings from Western officials had also become more pessimistic about Ukraine's military situation.[[334]](#cite_note-telegraph-20241030-337)[[335]](#cite_note-nyt-20241101-338) According to the Prosecutor General's Office, more than 100,000 criminal cases for [desertion](/wiki/Desertion "Desertion") were initiated by the end of November 2024.[[336]](#cite_note-339) Russian forces then captured the city of [Kurakhove](/wiki/Kurakhove "Kurakhove") in late December 2024, and the nearby [Kurakhove Power Station](/wiki/Kurakhove_Power_Station "Kurakhove Power Station") in January 2025.[[337]](#cite_note-340)[[338]](#cite_note-ISW_2025-01-03-341)

In early 2025, Russian forces advanced in eastern Ukraine,[[339]](#cite_note-342)[[340]](#cite_note-343) with Russia claiming to have captured [Velyka Novosilka](/wiki/Velyka_Novosilka "Velyka Novosilka") in January.[[341]](#cite_note-344)[[342]](#cite_note-345) Russia continued [attacks](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure (2022–present)") on Ukrainian energy infrastructure.[[343]](#cite_note-346) In February 2025, Ukraine's government approved a one-year contract for volunteers aged 18–24 not subject to [mobilisation](/wiki/Mobilisation "Mobilisation").[[344]](#cite_note-347) By April 2025, Russian advances had slowed, according to Seth Jones from the [Center for Strategic and International Studies](/wiki/Center_for_Strategic_and_International_Studies "Center for Strategic and International Studies").[[345]](#cite_note-h119-348) Russian attacks on civilians also intensified, with the month of June seeing the highest civilian casualty count in Ukraine since the start of the invasion, with 232 killed and 1,343 injured.[[346]](#cite_note-o749-349) Russia killed at least 21 civilians including children in the second largest strike of the war overnight on 27 and 28 August, damaging European diplomatic facilities along with civilian infrastructure.[[347]](#cite_note-c384-350)

Putin declared in March 2025 that "there are reasons to believe we can finish off Ukrainian forces", as a Russian summer offensive was expected. Russia planned to expand into Sumy and Kharkiv, however, the actual offensive was generally considered a failure with modest gains at the cost of heavy casualties.
