By September 2025, Russian forces had still not achieved any frontline breakthroughs, with key strategic objectives like Pokrovsk still held by Ukraine.[[348]](#cite_note-b037-351)[[349]](#cite_note-x018-352)

During October and November 2025, Russian forces intensified operations around Pokrovsk. According to open-source military assessments, Russia advanced hundreds of square miles during this period, applying sustained pressure on Ukrainian defensive lines.[[350]](#cite_note-353) Zelenskyy stated that Russia had deployed approximately 170,000 troops in response, describing the situation as difficult but highlighting continued Ukrainian resistance.[[351]](#cite_note-354)[[352]](#cite_note-355) By late October, there was fighting within Pokrovsk city proper.[[353]](#cite_note-356) On 1 December, Russia claimed to have captured the city, although there were still Ukrainian forces present in the northern portion of the city.[[354]](#cite_note-357)[[355]](#cite_note-358)

In December 2025, following Russian claims of controlling Kupiansk, Zelenskyy visited the city, hailed defending troops and recorded a video in the town, with Ukrainian military officials saying that 90% of the city was under Ukrainian control.[[356]](#cite_note-y195-359)[[357]](#cite_note-360) The ISW reported that Russian ultranationalist milbloggers acknowledged the severity for Russian forces in the direction, and that Russian claims of advances in the area had been used as part of a [cognitive warfare](/wiki/Cognitive_warfare "Cognitive warfare") effort.[[358]](#cite_note-d830-361)

Russia also escalated attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure throughout the period.[[359]](#cite_note-Chathamhouse_Nov2025-362) In one major strike, over 450 drones and 45 missiles were reportedly used, according to Ukrainian officials, causing civilian casualties and damaging critical infrastructure. In response, Ukraine attacked Russian energy and logistical networks, including targeting oil facilities, causing a Russian [fuel crisis](/wiki/2025_Russian_fuel_crisis "2025 Russian fuel crisis").[[360]](#cite_note-363)[[361]](#cite_note-364)[[362]](#cite_note-o817-365)

## Battlespaces

Further information: [Northern front](/wiki/Northern_front_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Northern front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), [Eastern front](/wiki/Eastern_front_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Eastern front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), and [Southern front](/wiki/Southern_front_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Southern front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

### Command

Further information: [Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present) order of battle](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present)_order_of_battle "Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present) order of battle")

The supreme commanders-in-chief are the heads of state: President Putin of Russia and President Zelenskyy of Ukraine. Putin has reportedly meddled in operational decisions, bypassing senior commanders and giving orders directly to brigade commanders.[[363]](#cite_note-366)

US general [Mark Milley](/wiki/Mark_Milley "Mark Milley") wrote in May 2022 that Ukraine's top military commander in the war, [commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine](/wiki/Commander-in-Chief_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine "Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine"), General [Valerii Zaluzhnyi](/wiki/Valerii_Zaluzhnyi "Valerii Zaluzhnyi"), "has emerged as the military mind his country needed. His leadership enabled the Ukrainian armed forces to adapt quickly with battlefield initiative against the Russians."[[364]](#cite_note-Shuster_2022-367) Russia began the invasion with no overall commander. The commanders of the four military districts were each responsible for their own offensives.[[365]](#cite_note-CRSR21323-368)

After initial setbacks, the commander of the Russian Southern Military District, [Aleksandr Dvornikov](/wiki/Aleksandr_Dvornikov "Aleksandr Dvornikov"), was placed in overall command on 8 April 2022,[[366]](#cite_note-369) while still responsible for his own campaign. Russian forces benefited from the centralisation of command under Dvornikov,[[367]](#cite_note-370) but continued failures to meet expectations in Moscow led to multiple changes in overall command:[[365]](#cite_note-CRSR21323-368)

* commander of the Eastern Military District [Gennady Zhidko](/wiki/Gennady_Zhidko "Gennady Zhidko") (Eastern Military District, 26  – 8 May October 2022)
* commander of the southern grouping of forces [Sergei Surovikin](/wiki/Sergei_Surovikin "Sergei Surovikin") (early October 2022 – 11 January 2023)
* commander-in-chief of the Russian Armed Forces [Valerii Gerasimov](/wiki/Valerii_Gerasimov "Valerii Gerasimov") (from 11 January 2023)

Russia has suffered a remarkably large number of casualties in the ranks of its officers, including [a number of generals](/wiki/List_of_Russian_generals_killed_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "List of Russian generals killed during the Russian invasion of Ukraine").[[368]](#cite_note-371)

### Missile attacks and aerial warfare

Main article: [Aerial warfare in the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Aerial_warfare_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Aerial warfare in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

See also: [List of aviation shootdowns and accidents during the Russo-Ukrainian war](/wiki/List_of_aviation_shootdowns_and_accidents_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "List of aviation shootdowns and accidents during the Russo-Ukrainian war")

Aerial warfare began the first day of the invasion. Dozens of missile attacks were recorded across both eastern and western Ukraine,[[122]](#cite_note-CriticalThreats-125)[[123]](#cite_note-ISW_4MAR-126) as far west as Lviv.[[369]](#cite_note-Rostov-Gazeta-2022-02-25-372)

By September 2022, Ukrainian air forces had shot down about 55 Russian warplanes.[[370]](#cite_note-373) In mid-October, Russian forces launched [missile strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure"), intended to knock out energy facilities.[[371]](#cite_note-374) By late November, hundreds of civilians had been killed or wounded,[[372]](#cite_note-375) and [rolling blackouts](/wiki/Rolling_blackout "Rolling blackout") had left millions without power.[[373]](#cite_note-376)

In December 2022, drones launched from Ukraine allegedly carried out several attacks on [Dyagilevo](/wiki/Dyagilevo_(air_base) "Dyagilevo (air base)") and [Engels](/wiki/Engels-2_(air_base) "Engels-2 (air base)") air bases in [western Russia](/wiki/2022%E2%80%932023_Western_Russia_attacks "2022–2023 Western Russia attacks"), killing 10 and heavily damaging two [Tu-95](/wiki/Tupolev_Tu-95 "Tupolev Tu-95") aircraft.[[374]](#cite_note-377)

On 1 June 2025, Ukraine carried out "[Operation Spiderweb](/wiki/Operation_Spiderweb "Operation Spiderweb")", targeting several air bases deep inside Russian territory using smuggled drones. The operation was seen as successful,[[375]](#cite_note-z595-378) with Ukraine saying it had damaged or destroyed 41 high-value aircraft, including strategic bombers used to coordinate and launch attacks on Ukrainian cities.[[376]](#cite_note-b319-379) US officials assessed a lower number, saying that Ukraine had hit 20 planes, destroying 10.[[377]](#cite_note-s394-380) The operation is estimated to have caused billions of dollars in damage to Russian aircraft.[[378]](#cite_note-b759-381)[[379]](#cite_note-p895-382)[[380]](#cite_note-t713-383)[[381]](#cite_note-d975-384)

#### Crimea attacks

Main article: [Crimea attacks](/wiki/Crimea_attacks "Crimea attacks")

On 31 July 2022, Russian Navy Day commemorations were cancelled after a drone attack reportedly wounded several people at the Russian [Black Sea Fleet](/wiki/Black_Sea_Fleet "Black Sea Fleet") headquarters in Sevastopol.[[382]](#cite_note-385) On 9 August 2022, [large explosions](/wiki/2022_Novofedorivka_explosions "2022 Novofedorivka explosions") were reported at [Saky Air Base](/wiki/Saky_(air_base) "Saky (air base)") in western Crimea. Satellite imagery showed at least eight aircraft damaged or destroyed. Initial speculation attributed the explosions to long-range missiles, sabotage by special forces or an accident;[[383]](#cite_note-386) Ukrainian general [Valerii Zaluzhnyi](/wiki/Valerii_Zaluzhnyi "Valerii Zaluzhnyi") claimed responsibility on 7 September.[[384]](#cite_note-387)

A week later Russia blamed "sabotage" for explosions and a fire at an arms depot near [Dzhankoi](/wiki/Dzhankoi "Dzhankoi") in northeastern Crimea that also damaged a railway line and power station. Russian regional head [Sergei Aksyonov](/wiki/Sergei_Aksyonov "Sergei Aksyonov") said that 2,000 people were evacuated from the area.[[385]](#cite_note-388) On 18 August, explosions were reported at [Belbek Air Base](/wiki/Belbek_Air_Base "Belbek Air Base") north of Sevastopol.[[386]](#cite_note-389) On 8 October 2022 the [Kerch Bridge](/wiki/Kerch_Bridge "Kerch Bridge"), linking occupied Crimea to Russia, [partially collapsed due to an explosion](/wiki/2022_Crimean_Bridge_explosion "2022 Crimean Bridge explosion").[[387]](#cite_note-nyttruck-390) On 17 July 2023, there was [another large explosion](/wiki/2023_Crimean_Bridge_explosion "2023 Crimean Bridge explosion") on the bridge.[[388]](#cite_note-391) On 3 June 2025, an [attack with underwater explosives](/wiki/2025_Crimean_Bridge_explosion "2025 Crimean Bridge explosion") damaged the foundations of the bridge; traffic resumed within hours.[[389]](#cite_note-392)

#### Russian attacks against Ukrainian civilian infrastructure

Main article: [Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure")

Further information: [Russian attacks on civilians in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Russian_attacks_on_civilians_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian attacks on civilians in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

Since 2022, Russia has carried out strikes on Ukrainian electrical and water systems.[[390]](#cite_note-intermittent-393) On 6 October 2022 the Ukrainian military reported that 86 [Shahed 136](/wiki/HESA_Shahed_136 "HESA Shahed 136") kamikaze drones had been launched by Russian forces, and between 30 September and 6 October Ukrainian forces had destroyed 24 out of 46 launched.[[391]](#cite_note-nw1-394) On 8 October, it was announced that [General of the Army](/wiki/General_of_the_Army "General of the Army") [Sergey Surovikin](/wiki/Sergey_Surovikin "Sergey Surovikin") would be commanding all Russian forces on the strength of his novel air assault technique.[[392]](#cite_note-alar1-395) On 16 October, *[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")* reported that Iran was planning to supply Russia with drones and missiles.[[393]](#cite_note-396) On 18 October the US State Department accused Iran of violating [Resolution 2231](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2231 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 2231") by selling [Shahed 131](/wiki/Shahed_131 "Shahed 131") and [Shahed 136](/wiki/Shahed_136 "Shahed 136") drones to Russia,[[394]](#cite_note-397) agreeing with France and the UK. Iran denied sending arms for the Ukraine war.[[395]](#cite_note-CNN:_Iran_denies_supplying_Russia_with_weapons_for_use_in_Ukraine-398) On 22 October France, Britain and Germany called for a UN investigation.[[396]](#cite_note-f24-20221022-399) On 1 November, CNN reported that Iran was preparing to send ballistic missiles and other weapons to Russia for use in Ukraine.[[397]](#cite_note-400)

On 15 November 2022, Russia fired 85 missiles at the [Ukrainian power grid](/wiki/Electricity_in_Ukraine "Electricity in Ukraine"), causing [power outages](/wiki/Power_outage "Power outage") in Kyiv and neighbouring regions.[[398]](#cite_note-401) In March 2023, *The New York Times* reported that Russia had used new hypersonic missiles in a massive missile attack on Ukraine. Such missiles are more effective in evading conventional Ukrainian anti-missile defences.[[399]](#cite_note-nyt2-402)

The UK Defence Ministry said strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure are part of Russia's 'Strategic Operation for the Destruction of Critically Important Targets' (SODCIT) military doctrine, intended to demoralise the population and force the Ukrainian leadership to capitulate.[[400]](#cite_note-403) According to the [Royal United Services Institute](/wiki/Royal_United_Services_Institute "Royal United Services Institute"):[[401]](#cite_note-404)

> Russian strikes had cumulatively destroyed 9 [gigawatts](/wiki/Gigawatts "Gigawatts") (GW) of Ukraine's domestic power generation by mid-June 2024. Peak consumption during the winter of 2023 was 18 GW, which means that half of Ukraine's production capacity has been destroyed.

On 8 July 2024, Russia used a [Kh-101](/wiki/Kh-101 "Kh-101") missile[[402]](#cite_note-bc8-405) to kill two and injure 16 at the [Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital](/wiki/Okhmatdyt "Okhmatdyt") in Kyiv.[[403]](#cite_note-ap8-406)[[404]](#cite_note-cnn8-407)[[405]](#cite_note-bbc8-408)[[406]](#cite_note-cbc8-409) At least 20 civilians were killed in Kyiv that night.[[407]](#cite_note-peu8-410)

In late 2024, Russia switched from attacking energy distribution infrastructure to striking power stations, affecting 15% of Ukraine's pre-war generating capacity. From the summer of 2025, attacks switched back to infrastructure with a much greater number of drones and ballistic missiles. Strikes were also made on Ukrainian gas production, with 60% of its capacity destroyed in October 2025.[[359]](#cite_note-Chathamhouse_Nov2025-362)

#### Ukrainian attacks on Russian oil production

In 2025, Ukraine intensified efforts to disrupt Russian oil production and export facilities, using drone and missile strikes assisted by Western targeting intelligence. By late October 2025, an estimated 50% of Russia's 38 major refineries had been hit more than once. The result has been an estimated drop in oil production of between 10 and 15%, leading to raised domestic fuel prices and shortages in some regions.[[359]](#cite_note-Chathamhouse_Nov2025-362)

### Naval blockade and engagements

Main article: [Naval warfare in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Naval_warfare_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Naval warfare in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

On 28 February 2022, Turkey invoked the 1936 [Montreux Convention](/wiki/Montreux_Convention "Montreux Convention") and sealed off the [Bosphorus](/wiki/Bosphorus "Bosphorus") and [Dardanelles](/wiki/Dardanelles "Dardanelles") straits to Russian warships that were not registered to [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") home bases and returning to their ports of origin. It specifically denied passage to four Russian naval vessels.[[408]](#cite_note-411) On 24 February, the [State Border Guard Service of Ukraine](/wiki/State_Border_Guard_Service_of_Ukraine "State Border Guard Service of Ukraine") announced that Russian Navy ships had begun an [attack on Snake Island](/wiki/Snake_Island_campaign "Snake Island campaign").[[409]](#cite_note-412) The guided missile cruiser and flagship of the [Black Sea Fleet](/wiki/Black_Sea_Fleet "Black Sea Fleet"), [*Moskva*](/wiki/Russian_cruiser_Moskva "Russian cruiser Moskva") and patrol boat [*Vasily Bykov*](/wiki/Russian_patrol_ship_Vasily_Bykov "Russian patrol ship Vasily Bykov") bombarded the island.[[410]](#cite_note-413) The Russian warship instructed the Ukrainians on the island to surrender. Their response was "[Russian warship, go fuck yourself!](/wiki/Russian_warship,_go_fuck_yourself "Russian warship, go fuck yourself")"[[411]](#cite_note-414) After the bombardment, Russian soldiers landed and took control of [Snake Island](/wiki/Snake_Island_(Ukraine) "Snake Island (Ukraine)").[[412]](#cite_note-415) Russia said on 26 February that US drones had supplied intelligence to the Ukrainian navy to help it target Russian warships in the Black Sea. The US denied this.[[413]](#cite_note-416)

By 3 March, Ukrainian forces in Mykolaiv [scuttled](/wiki/Scuttled "Scuttled") the frigate [*Hetman Sahaidachny*](/wiki/Ukrainian_frigate_Hetman_Sahaidachny "Ukrainian frigate Hetman Sahaidachny"), the flagship of the Ukrainian navy, to prevent its capture.[[414]](#cite_note-417) On 24 March, Ukrainian officials said that a Russian [landing ship](/wiki/Alligator-class_landing_ship "Alligator-class landing ship") docked in Berdiansk was destroyed by a Ukrainian rocket attack.[[165]](#cite_note-CNN-Berdyansk-168)[[415]](#cite_note-418) In March 2022, the UN [International Maritime Organization](/wiki/International_Maritime_Organization "International Maritime Organization") (IMO) sought to create a safe sea corridor for commercial vessels to leave Ukrainian ports.[[416]](#cite_note-reuters-20220312-419) On 27 March, Russia established a sea corridor 80 miles (130 km) long and 3 miles (4.8 km) wide through its [Maritime Exclusion Zone](/wiki/Maritime_Exclusion_Zone "Maritime Exclusion Zone"), for the transit of merchant vessels from the edge of Ukrainian territorial waters southeast of Odesa.[[417]](#cite_note-westpoint-20220412-420)[[418]](#cite_note-imo-20220328-421)

The *Moskva* was, according to Ukrainian sources and a US senior official,[[419]](#cite_note-422) hit on 13 April by two Ukrainian [Neptune anti-ship cruise missiles](/wiki/R-360_Neptune "R-360 Neptune"). The Russian Defence Ministry said the warship had suffered serious damage from a munition explosion caused by a fire, and that its crew had been evacuated.[[420]](#cite_note-423) Pentagon spokesman John Kirby reported on 14 April that satellite images showed that the Russian warship had suffered a sizeable explosion onboard but was heading to the east for expected repairs in [Sevastopol](/wiki/Sevastopol "Sevastopol").[[421]](#cite_note-424) Later the same day, the Russian Ministry of Defence stated that the [*Moskva* had sunk](/wiki/Sinking_of_the_Moskva "Sinking of the Moskva").[[422]](#cite_note-425) On 15 April, Reuters reported that Russia launched an apparent retaliatory missile strike against the missile factory [Luch Design Bureau](/wiki/Luch_Design_Bureau "Luch Design Bureau") in Kyiv where the Neptune missiles used in the *Moskva* attack were manufactured.[[423]](#cite_note-426) On 5 May, a US official confirmed that the US gave "a range of intelligence" to assist in the sinking.[[424]](#cite_note-427)

On 1 June, Russian Foreign Minister [Sergey Lavrov](/wiki/Sergey_Lavrov "Sergey Lavrov") asserted that Ukraine's policy of mining its own harbours to impede Russian maritime aggression had contributed to the food export crisis, saying: "If Kyiv solves the problem of demining ports, the Russian Navy will ensure the unimpeded passage of ships with grain to the Mediterranean Sea."[[425]](#cite_note-428) On 23 July, CNBC reported a Russian missile strike on the Ukrainian port of Odesa, swiftly condemned by world leaders amid a recent [UN- and Turkish-brokered deal](/wiki/Black_Sea_Grain_Initiative "Black Sea Grain Initiative") to secure a sea corridor for exports of foodstuffs.[[426]](#cite_note-429)

On 26 December 2023, Ukraine's air force attacked the [Russian landing ship *Novocherkassk*](/wiki/Russian_landing_ship_Novocherkassk "Russian landing ship Novocherkassk") docked in [Feodosia](/wiki/Feodosia "Feodosia"). Ukraine said it was destroyed. Russian authorities confirmed the attack, but not the loss, and said two attacking aircraft were destroyed. Independent analysts said the ship's loss could hamper future Russian attacks on Ukraine's coast.[[427]](#cite_note-strikes_2023_12_26_reuters-430)[[428]](#cite_note-attack_2023_12_26_foxnews-431)[[429]](#cite_note-strikes_2023_12_26_wsj_com-432) On 31 January 2024, Ukrainian sea drones struck the Russian [Tarantul-class corvette](/wiki/Tarantul-class_corvette "Tarantul-class corvette") Ivanovets in the Black Sea, causing the ship to sink.[[430]](#cite_note-The_Telegraph_2024_e989-433)[[431]](#cite_note-Greenall_2024_j308-434) On 14 February, the same type of Ukrainian sea drones struck and sank the [Russian landing ship *Tsezar Kunikov*](/wiki/Russian_ship_Tsezar_Kunikov "Russian ship Tsezar Kunikov").[[432]](#cite_note-Goryashko_2024_x892-435)[[433]](#cite_note-Tom_Balmforth_2024_k016-436)

### Ukrainian resistance

Main article: [Ukrainian resistance in Russian-occupied Ukraine](/wiki/Ukrainian_resistance_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "Ukrainian resistance in Russian-occupied Ukraine")

See also: [2022 protests in Russian-occupied Ukraine](/wiki/2022_protests_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "2022 protests in Russian-occupied Ukraine")

Ukrainian civilians resisted the Russian invasion by volunteering for territorial defence units, making [Molotov cocktails](/wiki/Molotov_cocktail "Molotov cocktail"), donating food, building barriers like [Czech hedgehogs](/wiki/Czech_hedgehog "Czech hedgehog"),[[434]](#cite_note-437) and helping to transport refugees.[[435]](#cite_note-438) Responding to a call from [Ukravtodor](/wiki/State_Agency_of_Automobile_Roads_of_Ukraine "State Agency of Automobile Roads of Ukraine"), Ukraine's transportation agency, civilians dismantled or altered road signs,[[436]](#cite_note-439) constructed makeshift barriers, and blocked roadways.[[437]](#cite_note-440) Social media reports showed spontaneous street [protests against Russian forces](/wiki/2022_protests_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "2022 protests in Russian-occupied Ukraine") in occupied settlements, often evolving into verbal altercations and physical standoffs with Russian troops.[[438]](#cite_note-yes!-441) By April, Ukrainian civilians began to organise as guerrillas, mostly in the wooded north and east of the country. The Ukrainian military announced plans for a large-scale guerrilla campaign to complement its conventional defence.[[439]](#cite_note-442)

People physically blocked Russian military vehicles, sometimes forcing them to retreat.[[438]](#cite_note-yes!-441)[[440]](#cite_note-443) The Russian soldiers' response to unarmed civilian resistance varied from reluctance to engage the protesters,[[438]](#cite_note-yes!-441) to firing directly into crowds.[[441]](#cite_note-444) There have been mass detentions of Ukrainian protesters, and Ukrainian media has reported forced disappearances, mock executions, hostage-taking, [extrajudicial killings](/wiki/Extrajudicial_killing "Extrajudicial killing"), and sexual violence perpetrated by the Russian military.[[442]](#cite_note-445) To facilitate Ukrainian attacks, civilians reported Russian military positions via a [Telegram](/wiki/Telegram_(software) "Telegram (software)") chatbot and [Diia](/wiki/Diia "Diia"), a Ukrainian government app. In response, Russian forces began destroying mobile phone network equipment, searching door-to-door for smartphones and computers, and in at least one case killed a civilian who had pictures of Russian tanks.[[443]](#cite_note-446) As of 21 May 2022, Zelenskyy indicated that Ukraine had 700,000 service members on active duty fighting the Russian invasion.[[444]](#cite_note-447) Ukraine withdrew soldiers and military equipment back to Ukraine over the course of 2022 that had been deployed to [United Nations peacekeeping](/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping "United Nations peacekeeping") missions.[[445]](#cite_note-448)

### Energy infrastructure

See also: [Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure") and [Russian sabotage operations in Europe § Energy and infrastructure](/wiki/Russian_sabotage_operations_in_Europe#Energy_and_infrastructure "Russian sabotage operations in Europe")

Throughout the war Russia and Ukraine have attacked each other's energy infrastructure. Ukrainian power generation and heating facilities and Russia's pipelines and refineries were hit.[[446]](#cite_note-449)[[447]](#cite_note-gas_infra-450)

As a reaction to [Russia's recognition of the occupied Ukrainian territories in Donetsk and Luhansk](/wiki/International_recognition_of_the_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic_and_the_Luhansk_People%27s_Republic "International recognition of the Donetsk People's Republic and the Luhansk People's Republic") Germany suspended its certification of the [Nord Stream 2](/wiki/Nord_Stream_2 "Nord Stream 2") pipeline on 22 February 2022.[[448]](#cite_note-451) In September 2022 the inactive Nord Stream pipeline between Russia and Germany was [sabotaged](/wiki/Nord_Stream_pipelines_sabotage "Nord Stream pipelines sabotage"), destroying three of the four pipelines. As of August 2025[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present)&action=edit) no party has claimed nor admitted responsibility and investigations are ongoing. A Ukrainian national was arrested in August 2025 on suspicion of being involved.[[449]](#cite_note-452) As part of the [economic sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") against Russia for its war the [EU Commission](/wiki/EU_Commission "EU Commission") has banned use of the Nord Stream pipelines.[[450]](#cite_note-453)[[451]](#cite_note-454)

Pipelines carrying natural gas and oil from Russia to Central Europe continued to operate during the war in a reduced manner. They have been attacked several times; in May 2025 both sides accused each other of attacking gas infrastructure in Russia's Kursk Oblast. In August 2025 Ukraine repeatedly attacked pumping stations of Russia's [Druzhba pipeline](/wiki/Druzhba_pipeline "Druzhba pipeline"), interrupting oil supply to Hungary and Slovakia,[[447]](#cite_note-gas_infra-450)[[452]](#cite_note-455) while the same month a Russian attack on Ukrainian energy infrastructure left more than 100,000 households without electricity.[[453]](#cite_note-u402-456)

By 28 August 2025 Ukraine's campaign to strike at Russia's petroleum industry had hit ten oil refineries and was estimated by [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") to have disrupted Russia's refinery capacity by at least 17% or 1.1 million barrels a day.[[454]](#cite_note-457) The effect was a fuel crisis in Crimea and both southern and far eastern regions with price surges and dry gas stations.[[455]](#cite_note-458) In September 2025 the [International Energy Agency](/wiki/International_Energy_Agency "International Energy Agency") stated that Russia's revenues from [oil product exports](/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Russia "Petroleum industry in Russia") had in August declined to five-year lows, contributing to Russia's economic slowdown.[[456]](#cite_note-459) Acknowledging Russia's strained [energy system](/wiki/Energy_in_Russia "Energy in Russia") president [Vladimir Putin](/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") pointed to Russia's [coal reserves](/wiki/Coal_in_Russia "Coal in Russia") to offset its gas shortage, insufficient infrastructure and under-developed grid economy.[[457]](#cite_note-460)

Following its 14 September 2025 attack on Russia's second largest refinery [Kinef](/wiki/Kinef "Kinef") the [General Staff of the Ukrainian Armed Forces](/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Ukrainian_Armed_Forces "General Staff of the Ukrainian Armed Forces") claimed to be "working 'systematically' to weaken Russia's military and economic capabilities with a particular focus on fuel, weapons, and ammunition production".[[458]](#cite_note-461)

## Foreign involvement

Main article: [Foreign involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Foreign_involvement_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Foreign involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

### Support for Ukraine

Main article: [Military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian war](/wiki/Military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian war")

Further information: [List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian war](/wiki/List_of_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian war"), [International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), and [International Legion (Ukraine)](/wiki/International_Legion_(Ukraine) "International Legion (Ukraine)")

Many countries have supplied military aid to Ukraine including weaponry, equipment, training, and logistical support. Several imposed limited sanctions on Russia in the prelude to the invasion and applied new sanctions when the invasion began, intending to cripple the Russian economy;[[459]](#cite_note-DA-462)[[460]](#cite_note-463) sanctions targeted individuals, banks, businesses, monetary exchanges, exports, and imports.[[459]](#cite_note-DA-462)

Military assistance has mostly been co-ordinated through the [Ukraine Defence Contact Group](/wiki/Ukraine_Defence_Contact_Group "Ukraine Defence Contact Group"), whose more than fifty countries include all 32 [member states](/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO "Member states of NATO") of [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO").[[461]](#cite_note-464) From January 2022 to January 2024, $380 billion in aid to Ukraine was tracked by the [Kiel Institute](/wiki/Kiel_Institute_for_the_World_Economy "Kiel Institute for the World Economy").[[462]](#cite_note-cnn-aid-465) European countries have provided the most aid in total (military, financial and humanitarian).[[463]](#cite_note-CNN_US_investment-466) Estonia and Denmark have provided the most military aid as a share of GDP.[[464]](#cite_note-CFR-467) The European Union co-ordinated the supply of military aid for the first time.[[465]](#cite_note-468) The [US has provided](/wiki/United_States_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "United States and the Russian invasion of Ukraine") the most military assistance to Ukraine,[[463]](#cite_note-CNN_US_investment-466) and has set aside $175 billion to help the country.[[464]](#cite_note-CFR-467) Most of the US military aid has been old American weaponry and equipment from [reserve stockpiles](/wiki/War_reserve_stock "War reserve stock"), while most of the US funding earmarked for Ukraine stays in the US economy and supports US industries, subsidising the manufacture of weapons and military equipment.[[464]](#cite_note-CFR-467)[[466]](#cite_note-Lawfare-469) Bulgaria supplied Ukraine with over one third of the ammunition needed in the early phase of the invasion and a plurality of needed fuel.[[467]](#cite_note-470) Most of Ukraine's supporters ruled out sending troops to the country in the early months of the invasion.[[468]](#cite_note-471)

Although [India has maintained a neutral stance](/wiki/India_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "India and the Russian invasion of Ukraine") on the invasion,[[469]](#cite_note-472) reports indicate that artillery shells made by Indian manufacturers were sold to European countries and then diverted to Ukraine. Indian officials have not intervened despite objections from Russia.[[470]](#cite_note-reuters-2024-09-19-473)

The Russian government has threatened retaliation against countries supplying military aid to Ukraine, and said it meant NATO was waging a proxy war against Russia.[[471]](#cite_note-474) According to the [Atlantic Council](/wiki/Atlantic_Council "Atlantic Council")'s Peter Dickinson, Russia's government has not followed through on its threats, despite most of its "[red lines](/wiki/Red_lines_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Red lines in the Russo-Ukrainian war")" being crossed.[[472]](#cite_note-475) President Putin said that if military aid stopped, Ukraine would not survive for long.[[473]](#cite_note-476)

In May 2025, Ralph Goff, a former chief of operations at the [CIA](/wiki/CIA "CIA"), said that the Biden administration gave Ukraine just enough weapons to bleed, but not to win, adding that "[They] allowed themselves to be bamboozled by Vladimir Putin and his nuclear-sabre rattling."[[474]](#cite_note-477)[[475]](#cite_note-478)

Since the start of Russia's invasion in 2022, the United States has been sharing intelligence gathered through sophisticated satellites and manned and unmanned aerial systems with Ukraine, with a focus on finished signal intelligence to aid in targeting.[[476]](#cite_note-479)[[477]](#cite_note-480) In March 2025, the United States paused intelligence sharing with Ukraine,[[478]](#cite_note-481) only to resume it a few days later.[[479]](#cite_note-482)[[480]](#cite_note-483) In October 2025, the Wall Street Journal and Reuters reported that the US was to provide intelligence to enable long-range strikes on Russian energy infrastructure deep in Russian territory.[[481]](#cite_note-484)[[482]](#cite_note-485)[[483]](#cite_note-486) In November 2025, Reuters reported that the United States threatened to cut intelligence sharing in order to pressure Ukraine into negotiating a peace agreement.[[484]](#cite_note-487)

### Support for Russia

Main article: [Support for Russia in the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Support_for_Russia_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Support for Russia in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

#### Belarus

See also: [Belarusian involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Belarusian_involvement_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Belarusian involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

Belarus has allowed Russia to use its territory to stage part of the invasion, and to launch missiles into Ukraine.[[485]](#cite_note-488) Belarus airspace was used by Russia, including for [radar early warning and control](/wiki/Airborne_early_warning_and_control "Airborne early warning and control") missions, until 2023, when a Russian [Beriev A-50](/wiki/Beriev_A-50 "Beriev A-50") surveillance plane was [damaged by drones](/wiki/Machulishchy_air_base_attack "Machulishchy air base attack").[[486]](#cite_note-489) Belarus is considered a [co-belligerent](/wiki/Co-belligerence "Co-belligerence").[[487]](#cite_note-490)[[488]](#cite_note-491)[[489]](#cite_note-492) Political scientist Matthew Frear considers Belarus a co-[combatant](/wiki/Combatant "Combatant"), with "[Lukashenko](/wiki/Alexander_Lukashenko "Alexander Lukashenko") repeatedly stated his support for Putin's military actions",[[490]](#cite_note-493) while the 2023 issue *Armed Conflict Survey* classified it as not a direct [co-combatant](/wiki/Combatant "Combatant").[[491]](#cite_note-494) Belarus provided Russia with weapons and ammunition, and later, according to the 2024 issue of *Armed Conflict Survey*, Russia deployed tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus.[[492]](#cite_note-495)

#### Iran

See also: [Iran and the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Iran_and_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Iran and the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

In June 2023, US military intelligence suggested Iran was providing both [Shahed combat drones](/wiki/Shahed_drone "Shahed drone") and production materials to develop a [drone manufactory](/wiki/Yelabuga_drone_factory "Yelabuga drone factory") to Russia.[[493]](#cite_note-496) In February 2024, a [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters "Reuters") report indicated that Iran sent ballistic missiles to the Russian military.[[494]](#cite_note-497) According to the US and Ukraine, Iranian troops have been stationed in Crimea to assist Russia in launching drone attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure.[[495]](#cite_note-498)[[496]](#cite_note-499) Iran has denied sending arms to Russia for use against Ukraine.[[395]](#cite_note-CNN:_Iran_denies_supplying_Russia_with_weapons_for_use_in_Ukraine-398)

#### North Korea

See also: [North Korean involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/North_Korean_involvement_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "North Korean involvement in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

[North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") has supplied Russia with ballistic missiles and launchers.[[497]](#cite_note-500)[[498]](#cite_note-501) In October 2024, Ukraine and [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") claimed North Korean engineers had been deployed to the battlefield to help with the launch of these missiles, and suffered casualties.[[499]](#cite_note-The_Guardian:_North_Korean_Troops_Deployed-502)[[500]](#cite_note-k284-503)[[501]](#cite_note-a180-504)

Later the same month, a White House spokesperson said the US was "concerned" about reports North Korean soldiers were fighting for Russia.[[502]](#cite_note-u147-505)[[503]](#cite_note-n959-506)[[504]](#cite_note-h428-507) Zelensky announced that Ukrainian intelligence believed there were 10,000 North Korean troops preparing to join Russian forces.[[505]](#cite_note-508) The North Korean government stated that none of their soldiers were fighting for Russia.[[506]](#cite_note-509)[[507]](#cite_note-510)[[508]](#cite_note-511)

The US later said it had seen evidence that North Korea had sent 3,000 soldiers to Russia for possible deployment to Ukraine, determining that the soldiers had been transported by ship in October and were training at three military bases in eastern Russia. The US added that the alleged North Korean deployment could be further evidence that the Russian military was having problems with manpower.[[509]](#cite_note-y335-512) On 28 October, NATO chief [Mark Rutte](/wiki/Mark_Rutte "Mark Rutte") confirmed earlier Ukrainian intelligence that North Korean troops had been deployed to [Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Kursk_Oblast "Kursk Oblast") to support Russia against the [Kursk offensive](/wiki/Kursk_offensive_(2024%E2%80%932025) "Kursk offensive (2024–2025)"), and the Pentagon reported that around 10,000 North Korean soldiers been sent in total.[[510]](#cite_note-513)[[511]](#cite_note-i587-514)[[512]](#cite_note-k484-515)

On 7 November, Ukraine's defence minister reported that North Korean troops had engaged in battle on 5 November.[[513]](#cite_note-516) On 13 November, the US State Department and South Korea confirmed that North Korean troops had engaged in combat against Ukrainian forces in Kursk Oblast.[[514]](#cite_note-r219-517)[[515]](#cite_note-b215-518)[[516]](#cite_note-u951-519)[[517]](#cite_note-520) On 24 November, the Ukrainian chief of general staff confirmed that North Korean troops had been engaged in battle.[[518]](#cite_note-521) On 2 December the Pentagon stated that it had no evidence of North Korean troops engaged in combat, but noted that North Korean soldiers had been integrated into Russian units.[[519]](#cite_note-522) The Ukrainian intelligence directorate confirmed that North Korean troops have been integrated into Russian units held in reserve, but said North Korean troops were unlikely to be engaged in combat and were still engaged in training.[[520]](#cite_note-523) On 16 December, the US confirmed that North Korean troops had been killed in combat in Russia's Kursk oblast.[[521]](#cite_note-524) By 18 December, the number of killed and wounded North Korean soldiers had reportedly reached a couple of hundred,[[522]](#cite_note-525) while South Korea reported 100 North Koreans dead and 1000 injured.[[523]](#cite_note-526) [US Army JAG](/wiki/United_States_Army_Judge_Advocate_General%27s_Corps "United States Army Judge Advocate General's Corps") officers Steve Szymanski and Joshua Keruski stated that North Korea had become a party to an international armed conflict with Ukraine as of the 5 November engagement.[[524]](#cite_note-Szymanski_&_Keruski-527)

Zelenskyy showcased footage which he said showed Russian troops burning the faces of killed North Korean soldiers to conceal their presence on the battlefield.[[525]](#cite_note-i614-528)[[526]](#cite_note-q291-529)[[527]](#cite_note-f970-530)[[528]](#cite_note-d245-531)

In January 2025, two North Korean servicemen were taken prisoner while fighting in Kursk Oblast. Intelligence debriefings indicate that North Korean soldiers have been issued false military papers stating that they are Russians from [Tuva](/wiki/Tuva "Tuva").[[529]](#cite_note-nk-soldiers-captured-532) In March 2025, South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said that North Korea had sent an additional 3,000 soldiers early in the year, along with military equipment including short-range ballistic missiles. According to South Korea, roughly 11,000 North Korean soldiers had been sent to Russia, 4,000 of which were killed or wounded.[[530]](#cite_note-533) The same month, Russia acknowledged the presence of North Korean soldiers helping its forces in Kursk for the first time, with [Valery Gerasimov](/wiki/Valery_Gerasimov "Valery Gerasimov") expressing gratitude to North Korean troops for assisting in "liberating border areas of the Kursk Region".[[531]](#cite_note-x755-534)

In June 2025, former Russian defence minister Sergei Shoigu announced that 1,000 North Korean military workers would be deployed to Kursk for demining, and another 5,000 for reconstruction.[[532]](#cite_note-535) The BBC reported that, in 2024, more than 10,000 North Korean workers were sent to work in "slave-like conditions" in Russian construction and other sectors, "in violation of the UN sanctions banning the use of North Korean labour." A South Korean intelligence official told the BBC that as many as 50,000 workers were to be deployed in 2025.[[533]](#cite_note-536)

#### Others and sanction evasions

See also: [China and the Russo-Ukrainian war](/wiki/China_and_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "China and the Russo-Ukrainian war") and [India and the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/India_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "India and the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

*[Politico](/wiki/Politico "Politico")* reported in March 2023 that Chinese state-owned weapons manufacturer [Norinco](/wiki/Norinco "Norinco") shipped assault rifles, drone parts, and body armour to Russia between June and December 2022, with some shipments via third countries including [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and the [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates").[[535]](#cite_note-538) According to the US, Chinese ammunition has been used on battlefields in Ukraine.[[536]](#cite_note-539) In May 2023, the European Union identified that Chinese and UAE firms were supplying weapon components to Russia.[[537]](#cite_note-540) In April 2024, China was reported to have provided Russia with [geospatial intelligence](/wiki/Geospatial_intelligence "Geospatial intelligence"), machine tools for tanks, and propellants for missiles.[[538]](#cite_note-541) In September 2024, Reuters reported documents indicating Russia had established a weapons programme in China to develop and produce long-range attack drones, with assistance from local specialists, for use in the invasion.[[539]](#cite_note-k324-542) In July 2025, Ukraine's [Main Directorate of Intelligence](/wiki/Main_Directorate_of_Intelligence_(Ukraine) "Main Directorate of Intelligence (Ukraine)") reported that [Laos](/wiki/Laos "Laos") had sent a 50-person demining crew to Kursk, though Laos denied the claim.[[540]](#cite_note-543)

Russia imports sensitive electronics, machinery, auto parts, and defence equipment from India.[[541]](#cite_note-544) Trade like oil sales has surged since 2022, boosting revenue for Russian state-owned companies. To bypass sanctions and manage its currency surplus, Russia pays in rupees, supporting both civilian and military needs.[[542]](#cite_note-545)[[543]](#cite_note-546) Reuters reported in July 2025 that according to Indian customs data, an Indian company shipped military-use explosive compounds valued at $1.4 million to Russia in December 2024.[[544]](#cite_note-o455-547)

Russia has continued to make billions from fossil fuel exports to the West. Ukraine's Western allies[*[which?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words "Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words")*] have paid Russia more for its hydrocarbons than they have given Ukraine in aid. In 2025 [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia") and [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") rejected an EU plan to phase out deliveries of Russian gas via Turkey by 2028. "Laundromat refineries" in Turkey and India process Russian crude and sell the refined fuel to sanctioning countries.[[545]](#cite_note-548)[[546]](#cite_note-549)[[547]](#cite_note-550) Russia has also developed partnerships with [India](/wiki/India "India") and [UAE](/wiki/UAE "UAE") that actively support its efforts to evade sanctions.[[548]](#cite_note-:23-551)[[549]](#cite_note-552)[[550]](#cite_note-553)

In 2022, approximately 400,000 US-made semiconductors worth $53.6 million were shipped to Russia via [Maldives](/wiki/Maldives "Maldives"), accounting for almost 20% of Maldives's exports. Maldives has no native semiconductor manufacturers; all of its exports are by Russian shell companies, most headquartered in Hong Kong.[[551]](#cite_note-554)[[552]](#cite_note-555) From 2015 to 2021, average annual trade between Russia and Turkey in 45 military-linked materials was $28 million; from January to October 2023 it was $158 million.[[553]](#cite_note-ftTurkeyRussiaTrade-556)

From January 2022 to mid-2025, the United States imported $24.51 billion of Russian goods, mainly fertilisers, [enriched uranium](/wiki/Enriched_uranium "Enriched uranium") and [plutonium](/wiki/Plutonium "Plutonium"), and [palladium](/wiki/Palladium "Palladium").[[554]](#cite_note-557)

## Casualties

Further information: [Casualties of the Russo-Ukrainian War § Russian invasion of Ukraine (2022–present)](/wiki/Casualties_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War#Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(2022–present) "Casualties of the Russo-Ukrainian War"), and [List of deaths during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/List_of_deaths_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "List of deaths during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

Russian and Ukrainian sources have been said to inflate opposing casualty numbers and downplay their own losses for morale.[[555]](#cite_note-558) Leaked US documents say "under-reporting of casualties within the [Russian] system highlights the military's 'continuing reluctance' to convey bad news up the chain of command."[[556]](#cite_note-559) Russian news outlets have largely stopped reporting the Russian death toll.[[557]](#cite_note-fortune-560) Russia and Ukraine have admitted suffering "significant"[[558]](#cite_note-tragedy-561) and "considerable" losses, respectively.[[559]](#cite_note-untilwarends-562)[[560]](#cite_note-563)

The numbers of civilian and military deaths have been [impossible to determine](/wiki/Fog_of_war "Fog of war") precisely.[[561]](#cite_note-564) [Agence France-Presse](/wiki/Agence_France-Presse "Agence France-Presse") (AFP) reported that neither it nor independent conflict monitors could verify Russian and Ukrainian claims of enemy losses and suspected they were inflated.[[562]](#cite_note-565) In October 2022, the independent Russian media project [iStories](/wiki/Important_Stories "Important Stories"), citing sources close to the Kremlin, reported that more than 90,000 Russian soldiers had been killed, seriously wounded, or gone missing.[[563]](#cite_note-566)

While combat deaths can be inferred from a variety of sources, including [satellite imagery](/wiki/Satellite_imagery "Satellite imagery") of military action, measuring civilian deaths is more difficult. In June 2022, the [Ukrainian Minister of Defence](/wiki/Ukrainian_Ministry_of_Defence "Ukrainian Ministry of Defence") told CNN that tens of thousands of Ukrainians had died, and he hoped the death toll was below 100,000.[[564]](#cite_note-567) By July 2024, about 20,000 Ukrainians had lost limbs.[[565]](#cite_note-568) In Mariupol, Ukrainian officials believe at least 25,000 have been killed,[[566]](#cite_note-569)[[567]](#cite_note-570) and bodies were still being discovered in September 2022.[[568]](#cite_note-571) The mayor said over 10,000 and possibly as many as 20,000 civilians died in the [siege of Mariupol](/wiki/Siege_of_Mariupol "Siege of Mariupol") and Russian forces had brought mobile cremation equipment when they entered the city.[[569]](#cite_note-572)[[570]](#cite_note-573)[[571]](#cite_note-574) An investigation by [AP](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press") from the end of 2022 estimated up to 75,000 killed civilians in the Mariupol area alone.[[572]](#cite_note-575)[[573]](#cite_note-576) [AFP](/wiki/Agence_France-Presse "Agence France-Presse") says "a key gap in casualty counts is the lack of information from Russian-occupied places like the port city of Mariupol, where tens of thousands of civilians are believed to have died".[[574]](#cite_note-577) There were at least 8,000 excess deaths in Mariupol between March 2022 and February 2023.[[575]](#cite_note-578) The [Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights](/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights "Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights") (OHCHR) believed the true civilian casualty numbers were significantly higher than it has been able to confirm.[[576]](#cite_note-OHCHR_sep-579)

In the Russian military, ethnic minorities have suffered disproportionately high casualties. In October 2022, the Russian regions with the highest death tolls were [Dagestan](/wiki/Dagestan "Dagestan"), [Tuva](/wiki/Tuva "Tuva") and [Buryatia](/wiki/Buryatia "Buryatia"), all minority regions. In February 2024, six out of ten Russian regions with the highest mortality rates in Ukraine were located in Siberia and the far east, and ethnic minorities' continuing outsized casualty rates prompted analysts to warn that the situation will lead to long-term destructive impacts on these communities.[[577]](#cite_note-n606-580)[[578]](#cite_note-g456-581)[[579]](#cite_note-g132-582)[[580]](#cite_note-c079-583)[[581]](#cite_note-j309-584) About 1,200 Russian soldiers were killed or wounded in Ukraine every day in May–June 2024,[[582]](#cite_note-585) which climbed to 1,500 by November 2024, when 45,690 casualties were estimated.[[583]](#cite_note-586) *[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek "Newsweek")* estimated that on the bloodiest day in November 2024 the ratio of killed Russian men (1,950) exceeded the average daily male birth rate in Russia (1,836).[[584]](#cite_note-587) Latvia-based news outlet *[Meduza](/wiki/Meduza "Meduza")* estimated that up to 140,000 Russian soldiers had died by July 2024.[[585]](#cite_note-588)

The Russian invasion became the deadliest European war in the last 80 years.[[586]](#cite_note-589) Ukrainian average [mortality rate](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_mortality_rate "List of countries by mortality rate") was 8.7/1000 people in 2020,[[587]](#cite_note-590) and jumped to 18.6 in 2024, whereas Russia's mortality rate was 14/1000, ranking them as #1 and #9, of countries with the highest mortality rates.[[588]](#cite_note-591) In August 2024, *[Haaretz](/wiki/Haaretz "Haaretz")* estimated 172,000 people had died in the Russian invasion.[[589]](#cite_note-592) In February 2025, [Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft](/wiki/Quincy_Institute_for_Responsible_Statecraft "Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft") estimated 250,000 dead.[[590]](#cite_note-593) In September 2024, the *[Wall Street Journal](/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal "Wall Street Journal")* reported that there were now one million Ukrainians and Russians who were killed or wounded.[[591]](#cite_note-WSJ-Casualties-594)
