## War crimes and attacks on civilians

Main articles: [War crimes in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "War crimes in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)") and [Russian attacks on civilians in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Russian_attacks_on_civilians_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian attacks on civilians in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

The Russian military and authorities have been responsible for deliberate [attacks against civilian targets](/wiki/Attacks_on_civilians_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Attacks on civilians in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")[[621]](#cite_note-630) (including [strikes on hospitals](/wiki/Russian_strikes_on_hospitals_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian strikes on hospitals during the Russian invasion of Ukraine") and [on the energy grid](/wiki/Russian_strikes_against_Ukrainian_infrastructure_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Russian strikes against Ukrainian infrastructure (2022–present)")), massacres of civilians, abduction and torture of civilians, [sexual violence](/wiki/Sexual_violence_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Sexual violence in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"),[[622]](#cite_note-631) forced deportation of civilians, and torture and murder of Ukrainian prisoners of war. They have also carried out [indiscriminate attacks](/wiki/Indiscriminate_attack "Indiscriminate attack") in densely populated areas, including [with cluster bombs](/wiki/Use_of_cluster_munitions_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Use of cluster munitions in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), in one instance killing 61 people in the [Kramatorsk railway station attack](/wiki/Kramatorsk_railway_station_attack "Kramatorsk railway station attack").[[623]](#cite_note-632)[[624]](#cite_note-633)[[625]](#cite_note-634)[[205]](#cite_note-z362-208) According to [Kyrylo Budanov](/wiki/Kyrylo_Budanov "Kyrylo Budanov"), the chief of the Ukrainian intelligence, Russia before the start of the invasion had created 'execution lists' of Ukrainian teachers, journalists, scientists, writers, priests, and politicians, and was preparing for a [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide") of Ukrainians; the plans included locations of [mass graves](/wiki/Mass_grave "Mass grave") and mobile [crematoria](/wiki/Crematorium "Crematorium").[[626]](#cite_note-635)

According to the [United Nations' Human Rights Office](/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights "Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights") (OHCHR), by December 2023, about 78% of confirmed civilian casualties had been killed in Ukrainian-held territory.[[628]](#cite_note-637) Over 12,300 civilians have been killed since the invasion began.[[629]](#cite_note-638) Russia has deliberately and repeatedly attacked Ukrainian civilians with [FPV drones](/wiki/First-person_view_(radio_control) "First-person view (radio control)"), including [first responders](/wiki/First_responder "First responder"),[[630]](#cite_note-p704-639) such as in the Kherson terror campaign dubbed the "[human safari](/wiki/Human_safari_(terror_campaign) "Human safari (terror campaign)")".[[631]](#cite_note-p249-640)[[632]](#cite_note-z211-641)[[633]](#cite_note-v798-642) In October 2025, the UN concluded that the Russian military were systematically attacking Ukrainian civilians and civilian targets with drones along a 300-kilometer stretch of the [Dnipro River](/wiki/Dnipro_River "Dnipro River"), to drive Ukrainians out of the region. The report said that these are war crimes and crimes against humanity.[[634]](#cite_note-OHCHR_report_Oct_25-643)

The UN Human Rights Office reports that Russia is committing severe [human rights violations in occupied Ukraine](/wiki/Russian-occupied_territories_of_Ukraine#Violations_and_war_crimes "Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine"), including [arbitrary detentions](/wiki/Arbitrary_arrest_and_detention "Arbitrary arrest and detention"), [enforced disappearances](/wiki/Enforced_disappearance "Enforced disappearance"), torture, crackdown on [protests](/wiki/2022_protests_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "2022 protests in Russian-occupied Ukraine") and [freedom of speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech "Freedom of speech"), enforced [Russification](/wiki/Russification "Russification"), indoctrination of children, and suppression of Ukrainian language and culture.[[635]](#cite_note-UN_report_March_24-644) The UN also found that Russian authorities were systematically deporting Ukrainian civilians from occupied provinces, which is a crime against humanity.[[634]](#cite_note-OHCHR_report_Oct_25-643) Ukrainians have been [coerced into taking Russian passports](/wiki/Passportization "Passportization") and becoming Russian citizens. Those who refuse are denied healthcare and other rights,[[635]](#cite_note-UN_report_March_24-644) and can be imprisoned as a "foreign citizen". Ukrainian men who take Russian citizenship are drafted to fight against Ukraine.[[636]](#cite_note-645)

Russian forces have reportedly used banned [chemical weapons](/wiki/Chemical_weapons "Chemical weapons"), usually [tear gas](/wiki/Tear_gas "Tear gas") grenades.[[637]](#cite_note-Hambling_2023_z855-646)[[638]](#cite_note-Field_2024_s609-647) In April 2024, a *[Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily Telegraph")* investigation concluded that "Russian troops are carrying out a systematic campaign of illegal chemical attacks against Ukrainian soldiers".[[639]](#cite_note-The_Telegraph_2024_g413-648)

### Prisoners of war

Main article: [Prisoners of war in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Prisoners_of_war_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Prisoners of war in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

An August 2022 report by the Humanitarian Research Lab of the [Yale School of Public Health](/wiki/Yale_School_of_Public_Health "Yale School of Public Health") identified 21 [filtration camps](/wiki/Russian_filtration_camps_for_Ukrainians "Russian filtration camps for Ukrainians") for Ukrainian "civilians, POWs [prisoners of war], and other personnel" in the vicinity of Donetsk oblast. Imaging of one camp, [Olenivka prison](/wiki/Olenivka,_Kalmiuske_Raion "Olenivka, Kalmiuske Raion"), found two sites of disturbed earth consistent with "potential graves".[[640]](#cite_note-Yale_School_of_Medicine-649) Kaveh Khoshnood, a professor at the Yale School of Public Health, said: "Incommunicado detention of civilians is more than a violation of international humanitarian law—it represents a threat to the public health of those currently in the custody of Russia and its proxies." Conditions described by freed prisoners include exposure, insufficient access to sanitation, food and water, cramped conditions, electrical shocks and assault.[[640]](#cite_note-Yale_School_of_Medicine-649)

An [OHCHR](/wiki/OHCHR "OHCHR") report released in November 2022 documented abuses on both sides, based on interviews with prisoners.[[641]](#cite_note-650) In March 2023, UN human rights commissioner [Volker Türk](/wiki/Volker_T%C3%BCrk "Volker Türk") reported that more than 90% of the Ukrainian POWs interviewed by his office said they had been tortured or ill-treated, including "welcoming beatings" on their arrival in penitentiary facilities, which Russia despite several requests did not give UN staff access to.[[642]](#cite_note-651)

In April 2023, several videos circulated on different websites purportedly showing Russian soldiers beheading Ukrainian soldiers.[[643]](#cite_note-AP_NEWS_2023-652)

In March 2024, the UN issued a report saying Russia may have executed more than 30 recently captured Ukrainian POWs over the winter. The UN Human Rights Office verified three incidents in which Russian servicemen executed seven Ukrainian servicemen. According to the same report, 39 of 60 released Ukrainian POWs "disclosed that they had been subjected to sexual violence during their internment, including attempted rape, threats of rape and castration, beatings or the administration of electric shocks to genitals, and repeated forced nudity, including during interrogations".[[644]](#cite_note-Melkozerova_2024_g984-653)

In October 2024, the [EEAS](/wiki/European_External_Action_Service "European External Action Service") released a statement describing the increasing frequency of Russian executions of Ukrainian prisoners, with at least 177 prisoners dying in Russian captivity since the beginning of the war. The statement included the OHCHR's confirmation of systematic use of different methods of torture used by Russians against Ukrainian prisoners.[[645]](#cite_note-m314-654)

The Ukrainian Armed Forces have been accused of executions and other abuses of Russian POWs, but the number of allegations has been significantly lower.[[646]](#cite_note-Report_OHCHR-655): para. 105[[647]](#cite_note-NYT-Russian-POW-656)[[648]](#cite_note-657)[[649]](#cite_note-658)

### Abduction of Ukrainian children

Main article: [Child abductions in the Russo-Ukrainian war](/wiki/Child_abductions_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Child abductions in the Russo-Ukrainian war")

In June 2024, an investigation by the *[Financial Times](/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times")* identified four Ukrainian children on a Russian government-linked adoption website who had been abducted from state care homes. The children's Ukrainian background was not mentioned. One child was shown with a new Russian name and an age that differed from their Ukrainian documents, while another was shown using a Russian version of their Ukrainian name. 17 other matches identified by the *Financial Times* on the adoption website were confirmed as Ukrainian children in a *New York Times* investigation. Ukrainian authorities estimate that nearly 20,000 Ukrainian children have been forcibly taken from occupied territories to Russia since the full-scale invasion began. Wayne Jordash, president of humanitarian law firm Global Rights Compliance, described forcibly transferring or deporting children as war crimes, adding that when done as part of a widespread or systematic attack on a civilian population, Russia is also committing crimes against humanity.[[650]](#cite_note-k182-659)[[651]](#cite_note-t017-660)

A March 2025 report published by the ISW suggests that the mass transfer of Ukrainian children to Russia had been an established component of Russia's war plans in Ukraine prior to the invasion. It references Russian governmental documents that predate the invasion by days which outlined plans to move Ukrainian orphans in occupied Ukraine to Russia described internally as 'humanitarian evacuations'. Since the invasion, tens to hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia, where they have been housed in camps, placed with adoptive families, and provided with new Russian identities including new or altered names, falsified birth certificates, and other state documentation. The report claims that Russia intends to convert the abductees into 'the next generation of Russians' whilst 'depriving [Ukraine] of its multi-generation potential'. Referencing Article 2 of the [Genocide Convention](/wiki/Genocide_Convention "Genocide Convention"), the author concludes the opening section by noting that 'International law explicitly forbids the forcible transfer of children from one group to another group for the purpose of destroying, in whole or in part, a national or ethnic group, and considers these violations as constituent acts of genocide.'[[652]](#cite_note-o490-661)

In August 2025, [Mykola Kuleba](/wiki/Mykola_Kuleba "Mykola Kuleba"), the head of a Ukrainian [NGO](/wiki/Non-governmental_organization "Non-governmental organization"), said that Russian occupation authorities in Ukraine had created an online "catalog" of Ukrainian children up for adoption sorted by physical traits such as hair and eye colour, denouncing the practice as [child trafficking](/wiki/Trafficking_of_children "Trafficking of children").[[653]](#cite_note-r419-662)[[654]](#cite_note-n637-663)[[655]](#cite_note-s452-664)[[656]](#cite_note-b387-665)

### International arrest warrants

Main article: [International Criminal Court arrest warrants for Russian leaders](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_arrest_warrants_for_Russian_leaders "International Criminal Court arrest warrants for Russian leaders")

The [International Criminal Court](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court "International Criminal Court") (ICC) opened [an investigation](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigation_in_Ukraine "International Criminal Court investigation in Ukraine") into possible [crimes against humanity](/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity "Crimes against humanity"), [genocide](/wiki/Allegations_of_genocide_of_Ukrainians_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Allegations of genocide of Ukrainians in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") and war crimes committed in Ukraine.[[657]](#cite_note-666) On 17 March 2023, the ICC issued a warrant for Putin's arrest, charging him with individual criminal responsibility in the [abduction of children](/wiki/Child_abductions_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Child abductions in the Russian invasion of Ukraine") forcibly deported to Russia.[[658]](#cite_note-issues_warrant_2023_03_17_reuters-667) It was the first time that the ICC had issued an arrest warrant for the head of state of a [permanent member](/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council "Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council") of the [United Nations Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security Council")[[658]](#cite_note-issues_warrant_2023_03_17_reuters-667) (the world's five principal nuclear powers).[[659]](#cite_note-nuclear_powers-668) Moscow has denied any involvement in war crimes, a response Vittorio Bufacchi of [University College Cork](/wiki/University_College_Cork "University College Cork") says "has bordered on the farcical",[[660]](#cite_note-669) and its contention that the images coming out of Bucha were fabricated "a disingenuous response born by delusional hubris, post-truth on overdrive, (that) does not merit to be taken seriously." Even the usually fractured [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") came together to call Putin a war criminal.[[661]](#cite_note-670)

One of several efforts to document Russian war crimes concerns its repeated bombardment of markets and bread lines, destruction of basic infrastructure and attacks on exports and supply convoys, in a country where deliberate starvation of Ukrainians by Soviets (the [Holodomor](/wiki/Holodomor "Holodomor")) still looms large in public memory.[[662]](#cite_note-671) Forcible deportation of populations, such as took place in Mariupol, is another area of focus:[[663]](#cite_note-672)

> forced deportations and transfers are defined both as war crimes under the [Fourth Geneva Convention](/wiki/Fourth_Geneva_Convention "Fourth Geneva Convention") and [Protocol II](/wiki/Protocol_II "Protocol II") and Article 8 of the Rome Statute—and as crimes against humanity—under Article 7 of the [Rome Statute](/wiki/Rome_Statute "Rome Statute"). As both war crimes and [crimes against humanity](/wiki/Crime_against_humanity "Crime against humanity"), they have several mechanisms for individual accountability, the International Criminal Court and also, at the individual state level, [universal jurisdiction](/wiki/Universal_jurisdiction "Universal jurisdiction") and [Magnitsky sanctions](/wiki/Magnitsky_legislation "Magnitsky legislation") legislation.

The ICC issued arrest warrants for military officials [Sergey Kobylash](/wiki/Sergey_Kobylash "Sergey Kobylash"), [Viktor Sokolov](/wiki/Viktor_Sokolov_(naval_officer) "Viktor Sokolov (naval officer)"), [Sergei Shoigu](/wiki/Sergei_Shoigu "Sergei Shoigu") and [Valery Gerasimov](/wiki/Valery_Gerasimov "Valery Gerasimov").[[664]](#cite_note-673)[[665]](#cite_note-WarCrime-674)

## Impacts

### Humanitarian impact

Main article: [Humanitarian impacts of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Humanitarian_impacts_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Humanitarian impacts of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

The invasion contributed to the [2022 food crises](/wiki/2022%E2%80%932023_global_food_crises "2022–2023 global food crises").[[666]](#cite_note-675) As of February 2025, 3.7 million Ukrainians were internally displaced and 6.9 million were refugees.[[667]](#cite_note-676)

Russian attacks on civilians, causing mass civilian casualties and displacement, have been characterised as [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide") and [democide](/wiki/Democide "Democide").[[30]](#cite_note-Etkind-33)[[31]](#cite_note-h710-34)[[32]](#cite_note-q611-35)[[33]](#cite_note-v008-36) In September 2023, a UN-mandated investigative body reported that Russian occupiers had tortured Ukrainians to death, and forced families to listen as they raped women.[[668]](#cite_note-Farge_2023_r049-677) The commission previously found that violations committed by Russian forces in Ukraine may constitute [crimes against humanity](/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity "Crimes against humanity").[[669]](#cite_note-Gabrielle_Tétrault-Farber_2023_t397-678)

By August 2024, the [WHO](/wiki/WHO "WHO") had recorded 1,940 [attacks against Ukrainian healthcare](/wiki/Russian_strikes_on_hospitals_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian strikes on hospitals during the Russian invasion of Ukraine") and reported widespread [double-tap](/wiki/Double_tap_strike "Double tap strike") attacks.[[670]](#cite_note-679) In 2023, [Physicians for Human Rights](/wiki/Physicians_for_Human_Rights "Physicians for Human Rights") described Russian attacks on Ukraine's healthcare system as having a "reasonable basis" to be considered war crimes, and could potentially constitute crimes against humanity.[[671]](#cite_note-PHR_2023_i908-680)

#### Cultural heritage

Main article: [Ukrainian culture during the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Ukrainian_culture_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Ukrainian culture during the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

As of August 2025, [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") has verified damage to 508 Ukrainian cultural sites, including 151 religious sites, 34 museums, 33 monuments, and 18 libraries.[[672]](#cite_note-681) In 2022, the [European Parliament](/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament") labelled Russia's destruction of Ukrainian cultural property a war crime.[[673]](#cite_note-682) Ukraine's [Minister of Culture](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_and_Strategic_Communications "Ministry of Culture and Strategic Communications") [Oleksandr Tkachenko](/wiki/Oleksandr_Tkachenko_(journalist) "Oleksandr Tkachenko (journalist)") called it [cultural genocide](/wiki/Cultural_genocide "Cultural genocide").[[674]](#cite_note-683)

### Refugee crisis

Main article: [Ukrainian refugee crisis](/wiki/Ukrainian_refugee_crisis "Ukrainian refugee crisis")

See also: [Transnational repression by Russia](/wiki/Transnational_repression_by_Russia "Transnational repression by Russia")

The war has caused the largest refugee and [humanitarian crisis](/wiki/Humanitarian_crisis "Humanitarian crisis") in Europe since World War II.[[675]](#cite_note-684) In the first week of the invasion, the UN reported over a million refugees had fled Ukraine; this reached over eight million by February 2023.[[676]](#cite_note-UNHCR-Ukraine-685)[[677]](#cite_note-686) In May 2022, following an influx of military equipment into Ukraine, a significant number of refugees sought to return to regions relatively isolated from the front in southeastern Ukraine.[[678]](#cite_note-687) By 3 May, another 8 million people were displaced inside Ukraine.[[679]](#cite_note-688)

Most refugees were women, children, elderly, or disabled.[[680]](#cite_note-689) Most male Ukrainian nationals aged 18 to 60 were denied exit from Ukraine as part of [mandatory conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_Ukraine "Conscription in Ukraine"),[[681]](#cite_note-690) unless they were responsible for the financial support of three or more children, single fathers, or were the parent/guardian of children with disabilities.[[682]](#cite_note-691) Many Ukrainian men, including teenagers, opted to remain in Ukraine voluntarily to join the resistance.[[683]](#cite_note-692)

According to the UN High Commission for Refugees as of May 2022, there were 3,315,711 refugees in Poland, 901,696 in Romania, 594,664 in Hungary, 461,742 in Moldova, 415,402 in Slovakia, and 27,308 in Belarus, while Russia reported it had received over 800,104 refugees.[[676]](#cite_note-UNHCR-Ukraine-685) By July 2022, over 390,000 Ukrainian refugees had arrived in the Czech Republic, where the average refugee was a woman accompanied by a child.[[684]](#cite_note-693) Turkey registered more than 58,000 Ukrainian refugees as of March 2022.[[685]](#cite_note-694) The EU invoked the [Temporary Protection Directive](/wiki/Temporary_Protection_Directive "Temporary Protection Directive") for the first time, granting Ukrainian refugees the right to live and work in the EU for up to three years.[[686]](#cite_note-695) Britain has accepted 146,379 refugees, as well as extending the ability to remain in the UK for three years.[[687]](#cite_note-696)

According to the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") (OSCE), Russia has engaged in "massive deportation" of over 1.3 million Ukrainian civilians, potentially constituting crimes against humanity.[[688]](#cite_note-697) The OSCE and Ukraine have accused Russia of [forcibly moving](/wiki/Forced_displacement "Forced displacement") civilians to filtration camps in Russian-held territory, and then into Russia. Ukrainian sources have compared this policy to [Soviet-era population transfers](/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union "Population transfer in the Soviet Union") and Russian actions in the [Chechen War of Independence](/wiki/Chechen_War_of_Independence "Chechen War of Independence").[[689]](#cite_note-Mackintosh-2022-04-08-698) For instance, as of April 2022, Russia claimed to have evacuated about 121,000 Mariupol residents to Russia.[[689]](#cite_note-Mackintosh-2022-04-08-698)[[690]](#cite_note-699) [RIA Novosti](/wiki/RIA_Novosti "RIA Novosti") and Ukrainian officials said that thousands were dispatched to centres in cities in Russia and Russian-occupied Ukraine,[[691]](#cite_note-700) from which people were sent to economically depressed regions of Russia.[[692]](#cite_note-701)[[693]](#cite_note-702)[[j]](#cite_note-704)

### Long-term demographic effects

Both [Russia](/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia "Demographics of Russia") and [Ukraine](/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine#Population_decline "Demographics of Ukraine") faced the prospect of significant [population decline](/wiki/Population_decline "Population decline") even before the war. It is the first time that two countries with an average age above 40 have gone to war against each other.[[695]](#cite_note-705) Russia had a fighting-age (18-to-40-year-old) male population more than four times higher than Ukraine's and slightly higher birth rates, while the willingness to fight was more pronounced in Ukraine.[[696]](#cite_note-706)

Several sources have pointed out that the war is considerably worsening Ukraine's demographic crisis, making significant shrinking very likely.[[697]](#cite_note-707) A July 2023 study by the [Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies](/wiki/The_Vienna_Institute_for_International_Economic_Studies "The Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies") stated that,[[698]](#cite_note-kna23-708)

> regardless of how long the war lasts and whether or not there is further military escalation, Ukraine is unlikely to recover demographically from the consequences of the war. Even in 2040 it will have only about 35 million inhabitants, around 20% fewer than before the war (2021: 42.8 million) and the decline in the working-age population is likely to be the most severe and far-reaching.

Flight from war affected especially the southern and eastern regions and especially educated women of child-bearing age and their children. With an estimate of more than 20% of refugees not returning, study author Maryna Tverdostup concluded that long-term shrinking will significantly impair reconstruction.[[698]](#cite_note-kna23-708)

The war in Ukraine and the associated emigration, lower [birth rates](/wiki/Birth_rate "Birth rate") and war-related casualties further deepened the [demographic crisis of Russia](/wiki/Demographic_crisis_of_Russia "Demographic crisis of Russia").[[699]](#cite_note-709) The UN is projecting that the decline that started in 2021 will continue, and if current demographic conditions persist, Russia's population would be 120 million in fifty years, a decline of about 17%.[[700]](#cite_note-710)[[701]](#cite_note-711) Since February 2022, hundreds of thousands of [Russians have emigrated](/wiki/Russian_emigration_following_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian emigration following the Russian invasion of Ukraine"); estimates range from 370,000 to over 820,000. Combined with mobilisation, this possibly removed roughly half a million to one million working-age males from Russia's population.[[702]](#cite_note-712) Studies report that this will have a demographic effect, especially in Russia, that lasts much longer than the conflict.[[703]](#cite_note-713)

According to BBC:[[704]](#cite_note-714)

> They come from different walks of life. Some are journalists like us, but there are also IT experts, designers, artists, academics, lawyers, doctors, PR specialists, and linguists. Most are under 50. Many share western liberal values and hope Russia will be a democratic country one day. Some are LGBTQ+. Sociologists studying the current Russian emigration say there is evidence that those leaving are younger, better educated and wealthier than those staying. More often they are from bigger cities.

According to Johannes Wachs, "The exodus of skilled human capital, sometimes called [brain drain](/wiki/Brain_drain "Brain drain"), out of Russia may have a significant effect on the course of the war and the Russian economy in the long run."[[705]](#cite_note-715) According to a survey, around 15 percent of those who left returned to Russia, either permanently or to settle their affairs.[[706]](#cite_note-716) In November 2023, at the [World Russian People's Council](/wiki/World_Russian_People%27s_Council "World Russian People's Council"), Putin urged Russian women to have eight or more children.[[707]](#cite_note-Sharma_2023_w549-717)

In July 2024, [Chief of the General Staff](/wiki/Chief_of_the_General_Staff_(United_Kingdom) "Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)") of the British Army [Roland Walker](/wiki/Roland_Walker "Roland Walker") said that with the current way of fighting, it would take Russia five years to control the four oblasts of Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia that Russia claims as its own, and it would cost Russia from 1.5 to 1.8 million casualties.[[708]](#cite_note-718)

### Environmental impact

Main article: [Environmental impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Environmental impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

Based on a preliminary assessment, the war has inflicted $51 billion in environmental damage in Ukraine; according to a report by the [Yale School of the Environment](/wiki/Yale_School_of_the_Environment "Yale School of the Environment"), 623,000 tonnes (1.4 billion pounds) of petrochemicals have burned as a result of shelling, while nearly 1,500 tonnes (3.2 million pounds) of pollutants have leaked into bodies of water. Hazardous chemicals have contaminated around 28 hectares (70 acres) of soil, and likely made agricultural activities temporarily impossible.[[709]](#cite_note-enviroyale-719) Around 30% of Ukraine's land is littered with explosives and more than 2.4 million hectares (5.9 million acres) of forest have been damaged.[[710]](#cite_note-720)

According to peace organisation PAX, Russia's "deliberate targeting of industrial and energy infrastructure" has caused "severe" pollution, and the use of explosive weapons has left "millions of tonnes" of contaminated debris in cities and towns.[[711]](#cite_note-pax-721) In early June 2023, the [Kakhovka Dam](/wiki/Kakhovka_Dam "Kakhovka Dam"), under Russian occupation, [was damaged](/wiki/Destruction_of_the_Kakhovka_Dam "Destruction of the Kakhovka Dam"), causing flooding and triggering warnings of an "ecological disaster".[[712]](#cite_note-722)

The Ukrainian government, international observers and journalists have described the damage as [ecocide](/wiki/Ecocide "Ecocide").[[713]](#cite_note-723) The Ukrainian government is investigating more crimes against the environment and ecocide (a crime in Ukraine).[[714]](#cite_note-724) Zelenskyy has met with prominent European figures ([Heidi Hautala](/wiki/Heidi_Hautala "Heidi Hautala"), [Margot Wallstrom](/wiki/Margot_Wallstrom "Margot Wallstrom"), [Mary Robinson](/wiki/Mary_Robinson "Mary Robinson") and [Greta Thunberg](/wiki/Greta_Thunberg "Greta Thunberg")) to discuss the environmental damage and how to prosecute it.[[715]](#cite_note-725)

According to an investigation by NGL Media published in April 2024, Russia has completely destroyed over 60,000 hectares (150,000 acres) of Ukrainian forests. The investigation stated that long-term ecological consequences may include lowering of the groundwater level, reduction of biodiversity, worsening of air quality, fire outbreaks, and rivers and ponds drying up.[[716]](#cite_note-Fornusek_2024_r049-726)

The war in Ukraine has severely disrupted global [climate policy](/wiki/Climate_policy "Climate policy") and increased CO2 emissions.[[717]](#cite_note-727)[[718]](#cite_note-728) The effects have been strongly felt in Asia,[[719]](#cite_note-729)[[720]](#cite_note-730)[[721]](#cite_note-731) Europe,[[722]](#cite_note-732) and the US.[[723]](#cite_note-733) [Fatih Birol](/wiki/Fatih_Birol "Fatih Birol"), the head of the [International Energy Agency](/wiki/International_Energy_Agency "International Energy Agency") talking about the prospects of [COP 28](/wiki/2023_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference "2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference") noted:[[724]](#cite_note-734)

> ... the geopolitical situation, with many nations at loggerheads over the [war in Ukraine](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War"), and still frosty relations between the [US](/wiki/United_States "United States") and [China](/wiki/China "China"), would make for a difficult summit. [...] The most important challenge [to limiting temperature rises to 1.5 °C (2.7 °F) above pre-industrial levels] is the lack of [international cooperation](/wiki/International_cooperation "International cooperation").

#### Nuclear risk

Main article: [Nuclear risk during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Nuclear_risk_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Nuclear risk during the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

Putin implied that Russia may use nuclear weapons if certain ["red lines"](/wiki/Red_lines_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Red lines in the Russo-Ukrainian war") were crossed. By 2024, most of the [Russian government's "red lines"](/wiki/Red_lines_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war "Red lines in the Russo-Ukrainian war") had been crossed without nuclear weapons being used in response.[[725]](#cite_note-735)

Four days into the invasion, Putin put Russia's nuclear forces on high alert, raising fears that Russia could use [tactical nuclear weapons](/wiki/Tactical_nuclear_weapon "Tactical nuclear weapon") against Ukraine.[[726]](#cite_note-736) In response to what he called "completely irresponsible actions", Zelenskyy suggested that there should be "global control" of Russia's nuclear assets.[[727]](#cite_note-737) In March 2023, Putin announced plans to install Russian tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus.[[728]](#cite_note-738)

The invasion had an [impact on Ukraine's nuclear power plants](/wiki/Impact_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_on_nuclear_power_plants "Impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on nuclear power plants"). Russian forces [captured Chernobyl](/wiki/Capture_of_Chernobyl "Capture of Chernobyl") on the first day, leading to a huge spike in radiation levels.[[729]](#cite_note-739) Russia also captured [Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant "Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant"), the largest in Europe, which has since [been at risk](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant_crisis "Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant crisis") and damaged by shelling. In August 2022, Zelenskyy described the situation as "Russian [nuclear terror](/wiki/Nuclear_terrorism "Nuclear terrorism")".[[730]](#cite_note-740) The [International Atomic Energy Agency](/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency "International Atomic Energy Agency") said it was the first time a military conflict occurred amid nuclear plants, and it called for a demilitarised zone around Zaporizhzhia NPP.[[731]](#cite_note-741)

### Economic impact

Main article: [Economic impact of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Economic impact of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

#### Ukraine

[Ukrainian Minister of Economic Development and Trade](/wiki/Ministry_of_Economy_(Ukraine) "Ministry of Economy (Ukraine)") [Yulia Svyrydenko](/wiki/Yulia_Svyrydenko "Yulia Svyrydenko") announced that for 2022 Ukraine had a 30% loss in their [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") (GDP).[[732]](#cite_note-742) The [International Monetary Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") predicted that Ukraine's GDP would decrease between 10% to 35%;[[733]](#cite_note-743) the [European Bank for Reconstruction and Development](/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development "European Bank for Reconstruction and Development") predicted a 20% decrease.[[734]](#cite_note-744) The Ukrainian statistics service said that the GDP of Ukraine in 2023 grew by 5.3%.[[735]](#cite_note-745)

Ukraine began issuing [war bonds](/wiki/War_bond "War bond") on 1 March 2022, and the following day the Ukrainian government announced that they had raised 6.14 billion hryvnias.[[736]](#cite_note-746) In May 2022 the European Commission banned grain sales in Bulgaria, Poland, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, with the only exception being if they were transiting through those countries; the ban was lifted in September 2023.[[737]](#cite_note-747)

The war has caused a major [humanitarian crisis](/wiki/Humanitarian_crisis "Humanitarian crisis") in Ukraine: the [United Nations Development Programme](/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme "United Nations Development Programme") calculated in March 2022 that a prolonged conflict would cause 30% of the Ukrainian population to fall below the poverty line, while a further 62% would be at risk of also falling into poverty within a year.[[738]](#cite_note-748)

#### Russia

The [Russian Ministry of Economic Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_Economic_Development_(Russia) "Ministry of Economic Development (Russia)") said that for 2022 the GDP contracted by 2.1%[[739]](#cite_note-749) and for 2023 Russia's government said the GDP grew by 3.6%.[[740]](#cite_note-750) On 27 April 2024, it was reported that Russia was planning tax increases to help finance the war.[[741]](#cite_note-751) In January 2025, it was reported that, since early 2022, Russia had used a two-prong strategy to finance the war. In addition to the official Russian government [defence budget](/wiki/Military_budget_of_Russia "Military budget of Russia")—direct financial expenditure for waging the war in Ukraine was estimated at US$250 billion through June 2024 for military spending through normal channels,[[27]](#cite_note-DU-30) with the military budget rising to over 20% of annual GDP—an additional off-budget financing mechanism was employed with over US$200 billion of debt funding obtained from preferential bank loans made to defence contractors and war-related businesses, loans that had been compelled by the Russian government.[[28]](#cite_note-mt20250114-31)[[29]](#cite_note-kpost20250115-32)

A report published in April 2025 by the Stockholm Institute of Transition Economics (SITE) noted that official Russian statistics are unreliable and opaque, and "serves to bolster the domestic narrative of economic resilience and questions the effectiveness of sanctions while masking underlying fragilities".[[742]](#cite_note-SITEreport1-752) The report, which was presented to the finance ministers of the EU at a meeting of the [Economic and Financial Affairs Council](/wiki/Economic_and_Financial_Affairs_Council "Economic and Financial Affairs Council") on 13 May 2025, also argued that Russian fiscal stimulus has kept the economy afloat so far, but that it is on an unsustainable trajectory.[[742]](#cite_note-SITEreport1-752)[[743]](#cite_note-sitepresent-753) "Even under optimistic growth scenarios, Russia's economic scale remains insufficient to match its Western adversaries' capacity in a sustained geopolitical rivalry", the report concluded.[[742]](#cite_note-SITEreport1-752) In August 2025, [VEB](/wiki/VEB.RF "VEB.RF"), one of the largest Russian state banks, assessed that the Russian economy had started slipping into recession.[[744]](#cite_note-e976-754)

A price cap was placed on Russian oil by the [Group of 7](/wiki/G7 "G7") (G7) at $60 on 5 December 2022.[[745]](#cite_note-EI-755) The US banned all imports of Russian oil on 8 March 2022.[[746]](#cite_note-756) The European Union placed an embargo on oil products from Russia on 5 February 2023.[[745]](#cite_note-EI-755) Other countries that embargoed Russian oil included [Five Eyes](/wiki/Five_Eyes "Five Eyes") partners Canada, the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand.[[747]](#cite_note-757) Russia issued a ban on foreign diesel sales starting on 21 September 2023, lifting it on 6 October.[[748]](#cite_note-758)

## Peace efforts

Main article: [Peace negotiations in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Peace negotiations in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

Peace negotiations between Russia and Ukraine took place on 28 February, 3 March, and 7 March 2022, on the [Belarus–Ukraine border](/wiki/Belarus%E2%80%93Ukraine_border "Belarus–Ukraine border"), with further talks held on 10 March in Turkey and a fourth round of negotiations beginning 14 March.[[749]](#cite_note-759) The talks ended without agreement.

In 2024, Ukraine's main peace terms were that Russia withdraw its troops, that Ukrainian prisoners be released, Russian leaders be prosecuted for [war crimes](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "War crimes in the Russian invasion of Ukraine"), and Ukraine be given security guarantees to prevent further aggression. Russia's main terms were that Russia must keep [all the land it occupied](/wiki/Russian-occupied_territories_of_Ukraine "Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine"), that it be given all of the [provinces that it claims](/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts "Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts") but does not fully control, that Ukraine end plans to join NATO, and sanctions against Russia be lifted.[[751]](#cite_note-Putin_terms-761) According to Western sources, allowing Russia to keep the land it seized would "[reward the aggressor](/wiki/Right_of_conquest "Right of conquest") while punishing the victim" and set a dangerous precedent.[[752]](#cite_note-Chatham_end-762) They predicted this would allow Russia to re-arm and encourage it "to continue its [imperialist](/wiki/Russian_neo-imperialism "Russian neo-imperialism") campaign of expansionism" against Ukraine and other neighbours, and embolden other expansionist regimes.[[752]](#cite_note-Chatham_end-762)[[753]](#cite_note-763)[[754]](#cite_note-764)[[755]](#cite_note-765)

After [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") became US president in 2025, there was a major shift in US policy. The Trump administration began negotiations with Russia and separately with Ukraine. In February 2025, the US under the Trump administration twice sided with Russia in UN resolutions, first opposing a European-drafted resolution condemning Russia's actions and supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine, and then drafting and voting for a UN Security Council resolution calling for the end of the conflict, but containing no criticism of Russia.[[756]](#cite_note-u697-766)

In November 2025, Trump adopted a peace plan for ending the war containing 28 points. The plan was interpreted as broadly pro-Russian,[[757]](#cite_note-e610-767)[[758]](#cite_note-l915-768) and according to [The Insider](/wiki/The_Insider_(website) "The Insider (website)"), was at its core a recycled Russian document substantially written by [Kirill Dmitriev](/wiki/Kirill_Dmitriev "Kirill Dmitriev"), a Kremlin operative.[[759]](#cite_note-j465-769)

## International reactions

Main article: [Reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Reactions_to_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine")

See also: [Protests against the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)](/wiki/Protests_against_the_Russo-Ukrainian_war_(2022%E2%80%93present) "Protests against the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)")

The invasion received widespread international condemnation from [governments and intergovernmental organisations](/wiki/Government_and_intergovernmental_reactions_to_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Government and intergovernmental reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine").[[760]](#cite_note-770) On 2 March 2022 and 23 February 2023, 141 [member states](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations "Member states of the United Nations") of the [UN General Assembly](/wiki/UN_General_Assembly "UN General Assembly") voted for a resolution that Russia should immediately withdraw. Seven, including Russia, voted against the measure.[[761]](#cite_note-771) Political reactions to the invasion included [new sanctions imposed on Russia](/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War"), which triggered [widespread economic effects on the Russian and world economies](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Economic impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine").[[762]](#cite_note-Sanctions_slams_Russian_economy-772) As of July 2025, the EU had adopted 18 packages of sanctions against Russia and Belarus, totalling over 2,500 listed entities and persons.[[763]](#cite_note-EU18sanctions-773) Sanctions forced Russia to reorient its oil exports, rely more on [LNG](/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas "Liquefied natural gas") (which was not subject to EU sanctions), and shift its coal exports from Europe to Asia.[[764]](#cite_note-774) Most European countries cancelled nuclear cooperation with Russia.[[765]](#cite_note-775)

Over 70 countries and the European Union delivered [humanitarian aid](/wiki/List_of_humanitarian_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "List of humanitarian aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War") to Ukraine, and nearly 50 countries plus the EU provided [military aid](/wiki/List_of_military_aid_to_Ukraine_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War "List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War").[[766]](#cite_note-776) Economic sanctions included a ban on Russian aircraft using EU airspace,[[767]](#cite_note-777) a [ban of certain Russian banks from the SWIFT payments system](/wiki/SWIFT_ban_against_Russian_banks "SWIFT ban against Russian banks"), and a ban on certain Russian media outlets.[[768]](#cite_note-778) Reactions to the invasion have included public response, media responses, [peace efforts](/wiki/2022_Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_peace_negotiations "2022 Russia–Ukraine peace negotiations"), and the examination of the [legal implications of the invasion](/wiki/Legality_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Legality of the Russian invasion of Ukraine").

Protests and demonstrations were held worldwide, including some [in Russia](/wiki/2022_anti-war_protests_in_Russia "2022 anti-war protests in Russia") and [parts of Ukraine occupied by Russia](/wiki/2022_protests_in_Russian-occupied_Ukraine "2022 protests in Russian-occupied Ukraine").[[769]](#cite_note-779) Calls for [a boycott of Russian goods](/wiki/2022_boycott_of_Russia_and_Belarus "2022 boycott of Russia and Belarus") spread on social media platforms,[[770]](#cite_note-780) while hackers attacked Russian websites, particularly those operated by the Russian government.[[771]](#cite_note-781) [Anti-Russian sentiment](/wiki/Anti-Russian_sentiment "Anti-Russian sentiment") against Russians living abroad surged after the invasion.[[772]](#cite_note-782) In March 2022, Russian president Putin introduced [prison sentences of up to 15 years](/wiki/Russian_2022_war_censorship_laws "Russian 2022 war censorship laws") for publishing "fake news" about Russian military operations,[[773]](#cite_note-783) intended to suppress any criticism related to the war.[[774]](#cite_note-784)

Some countries, particularly in the [Global South](/wiki/Global_North_and_Global_South "Global North and Global South"), saw public sympathy or outright support for Russia, due in part to distrust of [US foreign policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the United States").[[775]](#cite_note-nyt-eligon-785) According to the Economist Intelligence Unit in 2023, 31 percent of the world's population live in countries that are leaning towards or supportive of Russia, 30.7 percent live in neutral countries, and 36.2 percent live in countries that are against Russia in some way.[[776]](#cite_note-786)

A number of supranational and national parliaments passed resolutions declaring Russia to be a [state sponsor of terrorism](/wiki/State_sponsor_of_terrorism "State sponsor of terrorism").[[777]](#cite_note-787) By October 2022, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia had declared Russia a [terrorist state](/wiki/State_terrorism "State terrorism").[[778]](#cite_note-Fiedler_2022-788) On 1 August 2023, [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland") became the first European country to close its embassy in Russia as a result of the invasion.[[779]](#cite_note-Nova_2023_y784-789)

The invasion prompted Ukraine,[[780]](#cite_note-790) [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland") and [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") to officially apply for NATO membership.[[781]](#cite_note-791) Finland became a member of NATO on 4 April 2023,[[782]](#cite_note-792) followed by Sweden on 7 March 2024.[[783]](#cite_note-793)

A documentary film produced during the siege of Mariupol, *[20 Days in Mariupol](/wiki/20_Days_in_Mariupol "20 Days in Mariupol")*, won the [Oscar for best documentary](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Documentary_Feature_Film "Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature Film") in [2024](/wiki/97th_Academy_Awards "97th Academy Awards").[[784]](#cite_note-Pulver_Shoard_2024_a031-794)

7. **[^](#cite_ref-610)** The DPR stated 1,799 of its civilians were killed and 6,902 wounded in its territories between 1 January 2022 and 22 December 2024,[[602]](#cite_note-608) of which 8 died and 23 were wounded between 1 January and 25 February 2022,[[603]](#cite_note-ombudsman1-609) leaving a total of 1,791 killed and 6,879 wounded in the period of the Russian invasion.
8. **[^](#cite_ref-missing_620-0)** 63,000 missing as of 17 February 2025.[[611]](#cite_note-618) 90 percent of which were thought to be soldiers,[[612]](#cite_note-619) which would be around 56,700.

10. **[^](#cite_ref-704)** Most likely, new cities meant new industrial cities in Siberia, the construction plans of which were announced by Shoigu in the fall of 2021.[[694]](#cite_note-703)
